editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p: SCARRON's NOVELS.
Viz.
The FRUITLESS PRECAUTION.
The HYPOCRITES.
The INNOCENT ADULTERY.
The JUDGE IN HIS OVVN CAUSE.
The RIVAL-BROTHERS.
The INVISIBLE MISTRESS.
The CHASTISEMENT OF AVARICE.
Rendred into Englih, with ome Additions, by JOHN DAVIES of Kidwelly.
LONDON, Printed for Thomas Dring, at the George in Fleet-street near Cliffords-Inn. 1665.

div.head: To the mot ACCOMPLIS'D, THOMAS STANLEY Eq
div.p:
AT the firt coming abroad of the three former of thee Novels in Englih, they were addres'd to you, partly upon this accompt, that they were rendred into that Language at Cumberlow, it being but jut you hould have the Patronage, of what had its birth under your roof. The lightnes of the Subject might indeed have deterr'd me, from preixing before it, a Name, which will challenge veneration,
till that of Philoophy have lot the repect due to it, and the world be re-involv'd in Ignorance and Barbarim: but my preumption on the kindnees you were pleas'd to have for me, and the earnetnes I had to make ome publick acknowledgment of my extraordinary obligations to you, overcame that difficulty.

When the Books of the former Edition were nigh pent, and that I was call'd upon, to provide for another, it was again my fortune, after almot two years retirement in Wales, to come to your Houe, where I had the opportunity, to review what was printed, and make what additions I could thereto, out of the ame Author's works. So that the ame reaon, which I had, at firt, to make, obliges me to continue, the Dedication of thee Pieces to you; but with this advantage now, that I am the les ollicitous of their fate, ince the entertainment, ome of them have already found, is uch, as hath encourag'd the Book-eller to venture at a Second Impreion.

But if thee were not ufficient, I have everal other motives, which would not
uffer me to decline the doing of what I am now upon, but particularly one, whence I derive the greatet atisfaction imaginable, which is, that, by this Addres, all thoe who love, that is, all who know you, will be aur'd, of your having o'rcome a Sicknes, which begat a general report of your death.

And this reflection, me-thinks, may well dipence a little, with my retreat into the tyle of the antient Dedicatories, which were commonly concluded with wihes and prayers. Mine are, at the preent, that, for ome time yet, we may not have the occaion to bemoan the los of o precious a life as yours; That the Health you have o happily recover'd may have an uninterrupted continuance for many years; And when you are cloy'd with the enjoyments and happines of this world, (which, as you are wont to expres it, conit in thee three words, Wife, Children, Friends) you may, by the attendance of thoe Learned men, whoe Labours all ubequent Ages will be oblig'd to, be convey'd into the joys and blis of another. And I doubt not of my having, after o long acquaintance, o much
credit with you, as that, when I am devour, you will believe me incere, and, conequently, that thee are the hearty wihes of,

closer.signed: Your mot humble and mot obliged Servant, J. DAVIES.

div.head: THE PREFACE, Giving an Accompt of the Author of thee Novels, ome of his other Works, and his Peron.
div.p:
THE three former of thee Novels were printed here ome four or five years ince, and o well receiv'd, that the carcity of them • on call'd upon the Book-eller for a econd Impreion. This kind entertainment thereof put me upon an enquiry, what there might be more,
of the ame kind, written by the ame Author, and I have made a hift to pick up four, out of everal parts of his Works, printed together, ince his Death, in ix mall Volumes in 12 • . of which I have onely this hort accompt to give.

Of the Six, there are onely two Volumes in Proe, whereof one, he entitles Le Roman Comique, or, The Comical Romance. It is a decription of the Lives of certain Country-Comedians, and other people, of everal Conditions; but done, with uch a natural martnes, as very few Authors have been o happy as to arrive to, and he does not bring any upon the Stage, to whom there happen not ome very pleaant adventures. To this it may be added, that it is written in a tile particular to this Author, whoe inclination to raillery is o much the more remarkable, in that he could not forbear it, even in thoe rela • ions, wherein he was himelf concern'd.

I am inform'd, that, ome years ince, a Peron of Quality made it his recreation, to render part of that divertive Romance into Englih, tranlating not onely the Work, but alo the Scene, out of France into England: and no doubt but the deign would have taken
infinitely well, had it been proecuted. But ere he had compleated his Work, the Scene of our Englih Affairs was miraculouly chang'd, from Anarchy to Monarchy, and that Peron being highly engag'd in the Tranactions happening upon his Majesty's happy Retauration, there was uch a stop put to what he had done therein, that it hath remain'd imperfect ever ince: whence it may well be ghes'd, there is omewhat in it o far trancending ordinary Tranlation, that no other Hand durt attempt it.

Out of this Romance, whereof there are now two parts extant in French, I have taken three of the Newly-printed Novels; to wit,
The Judge in his own Caue;
The Rival-Brothers; and
The Inviible Mitres.

'Tis a thouand pitties, that the Author hath, prevented by Death, left the Work imperfect; o that we are, and ever hall be, at a los, to know, what period he might bring o many noble Adventures to. Had he compleated it, we hould have found, whether he could have given his principal Heroe a more honourable Exit, than to make it, on a Gibbet,
at Pontoie, as he was wont to ay himelf, and may be een in a Dedicatory of his to the Abbot Menagius, and Monieur Sarrazin, before a little Piece in Vere, entituled, A true Relation of what happened between the Poets and the Detinies, upon the Death of Monieur de Voiture.

His other Works, in Proe, are onely thee NOVELS, and ome LETTERS, which being but few, and thoe o particular about his own occaions and neceities, there will not be much worth the Tranlation into Englih. Among thee was found the lat Novel; to wit,

All the rest of his Works are Poetry, in four Volumes; two, of Plays, Fragments of Plays, Epistles, &c. One, of Poems, upon everal occaions; and the last, containing eight Books of the Aeneids, in Burleque, under the title of, Le Virgile Travety; in which kind of Writing lay his chiefet excellency: but all together may jutly ecure him the title of the martet, and mot pleaant Writer of this lat Age.

As to his Peron, the accompt we have to give of it, is deriv'd, partly from what he hath deliver'd himelf, and partly from the Character given him by his Friends. What we have from himelf happen'd upon this occaion. The fore-mentioned Piece dedicated to Menagius and Sarrazin, being in the Pres, there chanc'd to be ome vacant Pages, whereupon the Book-eller intreating Monieur Scarron, to bethink himelf of ome thing to fill them up, (for the humour of doing it with Catalogues of other Books, it eems, was not much in vogue in France) he gave him the enuing Decription of himelf, at the beginning whereof, there was a Bras-cut, wherein he was repreented itting in a great Chair; with his back towards the Beholders, and five Women on the one ide, and four on the other, as it were to repreent the nine Mues. I hall here give the aid Decription, just as if I had the ame occaion to do it as my Author had.

div.head: TO THE READER, Who never aw me.
div.p:
REader, who never aw't me, and haply are not much troubled at it, out of conceit, that there is little to be gotten by the ight of uch a peron as I am, know, that, for my part, I hould have been as indifferent, as thou art, whether I were een by thee or not, if I had not been inform'd, that ome, very ingenious Perons, make my miery their port, and give a d • cription of me quite different from what I am. Some ay, that, if I could be capable of any motion, it would not be much unlike that of thoe exemplary Cripples, who go on their Hands and Britch; others affirm I have no Thighs, and that, being et on the Table in a Box, purpoely made for me, I there fall a prating like an one-ey'd Parrat: And others y • t are o pleaant, as to ay, that, my Hat being ty'd to the end of a Cord, which runs
through a Pully faten'd to the Roof of my Chamber, I, having the other end of the aid Cord in my hands (which it eems I must not be able to lift up to my head) make a hift, to raie up, and let it fall, to alute thoe who come to viit me.

I conceive my elf therefore oblig'd in concience, to give a check to thee calumnies, that the World may at length be undeceiv'd, and to that end, have I caus'd the Plate, which thou maist ee at the beginning of this Preface, to be graven. I doubt not, Reader, but thou wilt grumble, (for grumbling is very natural to all Readers, and I am inclin'd to it my elf, as well as others, when I am a Reader) thou wilt grumble, I ay, and quarrel at me, that thou hast not a ight of my fore-part. To atisfie thee, know, that it is not out of any irreverence, or want of civility, that I turn my back-ide to the Company, but for this reaon, that the convexity of my Back is fitter to receive an incription, than the concavity of my Breat, which is over-hadow'd by the pendency of my Head, and that by that ide, as well as the other, a Man may take a urvey of the Site, or rather, the irregular platform of my Peron. Without any imagination, that the
world hould think it elf oblig'd by uch a Preent (for, by the Nine Gentle-Laes that tand about me, I never hop'd my Head would ever become the Original of a Medal) I would have had my Picture drawn, if any Painter durst have attempted it. For want of that, take this account of my Peron.

I am omewhat above thirty years of age, as thou maist ee by the back of my chair. If I live to forty, I hall make a great addition of mieries, to thoe I have already uffer'd, within thee eight or nine years. I was of a paable stature, though omewhat below the middle ize; but my dieaes have hortned it by a foot and better. My head is omewhat of the bigget, conidering my stature. My face is pretty full, and plump, compar'd to the Skeleton I am thence downwards. I am o well furnih'd with hair, that I need wear no Periwig, and much of it is turn'd grey, in pight of the Proverb. My ight is good enough, though my eyes omewhat larger than they hould be: they are blew, and one of them more unk into my head than the other. My noe tands well enough. My teeth, ometimes o many pearls, are
now of a colour between black and blew. I have lot one and a half on the left ide, and two and a half on the right, and I have two a little broken. My legs and thighs made at firt an obtue, then an equal, and at lat, an acute angle. My thighs and my body making another, and my head hanging down over my breat, I am a certain repreentative or Hieroglyphick of the Letter Z. My arms are contracted as well as my legs, and my fingers as well as my arms. In a word, I am a certain contraction or Epitome of humane miery.

Thus much as to my figure; and ince I am o far in my way, I will give thee a light touch of my humour. 'Tis more than I promis'd; but, to deal freely with thee, Reader, take notice, that this Preface is deign'd onely to well the Book, upon the importunity of the Seller, whoe fear it was, he hould not ave himelf by the Impreion. Were it not for that, it would be to as little purpoe as many others are. But this is not the firt time, that ome people hew themelves fools, out of compliance with others, beides the fooleries they are guilty of upon their own account.

As to my humour then; I am to confes, that I am omewhat cholerick, a lover of good meat, and inclin'd to loath. I often call my Man fool or coxcomb, and preently after, Sir, and Monieur. I ha • e no body, God grant others have the ame kindnes for me. I am very glad when I have mony, and would be much more, if I had my health. I am merry enough in company, and not much unatisfi'd, when I am alone. I endure my mieries patiently enough. And now I think my Preface is long enough, and that it is time I hould make an • nd of it.

So far the Author's decription of himelf, upon the occaion before mentioned. What we have from his friends is before his Virgil Travety, coniting of certain Papers of Veres before that Piece, whereof ome being in French, ome in Latine, we hall cull out onely the Latine Copies, as more particularly decribing his Peron and Indipoitions.

div.head: In Gallicam Scarronis Aeneidem ludicro carmine criptam.
div.l:
DEbile Scarronis corpus, contracta
que membra,
Indomitus vexat nocte diéque dolor.
Hinc caput obliquâ pronum cervice faticit,
Nec licet obtutus tollere ad atra uos.
Utque manus premit innocuas cruciatque chiragra,
Sicecat immeritos aeva podagra pedes.
Et malè nodoos macies depacitur artus,
Tabidáque arecens vix tegit oa cutis.
Torqueris leviùs volvendo, Siyphe, axo;
Quique renacenti pectore pacis avem.
Et tamen in mediis ridere doloribus audet,
Nec mierum laeti deeruêre joci.

Riciculum Aeneam, Troas, Danaó
que facetus,
Inolitâ Gallis arte, Poëta facit.
Oblectant animos, non jam naufragia terrent,
Itala que finxit, Vate Marone, Clio.

Fetivè ventique ruunt, at
que aequora verant,
Jucundè Phrygias & quatit unda rates.
Et upplex precibus uperos dicacibus orat
Naufragus, & grato cum ale nauta perit.
Nec flenda ingentis modo unt incendia Trojae;
Haec point Priamo ic placuie eni.
Ipa quoque in Teucros joculares concipit iras
Altioni conjux, Juno, ororque Jovis.
Tam benè qui ludit, dum toto corpore, languens,
Deficit, innumeris obruiturque malis:
Vel certè humanâ Deus et ub imagine Scarro,
Ingenio pollet vel propiore Dei.

div.head: In Aeneida Mimicam & jocoam Pauli Scarronis.
div.l: COrpore Scarro aeger, ed cui ridere decorum,
Phoebus, Amor, Charites, & Venus ipa dedit.
Gratum opus urbanis, Urbanae Aeneidos Autor,
Trantulit in lepidos Arma Virumque jocos.

div.head: SCARRONI ex Patre Nepoti.
div.l: SI punctum omne tulit, qui micuit utile dulci,
Ludendo cribens eria quid meruit?
Virgilii miranda legens ridere jubetur;
Hoc debet, Scarro, Gallica Mua, tibi.

div.head: THE FRUITLESS PRECAUTION.
The Firt Novel.
div.p:
A Gentleman of Granada, whoe true name I hall forbear to dicover, and on whom I will betow that of Don Pedro of Cateel, Aragon, and Toledo, or what you pleae, ince that a glorious name in a Romance cots no more than another, (which is haply the reaon that the Spaniards, not content with their own, ever give themelves of the mot illutrious, nay hardly
it down with one:) this Gentleman, I ay, (now Don Pedro) being arriv'd at the twentieth year of his age, lot both Father and Mother, and by their death came to a very great etare: all which hapning to the ame peron contributes very much to his micarriage if he be born a fool; but, if nature hath been more indulgent to him, puts him int •• capacity of improving himelf to ome eteem in the world. During the year of his mourning, he very prudently wean'd himelf from mot part of the divertiements, which perons of his age are ordinarily addicted to, and buied himelf in looking into the poture of his etate, and putting his affairs into a good order. He was a very graceful peron, of an excellent wit, and behav'd himelf, in his youth, with a prudence and conduct uch as might have become grey hairs. There was not in Granada any Lady who would not gladly have had him to her husband, nor any Father o prepoes'd with the deerts of his daughter, as not to wih him his Son-in-law. Of the Beauties in Granada, which tood in competition for the Monarchy of hearts, one onely there was able to captivate that of Don Pedro. Her name was Seraphina, beautiful indeed as a Seraphin, young, rich, well decended, and, in a word, though of a fortune omewhat below that of Don Pedro's, yet a peron as well accomplih'd to make a wife, as he a husband. He made no quetion, but that upon the firt propoal of marriage made to her Friends, he hould obtain their conent to become her Servant: but he choe rather to gain her by his own worth and deert, than their compliance, and reolv'd to court her with all the paion, ubmiions, and ervices imaginable, o to
make a conquet of her heart, before he became poeor of her peron.

His deign was noble, and might accordingly have prov'd more uccesful, if Fortune, who is, many times, maliciouly pleas'd to diturb things manag'd with the greatet conduct and circumpection, had not rais'd him a Rival, who was become Mater of the place he would have taken, while he was but yet making his firt approaches. His name we have here little to do with, he was much about the age of Don Pedro, perhaps as lovely as he, and without doubt much more belov'd.

It was not long ere Don Pedro perceiv'd he had a Competitor, and was not much troubled at it, as having the advantage of him in point of etate. He was at the charge of Muick in the treet where his Mitres liv'd; his Rival had the pleaure of it in her Chamber, and haply receiv'd more than ordinary kindnees from her, while poor Don Pedro's teeth hatter'd in his head. At lat he grew weary of hunting the bats, I mean, of the charge and inconveniences of that kind of Courthip, without making any progres in his buines: Yet o as this ill ucces caus'd not any remiion of his Love, but onely made him quit the deign he had to be too prodigal of his addrees to his Mitres, before he had obtain'd her of her Friends. He therefore went and demanded her of them, and they very liberally g • ve their conent he hould have her, without ever adviing with, or communicating the buines to, their daughter; out of an exces of joy, to be intreated, to do what they earnetly deir'd, and indeed durt hardly hope. They oon after acquainted Seraphina with the good fortune that came to
court her, and prepar'd her to entertain the addrees of Don Pedro, and; within a few days, to marry him. The news, which he hould have receiv'd with joy, rais'd in her no mall diturbance; inomuch, that, not able to mother the los he was at, he hardly made a hift to conceal the occaion thereof from them, by peruading them it proceeded from the affliction, it would be to her, to part with thoe, for whom he had o dutiful an affection. She acted her part o handomely, that, out of pure tendernes, the old people could not forbear tears, nor commending the good nature of their daughter. She us'd all the intreaties he could to peruade them to put off the marriage for four or five months, repreenting to them, that the decay of her health was viible in her countenance; and preing, that, if ever he married, it might not be till he had recover'd her perfect health, to the end he might be in a better dipoition to pleae her husband, let he might take any occaion to be diatisfi'd with her, in the dawning of their marriage, and repent of his choice.

Now whereas it was indeed true, that for ome time before he eem'd not to have her health as he was wont, her Friends were well atisfi'd with what he had aid to them, and gave an account of it to Don Pedro, who alo had nothing to except againt it, as conceiving it argu'd the dicretion of his Mitres. Nevertheles, they thought it not amis to put things in order, as to the contract of marriage, and the ettlement to be made thereupon.

But though things were brought to this pas, the amoro • s Don Pedro omitted not any of thoe
Expreions of Gallantry and Courthip, expect • d in the carrying on of a Match with conent of all parties. He ent his Mitres many preents, and writ to her every day. She on the other ide return'd him uch anwers as were at leat very civil, thouh they betrai'd much les of paion than was viible in his Letters. But he would not by any means be een in the day time, excuing her elf by reaon of her indipoition; nay in the evenings was eldom een at her window, which rais'd in Don Pedro a great admiration of her reerv'dnes. He was better conceited of his own worth than any way to quetion the ucces of his applications, or doubt his being deeply in the favour of his Mitres, when he hould be better known to her than he was, even though he might have had an averion for him before he knew him.

His affairs hitherto went on moothly without any rub; but, on a uddain, it happen'd that he could not get a ight of his Mitres in four or five days. He was extremely troubled at it, or at le • t pretended it; he writ veres upon that occaion, or, it may be, hired, or bought ome, and caus'd them to be ung under her window: but notwithtanding thee great attempts of a mot paionate Love • , all he could do was to peak with one of the Chamber-maids, who told him, that his Mitres was much icker than he had been. His Poetick vein well'd at this account of h • r, or, if not his, that of his mercenary Poet mut breathe and bleed for it: for I could never be truly inform'd whether he himelf had any gift in rhiming. Having got what he had, et to ome doleful tune, and loaden, beides his offenive and defenive arms, with a
Guitarrhe, (which I am apt to believe was the bet the City could afford) he took his way very boiterouly towards his Mitres's, either to move her to compaion, or to et the dogs thereabouts a barking. 'Tis not unlikely he hould have done one of the two, or both together, and yet it o happen'd he did neither.

Being come within fifty paces hort of the bleed manion of his Divinity, he perceives the door open, and a woman coming out, who eem'd much like his almot-inviible Angel. He could not imagine what hould oblige a Woman, all alone, and at uch a time of the night, to enter, of et purpoe, into a great deolate building, detroy'd not long before by a fire that had happen'd. To find out what the matter hould be, he walk'd round about thoe ruins, into which there were everal ways to get in, o, with as much convenience as he could, to get near the peron whom he had follow'd in thither. It came into his imagination, that it might be his Mitres who had appointed his Rival a meeting in that trange place, as not daring to be een at her houe, and haply unwilling to have any third peron privy to an action, which it concern'd him o much to be kept ecret; and if what he did as yet but onely upect, hould prove tru • , his inviolable reolution was to be the death of his Rival, and to be reveng'd of Seraphina, by loading her with the greatet reproaches he could think on. He thereupon crawl'd along with as little noie as he could, till he came to a place whence he aw her (for it was he) itting upon the ground, bemoaning her elf, as a peron ready to give up the ghot, or what ignifies little les (to give it you
in a word) in Labour, and with inexpreible pain, upon the delivery of a little creature, in the making whereof he had haply taken a great deal of pleaure. She no ooner aw her elf disburthen'd, but deriving trength from her courage, he return'd the ame way he came, without taking any further thought, what hould become of the Child he had brought into the world.

I leave you to judge what atonihment Don Pedro was in at this trange accident. Now was he atisfi'd what was the true caue of his Mitres's icknes: he was a little frighted at the danger he was likely to have fallen into, and made his acknowledgment to Heaven, that he had ecap'd it. And being of a noble and generous dipoition, he would not be reveng'd of one that had put uch a treacherous trick upon him, to the dihonour of an illutrious Family, nor in his jut reentment uffer the innocent little creature to perih, which he aw at his feet expos'd to the mercy of the firt dog or wine that had come that way. He took it up in his handkerchief, for want of omething ele to wrap it in, and, with as much hate as he could, went to a Midwife of his acquaintance, to whoe care he recommended the Child he put into her hands, and gave her mony to buy all things neceary for it. The Midwife, well paid, did what might have been expected from her, inomuch that the very next day, the Child was put out to nure, chritned, and (proving a girl) named Laura.

In the interim, Don Pedro went to ee a certain Kinwoman of his, one in whom he repos'd very much confidence: he told her that he had chang'd
the deign he had of marrying o young into that of travelling, entreated her to take upon her the management of his etate, and to entertain into her houe a little Girl, whom he made her believe was his own, to be very liberal in what concern'd her education, and, for certain reaons, which he hould one day know, as oon as he were three years old, to put her into a Nunnery, and above all things to take order that he hould have no acquaintance with the things of this world. He gave his kinwoman Letters of Atturney, and what ele was neceary for her management of his etate, furnih'd himelf with mony and jewels; got a truty ervant; and, before he left Granada, writ a Letter to Seraphina. She receiv'd it much about the time that he was acquainting her Friends, that her icknes would not any longer delay her marriage: but Don Pedro's Letter, wherein he dicover'd what he knew of her condition, fill'd her with other thoughts. And thoe were wholly directed towards God, inomuch that, not long after, he went into a Nunnery, never to come out again, it being not in the power of her Friends, with all their entreaties and tears, to divert her from that reolution, which they thought o much the more trange, the more they were to eek what the motives of it hould be.

But we will leave them bewailing their daughter, now turn'd Nun: Her, on the other ide, bewailing her own micarriage; the little Laura g • owing up, and blooming forth; and overtake Don Pedro upon his way to Sevil, not able to divert his thoughts from running upon the adventure that had happen'd to him, and thereupon entertaining a cruel
averion againt marriage, after his having o great a deire to tate of it. All the women he meets he is frightned at, and without any reflection that, as well as men, there are ome good, ome bad among them, he concludes with himelf, that a man mut ever be ditrutful of them, and much more of thoe who pretend to wit, than the imple; being apt enough to embrace their opinion, who hold that a woman knows more than he ought, if he knows any thing beyond what belongs to Houe-keeping, and the bringing up of her Children.

Embracing thee Hereies with ome peruaion, he enters Sevil, and went to the houe of Don John— (His name is quite out of my head) a rich man, and a peron of quality, who was not onely his Kinman, but much his Friend, and o kind as that he would not uffer him to lodge any where ele. The pleaantnes of Sevil raied in him an inclination to make a longer tay there than he thought to have done: which his Couin Don John perceiving, and wihing his divertiement yet greater than it was, pent ome time in hewing him whatever that place afforded that were any thing rare or coniderable.

One day, as they were riding through one of the principal Streets of the City, they aw, in a Coach that went into a great perons houe, a young Lady, habited like a Widow; but o handome, o attractive, that Don Pedro was urprized at her beauty, and made Don John laugh to hear the exclamations and oaths he made, that he had never een any thing comparable to her in his Life. This angelical Widow reconciled to his favour all thoe of the female Sex, whom Seraphina had
made abominable in his apprehenion. He intreated Don John to ride once more through the ame Street, and acknowledg'd to him, that ever o little more ight of her had really wounded him. 'Tis more than needed, replied Don John; for, if I am not much mitaken, you are o far wounded as requires ome remedy. Ah, Couin, ays Don Pedro to him, I think I may confidently tell you, that I hould eteem my elf very happy, might I pas away my days with o excellent a peron. Nay, if you take that coure, replies Don John, and make uch hate as you do, you may oon come to your journeys end, and be mater of the happines you propoe to your elf. Not but that uch an enterprize mut needs be difficult, Elvira is a peron of quality, and very rich, her beauty is uch as you have oberved it, her virtue not inferiour, and for the pace of two years that he hath been a Widow, the wealthiet fortunes in Andaluzia have not raied in her any motions to change her condition. But a peron of your endowments and excellencies may conquer that which others have not been able to tand againt. She is a Kinwoman of my Wives, and I ometimes viit her. I hall, if you pleae, acquaint her with your inclinations, and I am the more apt to hope my negotiation may prove effectual, in regard I have the honour to ee her in her Balcony which is over againt us, a favour not ordinary from a Lady o reerv'd, ince he might as well hut up her own jealouies and her windows together, and o make us be laugh'd at after all our gallantry.

With which words both the Cavaliers made
each of them an obeiance to the Spanih Lady, which it cot them no mall pains to acquit themelves well of. But particularly Don Pedro did his with uch contorion and violence to his whole body, that a little more he had injur'd his reins. The Lady in the Balcony return'd them one not much to be found fault with, which engag'd Don Pedro and his companion to revy it with two others;
But eeing the Sun from th' Balcony was gone,
They thought it full time to depart,
One went away well, and as ound as a Bell,
But the other was truck to the heart.

p.q: Ah! Couin, ays Don Pedro to Don John, what probability is there that a tranger hould torm a heart that hath tood out the aaults of all the bet and noblet Champions as to quality and deert that Sevil affords? But, continued he, ince the little hope I have of obtaining her favour is enough to occaion my death, it will come but all to one, if I hazard my Life upon her denials and didains. Let me therefore, dear Couin, intreat you to peak to her, as oon as poibly you can, and pres not to her o much the greatnes of my quality or etate, as the violence of my paion.

div.p:
Don Pedro was o over head and ears in love, that he could not peak of any thing ele, in o much, that his Couin perceiv'd the greatet kindnes he could do him, was, to peak with the oonet to Elvira. He did it, and that with good ucces. The fair Widow entertain'd o kindly the Propoition he made on the behalf of his Friend, that he
dicover'd rather a atisfaction, than any dipleaure thereat. But, in Anwer thereto, he told him, that having made a vow he would not hear of any addrees in order to a econd Marriage till three years were expired after her former Husband's death, no conideration in the world hould prevail with her to break it. She added further, that out of an exact obervance of what he had promied the memory of her late Husband, he had till then behaved her elf inflexibly towards all thoe that had made their addrees to her; and that if Don Pedro had o much command of himelf as to continue his devotions to her for the pace of one whole year, during which time they might become better acquainted one with another, he would promie never to be any man's Wife but his.

Don John, upon his return, gave Don Pedro an account of his negotiation, and render'd him the mot atisfied and mot amorous man in the world. The long time he was to expect troubled him not at all, reolving to employ it in all manner of courthips, worthy atchievments, and adventures, befitting a pruce Lover. He bought a Coach and Hores, took a Houe, and entertain'd Servants, et the Embroiderers and Tailors of Sevil a ewing, and the Muicians a inging. He would have preented Elvira with ome things; but he would by no means permit it. Her Maids were much more eaily intreated, and received his Preents as willingly as he betow'd them. In a hort time, Elvira's Servants were more at his devotion than at hers, they cauing her to hew her elf in the Balcony, though much againt her humour, as
often as Don Pedro was inging in the Street; in which employment, as I have been told, he was grown to be a Crafts-mater, not making ue of his lips and tongue to quaver out the notes as many good Singers do.

Six Moneths were already pat ince Don Pedro had laid a Siege to the affections of Elvira, yet had not the leat private Parley with her; which added daily more and more to the eteem and devotion he had for her. At lat, upon an importunity of Prayers and Preents, one of her Gentlewomen, better tored with confidence than any of the ret, or rather better brib'd, promied to bring him in the night-time to her Lady's Lodgings, and o to dipoe of him as that he hould ee her put off her cloaths before he went to bed, walking in her Smock about the chamber for coolnes, and inging and playing upon the Lute, which he did admirably well.

This took Don Pedro o highly, that he gave his Intelligencer much beyond what he had promied her; o that, night being come, the bold Granadine, according to the Gentlewoman's directions, comes into Elvira's houe, lunk into her lodgings, and there, from a little acent, which was over againt her chamber-door, he aw her itting on a couch, reading in a Prayer-book, how attentively I know not, while her women were undreing her. She had onely a thin looe coat about her, and was upon getting into bed when Don Pedro's Penion-Gentlewoman, deirous to give him caue to be as much atisfied with her as he with him, entreats her Mitres to ing. To her's, her Companions added their intreaties; yet Elvira put them off a
long time, telling them, he was melancholy, nay, auring them he had ome reaon to be o: but the Gentlewoman who was o much at the devotion of Don Pedro, having put a Lute into her Mitres's hands, Elvira had the compliance to ing, and did it with o much excellency and delight, that Don Pedro could hardly forbear cating himelf at her feet, there to act the part of the ectatick Lover. She ung not long, but went to bed: her Women withdrew into their chambers, and Don Pedro, who would gladly have gotten into the Street, was at a cruel los what to do when he found the great Gate fat. There was no other coure to be taken, than to expect till it were day. He ate down on the brink of a Well which was at one corner of the Court, in no mall diturbance, by reaon of the fear he was in of being dicovered, and to incur the dipleaure of his Mitres, for his preumption.

While he was thus engaged, his thoughts running upon thouands of deigns, and thoe attended by o many fruitles wihes, he perceives a Door opening that belonged to ome part of Elvira's Lodgings. He turn'd toward that ide on which he heard the noie, and was much at a los to ee coming into the Court the fair Widow whom he thought fat aleep. By the light of a mall Wax-candle he had in her hand, he perceiv'd her night-cloaths were very neat about her head; that he was bare-neck'd, had an excellent Neck-lace of Pearl on, and that upon her Smock, about which was abundance of Lace, he had onely a long rich Mantle. She had in her hand a Silver-plate cover'd with Jelly, Sweet-meats, and Conerves; and
in that trange poture he was o full of charm and attraction, that Don Pedro was once in a mind to atisfie himelf with the enjoyment of looking on her, though he hould thereby draw on himelf all the dipleaure, which a preumption o great might jutly deerve. But upon better thoughts he hid himelf behind the Well, yet o as that he till oberv'd his Mitres, flattering himelf ometimes with an imagination, that he was the peron he ought after. She went on towards the Stable, whither Don Pedro, at a ditance, follow'd her, and aw her go into a little Chamber. The firt apprehenion he had, was, that his Mitres, out of an exces of pious charity, went to viit ome ervant of the Houe that was ick, though, without any prejudice to her charitable inclinations, he might have put that employment upon ome one of her women. He hid himelf behind a hore, which tood not far from the door of the Chamber, and thence oberving his dear Widow, he aw her et down, on a little Table, the Candletick, the Plate, and whatever ele he had brought that was burthenome to her Ivory hands; and perceiv'd, in a bed which took up almot all the Chamber, a Blackamore that was ick, who eem'd to be about thirty years of age, but o deformed, and of o dreadful a look, that he was in a manner frightned at the ight of him. His meagre countenance, and the painful emiion of his breath argu'd him very ick and much pent. Don Pedro could not but admire the unparallel'd goodnes of the fair Elvira, who took up the Negro's coverlet, and having thrut up his head, ate down by the ick peron, and put her hand on his fore-head, all wet, haply with
the weats and pains of approaching death. The Negro beheld, with a gatly look, the charitable Angel that came to comfort him, and who till view'd him with tears in her eyes. Don Pedro knew not what he hould think of a charity o trancendent, and having for a while admir'd it, he began to think it exceive: but as yet he had not een any thing.

At lat, the fair Widow breaking forth into dicoure, yet weeping as if it had been at the taking of a final farewel, he ask'd the Negro, How he did My dear Anthony, aid he to him with a voice interrupted by obbs, Art thou then reolv'd to dy, and, with thy own, to be my death too? Thou peak't not to me, my dearet; take heart, my oul, take heart, if thou deiret I hould live, and eat a little of this jelly, for my ake. Thou dot not vouchafe o much as to look on me, cruel man; not on me, who love thee, who adore thee; kis me, my Angel, kis me, and recover thy health, if thou wouldt not have my company to Death, after I had o much lov'd thee whil't thou hadt any Life.

Having o aid, he lunk down into the bed, o uddenly, that the unfortunate Elvira could not get a word from him by way of return, notwithtanding all the kindnees both of words and getures he us'd towards him; whether it were that he was already dead, or obtinately reolv'd, not to peak to a peron whom he thought the occaion of his death. Elvira, melted into tears, and in a manner out of her elf, to ee what a ad condition he left her dear Negro in, and mot of all to conider his inhumanity towards her, took up all he had brought with her, and return'd to her chamber, with o much adnes and affliction in her countenance, that it was much to her los, he had not been een in that poture by her apotate Lover, Don Pedro.

He in the mean time lay cloe and undicover'd, in the mot obcure part of the table, o atonih'd as that he had not been half as much, when he was preent at the happy delivery of Seraphina. He aw the counterfeit Matron returning to her chamber, diconolate as a Widow at the Funeral of a Husband he dearly lov'd; and, not long after, finding the great gate open, he got into the
treet, not much ollicitous whether he were een or not, as not eteeming the reputation of Elvira worthy the leat tendernes or repect. Yet even in that did he follow the dictates of his own vertue, o far as that he dicover'd not what he had een even to his Friend. He pas'd by Elvira's door the next day jut as the Moor was carried out to his burial. Her Woman told him, that he was ick, and for the pace of four or five days that he pas'd to and fro that way, he was not to be een at her window, o incapable was he of any conolation upon the death of the African. Don Pedro was much deirous to hear from her. One day as he was in dicoure with Don John, a lave of Elvira's brought him a Letter from her Mitres. He open'd it with ome impatience, and read in it what you are like to do, if you pleae.

p.hi:
TWo perons, between whom there is a mutual affection in order to marriage, need no third peron to ollicite the buines between them. You would have me believe, that you think me not unhandome, and I cannot but acknowledge I am o far taken with you, as that I am willing to grant you immediately, what I had not promis'd till a year were expir'd. My Peron and Etate are at your dipoal, when you pleae to command them; and I am to deire you to believe, that though I cannot be too circumpect in a buines of this nature, yet your merit
and my own affection hall be my ecurity, and enable me to overcome what difficulties oever I may meet with therein.

div.p:
Don Pedro read over the Letter twice or thrice, o much ado had he to believe what he read. He conider'd with himelf that he had been twice in danger to have been as unfortunately married as any man in Spain, and ent up his hearty thanks to Heaven which had enabled him to ecape it, by dicovering to him two ecrets of o great importance. The reolution of marrying uddenly, which the Negro's death had put Elvira upon, rais'd in Don Pedro a quite contrary, which was, that of getting from her as oon as he could. He therefore told Don John, that it concern'd both his life and honour, that he hould be out of Sevil within an hour, and that he would take along with him onely that ervant whom he had brought from Granada. He intreated him to ell his Coach and Hores, and with the mony to dicharge his Servants; but above all things he deir'd him not to make any enquiry after the occaion of o udden a change, and o unexpected a departure, promiing to give him an account in writing from the firt place he hould make any tay at. He writ to Elvira, while ome were gone to take up two Mules for him; he deliver'd his Letter to the lave, and, the Mules being come, took his way towards Madrid, confirm'd, more than ever, in his former opinion, of being ditrutful of all women of more than ordinary wit, nay indeed to have a horrour of them. While he is
purring on his Mule, Elvira opens his Letter, and finds in it thee words.

p.hi: HOw violent oever the affection I had for you might have been, yet have I ever preferr'd the deire of preerving your honour, before the pleaure of enjoying your peron. Thence you might have perceiv'd with what dicretion all my Courthips and addrees were attended. I am naturally a peron of a very nice concience, and therefore cannot without ome remore anwer your propoal of marriage, you being a Widow but ince yeterday. You are much more oblig'd to the memory of the poor Negro, who hath lost his life in your ervice, and can betow no les than a year in bewailing the micarriage of a peron, whoe performances you thought o extraordinary. In the interim, we hall both of us have time to conider what we have to do.

div.p:
Elvira was almot out of her elf at the reading of this Letter; the affliction he conceiv'd thereat made her more ick, than he had been upon the los of her Lover of Guinny. But bethinking her elf that Don Pedro had left Sevil, and another peron, whom he thought furnih'd for her turn, making his addrees to her in order to marriage, he took him at his word, and entertain'd him, to upply
the place of the Negro. Not but that there were other Negroes choice enough; but he had heard ay that there were everal orts of Negroes, and that they are not o far Devils as they eem black.

By this time was Don Pedro got to Madrid, where he alighted at an Uncle's of his, who entertain'd him very kindly. This Uncle was a Gentleman of a very great etate, had onely one on, detin'd in marriage for a Couin of his, an Heires, one that being but ten years of age was kept in a Monatery, till uch time as he were ripe for the enjoyments of her Couin. This Couin's name was Don Rodrigues, a peron as lovely as could be look'd on, every way o accomplih'd, that Don Pedro entred into a friendhip with him much beyond what a man hath for a kinman, whom yet he may love very well; for they are not always of his kindred that a man loves bet.

Don Rodrigues had many times his thoughts o taken up with ome reflections unknown to any but himelf, that he minded not much what he did, or what company he was in, and thee fits were often accompani'd with certain agitations and diturbances. Don Pedro, having oberv'd it, acquainted him with his adventures, to oblige him, by th • t confidence, to give him an account of his, and, in cae there were any thing wherein he might erve him, to aure him of his being much more his Friend than his Kinman. Whereupon he to • d him how he h • d taken notice of his adnes and diquiet, and intreated him to dicover the occaion of it; or otherwie, that he hould think his friendhip not anwerable to his own.

Don Rodrigues deired nothing o much, hoping to be disburthen'd of his grief, when he had communicated it. He thereupon told Don Pedro, that he was paionately fallen in love with a Gentlewoman at Madrid, deign'd in marriage to a Couin of hers whom he expected from the Indies, and whom he had never een, much after the ame manner as he was made ure to a Couin of his whom he taid for till he were of age to be married, and whom he had but little acquaintance with.

p.q:
Ah! that's it makes me the more to pity you, replies Don Pedro. And why o, ays Don Rodrigues? Becaue a ubtil Woman, replies Don Pedro, will be ure, ooner or later, to put a trick upon you. You know by the Relation I have given you of my adventures, how I had been like to be trapann'd by them; and I am to aure you that were I but in hopes to find a Woman as imple, as I know there are witty, I would court her in the highet manner imaginable, and prefer her before prudence it elf, if he would entertain me to be her Servant. Sure, you do not peak eriouly, replies Don Rodrigues; for I never knew any undertanding man, but thought it the mot inupportable thing in the world, nay, a certain torment, to be but a quarter of an hour in company with a Woman that's little better than a natural Fool. 'Twere mot irrational, that, while our eyes, our hands, in a word, our whole body, finds omething of diverion, our ouls, our noblet part, hould be upon the rack of a tedious converation, uch as mut needs be that of perons that have nothing in them. Let's have no more diputing, ays Don Pedro to him, ince there is but too much to be aid upon this ubject; be it your buines to bring me as oon as you can to a ight of this admirable Lady, as alo of her Couin, to the end, if he uit with my humour, I may have omething to trifle away
the time withal while I tay at Madrid. I believe you will find them much otherwie than you expect, when you do, ays Don Rodrigues. And why, I pray, replies Don Pedro. Becaue, ays Don Rodrigues, the peron you would ee is at the greatet ditance with implicity of any I know. I hall comply with time and circumtances, replies Don Pedro. To be real with you, added Don Rodrigues, I know not well how Madam Virginia will entertain us, it's above eight days ince th • t he hath treated me with all poible rigour and averion, return'd my Letters without ever opening them, and ent me word he would never ee me, becaue not long ince he found me in the Church, peaking to a young Lady, with whom he aw me the ame day in a Coach, and upon this occaion it was that you aw me o ad and melancholy. It matters not, ays Don Pedro, let's go and ee them however, and take it from me, you will ooner atisfie her by vindicating your elf in her preence, than with all the Letters the whole Academy of Eloquence could furnih you with.

div.p:
Hereupon the two men-Couins went to ee the two women-Couins; and the fair Virginia permitted Don Rodrigues to vindicate himelf, which he found it no hard matter to do. Don Pedro thought them both handomer than any he had een of the ex before, not excepting the imprudent Seraphina, nor the counterfeit Matron Elvira. Violanta, who had dres'd her elf that day richer than ordinary, in order to have her Picture drawn, dazzled the eyes of Don Pedro o far, that he immediately broke the reolution he had taken, never to love
any Woman unles he were a Fool. For his part, Violanta was no les taken with him, it being his fortune to peak things o obliging upon her Picture, among which ome infinitely witty and mart, that they wrought in her an admiration of his excellent parts, and no mall atisfaction at the firt allies of his courthips.

But here I cannot avoid making a little digreion, though it be onely to tell thoe who know not o much, that your et-peeches to Gentlewomen, and your erious Students in the Academy of Complements, are a ort of people that would be good at the putting off of whipp'd Cream and Syllibubs, and are charg'd with, nay, convicted of, an aery fl • tuous eloquence by perons of good undertanding and judgment. If this word of advertiement be well conider'd by the publick, ome would find the conveniences of it equal to thoe of a good receipt againt the Flies in Summer, and ag • int tinking Breaths all the year long. Don Pedro, who had olemnly worn never to marry unles he met with a Woman the next degree remov'd from an Ideot, made it appear that the Oaths of Gameters and Lovers are not obligatory, though the late Cauits had not been o indulgent as to dipene with them. He was o infinitely taken, as with the beauty, o with the wit of Violanta, that depairing to obtain any favour of her but what might be granted without any prejudice to her honour, he was reolv'd to marry her, if he had no averion for that kind of life. He many times gave her occaion to make ome dicovery of her thoughts, as to that particular; but either he undertood him not, or at leat would
not, whether it were that he lov'd her freedom, or could not entertain any thoughts of Marriage.

All went hitherto very properouly on with thee four Lovers; but misfortune comes ever when 'tis leat expected. One day it happened, that the two young Gentlemen having tyred their Tailors, Barbers, Millaners, Shoomakers, Sempters, and all thoe other Trades which young Gallants put upon the rack when they would dazle their eys whom they pretend to adore, or to ay all in a word, made themelves as fine as Cator and Pollux, and not making the leat doubt to become Maters of the out-works at leat of the places they beieg'd, there comes an unlucky Scrich-owl, I mean an old Servant-maid, to acquaint the two Couins, that the Indian Spark, Husband to the fair Catilian, was come to Madrid, without o much as ending a Letter before him from Sevil, where the Ship came in; that the two fair Couins knew not what he meant by his urpriing them in that manner, and intreated the Gallants to have patience till uch time as Virginia had made uch dicovery of the humours of her Indian, as to know how to deal with him, and that they hould not onely forbear viiting them, but even appearing before their Windows, till further order.

Thus was all the trimming, couring and poudring of that day clearly lot, nay, as if upon this account of their Mitrees they had a remore for their vanity, for two days after, they had no more care of themelves than if they had been irreprievable Malefactors. They undertood from common report about the Town, that the Indian
• nd Virginia had been privately married; that he • as naturally jealous, a peron of experience, as being turn'd of forty years of age, and had taken uch order in his houe, and was o vigilant over the actions of his Wife, that her Gallants, if he had any, could not hope o much as a ight of her at her Window. The further order they had been promied came not, and they thought long to expect it. They made their appearance in the Street where their Mitrees liv'd, and rode up and down, as they were wont, before their doors, yet could never ee, either going in or coming out, any face they knew, or meet with any Boy or Maid they had any acquaintance with. They one day aw the Huband go in accompanied by his Brother, a peron handome enough, and o young that he was then a young Student in the Univerity. All this did but add to their affliction, and heighten the trouble they were in. They went forth betimes in the morning, they came not home till 'twere very late, and pent both time and pains to no purpoe. At lat one Holiday, being upon the Sentry, they aw coming out, at the Break of Day, one of Violenta's Maids to go to Mas. They made her tand at the Church-door, and through the peruaion of a many Preents Don Rodrigues prevailed with her to carry a Letter to her Mitres. The buines of it was this.

body.head: THE LETTER.
body.p: I Find a greater unkindnes in your oblivion of me, than I feel torment in my own jealouie, ince there is no remedy for this latter, now that you are at the dipoal of a Husband. However you are not to think your elf beyond the reach of my importunities, though you have dicharged me your remembrance. I beg of you, as the last favour I am to expect, to let me know whether I have yet any ground to hope, or mut reolve not to live any longer,

div.p: They followed the Maid at a ditance; he delivered the Letter as he had promied them, and having made a ign to them to come near the houe, he dropped out at the Window the Anwer you are like to read.

body.head: THE LETTER.
body.p:
A Jealous man, that hath not been married long, is but little from his Wife, and cannot o oon think himelf dipened from the
duty he conceives lies upon him, to expres his tendernes over her and oberve her actions. There is ome talk of taking a journey to Vailladolid, without my company, which if it happen, I hall vindicate my elf, atisfie my engagements, and pay my debts.

div.p: This Letter, which they both with a certain emulation kis'd a hundred and a hundred times, reviv'd their decaying hopes, and nourih'd them for ome days: but at lat, not hearing any thing from their forgetful Mitrees, they renew'd their marches and countermarches before their windows, pent whole nights there; and could not ee any going to and fro, no more than if the houe had been haunted and no body liv'd in it.

But one day it happen'd, that, thee two depairing Lovers being in the Church, comes in Mitres Bride; Don Rodrigues went and kneel'd down cloe by her, as t'were to outface an old Gentleman-Uher that had brought her thither. He in few words made his complaints to her; he in as few excus'd her elf, and at lat he told Don Rodrigues, that her husband was not yet gone to Vailladolid, though he talk'd of going every day: that her impatience to have a private meeting with him was no les than his; and that he knew but one way to atisfie his deires, which abolutely depended on Don Pedro. My husband, aid he, is a man, whom, when once fallen aleep, the hooting off of great Guns would hardly awake, and it is four or five days ince we poke one to another, by reaon of a little difference that is happened
between us, which is not yet ripened to a • overtures of reconciliation. I have been at m • Couin Violanta to upply my place in the Bed but he is not well, and in regard he and D •• Pedro are the onely perons that are privy t • our Loves, and that I am unwilling there houl • be any more, though it concern'd my life, w • mut make ue of him in her tead, and, if he loves you o well as to do it, prevail with him t • go into bed to my husband after he is fallen aleep. There eems at firt to be omething o • hazard in uch an enterprie; but it being conider'd withall that my husband and I are at • ditance, and that he is not eaily awak'd, doub • not but all may prove well enough as I imagine to my elf; and this is the utmot I can do for you.

This happy tratageme of Love, which Do • Rodrigues was o hot to undertand, upon the firt propoal of it, prov'd a cooler to his deires when he had heard it; for he was not onely in doubt whether his Couin would act the dangerous part which was impos'd upon him in that extravagant adventure, but was in upence, whether he hould o much as propoe it to him. His Mitres continu'd firm to her reolution, and, as he parted with her diatisfy'd Gallant, aur'd him, that if the propoition he made to him were not well entertain'd and put in execution, as he had directed, there were never any thing to be hoped from her, nay he gave him leave to forget her, though a time had been he would ooner have ign'd the entence of her own death.

The time and place broke off the dicoure between
Don Rodrigues and his Lady; he return'd home, he to his Camrade, who could not get a word from him, o much was he troubled that he mut either make a requet to him which he thought o unreaonable, or live without a happines which is ever much more valued before the enjoyment than afterwards. At lat, being gotten together into a private Chamber, Don Rodrigues having done himelf all poible violence, made the extravagant propoition to Don Pedro, allaying it what he could with thoe circumtances which might render it the more entertainable. Don Pedro could not at firt imagine but all was in jet, but his Couin on the contrary proteting he poke eriouly, o far as to confirm it with uch Oaths as convinc'd him he was in earnet, he would needs make ome port at it, telling him, he was very much oblig'd to his Mitres, for providing him an entertainment with o weet a Gentlewoman, and that no doubt it was an expreion of Violanta's gratitude towards him, who being not, by reaon of her indipoition, in a capacity to requite the ervices he had done her, and thinking her engagement a burthen, turn'd him over for the payment of it to her Couin's husband, with whom he mut expect a very pleaant night's lodging.

Thus did he endeavour to divert both his Friend and himelfe with witty decants on o odde an adventure, but Don Rodrigues was in uch a ditraction of thought as that he minded them but little, and was o cat down, that his Couin could no les than pitty him, and was omewhat in fear how dangerous the conequences of his depair might be. Don Pedro was a peron naturally
daring enough, one that had run through many adventures, and durt undertake any thing thoug • never o extravagant; he had alo a great love for Don Rodrigues, o that, all put together, he was content to upply the place of the fair Virginia, thoug • with the hazard of what michief he might receive from an exaperated and jealous husband. Being therefore fixt in his reolution, he embrac'd his Couin, and rais'd him to Life again by telling him what hazard he would run, to procure him the enjoyment of his Mitres. You hall not be, aid he to him, o extreamly oblig'd to me as you imagine for what I hall do for you, I find my elf inclin'd to undertake it as an action of honour, wherein I pretend to as much reputation as if I had behav'd my elf ever o gallantly at the torming of ome trong place.

Things thus concluded, word was ent to Virginia, that her propoition was accepted; he appointed the time that very night; the two Couins came according to appointment, were conducted into the houe with as little noie as might be; and Don Pedro was forc'd, in the preence of the fair Lady, to put off his cloaths, as being deirous her orders hould be oberv'd with the greatet exactnes. Don Pedro being thus tript to his linnen, he brought him, as oftly as if his way had been pav'd with eggs, and with the greatet caution imaginable, to the dangerous bed-ide, and, having drawn the curtains, and turn'd down the cloaths as eaily as might be, held the daring Don Pedro by the arms, while he gingerly laid himelf down in the bed, who haply now began to repent him of his confidence, and no doubt contented himelf with uch
a part of the bed as that he came not near the middle.

Having thus dispos'd of him, he went her ways, lock'd the chamber door without ever minding the noie he made in doing it, which Don Pedro was troubled mot of all at. Her buines now was to get to Don Rodrigues, whom I am apt to believe he paid, like a gallant good natur'd woman, what ever he was in his debt, at leat as much as he would take of it.

Don Pedro in the mean time was in a condition much different from that of his Couin's, who no doubt was over head and ears in the embraces of a fair Lady that was a bed with him, while this overcharitable Kinman lay in fear of nothing o much as of thoe of a ordid man, who, to his great misfortune, was a very troubleome bed-fellow. Then did he begin to reflect, but too late, on his foolih preumption, that being what he hould have done before he engag'd himelf in uch a deign; he blam'd himelf, call'd himelf fool, and acknowledg'd that the injury he did a husband was one of thoe that are unpardonable, if he himelf were to pas his entence upon it.

But it was not long ere thee ad reflections were interrupted, and his jut fears heightned by his Bed-fellow's turning to him, and cating his burdenome arm about his neck, as if he would have embrac'd his wife. Don Pedro omewhat frighten'd at thoe unwelcome carees, the more haply becaue accompani'd with certain words imperfectly uttered, made a hift to disburthen himelf of the arm which he thought more weighty than a far heavier burthen, and lipp'd his neck from under it,
taking great care not to do him any hurt; and having o done, he got to the bed-ide, with his body o far over, that he had much ado to keep in the bed, wihing his life fairly at an end, and blaming onely himelf for running o great a hazard to comply with the paion of two indicreet Lovers. He had hardly time to breathe, and recover his pirits ever o little, ere the unquiet Bed-fellow thrut in his legs between his; which lat action, added to the foregoing perecutions, made him look pale as death it elf. At lat, whil't one came till nearer, and the other remov'd, day comes on, very expectedly to Don Pedro, who was not able to tand out any longer againt his Adverary, who had thrut him as far as he could go.

He got out of bed as gently as he could, and went to open the door, which he found very carefully double lock'd, a misfortune as indigetible as any of the precedent. As he was trying, to little purpoe, to thrut back the lock, it flew open of a udden, and the door had almot taken him over the face. Virginia comes into the room as it were in much hate, and ask'd him loud enough, Whither he made uch hate? Don Pedro entreating her with a low voice to peak more gently, ask'd her whether he were mad to hazard in that manner the waking of her husband, and deir'd her he would let him out. How! go out? replies the Lady with a loud voice. No, I would have my husband ee what bed-fellow he hath had to night, that he may ee the fruits of his own jealouie, and what I am able to do.

Having o aid, bold as a Liones he took Don Pedro by the arm; then, in uch diturbance as that
he had not the trength to get from her, open'd the hutters of the windows, without letting go her prize, and dragging him to the bed-ide, drew the curtains, aying aloud, See, Mr. Jealous-brains, whom you have had to your bed-fellow! Don Pedro was not o cared, but that he had the confidence to look into that dreadful bed, where, intead of the imagin'd Satyre, he found his amiable Violanta, who had lain with him, and not Virginia's husband, who was gone into the Country eight days before. The two fair Couins jeer'd him mot unmercifully, never had a witty man uch a task to vindicate himelf, or betrai'd a greater confuion. Violanta, who was extremely a lover of mirth, and poke things handomly and ingeniouly, made her Couin almot burt with laughing when he related what frights he had put Don Pedro to, whenever, pretending to be between leeping and waking, he got any t • ing near him.

This baiting put Don Pedro, who was till in his hirt, almot out of countenance; o that it was a long time ere he could recover himelf out of the confuion he was in. At lat Virginia took pity of him, and left him and her Couin to themelves, to make up the accounts that were between them, which were of ome conequence, for it took up their time from morning till it was noon. From that time, while the Husband was in the Country, the two he-Couins and the two he-Couins had frequent meetings, and made their advantages of the opportunity. The Indian being return'd, onely Don Rodrigues far'd the wore for it; for Don Pedro, by the aitance of the Servants whom his Preents had brought to his Lure, made a hift, for two
or three months, to pend mot flights with Violanta, who was at her own dipoal, and, ince her Couin's marriage, lodg'd in a part of the houe whereof he had the command, and which had a back-door that opened into another treet. He was o deeply in love with her, that he earnetly wih'd himelf married to her, but when he made any Propoal of that nature to her, he o handomely put off the dicoure, that he knew not whether it were out of deign, or that he minded not much what he aid to her. At lat, to confirm the general opinion, that this world is a Stage of perpetual changes, Violanta began to remit much of her paion, and by little and little grew to that coldnes towards Don Pedro, that he could not forbear complaining of it, and, not knowing what to quarrel at, charg'd her with infidelity, reproaching her, that he had entertain'd ome other Gallant into her favour.

But intead of recovering himelf by this means into that place in her affections which he had formerly poeed, it made him o inupportable to Violanta, that he did not onely forbear the kindnees he did him in the night, but could not endure his company in the day time. Yet was he not a jot cat down at it. He, by the charms of a many Preents, prevail'd o far with one of the Gentlewomen, treacherous enough of her own inclination, as that he dicover'd to him, that her Mitres was extremely taken with her Couin's Brother-in-law, who was then jut come from the Univerity; that he was a very handome young man, and no les in love with Violanta, than Violanta was with him. To act omething notorious for the perfidiounes of it, this wicked Wench advied him to
pretend himelf ick, to end his Mitres notice of it, complaining as if he were the caue of his indipoition, which, by reaon of the likelihood of it, might be credited; and, in a word, to pretend it o eriouly, that her Mitres might not be o vigilant, nor tand o much upon her guard, as he had ever done, ince he broke off her correpondence with him. Don Pedro plaid his part as well as if he had been an old Actor at it. Violanta perceiv'd not the Mit that was cat before her eyes, and the perfidious Author of the Plot, had no ooner brought her Mitres's new Adonis into that chamber, but he went to open the gate to the jealous Don Pedro.

He comes all fury into Violanta's chamber, and urpries her already in bed, and her young Exercier putting off his cloaths to lay himelf by her. He went with his word drawn treight to his Rival, haply to frighten him a little. The young man had his wits about him, o that taking up one of his hoes, and holding it out as one would do a pocket-pitol, aim'd at Don Pedro's face, o confidently, that Don Pedro, who mitruted no uch thing, and doubted not but that he would have hot at him, lunk down and turn'd of one ide, in which interval the young man got out at the door. Violanta, who was reolv'd to make an abolute rupture with Don Pedro, broke out into a laughter, and jear'd at his fear of being pitoll'd with a hoe. He took her abues o heinouly, that he fell a boxing of her; he had him by the hair; it came to a bloudy cuffle, inomuch, that at lat, the hard-hearted Granadin, having ued her o unmercifully, that he was forced to cry out
Murder, made his ecape into the treet, jut as Virginia, her husband, and all the ervants, arm'd, as it were to engage an enemy, that had beat up their quarters, came into Violanta's chamber.

In the mean time Don Pedro gave Don Rodrigues an account of what had paed, and, not loing any time, went and proffer'd his ervice to the Duke of Oonne, who was to depart the next day to be Vice-Roy of Naples. Don Pedro expected him at the Port, where they were to embark, leaving his dear Couin extremely troubled both at his departure and the occaion of it. He continued ix or even years at Naples, much repected by the Vice-Roy, who allow'd him very coniderable penions. He receiv'd alo no mall umms out of Spain, o that there was not any peron in Naples liv'd at • higher rate than he did, which made him more coniderable in Italy than mot of your Spaniards, who go thither as much out of a deign to grow rich, as the French do to pend their mony. He travell'd to Sicily, made ome tay in the more eminent Cities, and, being return'd into Italy, pent two or three years at Rome, as many at Venice, viited all the places he thought worth it; and, at lat, having been fourteen or fifteen years out of Spain, ever in love, or, if you will, ever making it his main buines to atisfie his lut, till engag'd in ome adventure or other, and more and more confirm'd in his opinion, that a man could not be afely married to a witty woman, an humour took him to put a period to all his extravagant coures, and to return to GRANADA, to ee all the friends he had left there.

But the greatet motive of his departure out of
Italy, was, that his returns of mony fail'd him, through the diappointment of his correpondents; or, at leat, his Exchequer was grown o low, that he had hardly o much as carri'd him to Barcelona. There he old what cloaths he could pare, to buy him a Mule, and keeping onely the bet he had for his journey, he took his way towards his dear Country, without any retinue at all, the ervant whom he had brought with him out of Spain being, in all probability, dead of the Neapolitan dieae, and his tock o mall, as would not haply defray the charges of another.

He left Barcelona at the break of day, to avoid the heat, and the importunity of the flies, which in Augut are very troubleome, o that by nine of the clock he was gotten four or five leagues in his way. He rode through the middle of a pretty large country village, where a certain Duke of Cataloniae pas'd away part of the Summer, as having in that place a fair Catle that tood upon the road. The Duke was an antient man, and had to his Lady a woman of an excellent humour, a great both lover and maker of port, and about twenty years of age. He was that day gone abroad upon ome hunting-meeting, and was not to return till the next. The young Dutches tanding in a Balcony of the Catle cat her eye on our Adventurer of Granada. His goodly preence and the tate of his riding rais'd in her a deire to have a ight of him nearer hand; beides, that he was of an inquiitive nature, and uffer'd few trangers to pas through the Town without ending for them. Though he had reolv'd to bait ome leagues off the place where he then was, yet could he not civilly anwer a requet
made to him from the Dutches with a denial, amounting to no more than his waiting on her onely as long as the urgency of his occaions would permit. She was beautiful as an Angel, and the Granadin was one that felt a certain warmth diffue it elf through his whole body, at the ight of uch beauties, though they were not Dutchees. He, on the other ide, was a peron every way graceful, and the Dutches took much pleaure to ee men of his making; to redeem, in ome meaure, the time he mi-pent with her husband, who, to her great misfortune, thought her o handome, and was o infinitely taken with the pleaantnes of her behaviour, that he imagin'd he never aw her enough, though he were eldome out of his ight.

Don Pedro, being a peron of excellent parts and good judgment, found the Dutches much diverion by giving her a relation of his Travels, and oon oberv'd her to be of a nature much inclin'd to mirth and a pleaant paing away of the time. She inquir'd particularly concerning the Gallantry at Naples, would needs know whether the Women there have much freedom, and whether the Gallants of Italy were comparable to thoe of Spain. In fine, Don Pedro was confirm'd by the quetions he put to him, that if he were not very well read in the buines of Courthip and Gallantry, it was not for want of good-will. She would needs entertain him at dinner to both their mutual atisfaction: oon after dinner he would have taken his leave of her, but he would not by any means permit it telling him her Lord would not return that day, that he mut needs be her guet, and very obligingly adoing, that perons of his worth being very rare in
Catalonia, they were not to be parted with till ome extraordinary neceity forc'd them away, and conequently the happines of their company was to be improv'd to the utmot.

She thereupon led him into a Cloet, which by reaon of its paciounes was very cool, adorn'd with Pictures, Porcelane, and other Rarities, and furnih'd, beides all things uitable to the greatnes of the peron, with a umptuous Couch, cover'd with a Satin quilt. Having eated him on it, he related to her his adventures at Granada, Sevil, and Madrid, as alo thoe he had met with in Italy, which are not come to my knowledge. The Dutches heard him with much attention, and he told her at lat, that he was reolv'd to marry, if he could but meet with a woman imple enough to ecure him, as to thoe inconveniences which witty women run their husbands into. An Etate I have, continu'd he, plentiful enough, and though he I hall marry have no fortune at all, o he be well brought up, and not over-deformed, I hall not cruple to marry her; though, to be incere with you, I hould rather make choice of one that were unhandome, o he were imple, than a handome one that were not. Ah how trangely do you miapprehend things in my judgement, ays the Dutches to him, or, what do you mean, when you ay, well brought up? I mean a virtuous woman and of good reputation, replies he. And how is it poible a woman that's little better than a natural fool can be virtuous, ays the fair Lady, ince he knows not what Virtue is, nay is not in a capacity to learn? How do you imagine a fool can have any affection for you,
having not the apprehenion to know you? She will be wanting to her duty, yet not be enible of it; whereas a woman of undertanding, in cae he hould be ditrutful of her own virtue, will make a hift to avoid the occaions which may endanger the los of it.

Their contetation took up much longer time, th •
Granadine maintaining, that a woman hould apire to no greater knowledg than that of loving her husband, being faithful to him, and careful of the government of her houe and children; and the Dutches on the other ide deirous to convince him, that a imple woman was not able to do any thing of all this; nay that, though he were handome, it would not be long e'r he would be thought troubleome They were both atisfi'd of one another's wit and judgment, and the mutual good opinion they had conceiv'd one of another was oon heightned into an affection, nay, I may ay, omething yet greater. There was not onely a difference between the Granadine and the Duke, as to age, undertanding, and peron, but the former was of uch an exact compoure as the world haply afforded but few like him; and if he was thought uch by his Dutches, he in requital thought her the handomet woman he had ever een. He was bold as a Lyon, and never had the opportunity to be alone with a woman, but he made proffer of his ervice to her. If it were accepted, he did the bet he could; if offence were taken, he cat himelf on his knees, and calling himelf firt the preumptuous Ixion, he crav'd pardon o ingenuouly and with uch exquiite hypocriie, that either his offence was pardon'd, or haply it would not have been taken amis if he offended
again. I never thought, aid he to the Magnetick Dutches, to have met with a peron able to force me out of an opinion wherein o many experiences had confirm'd me: but I mut withall confes, I never was before oppos'd in it by a peron extraordinary as you are, whoe oul alone, without making any advantage of your beauty (which yet defies the world to parallel it) may exercie what juridiction it pleaes over all thoe who have apprehenion enough to acknowledge, that your excellencies are greater than thoe of all other women put together. You have cur'd me of one error, but uffer me to groan under omething ele which is o much the more dangerous, and hard to be cur'd, by how much I take greater pleaure in my icknes, and atisfie, by enduring it, the noblet ambition man can be capable of.

I have now forgot what other hyperboles he drew up together, to engage the Dutches's virtuous inclinations; as alo what reerves of pathetical impertinences he was forc'd to make ue of; for, he was upon a very hot and dangerous ervice of Courthip. Nor could I ever learn with what countenance the Dutches entertain'd a Forlorn of Love and Gallantry o confidently brought up; whether he receiv'd the amorous charge uitably to the fiercenes of it; or made the weaker reitance out of hope of better quarter. Thee particulars, though much deirous of it, I could never have any account of, and onely have it from one of the Dutches's Gentlewomen, ince dead in France of the King's Evil, that the Cloet-door was lock'd upon them at two of the Clock, and that they were there together till Supper-time; and beides
what the Gentlewoman aid, I know my elf by experience, that Opportunity makes the Thief.
