Night came on, the indulgent Deity of tollen Loves but Don Pedro and the Dutches were prejudic'd rather than oblig'd by it, for out of a regard to Civility, and to keep the Servants from talking, (whoe jealouies ever magnifie things to the great prejudice of Truth, a Virtue they are profes'd enemies to) they call'd for lights, which, being brought, were darkned by the two bright eyes Heaven had betow'd on the Dutches, and which then out-vy'd the Stars with their lively parkling. Her complexion, which now had doubled the hue of its native carnation, appear'd brighter to Don Pedro than the Sun in a Summers day, and his face too had a little touch of the violent inclining to red.

But as they were beholding one another with much confidence and atisfaction, an alarm came to the Dutches, that the Duke her husband was come into the Court. All he could do upon o udden notice, was, to dipoe her much atonih'd Gallant into a Cloet where he kept her perfum'd waters, and, having lock'd him in, to cat her elf on a Bed. The Duke, who was a man of threecore years of age at leat, comes into his Lady's Cloet, and finds her freh as a roe upon the buh. He told her, that a Letter he had receiv'd from the Vice-roy had occaion'd his return ooner than he expected. He was grown very hungry, ordered to be brought him into the Cloet what there was ready, and the Dutches, though he had no great tomach to eat any thing with him, while her Gallant hook, or haply did omething ele, for fear,
yet took a Chair and at near the Table. She was of a dipoition extreamly inclin'd to make port, and o divertive, as that it, in a manner, retriv'd her old husband into youth again, o much was he pleas'd at every thing he did. It was an ordinary thing between them to lay extravagant wagers, and that mot commonly when he had ome occaion or humour to get money out of him, which the imple man took great delight to looe, as one that inexpreibly doted on o excellent a woman.

He never admir'd her o much as at this time; She, to heighten his admiration, told him a hundred pleaant tories; at which the good Duke was ready to burt with Laughing; for eating with a good tomack, and at the ame time laughing very heartily, he was two or three times o near choaking, that they were forc'd to give him uch thumps in the back, as he would have taken very unkindly at another time: but through God's mercy, he got no hurt, onely a crum or two mis'd their way down his throat. At lat, the Dutches, who had a malicious humour to make port at any thing, would needs divert her elf at the cot of her imprion'd Gallant. She told the Duke, that it eem'd a long time to her ince they had laid any wager; and that he would gladly lay a hundred Pitols with him, upon uch a match and tearms as they hould agree upon. The Duke told her he was at her ervice, and expected what he would propoe. The Dutches made many propoals to him, which he was confident he would not accept; and at lat he ask'd him, whether he would lay any wager, that he nam'd all thoe things, requiite about a houe, that were made of iron. The Duke
took her up, though he thought the wager very extravagant, and having call'd for pen, ink, and paper, as oon as they had taken away, and his Almoner aid Grace (for the Duke was a man of good example) he writ down the names of all the Iron things he could think on; But uch was the Dutches's good fortune, as that he forgot to et down Keys. She caus'd him divers times to read over what he had writ, and having ask'd him whether he had any thing to add, he folded up the paper, and told him he would take time to examine it, and in the interim acquaint him with an adventure had happened to her, one of the mot pleaant he had ever heard of.

p.q:
I was gotten, continued he, preently after your departure, to one of the Balconies of the Catle which look towards the Road, where I had not been long, ere I py'd paing by, mounted on a Mule, a man of a goodly and graceful preence, who, by the rate of his riding, eem'd to be employ'd upon ome buines that requir'd more than ordinary expedition. I was very deirous to know what might be the occaion of his hate, and thereupon ent a Page after him to bring him to me. I mut needs acknowledge, I never aw a handomer Man, nor one more likely to make the gravet Matron, or trictet Nun, break their vows of chatity. I ask'd him, Whence he travell'd and What he was? He gave me an account of himelf with o much gallantry and ingenuity, that he enflam'd me with a deire of more of his converation. I prevail'd with him o far as that he was willing to tay the remainder of the day in the Catle,
and give me a relation of his Adventures, which mut needs have been very remarkable, and conequently very pleaant in the relation. He acquitted himelf anwerably to my expectation, and I mut confes, I was never better pleas'd with any tory in my life; and I hall not think it much to let you participate of the pleaantnes of it.

div.p: She thereupon acquainted the Duke what had happen'd to Don Pedro at Granada, Sevil, and Madrid, whereat the good man, who made as much port at a foolih tory as any Duke within a hundred miles of him, pent his pleen in uch violent and immoderate Laughters, as occaion'd thoe as well of the Dutches, as the chiefet of the Duke's Menial Servants, with whom he innocently liv'd in great intimacy and familiarity. She afterwards acquainted him what had happen'd to her Gallant in Italy, which was alo very pleaant, as I have been told, but the particulars I could never learn. Onely this I know, that the Duke laughed o heartily thereat, that Don Pedro himelf, lock'd up as he was, could hardly forbear. She told him what an ill opinion he had of all women that pretended to any thing of wit, the reaons which he alledg'd to maintain it, and thoe which he had urg'd in oppoition thereto.

At lat, having found her husband, and all that were preent, nay Don Pedro himelf o much port that they were weary of it, he told the Duke, that the Gallant of Granada, after the relation of his adventures, grew o preumptuous as to make his applications to her, and had done it with o much
addres, that, not knowing how to take it am • from a tranger, that he was o confident in • Courthip, as to aim at her enjoyments, he • o taken with him that it was no hard matter w •• him to perceive it. To be hort, to what e •• hould I detain you longer, continu'd the Dutches, uch a peron may attempt any thing, an • not be thought too confident. We pent mo •• part of the day together, to our mutual atisfaction, and would have been together till, had you not come upon us when I leat expected you I hall not diemble with you, I was both troubled and urpriz'd at your return. My lovely tranger eem'd to be more atonih'd than I was; I with much precipitation got him into my Cloet of perfum'd waters, whence he hea • s me if he be not dead out of fear: but confiden • in the influence I have over you, and being of my own nature, unwilling to diemble, even in thoe things wherein the freedome of my humour might prove prejudicial to me, I would needs find you matter of d •• erion at the cot of that poor Gentleman, whom I will et at liberty as oon as you are departed to your Chamber, and dimis him that he may return to Granada, where, he ays, he goes to find out a woman imple enough to be his wife.

The Dutches accompany'd her relation with o much ingenuity, freedome, and likelihood, that the Duke began to quit his mirth and to take things in good earnet. He grew pale; was afraid his Lady had aid no more than what was true; nay, could not forbear asking her for the Key of the Cloet, where he aid the Granadine was lock'd
up. She fell to ome other dicoure, and thereby heightned both his jealouies and his fear; he ask'd her a econd time for the key of the cloet; he deni'd to give it him. He would needs have it, and tarted out of his chair in a great fury. Not o fat, my Lord, not o fat, ays the Dutches to him; before you ask for keys o hatily, pray have the patience, leiurely to read the Inventory you have given me; you have forgotten to et down, keys, you cannot deny they are uually made of iron, and that you have lot your hundred Pitols, which I accordingly expect to be immediately paid me; and know withal, that it was onely to convince you that you had lot, as alo to put you into o good an humour as that you might part the more freely with your money, that I have entertain'd you with o pleaant a tory. Take heed another time you be not o eaie of belief, as to receive for true what is pure fiction and Romance. There's no probability, that o many extraordinary adventures hould happen to the ame man, and much les, that I hould have related uch a tory, if it were true.

The Dutches poke this with uch a confident indifference, that the Duke was more eaily induc'd to believe all he had aid was fabulous, than he had been to think it true. He laugh'd at all, as if he had been little better than out of his wits; he admir'd the miraculous ingenuity of his wife, and oblig'd all his dometicks that were preent to a like admiration, who were haply as credulous fools as their Mater. Do but ee, for God's ake, aid he, breaking forth into loud exclamations
and laughter, do but ee, with what artifices he hath atisfi'd me that I had lot my wager. The Dutches was ready to burt with laughing, her Gentlewomen were not much behind. Don Pedro in the cloet was forc'd to adde to the Dutches's perfum'd waters, the better to mother his joy. At lat having given his Steward order to deliver his Lady the hundred Pitols, he took his leave of her and went to his own lodgings, often telling her, one while, that he was a female Devil, another, that he had a wit and invention beyond the Devil. The ervants repeated the ame thing after their Mater, o that till he was abed and aleep, nothing was talk'd of about the houe, but the damnable wit of the Dutches.

In the mean time, the Dutches being paid the hundred Pitols by the Steward, caus'd the chamber-door to be lock'd; and having brought Don Pedro out of his imprionment, not fully recover'd of the fear he had put him into, he pres'd him to acknowledge, that a witty and dicreet woman may, without prejudice to her honour, alve a misfortune, whereof the very thought would make a imple one die for fear. She would needs have him eat of what her Women had brought up for her elf. He intreated her to excue him, and to dimis him as oon as might be. She gave him the hundred Pitols he had got of her Husband, with a Gold-chain, and her own Picture, which amounted to as much, and deir'd him to remember her, and to give her an account of his further Adventures.

Having thereupon embrac'd him with much affection,
he recommended him to the conduct of her Women, who put him and his Mule ecretly out at a back-door. He thought it no prudence to lodge in that place, but to ride forward two Leagues, to the Town where he thought to have din'd the day before, when the Dutches retain'd him.

As he rid along, what had hapned to him with the amorous Dutches was perpetually preent to his thoughts. He could not ufficiently admire, at leat as he then thought, the readines wherewith at firt ight he entertain'd his affection, even before he knew him; her confidence to make o trange and pleaant a tory to the Duke, which yet was but too true; and latly, her ubtilty in alving all by applying it to the Wager. He could not alo but admire the eaie nature and implicity of the Duke; he pitied him, and, after all accidents and circumtances weigh'd, was confirm'd more than ever in the opinion, that a witty Woman was of a difficult keeping; and thence inferr'd, that, if the Dutches had not been over-confident of her own wit, he would not o eaily have executed what he had been o deirous to do, nor have been guilty of a preumption o incredible as to declare it to her Husband.

In fine, from all the Adventures he had run through, and all the experiences he had of mankind, he deriv'd a certain confidence, that he hould never run the hazard of being unfortunately married, either by not taking any Wife at all, or marrying one o imple, as knew no difference between love and averion.

Amidt thee reflections he arriv'd at Madrid,
where he found his Couin Don Rodrigues poes'd of his Father's etate, and married to his Couin. He undertood from him, that Violanta was married; and that the fair Virginia was gone to the Indies with her Husband. From Madrid he took his journey for Granada. He alighted at his Aunt's, who entertain'd him with inexpreible kindnes, and acquainted him that Seraphina led a Saint's life in the Nunnery, and that her beloved Servant was dead, out of pure grief and indignation that he had not prevail'd with her, to quit the holy life he had oblig'd her elf to, and marry him.

The next day he went along with his Aunt to ee young Laura, Seraphina's daughter, he had been put into a Convent at four years of age, and might then be about ixteen or eventeen. He thought her beautiful as all the Angels together, and withal imple beyond all the Nuns that came into the wo • ld without wit, and were taken out of it ere they got any. He view'd her very eriouly, and w • s extremely taken with her beauty. He oblig'd her to peak, and could not but admire her implicity and her innocence. He doubted not but that he had found out what he ought; and what made him have a greater inclination for Laura, was, that he had had a great love for Seraphina, and perceiv'd her daughter to be much like her, though incomparably more handome. He acquainted his Aunt that he was not his daughter, and how that he had ome intentions to marry her: His Aunt encourag'd him in his deign, and acquainted Laura therewith, who expreed not any either atisfaction or diatisfaction thereat. Don Pedro took order for the furnihing of his
houe, hearkned out for uch Men-ervants as were in ome meaure remarkable for their ottihnes, laid out for Maids as imple as the Mitres that was to govern them, and had much ado to find any. He made her cloaths as rich and umptuous as any could be had in Granada. All the perons of quality about the City were at the Wedding, and were no les atisfi'd with Laura's beauty, than diatisfi'd with her want of undertanding. The ceremonies of the wedding were over in very good time, o that the new married couple were left alone. Don Pedro order'd his Servants to go to their beds, and having ent away his wife's maids, after they had undres'd her, lock'd the chamber door.

Having thus order'd things, Don Pedro, out of a trancendency of prudence, which was the greatet madnes in the world, put in execution the mot fantatick deign that could fall into the imagination of a man, who had all his life been accounted a peron of undertanding. Being more fool than his wife was imple, he would needs try how far he might trut her implicity. He et himelf in a chair, caus'd his wife to tand before him, and aid thee words to her, or others haply no les impertinent; You are now my wife, a happines for which I hope I hall have caue to bles God as long as we live together. Let it ink very deeply into your mind, what I am going to tell you, and oberve it exactly as long as you live, both for fear of offending God, and dipleaing me. At all thee hony'd words, the innocent Laura made very low courtzies, whether eaonably, or not, is no great matter, and
look'd on her Husband as timerouly as a Boy newly ent to School would on an imperious Pedant. Do you know, continu'd Don Pedro, what kind of life perons that are married do lead? I know nothing of it, replies Laura, making a courtzie lower than any before; but if you will teach it me, I hall be as perfect in it as in my Ave-mary, and then another courtzie.
Don Pedro was the mot atisfi'd man in the world, to find his wife much more imple than he could well have expected. He drew out of a cloet that was in the chamber a uit of Armour, very rich and very light, which he had ometime worn at a magnificent reception, which the City had made for the King of Spain. He put his idiot-wife into them, he put on her head a little gilt Head-piece cover'd with a plume of feathers, girt a hort Sword to her ide, and having put a Lance into her hand, told her, that the duty of uch married Women as would be accounted virtuous, was, to watch their Husbands while they lept, arm'd all over as he then was. She made him no anwer; but with her ordinary reverences, which had not haply been at an end a good while, if he had not commanded her to take two or three turns about the chamber which he did by chance with o much Majety, (her natural beauty, and Pallas-like accoutrements contributing much thereto) that the over-ubtil Granadin was in a manner out of himelf for joy to ee it. He went to bed, and Laura continu'd in the poture he had left her in, till five in the morning.

The mot prudent and mot circumpect of all the Husbands that ever were, at leat who thought
himelf no les, got up, put on his cloaths, diarm'd his wife, help'd her to put off her cloaths, and having dipos'd her into the bed out of which he roe, kis'd her over and over, and wept out of pure joy that he had found, as he thought, what he look'd for. He order'd her to lie a bed till it were very late, and having commanded the Maids not to diturb her, he went to Mas, and thence about his occaions; for I had forgot to tell you, that he had bought an Office at Granada, uch as might be that of a perpetual Major or Sheriff.

The firt night of the Nuptials was pent in the manner you heard, and the Husband was uch a Coxcomb as to make no better ue of the econd. But Heaven punih'd him according to the ue he made of his Talent. There happen'd a buines, which oblig'd him, all excues laid aide, to take pot the ame day, and make all the expedition he could to Court. He had no more time allow'd him than to hift himelf, to put on other cloaths, and to take leave of his wife, whom he commanded, upon pain of God's dipleaure and his own, exactly to oberve, in his abence, the life that married women were to lead.

Thoe who have any thing to do at Court, are uncertain how long it may be, ere they are dipatch'd. Don Pedro thought not to have taid abroad above five or ix days, but his buines kept him there like a Burre, now ticking to one Courtier, anon to another, for four or five months; in the mean time, the imple Laura neglected not her duty, pent the nights according to her Husband's order, in armour, and the days that succeeded
them in uch works as he had learn'd among the Nuns.

Much about this time came a Gentleman of Corduba to proecute a Law-uit at Granada. He was, as to his internals, no fool; as to his externals, handome enough. He often aw Laura in her Balcony, and thought her very handome: he often pas'd and repas'd by her windows, a kind of Courthip ordinary in Spain: and Laura, on the other ide, o let him go to and fro, without either knowing what it meant, or indeed having any deire to know. A Citizen's wife, of mean quality, who liv'd over againt Don Pedro's houe, being of a nature extremely charitable, and concerning her elf much in the exigencies of any he aw ditres'd, oon took notice both of the affection of the Stranger, and the inenibility of her fair Neighbour thereof. She was a woman could manage a buines with abundance of conduct and circumpection, and the principal quality he profes'd, was that of making Matches, and olliciting venereal caues, whether they were jut or unjut it matter'd not, o they brought in omething to make the pot boil. And this employment Nature eem'd to have deign'd her for, as having furnih'd her with all the accomplihments requiite in uch as would be eminent therein; for he had ome skill in making of Periwigs, he had a penion from all Chamber-maids, and Waiting-Gentlewomen, to ell their Lady's cat cloaths and their own, and other things which your meaner ort of Gentlewomen make a great how with; he ditill'd everal orts of Waters, he had ome ecrets for the beautifying of the body, and above
all, he had confidence enough to pretend to ome skil in Chiromancy and Atrology, and upon that account, lay under ome upition of being a Witch. She o contantly aluted the Gentleman of Corduba every time he pas'd by her Neighbour's door, that he could not but imagine it done out of ome deign. He return'd her Salutation, went to her, and with the fame labour became acquainted with her, and improv'd that acquaintance into Friendhip; he made her privy to his Love, and promis'd her a very good reward if he prov'd a uccesful ollicitres on his behalf to her Neighbour.

Upon this encouragement (intructions he needed not any) the old piece of Brokery betirs her elf immediately; he oon prevail'd with the imple Servants to let her in to the Mitres, under pretence of hewing her ome rarities which he had to ell; She commended her beauty, bemoan'd her being depriv'd o oon of her Husband's company; and, being left alone with her, brought in ome dicoure of the gallant Gentleman who pas'd by her doors o often. She told her that he lov'd her beyond his own life, and was p • ionately deirous to become her ervant, if o be he would permit him. Truly, truly, I am very much oblig'd to him, replies the innocent Laura, and hould gladly entertain him into my ervice; but the houe is now full of ervants, and till ome one of them be dimis'd, I dare not entertain any in my husband's abence. I will write to him about it, if this Gentleman be deirous I hould, and doubt not but he will do any thing I hall pres him to.

The tempting Gipie needed not o great a dicovery to be atisfi'd, that Laura was little remov'd from implicity it elf. She therfore made her apprehend, as well as he could, after what manner the Gentleman was deirous to erve her; told her he was a peron of as great an etate as her husband, and that if he were deirous to make any trial of it, he would bring her, as a preent from him, Jewels of great value, and what ele he hould deire. Alas, Madam! ays Laura, I have o much of what you peak of, that I know not what to do with them. Nay, if it be o, repli'd the Satanical Ambaadres, and that you do not much care whether he make you any preents, do him but the favour as that he may give you a viit. That he may do when he pleaes, ays Laura, there's no body hinders him. That will do very well, replies the Old one, but it were better, if none of your Servants knew of it. That's no hard matter, replies Laura, for my Women lye not in my own Chamber, and I go to Bed without their aitance, and that very late. Take this key, which opens any lock about the houe, and, about eleaven at night, he may come in at the Garden-gate, where there is a little pair of tairs that lead to my Chamber.

The old Crone upon that took her by the hands, and kis'd them over and over, telling her he would go and revive that poor Gentleman, whom he had left half dead. How comes he to be in that condition, cries Laura not a little frightned? 'Tis you are the occaion of his death, replies the old tremptres.
Laura grew pale, as if he had been convicted of a murther, and would
have made protetations of her innocence, if the wicked Agent, who thought not fit to make any further trial of her ignorance, had not cat her arms about her neck, and, auring her the ick party would not dye, taken leave of her.

It may be well imagin'd he was not o neglectful as to leave behind her that miraculous Key, which open'd all doors. There may haply be ome body, who upon reading what is here aid of that Key, will think he hath play'd the Critick rarely, when he hall ay, that it was enchanted, and that this paage betrays omething of fable: but whoever he be, let him know thus much from his mot humble Servant, that the M • ters of Families in Spain have uch Keys, which they call Mitres-keys, and accordingly take heed another time, how he carps at what he undertands not. But now I think on't, let him take what falls within his narrow apprehenion which way he pleaes: may I be thought as impertinent as he, if ever I trouble my head with it.

Nor hall I care a jot if he think this very digreion impertinent; let him make a Parentheis of it if he will. I know he is impatient to know what the old woman does. She is jut gone to the amorous Gentleman, who is at her houe entertaining a Daughter of hers; one her Mother deigns to be her ucceor in the Dicipline of advancing the enjoyments and accommodations of Mankind. Knocking as hard as he could at the door, the Gentleman began to upect he might be betray'd; but the Daughter undertood it to ignifie the happy ucces of her Mother's interceion, as having learnt from her, and he from the common proverb,
that, Who brings good news is not afraid to knock at the door. She comes into the room with an infernal mile in her countenance, and gave him that account of her furtherance of the buines, as made him ready to leap out at the windows for joy. He rewarded her very liberally, and expected night with much impatience. It comes at l • t, though never the ooner for his expectation. He gets into the Garden, and with as little noie as might be to Laura's Chamber-door, while he was walking very eriouly up and down the Chamber, all in Armour and a Lance in her hand, according to the wie intructions of her extravagant Husband There was one mall light, and that plac'd in a remote corner of the Chamber, the Door being wide open to receive the Gallant he expected; but he eeing the glimpe of a peron all in Armour, made no doubt but there was ome treachery in the buines. His fear at that time over-mater'd his love, how violent oever it might be, o that h • made more hate to be gone than he had to come thither, imagining he could hardly get oon enough into the Street. He went to his Proxey, and acquainted her what danger he had been in. She, to vindicate the incerity of her procedure, went the next day to Laura, who preently ask'd her, Whether the Gentleman were till ick, and why he came not according to appointment? He is neither ick, nor hath fail'd to come, repli'd Satan, but finding a man all in Armour walking up and down your Chamber, it frightned him away Laura at this burt out into a laughter, he could not recover her elf out of for a good while, which the Old one knew not how to interpret. At lat,
not able to laugh any longer, and making a hift to peak, he told her Neighbour, that it mut needs be the Gentleman was never married, and that it was he her elf who walk'd up and down the Chamber in Armour.

The old woman was till to eek what Laura hould mean by that, and for a good while could not believe he was well in her wits; but after abundance of quetions and anwers, he apprehended what he could never have believ'd, as well, of the implicity of a young Maid of ixteen years of age, that hould know any thing almot; as the extravagant precaution her Husband had bethought him of to ecure his Wives honour. She thought it her bet coure to let Laura continue in her error till he were undeceiv'd by her expected Gallant, and o, in tead of betraying her urprize at the trangenes of the thing, he joyn'd with Laura in laughing at the fright he had put the Gentleman into. Another appointment was made that he hould give his peronal appearance at her Chamber that night. The old woman atisfied the Gallant, and both admir'd the ottihnes as well of the Husband as the Wife.

Night came on, he gets into the Garden, thence up the private tairs, and found his Lady all in Armour, upon duty, as he us'd to be. He embrac'd her though all clad in Iron, and he entertain'd him, as if he had known him from the longet day he could remember. At lat he ask'd her, Why he was all in Armour? She made anwer, miling, that he might not put them off, nor pas away the night in any other poture, and told him, ince he eem'd not to know o much, that it was the life of
married women, and that to fail in the obervance thereof was a very great in. The crafty Cordu • e had all the trouble in the world to undeceive her, and to peruade her that he was abus'd, and that the Life of married perons was quite another thing.

At lat he prevail'd with her o far as that he was content he hould diarm her, and to learn of him another way of exerciing Marriage much more commodious and pleaant than that which her Husband made her practie, which Laura acknowledg'd to be very inconvenient and weariome. He was not loathful in diarming her, he help'd alo to undres her, as not finding her ready enough at it, and having oon put off his own Cloaths he laid himelf by her, and made her confes there was a vat difference between his Precepts of Marriage and thoe her Husband had given her; he read her all the Lectures he could upon that ubject, and he was o far apprehenive of hi • intructions, as that he grew not weary of learning, plying it very hard as long as her Husband continu'd at the Court. At lat he receiv'd a Letter from him, which acquainted her that he was upon his return, and that he had dipatch'd his buines at Court, and the Corduba-blade having alo dipatch'd his at Granada, the crafty Companion return'd home, without o much as taking his leave of Laura, and I think without the leat regret for the los of her company, nothing being o frail as the Love a Man hath for a Woman that's little better than a natural Fool.

Nor was Laura on the other ide les indifferent, but receiv'd her Husband with o much atisfaction,
and betray'd o little reentment for the los of her Gallant, as if he had never een him. Don Pedro and his Wife upp'd together to the great atisfaction of both. Bed-time came on. Don Pedro went into Bed as he was wont to do, and was much atonih'd to ee his Wife in her Smock coming to ly down by him. He ask'd her in a great fury, why he was not in Armour? So I hould indeed, aid he to him, had not another Husband taught me a more pleaant way for a Woman to pas away the Night with her Huband. It eems then you have another Husband, replies Don Pedro? Yea, that I have, ays he to him, o pretty a man, and o handome, that you will be ravih'd to ee him; and yet I know nor when we hall ee him, for ince I receiv'd the lat Letter you ent, I could never et Eyes on him.

p.U:
mothering the trouble of his thoughts, ask'd her, Who it was? She could not give any further account concerning him, but in requital proffer'd Don Pedro to hew him what the other Husband had taught her. The unhappy man pretended himelf ick, and it's not unlikely he was o, at leat in his mind. He thereupon turn'd from her, and bethinking himelf that he had made choice of an Idiot to his Wife, who had not onely done what blemih'd his Reputation, but thought her elf not oblig'd to conceal it, he call'd to mind the wholeome advice of the Dutches, who no doubt would have been pleas'd with the account of this lat Adventure of his. He thereupon deteted his Error, and was atisfied, though too late; That a virtuous and dicreet Woman knows how to oberve
the Laws of Honour; and if, out of frailty, he chance to break them, that he can conceal her micarriage.

div.p: At lat, taking heart, he reolv'd to ubmit with patience to a misfortune that was not to be remedied. He continued for a time his pretence of being indipoed, to ee whether the Lectures of his Lieutenant had done any thing beides reaching his Wife what he had done better to have taught her himelf. They lived together ome years afterwards; he had always an eye over her Actions, and, before he died, (having had no Children by her) he left her his whole Etate, upon condition he would become a Nun, and go into the ame Convent where Seraphina was, whom he acquainted that Laura was her Daughter. He writ to Madrid, to his Couin Don Rodrigues, and ent him the Hitory of his Life and Adventures, and acknowledged that his embracing of o erroneous an opinion had reduced him to that misfortune which he feared mot of any, and againt which he thought he had ued the greatet precaution.

He died; Laura was neither troubled at it, not glad of it; he went into the Nunnery where her Mother was, who finding the Etate left by Don Pedro to her Daughter to be very great, founded a Convent, and became the firt Abbes of it. The Hitory of Don Pedro was divulged after his death, and erved to atisfie thoe that made any doubt of it. That, without wit, Virtue cannot be perfect; That a witty Woman may be Virtuous of her elf; And that a imple Woman cannot be uch, without the aistance and good directions of ome other.

div.head: THE HYPOCRITES.
The Second Novel.
div.p:
THE mot delightful eaon of the year was putting the Fields and Trees into a verdant Livery, when a certain Woman came into Toledo; a City, which, as well for its antiquity, as its eminence, takes place of any in Spain. The woman was handome, young, ubtil, and uch a profes'd enemy to Truth, that for whole years together, that Vertue came not o much as once into her mouth, and what is yet much more to be admir'd, is, that Truth was never the wore for't, at leat never complain'd of it. She had either the artifice, or the good fortune to be ever very uccesful in her lies; and there is not any thing
more certain, than that a fiction of her dreing hath ometimes met with approbation of the everet enemies of Falhood. This was a S ••• nce he was o great a profeor in, as that her Dictates would have furnih'd the bet cutom'd Atrolog • rs, the Poets, and the Mountebanks: in a word, this natural endowment was uch in her, that the conjunction of it with the beauty of her countenance, in a hort time, got her pieces of Gold anwerably to her ininuations and the crafty deigns he carried on. Her eyes were black, weet, prightly, full of gallantry, and yet unmerciful Hectors, that had been convicted of four or five murthers, and tood charg'd with the upition of above fifty, which could not be fully prov'd againt them; but as for the unfortunate wretches whom they had wounded, it is hard to ghes, nay indeed to imagine, the number of them. For matter of dreing, he had an excellency and happines in it beyond any of her ex, inomuch that the leat pin faten'd by her hand wanted not its particular grace. For what epecially related to her head, he never troubled any for either advice or aitance; as making her Looking-glas, at the ame time, her Councel of State, her Councel of War, and her Exchequer. How fatal mut it be for any man to ee uch a Woman! ince that if he aw her, he could not forbear falling in love with her, and if he lov'd her he could not do it long, and be withal long without trouble.

This Lady, accomplih'd as I have decrib'd her, came into Toledo jut in the cloe of the evening, much about the time that all the young Gentlemen of quality in the City were preparing for a
Mask to be repreented at the Nuptial olemnity of a trange Lord, who was to be married to a Lady of one of the bet Families in the Country. The Windows were become a kind of Firmament, by reaon of the Torches which were placed in them, but much more in repect of the Ladies who look'd out at them; the great number of lights having retor'd to the treets that day which the night had depriv'd them of. The Ladies of meaner quality clad in their mantles, dicover'd to thoe who beheld them, no more than what they thought mot worth the looking on. Many Bravoes, or rather (to ue the modern word) Trapanners, Blades, and Hectors, were hunting after ome prize, a ort of people that great Cities ever were and will be peter'd with, who trouble themelves not much whether their good fortunes be real, provided they be thought uch, or at leat doubted of; who never et upon any, but in coniderable numbers, and that with inolence enough; and who, upon their good faces and a hort hanger within their breeches, aume to themelves a juridiction over the lives of others, and think to make all the women die for love, and the men for fear. O what work would this day have found the oft-headed Complementers and Cajollers of Woman-kind, and what low and pitiful equivocations were there us'd!

But among the ret, a young man, who, of a Schollar, was not long before turn'd Page, was o prodigal of his Rhetorical fooleries before our Lady errant, as if he had thought beyond all language to expres how highly he admir'd her. He had een her alight out of the Hackney Coach that
brought her, and was o dazled at the ight of her, that, not content with that, he had follow'd her to the houe where he had taken a chamber, and thence up and down to all thoe places whither he went out of a deire to ee omething. At lat the trange Lady, having eated her elf in a place he thought convenient to ee the Maskers go by, the eloquent Page, dres'd that day all in linnen, much finer than ordinary, had oon fatned on ome dicoure with her, he being not the firt man he had ever een. Of all the women in the world, he had the bet faculty to engage a young conceited fool upon many impertinencies, and that with the greatet ininuation and mot unupected malice that could be. Imagine then, if finding this Page a Talker beyond all confidence, whether he engag'd him not to peak much more than he knew. She beotted him with flatteries and commendations, and afterwards did what he would with him. She learn'd of him, that he erv'd an old Gentleman of Andaluzia, Uncle to him who was upon marriage, and upon whoe account the whole City was in olemnity; that he was one of the wealthiet men there of his quality; and that he h • d not any to make his heir but that Nephew, whom he had a great tendernes for, though he were one of the mot diolute young men in all Spain, one that fell in love with all the women he aw, and, beides the common Slugs, and uch as he could command upon the account of his Gallantry or his Preents, had ometimes exercis'd his atyrical violences upon Maids, without any regard of their qualities and conditions. To this he added, that his riots and extravagances had made
him a dear Nephew to his Uncle, and out of that reflection was he the more inclin'd to ee him married, to try, if upon a change of his condition there would enue a change of manners.

While the Page was revealing all the ecrets and concernments of his Mater to her, he till by her oothing and admiring interruptions egg'd him on to further di • coveries, making her remarks to thoe of her company, with what grace and pleaingnes he poke handome things: and, in fine, omitting nothing that might contribute ought to the undoing of a young man, who had already conceiv'd but too good an opinion of himelf. Commendations and applaues coming from a handome woman that hath ome deign in it, are dangerous and much to be fear'd. The poor Page had no ooner acquainted Helenilla that he was born at Vailladolid, but he preently breaks forth into praies of th • t City and the Inhabitants of it, inomuch that having run her elf out of breath in the commendations of them, even to hyperboles, he told the befool'd Page, that of all he had known of that Country, he had not een any o handome and accomplih'd as himelf. After this lat touch of her flattery there needed no more to make an abolute fool of him. She invited him to ee her at her lodging, and it is not to be quetion'd, whether he gave him her hand rather than any other. He felt in himelf uch agitations of joy, as made him ever and anon do uch thing • as ome would have thought him a little crack-brain'd, and he was fully atisfi'd, that a man hould never depair of a good fortune how mierable oever he were.

The Lady being come to her chamber caus'd the bet Chair to be preented to the Page. He was o beotted with his imaginary happines, that going to it down before he had well look'd about him, he fell hort of the Chair, his britch took acquaintance with the ground, he catter'd his cloak, hat, and gloves about the room, and had like to have fallen upon a dagger he had, which in his fall got out of the heath. Helenilla run to help him up, making as much tir as a Tygres robb'd of her young ones: She took up the dagger, and told him, that he could not endure he hould wear it any more that day, after the michief it was like to have done him. The Page got up all he had let fall, and made many pitiful complements utable to the occaion and the accident.

In the mean time, Helenilla made as if he could not recover her elf out of the fright he had been put into, and began to admire the neatnes of the dagger. The Page told her it came from his old Mater, who had ometimes given it to his Nephew, together with a word and all things belonging thereto, and that he had made choice of it that day before many others that were in his Mater's wardrobe, to wear upon ome extraordinary occaion. Helenilla propos'd to the Page whether he might not go diguis'd to ee after what manner perons of quality were married at Toledo. The Page told her, the ceremony would not be till midnight, and invited her to a Collation in the Steward's chamber, who was very much his friend. He thereupon took occaion to cure his misfortune, and that he was oblig'd to exchange the mot pleaant company in the world for that
of his old Mater, whom the indipoition incident to age confin'd to his bed. He added that being extremely troubled with the Gout he would not be at the wedding, which was kept at a houe in the City far from that of the Count of Fuen • alide where the old Marques his Mater liv'd. Being upon taking his leave, he was pumping for ome handome complement, when ome body knock'd at the door in as much hate as if they had come for a Midwife. Helenilla eem'd a little troubled thereat, and deit'd the Page to go into a little cloet, where he lock'd him up for a longer time than he thought of. He who knock'd o confidently at the door was a Gallant of Helenilla's, who to blind the world he made people believe was her Brother. He was privy to all her leudnees, and the ordinary intrument of her leighter pleaures. She immediately gave him an account of the Page who was lock'd up in the cloet, and the deign he had conceiv'd within her elf to queeze ome pieces of Gold out of his old Mater, uch a deign as whereof the execution requir'd no les diligence than ubtilty.

Having reolv'd how all things hould be carried, the Coach-man was call'd and order'd with all expedition to make ready his Coach, though the poor Beats which had brought them thither from Madrid were ufficiently tir'd. All being in readines, Helenilla and her retinue (which conited of the dreadful Montufar, an old woman called Mendez, venerable for a weighty pair of Beads, and a Matronlike carriage and countenance, and a little pigmey of a Lacquey) embark'd themelves in that hatter'd Veel, and gave command
to drive into the treet, where live the Modern Chritians, whoe Faith is of a newer fahion than the cloaths they ell. The Maskers were till about the treets, inomuch that it happen'd the Bride-groom, diguis'd as the ret, met the Coach wherein Helenilla was, and aw that dangerous Stranger, who eem'd to him a Venus in triumph or, to peak a little more hyperbolically, the Sun it elf in a Progres. He had uch a temptation to her, that a mall matter would have put all thoughts of his wedding out of his head, to go and endeavour the conquet of that unknown Beauty; but for that time he had o much command of himelf, as that he moothe • 'd a deire violent enough though it were but jut prung in him. He follow'd the Maskers, and the Hackney-Coach kept on its way towards the Brokery, where in a trice, and without two words to the bargain, Helenilla bought her a uit of Mourning from head to foot, and put the old woman Mendez, her Gallant Montufar, and her little Lacquey into the like, and taking Coach again alighted at the houe of the Count of Fuenalide. The little Lacquey went in, enquir'd out the lodgings of the Marques of Villefagnan, and demanded audience of him for a trange Lady come from the Mountains of Leon, who had ome buines with him of great conequence. The good man was much urpriz'd at the viit of uch a Lady, and at uch an uneaonable hour. He etled himelf in the bed the bet he could; order'd his rumpled band, and caus'd to be thrut under his back two cuhions more than he had before, to receive o important a viit with greater ceremony.

This poture was he in, having his Eyes fatened on the Chamber-door, when he perceives, not without the great admitation of his eyes, nor les diturbance of his heart, the diconolate Montufar, in Mourning down to the ground, accompanied by two Women in the ame dres, whereof the younger, whom he led by the hand, and who had ome part of her face covered by a thin Hood, eemed to be the mot ad, and the more coniderable of the two. A Lacquey bore up her Train after her, which had o much tuff in it, as that being held out with advantage, it took up the bet part of the Chamber. As oon as they were come within the Chamber-door, they aluted the old Marques who lay ick a-bed, and gave him a volley of three low reverences, not counting that of the little Lacquey, whoe congey was not worth the remembring. Being come to the midt of the Chamber they made three reverences more, all at the ame time, and afterwards three more ere they took eats, which were brought them by a young Page, Camerade to him whom Helenilla had locked up in her Chamber: but thee three lat reverences were uch, as if the former had been forgotten. The ofter, I mean the kinder, part of the old Man's oul was trangely moved there it; the Ladies ate down, and Montufar and the little Lacquey withdrew, bare-headed, to the Chamber-door.

The old Man all this while put himelf to no mall torment to requite their complements, and was much troubled for their being in Mourning, before he knew the occaion of it, which he intreated them to acquaint him with, as alo upon
what account they honoured him with a viit at a time o uneaonable for perons of their quality. Helenilla, who but too well knew, what compaion a weeping Beauty raies in the beholders, opens the luces of her fair eyes to let out the tears they eemed to be burdened with, and accompanied them with ighs ometimes loud, ometimes low, as he thought fit, taking occaion ever and anon to put out her Ivory hand to wipe her face, which he alo thought it not amis to dicover, to hew it was as troubled, as beautiful.

The old Man expected with much impatience that he hould peak, and began to conceive ome hopes of it; for the torrent of tears which had broke forth at her eyes, was already o far fallen and dried up, that the Lillies and Roes it had oreflown were to be een, when the old Mendez, who thought it became her to go on with the doleful part where the other had left, beet her elf to weep and ob with o much earnetnes, that it was ome hame to Helenilla to be out-done by a thing that eemed not to have o much moiture in her as the tears he pilt amounted to. Nay, the old Woman thought not that enough, but to have the advantage of Helenilla, beyond all dipute, he conceived a handful or two of hair might do well, and prevail much upon the Auditory. No ooner thought than done; he made a fearful devatation upon her head; but the troth on't is, he poiled nothing of her own, nor medled with o much as a hair that ever grew there.

Helenilla and Mendez were lamenting in this manner, as if it had been upon a wager, when Montufar and the Lacquey, upon a ignal agreed
betwixt them, were heard at the Chamber-door ighing and weeping, though not o violently as thoe by the Bed-ide, who yet upon that new Conort, took occaion to renew their Lamentations. The old Marques was out of himelf to ee o much weeping, and not know the occaion of it. He wept too, as well as he could make a hift to do it; obb'd as vigorouly as any in the company, and intreated the ditreed Ladies, for Heaven's ake, and all in it, to moderate their affliction, and to acquaint him with the occaion thereof, auring them his life hould be the leat thing he would hazard and acrifice to erve them, and regretting his pat youth, as being now uncapable to give them effectual demontrations of the incerity of his good intentions.

They were a little appeaed at thee words, their countenances appear'd more pleaant, and they thought they had wept enough, becaue they could not, without ome violence to themelves, weep any more. Beides, they were thrifty of their time, as knowing they had not any to loe. So that the old Woman uncovering her Head, to the end her venerable and Matron-like countenance might give her all the credit he tood in need of, began her declamation in this manner. May it pleae God, out of his omnipotence, to preerve the Right Honourable the Marques of Ville-fagnan, and afford him all the Health he tands in need of; though, to ay truth, what we come to acquaint him withal be uch news, as from which he will derive but little joy, which is indeed the flower of Health: but the misfortune of our misfortune is uch, that we mut communicate it to
others. The Marques gave himelf a thump on the breat with his fit, which at the ame time dicharged it elf of a deep igh: May it be the pleaure of Heaven that I am mitaken, cries he, but I fear me, this is ome new pranck, or rather ome extravagance of my Nephew's, that I am like to hear of. Go on, Madam, go on, and pardon me for interrupting you. The old Woman, intead of making any anwer began to weep afreh, o that Helenilla was forced to go on with the dicoure. Since you know by experience, aid he, that your Nephew is a peron, that, of any man, hath leat command of his paions, and that you have been often troubled to mother the reports of his violences, you will be the more eaily induced to credit that which he hath done me. Being at Leon the lat Spring, whither I conceive you had ent him, he meets with me in a Church, and upon the firt ight told me uch things, as, had they been true, we hould both have continued till in that Church to avoid the Hands of Jutice, I as a Murderes, he as the dead man I had killed and made ready to be put into the ground. He told me a hundred times that my eyes had murder'd him, nay, he omitted not the leat of thoe flatteries and ininuations which are ordinary among Lovers, who would abue their implicity upon whom they have ome deign. He follow'd me to my Lodging, rode every day up and down before my Windows, and every night importuned all the Neighbour-hood with the Muick he intended onely for me. At lat, perceiving that all his amorous addrees prevailed nothing, he with
Preents corrupted a Negro-lave that I had, and, through her treachery and advice, urprized me in a Garden we had in the Suburbs. I had no body with me but the perfidious lave; he had in company with him a man as lewd as himelf, and had given money to the Gardener to go an Errand for him to the other end of the Town, upon pretence of ome important buines. What need I make many words, he et his Dagger to my Throat, and finding nevertheles that I had a greater value for my Honour than my Life, with the aitance of his Complice, he did that by violence, which all his courthip and importunities hould never have obtain'd. The Slave made no mall tir, and the better to diguie her perdiounes, got a leight wound in one of her hands, and preently after fell into a feigned wound. The Gardener returns: Your Nephew frightned at the thought of his crime got away over the Garden-wall, with o much precipitation that he let fall his Dagger, which I took up. Yet needed not the inolent young man have been in uch fear; for being not in a capacity to caue him to be taid, I might have had that command of my elf as to put a good countenance on it, and diemble the horrid misfortune that had happened to me. I did what I could, not to appear more ad than I was wont to do. The wicked lave not long after run quite away. I lot my Mother, and I may ay, I had with her lot all, if my Aunt, who is here come along with me, had not had the goodnes to give me entertainment, which he does o nobly, as that I have the ame treatment with her own two excellent
Daughters. In her houe it was that I heard, your Nephew is o far from thinking of any reparation for the wrong he hath done me, that he is upon Marriage in this City. I have made the greatet hate I could hither, to the end that before I go out of your Chamber, you hould give me in money or jewels two thouand Crowns, to put my elf into a Nunnery: for knowing as much as I do by experience of the dipoition of your Nephew, I could never fancy to marry him, though he and all the Friends he hath hould ue all the proffers and intreaties that may be to perwade me to it. I know he is to be married this night, but I'l break off the match if I can, at leat make a diturbance he hall hear of while he lives, if you do not take that coure to prevent it which I propoe to you. And that you may be atisfi'd, added he, that there cannot be any thing more true, than what I tell you, of the violence your Nephew hath done me, behold the very Dagger he et to my Throat! I wih, God had o pleas'd he had done omewhat more than threatned me with it.

Having given over peaking, he beet her elf to weeping afreh. Mendez kept till a note above her, and the muical conort at the door, whereof the little Lacquey made the treble and Montufar the bae, was no les ambitious to be heard.

The old Marques, who had already given but too much credit to what had been aid to him, by the craftiet of all Woman-kind, no ooner cat his Eye on the Dagger, but he immediately knew it to be the ame he had ometime given his Nephew.
All therefore his thoughts ran upon was to prevent the diturbance which might happen at his Nephew's wedding. He would gladly have ent for him, but he was afraid ome body might be o inquiitive as to ask what hould be the occaion of his o doing; and, as it happens our fears are extraordinary when our deires are uch, he no ooner perceiv'd the afflicted Ladies making as if they would go and break off the match, which it had cot him abundance of trouble to bring to the poture it was in, but he commands one of the Pages to bring a certain Cabinet, and to take out of it two thouand Crowns in pieces of Gold of four Pitols. Montufar receiv'd them, and told them very exactly one after another; whereupon the old Marques, having made them promie to give him a viit the next day, made a thouand excues to the Ladies, that he was not in a condition to wait on them to their Coach. They got into it very well atisfi'd with their viit, and made the Coach-man drive back again towards Madrid, bethinking themelves that if they were puru'd, it would be towards Leon. Their Hotes in the mean time, eeing her guets were vanih'd, goes into the Chamber: She finds the Page in the Cloet, who could not imagine what reaon they had to lock him in there; he uffer'd him to go his ways becaue he knew him, or rather becaue he found all things as hould be in the Chamber. Thoe, who make it their profeion to teal, and think of no other way of livelihood, tand in little fear of God, and therefore are o much the more afraid of Men. They are of all Countries, and yet are not of any, and never have any etled habitation. As oon as they
have et foot in a place, they make their advantages, and then hift into another. This unhappy profeion, which is learnt with o much pains and diligence is different from others: for people quit thoe out of age, or for want of trength; but a man eldome quits that of telling unles it be in his youth, and for want of longer life. It mut needs be that thoe, who follow it o cloely, find a trange pleaure in it, ince, for that, they hazard a great number of years, which, ooner or later, the Executioner cuts them hort of.

But alas! Helenilla, Mendez, and Montufar, were little troubled with uch reflections as thee their thoughts were wholly et upon the cruel fear they were in of being puru'd. They gave the Coach-man double the rate he demanded, that he might make the greater hate; which he honetly did, anwerably to his hire; o that it may be imagin'd that never did hackney Coach make uch peed upon the Road to Madrid. They had no inclination to leep, though the night were far pent Montufar was much troubled in mind, and, by his frequent ighing, dicover'd more remore than atisfaction. Helenilla, who aw into his very thoughts, would needs divert him with a relation of the particulars of her life, which till then he had kept from him as a great ecret. Since I ee thou art omewhat out of order, aid he to him, I will now atisfie the deire thou hat ever had to know who I am, and to be inform'd of the Adventures that happen'd to me before our acquaintance. 'Twere eaie for me to tell the • that I am well decended, and give my elf an illutrious name, as mot do: but I will oberve
that incerity towards thee, as that I will dicover to thee even the mot inconiderable imperfections of thoe that brought me into the world.

p.q:
Thou art then to know, that my Father was born in Galicia, by profeion a Lacquey, or, to peak more honourably of him, a Serving-man. He had a great veneration for the memory of the Patriarch Noah, for his excellent invention of the Vine, and indeed, abating the inclination he had to the juice of that noble Plant, it may be aid of him, that he car'd not much for the temporal goods of this world. My Mother was of Granada, by condition, (to be free with you) a Slave: but there's no conteting with the Stars. She anwer'd to the name of Mary, which her Maters had given her, and it was indeed the name he receiv'd at her Baptim, but he would have taken it more kindly if one call'd her Zara, which was her name before he was converted from the Turkih Religion; for (ince I mut tell you all) he was a Chritian onely out of compliance, and conformity, but in heart a Moor. Yet would he often go to Confeion, but rather to dicover the ins of her Maters, than her own; and whereas he entertain'd her Confeor much more with the hardhips and inconveniences of her Services, than her own imperfections, and made him believe miracles of her patience; He, being a very holy man, and meauring others by himelf, took all for true that he aid, and, intead of reproving, commended her, o that who hould have been near my Mother at Confeion, would have
heard nothing but commendations of all ides. You are haply deirous to know how I came to dicover o great a ecret, and you may well think, I have it not from my Mother; but I am naturally much inclin'd to pry into things, and young as I was, my Mother never went to Confeion but I got as near her as I could to overhear what he aid. Though he were warthy, or rather black, yet was there in her countenance and making, omewhat that was not unhandome, and above ix Knights, Commanders of white and red Croes, have courted her favour. She was o charitable, that he divided amongt them all, what was o much deir'd by every one in particular, and he was of a nature o full of acknowledgment towards her Maters, that, to requite, in ome meaure, the trouble they had been at in her education from her infancy, he did all that lay in her power to bring them every year a little Slave male or female; but Heaven was not pleas'd to further her good intentions, for all the little half-Negroes died preently after they were born. She was much more fortunate in bringing up the children of others. Her Maters, who lot all their own as oon as they came into the world, made her Nure to a Child given over by the Phyicians, who yet in a hort time, through my Mother's tendernes of it, and the goodnes of her Milk, dicover'd igns of perfect health, and hopes of a long life. In requital of this ervice, my Mother's Mitres g • ve her her liberty when he died. My Mother is now a free-woman; he turns Laundres, and proves o excellent at it, that in a
hort time, there was not a Courtier in Madrid who thought his Linnen well done unles it came from the Turkih Laundres. Now had he leiure and opportunities to put in practice the Lectures which her Mother had ometime read to her, about a familiarity with the people of the other world. She had deited from that tempting Profeion, more out of modety, and as wearied with the commendations people gave her of being excellent in her Art, than out of any fear of the Magitrate. But now he made it her principal Employment, onely to oblige and pleaure her Friends, and in a hort time, he made uch coniderable acquaintances, and rais'd her elf to uch credit in the Court of Darknes, that to be a Devil of any reputation there was a neceity of holding a correpondence with her. I peak not this out of any vanity, for I never tell a Lye, added Helenilla, and would not give my Mother the commendations of thoe excellencies which were not in her; but indeed I could do no les than give this tetimony to her virtue. The ecrets he old, thoe he reveal'd, and her Oracular faculty in anwering quetions (for all which he was pointed at as he went along the Streets) were but ordinary talents among thoe of her Nation, in comparion of her experience in the buines of Maiden-heads. A crack'd Wench, after he had been under her hands, went for a better Maid than he was before the Micarriage, and her Maiden-head old at a higher rate the econd time than the firt. She might be about forty years of age when he was married to my Father, honet Rodrigues.
'Twas the wonder of the whole Quarter, that a Man who lov'd Wine o well would take a Woman that drunk not any, as oberving the Law of Mahomet, and one that had her hands perpetually in the Water, as being a Laundres: but my Father made anwer, There would be the more Wine for himelf, and that Love made all things pleaant. Not long after, he made a hift to get her with child, and, when the time came, he was brought to bed of Me. This joy continu'd not long in our houe. For when I was about ix years old, a certain Prince would needs put a hundred Lacqueys into Liveries to run down a m • d Bull. My Father being one of thoe that were made choice of, he drunk that day without any dicretion, and going in the valour of his drink to oppoe the paage of the furious Bull, he was by him tos'd into everal pieces. I remember there were Songs made of him, and that it was aid upon occaion of my Father's death, that no body car'd for thoe of his Profeion. It was a good while after ere I apprehended it to be a jear put upon him, as if he wore Horns as well as the Bull; but ill tongues will be wagging, nay, to forbid people to be abuive would but make them the more uch. My Mother was griev'd at my Father's death, I alo was griev'd at it; he took heart and forgot it, I did the like. Not long after, my Beauty began to make people talk of me. There was no mall emulation at Madrid, who hould take me abroad in a Coach, c • rry me to Plays, and entertain me with Coll • tions upon the Banks of the Maanares. My
Mother was as watchful over me as an Argus, which I took very heinouly; but it was not long, ere I was convinc'd it was for my advantage. Her everity, and the high rate he et on me, made the commodity the more valuable, and rais'd an emulation among thoe whoe teeth water'd at me. I was to be his that bid mot; yet every one thought he had had me before his Rival; and every one imagin'd he found that which was gone long before. A rich Geneva Merchant, whoe addrees were onely in private, dazled my prudent Mother's eyes with o much Gold, and dicover'd o much incerity in his procedure, that he anwer'd his good intentions as he expected. He had the precedency of all others in my favour, but it cot him dearly. There was a faithfulnes oberv'd towards him, as long as he was ditrutful of us; but as oon as he eem'd peruaded of our faith, we immediately broke it. My Mother had too great a ympathy for the ufferings of others not to be mov'd at the continual complaints of my Gallants, all perons of quality about the Court, and all very rich. 'Tis true, they quander'd not their Gold away as my Geneva man did; but my Mother knew how to eteem gre • t gains, and yet lighted not the mall; beides, he was very obliging out of a principle rather of charity than interet. The Geneva Blade broke, I know not whether we were the caue of it. There happen'd to be ome quarrels upon my account; the Magitrates viited us, rather out of civility than otherwie: but my Mother indeed had an averion
for young Lawyers and Scholars, and hated no les the Hectors and elf-conceited Gallantillo's, who began to haunt us. She therefore thought it her bet coure to remove to Sevil, made money of all her Goods, and took a return'd Hackney Coach for her elf and me. We were baely betray'd by the Coach-man, robb'd of all we had, and my Mother o unmercifully beaten, becaue he would not over-readily part with what he had, but oppos'd the Villains as much as her trength would permit, that before we could get to a wretched Inn he fairly died at the foot of a Rock. I pluck'd up a good heart, though I were yet but very young. I felt all about the folds of my Mother's cloaths; but there was nothing to be expected after the exact Searchers that had been there before me. I left her to the mercy of thoe that pas'd by, not a doubting but that in a great Road, uch as that between Madrid and Sevil, there would come by, ome people o charitable as to betow Burial on her. I return'd back again to Madrid; my Gallants heard of my misfortune, made a contribution to et me up again, o that in a hort time I was got into Cloaths, and a Houe very well furnih'd. About this time was it that I aw thee at a Friend's of mine of the ame Profeion, and was immediately taken with thy good endowments. I need not give thee any further account of my Life, ince that we have ever ince liv'd together. We came to Toledo; we leave it all in hate; and o well furnih'd with Money, that if thou hadt as much courage as I thought thou hadt had,
thou wouldt be more chearful than thou art. And ince the relation I have made to thee hath had the virtue to make thee leepy, as I perceive by thy reiterated yawnings and noddings of the head, lay it in my lap, and take thy ret. But know, that what ever there may be good and profitable in Fear, before the committing of a crime, proves very bae, and very dangerous when it is once committed. Fear ever ditracts the mind of the guilty peron; o that intead of avoiding his puruer, he many times cats himelf into his hands.

div.p: Montufar fell aleep, and the morning broke forth o pleaant and gay, that the birds, the flowers, and the fountains aluted her, each according to their mode; the birds in inging, the flowers in perfuming the air, and the fountains in laughing or making a noie, which you pleae; one's as good as the other.

In the mean time the Marques of Villefagnan's Nephew, the enual Don Sancho, was thinking to get up from his new Bride, much wearied, and haply already cloy'd with the enjoyments of marriage. His imagination was full of the beautiful tranger, the dangerous Helenilla, whom he had een in the Hackney-coach; and repreented her to him wholly admirable: doing thereby a very great injutice to his Wife who was a Lady o handome and o accomplih'd, that there were not a few in Toledo that igh'd for her, while he igh'd to think on the unkindnes of her Husband; and he, fickle Man as he was, wih'd himelf in the embraces of an infamous Strumpet, who communicated her elf for a mall matter to any that had a mind to her. What a
trange irregularity is this of our Appetite! A man that hath a handome wife of his own, hath a greater inclination to one of his maids. A Noble man, who hath his Table ordinarily furnih'd with Biques and Pheaants, looks on them with didain, and calls for a mes of Broath, and the plain Piece of Beef provided for the Servants. Mot People are deprav'd in their tate as to many things, and your great Lords more than any. For having greater Etates than they know what to do withall, and being inclin'd till to eek after what they have not, they are drawn in, to do that which is evil, purely out of diverion: and, to compas their enjoyments, they care not much what pains they are at, nor what time and money they pend, nor think it much to be guilty of bae importunities to ome cornful Wench to obtain that of her, which he ometimes betows on others without o much as being intreated to do it.

All this happens through the jut permiion of Heaven, to punih Men's inclinations to evil by the very inconveniences of the evil. Ah unfortunate Don Sancho! Heaven hath been pleas'd to bles thee with thoe two things, which, of ought this world affords, can mot contribute to thy felicity, wealth in abundance, and a lovely peron to thy wife; wealth, to upply thoe who deerve, yet have it not; and, becaue they have it not, are many times engag'd in thoe unworthy coures to which poverty reduces the mot generous pirits: and a wife, equal to thee as to quality and etate, accomplih'd as to both mind and body, beautiful even in thy eyes, and much more in thoe of others, who ee more clearly in the affairs of other people than
they do in their own, and, in a word, reerv'd, modet, and virtuous. What dot thou look for abroad? Hat thou not in thy own houe thy econd elf, a Woman, whoe ingenious converation will delight thee, whoe body is abolutely at thy devotion, who is tender of thy honour, careful in manageing thy houe, prudent to improve thy etate, furnihes thee with Children, who divert thee in their youth, and will relieve thee in thy age? What, I ay, cant thou look for abroad? I'l tell thee in few words, what will be thy fortune; thou wilt ruine thy elf, both as to etate and reputation, thou wilt loe the repect of thy friends, and wilt raie thy elf many powerful enemies. Dot thou think thy honour ecure becaue thou hat a virtuous woman to thy wife? Alas! what little experience hat thou of the things of this world, and how little reflect on humane frailty? The uret hore of his feet in the world, and the mot at command, lips under an unskilful Rider, and haply gives him a fall. A woman may reit uch and uch a temptation to do omething that's unhandome; and haply trangres in the highet degree, when he thinks her elf mot ecure. One micarriage is a trap-door to let in everal others after it; and the ditance which is between Vertue and Vice, is ometimes but a hort day's journey.

But to what end are we troubled with all thee moral truths, and of what benefit are they, will ome body ay? And why does that ome body trouble his head o much? let him make ue of them or let them alone, as his convenience hall advie him, however, he may think himelf
oblig'd to the peron who gives them for nothing.

Don Sancho was thinking to get up from his wife, when his Uncle's teward brought him a Letter, giving him an account of the trange Lady, who he could not but think had trapann'd him, becaue he was not to be heard of in any of the Inns about Toledo, where he had caus'd inquiry to be made after her, and in the ame Letter intreating him to let him have one of his men to end after the Slut towards Madrid, which way he thought he might be gone, for that he had ent people to all the other great Roads that went to the Towns about Toledo, that onely to Madrid excepted. Don Sancho was out of all patience at this news: he found himelf aaulted in that part of his oul which was leat able to reit, and was elevated to a trange heighth, to find himelf unjutly charg'd with one weaknes, though he had been convicted of many. The los of the mony, and the cheat put upon his Uncle, he was equally enraged at. He made a relation of the buines to his wife, and ome of his kindred, who were come to viit him the next morning after his marriage; and periting in the reolution he had taken to do what he intended, notwithtanding the intreaties of his wife and friends, he lips on his cloaths, eats omething, then runs to his Uncle's, and thence after he had learn'd of the Page who had brought the Ladies into the old Marques's chamber, what kind of Coach they were in, how many in company, and by what marks they might be known, he took pot for Madrid, attended by two ervants, in whoe courage he repos'd much confidence.
He rode on four or five Stages with o much peed, that he had not the leat thought of the beautiful tranger: but his choler being a little evaporated by o violent agitation of his body, Helenilla reaumed her former place in his imagination, o beautiful, and attractive, that he was everal times in a mind to return to Toledo, to find her out. He was a hundred times angry with himelf that he had been o far tranported upon the trick put upon his Uncle, and often call'd himelf an undicreet peron, and an enemy to his own enjoyments, for bruiing his body in that manner by riding pote, intead of betowing his time better in eeking after a happines, the poeion whereof would, in his opinion, raie him to the highet pitch of felicity.

While he was in his amorous reflections, he often poke to himelf, as one ditracted, and that o loud, that his ervants, who were a pretty ditance before him, making a udden top, would turn about, and in much hate ride back to know what he would have. What reaon is there, would he cry ometimes, I hould leave the place where I aw her? Mut I not be the mot unhappy man in the world, if this Stranger have left Toledo before I get back again thither? 'Twere no more than my deert, for offering to turn Contable, and running with a Hue and Cry after I know not whom. But if I return to Tol • do, continu'd he, without doing any thing, what will they ay of me, who would have diverted me from uch an enterprize? Or mut I let a ort of trapanning Rogues go unpunih'd, after uch an unheard of affront put upon my
Uncle, and my own reputation o treacherouly wounded.

The diolute young Spark was thus ballancing of things, when, coming near Xetaffa, his ervants dicover'd Helenilla's Coach by the marks that had been given thereof. They preently cri'd out to their Mater, that they had taken the Thieves, and not taying till he came up to them, rode full peed after the Coach with their words drawn. The Coach-man topp'd extremely frightned; Montufar was no les. Helenilla caus'd him to remove out of the Boot, and ate there her elf, to ee what might be done to remedy o great a misfortune. She aw Don Sancho coming towards her with his word drawn, and could perceive nothing in his countenance whence he might promie her elf any favour: but the amorous Gentleman had no ooner faten'd his eyes on her who had already o deeply wounded him, but he was immediately peruaded that his ervants were mitaken: For it is natural for a man to have a good opinion of what he loves, and thereupon, as if he had known Helenilla from his infancy for a Lady not to be charg'd with any thing unhandome, he run upon his ervants triking at them as hard as he could with the flat of his word. You Racals, aid he to them, have I not given you ufficient warning to take heed you were not mitaken? and do you not deerve I hould break your arms and legs for o unmannerly topping a Ladie's Coach whoe very preence might have forc'd you to more repect? The poor Slaves, who had not been o forward but upon the marks given them by the Page, and aw they
had to do with a woman extremely handome, an object that raies ubmiions and repects in the mot unciviliz'd ouls, avoided, by getting out of the way, the fury of their Mater, and thought he had reaon to be angry, and that it was an exces of his kindnes that he had not ufficiently loaded them with blows.

Don Sancho, having thus diengag'd his ervants, crav'd pardon of Helenilla, and told her upon what ground his preumptuous ervants were like to have done her ome violence, which he knew as well as himelf. He intreated her to conider how apt a peron blinded with choler is to be mitaken. Do but ee, I beeech you, aid he, into what inconveniences ervants may engage their Maters? Had I not been with thee Villains that came along with me, they had upon very uncertain appearances put the whole Country into an Allarm, and having the power in their own hands, would have brought you to Toledo, as a Thief. Not indeed but that you are uch, added he, compoing himelf to mildnes, but the Robberies you are guilty of are rather thoe of hearts than any thing ele. Helenilla acknowledg'd the indulgence of Heaven towards her, in betowing on her a face which pleaded her exemption from punihment, notwithtanding the many leudnees he was ordinarily guilty of, and auming a confidence which banih'd the fear he had been in, he anwer'd Don Sancho with much modety and in few words, as knowing that for one to be over-earnet in diclaiming a thing laid to his charge increaes the upicion of his guilt. Don Sancho could not
but admire he hould meet with what he ought, after o trange a manner; and, beotted as he was, thought Heaven proper'd his deigns, ince it had prevented him from returning to Toledo, as he had everal times thought to have done: which no doubt had been to avoid that good which he ought after with o much earnetnes. He ask'd Helenilla her name, and the place of her abode at Madrid, and intreated her not to take it amis if he waited on her thither, to confirm the proffers he had made her of his ervices. Helenilla gave him uch an account of both as he was for the pr •
ent atisfi'd with, and told him he hould think her elf very happy to receive his viits. He proffer'd to wait on her all along the way, but he would by no means permit it, repreenting to him that he was married, and that her Husband was to meet her in a Coach, and whiper'd him in the ear, that he was omewhat ditrutful of her own ervants, but above all tood in fear of the dipleaure of her Husband.

This light expreion of confidence rais'd in Don Sancho an imagination that he had ome kindnes for him. He took leave of her, and, carryed more upon his own hopes than the Pot-hore he had under him, (if I may o ay) he et forward towards Madrid. He was no ooner arriv'd but he made enquiry after Helenilla and her habitation, according to the directions he had given him. His ervants were tir'd to find her out, and the endeavours of his friends were not par'd, yet all to no purpoe. Helenilla, Montufar, and the venerable Mendez, were no ooner got to Madrid but they were thinking which
way to get out of it. They were enible they could not avoid the Cavalier of Toledo, if they taid there, and that if they gave him a more particular account of their perons and quality, they hould find him as dangerous an Enemy, as they thought him then their paionate Servant. Helenilla put all the goods he had into a ure hand, and the very next day after her arrival, putting her elf and her train into the habit of Pilgrims, he took her way towards Burgos, the place where Mendez was born, and where he had till a iter living, of the ame profeion with her elf.

In the mean time, Don Sancho out of all hopes of meeting with Helenilla, returns to Toledo, with o much hame and confuion, that from his departure out of Madrid till he came to his own houe, he was not heard to peak one word. After he had aluted his wife, who entertain'd him with thouands of carees and kindnees, he gave him ome Letters from his Brother, wherein he found that he lay very ick at one of the chiefet Cities of Spain, where he poes'd the greatet dignities of the Cathedral Church, and was one of the richet Clergy-men in that Country. He tai'd but one night at Toledo, and the next morning took Pote, to go and ee his Brother recover'd, or poes himelf of what he left if he di'd.

While Don Sancho is upon his way to his Brother, Helenilla is upon hers to Burgos, having conceiv'd a diatisfaction of Montufar greater than the love he had ometimes born him. He had expres'd o little reolution, when Don Sancho and his ervants topp'd the Coach, that he made
no doubt but he was an arrant coward. Out of this reflection was he become o odious to her, that it was with ome violence to her elf that he could endure the ight of him, inomuch that her thoughts were wholly taken up to find out ome way to be rid of this dometick Tyrant: and till it were done comforted her elf with the hope of eeing her elf ere long at liberty and her own dipoal.
