This advice was given her by Mendez, which prevail'd the more upon her, for that it was fortifi'd with all the reaons which her prudence could ugget. She could not endure, that in a houe, where he was to live, there hould be any Montufar to command her, who hould have the Mitres of it, at his devotion; and, not doing any thing towards it, pend what they both had much ado to get. She perpetually repreented to Helenilla the wretchednes of her condition, comparing it to that of the Slaves emploi'd in the Mines, who to enrich their Maters with the Gold which they take o much pains to force out of the earth, and intead of being better treated for their endeavours, are many times rewarded with blows. She would be always telling her, that Beauty is a flower, and conequently of no long continuance, and that her Looking-glas, which then repreented to her but what was mot amiable, and ever poke to her advantage, would oon, entertain her with objects he hould be little atisfi'd with, and tell her uch news as he hould not be well pleas'd at. Aure your elf, Madam, aid he to her, that a woman once turn'd of thirty, loes omething particular of beauty every ix months, and makes new dicoveries every day,
either in her body or face, of ome pot, or ome wrinckle. 'Tis the malice of Time to make young Women old, and to make old Women wrinkled. If a Woman that's grown rich, at the cot of her modety and reputation, meets nevertheles with the contempt and reproaches of the world; what horrour mut he needs raie in people, who through want of conduct is reduc'd to both poverty and infamy? upon what ground can he hope to be reliev'd in her miery? If with the wealth you have made a hift to get, by uch coures as are not approv'd of by all the world, you rais'd the fortunes of ome deerving virtuous peron, who would in requital marry you, it were an action acceptable in the ight of God and Men, and the end of your Life would expiate the beginning of it: but to cat your elf away as you do, by being at the dipoal of a Raskal, as lewd as cowardly, one whoe great atchievements conits in the trappanning of Women, who yet are never gain'd by him but with Threats, nor kept but by Tyranny, is, me-thinks, the direct way to bring your elf to the greatet extremities imaginable, and to be the Author of your own ruine.

With thee and the like arguments did the judicious Mendez, who was much better at peaking than doing, endeavour to exaperate Helenilla againt Montufar, whom he till lov'd, though rather becaue he was accutom'd to it than that he could give any reaon for it; as indeed having too long experience of his manners, not to have found out of her elf all the pecious inducements laid down to her by her old Remembrancer. Yet did
they not prove ineffectual. Helenilla took them in very good part, and the more readily for that Mendez advis'd her to things which he her elf would be not a little the better for, if he hould put them in execution; o that perceiving Montufar coming up to them, being to go together to Guadarrama, where they were to dine that day, they put it off to another time to conider of the coure they hould take to be rid of him, o as never to have a ight of him again.

All Dinner-time he eemed to be indipos'd, having no tomach at all to any thing, and as he roe from table, he was taken with a hivering, and not long after with a violent feaver, which tuck cloe to him the ret of that day and all night; and the violence of it being augmented towards the morning, put Helenilla and Mendez into good hope • the feaver would do them a courteie, though 'twere onely to free them from further trouble how to hake him off. Montufar finding himelf o weak as that he was not able to tand, told the Ladies they mut not tir from Guadarrama; that a Phyitian mut be had, what ever it cot; and that all imaginable care hould be taken of him. This was aid with o much imperiounes and authority, as if he had poken to Slaves, and that their Lives and all things ele were abolutely at his dipoal. His Body in the mean time became more and more weak of the Feavour, which had reduc'd him to uch a condition, as that, had it not been for his often calling for drink, he might have been given over for a Dead man.

There was no mall tir about the Inn, that a Confeor was not all this while brought to him,
that he might, as a good Chritian, dicharge his Concience in this world, before he took his journey for the next. At lat, while the Good man was gone for, Helenilla and Mendez, making no doubt but the Feavour would carry him away, came to him, and itting down on both ides of his bed, Helenilla broke her mind to him in thee tearms.

p.q:
If thou hat o much memory left, dearet Montufar, as to remember after what manner thou hat ever liv'd with me, that is, how thou hat behav'd thy elf towards one who had lay'd the greatet obligations imaginable upon thee, as alo towards Mendez, a peron venerable upon the account of her Sex, her Age, and her Virtue, thou wilt not be o fond as to imagine, I hould importune God Almighty for the recovery of thy health: but though I were as deirous of it, as I have reaon to wih thy detruction, yet is there a neceity we poor mortals hould comply with his holy dipoal of us and ours, and that I hould offer up, my elf, what ometime I had mot doated on, and had been mot dear to me. But to deal freely with thee, we begin to be o weary of thy Tyranny, that our eparation was unavoidable, and, if God had not brought things to this pas, we hould have had that conideration of our own happines as to have endeavour'd it otherwie. Thou art going with all expedition to the other world, we envy thee not the good entertainment thou wilt find there: but, hadt thou been ordain'd to make any longer tay here, we hould, to avoid thy inupportable company and behaviour,
have remov'd into ome part of SPAIN, where we hould have thought no more of thee, than if there never had been any uch thing as thou art in the world. Thou think't life weet, but if thou conider well how thou hat liv'd, thou hat much reaon to take thy death kindly, ince Heaven, for reaons unknown to men, ends it thee in a more honourable way than thou hat deerv'd, permitting a Feaver to do that, which the Executioner does to pe • ons les wicked than thou hat been, or Fear to uch white-liver'd cowardly Raskals as thou art. But, my dear Montufar, before our final eparation, peak to me incerely once in thy life. Is it true, that thou didt really expect I hould tay here to look to thee and nure thee up? Alas, uffer not thee vanities to come into thy mind, o near thy death. So little regard have I of thy welfare, that were it to retore thy whole Race, I would not tay a quarter of an hour here. Make friends, and get into the Hopital, if thy Dieae do not dipatch thee the ooner; and ince all the advice I ever gave thee hath been for thy good, do not light the lat I am like to give thee. 'Tis this, my poor Montufar; Not to trouble thy elf to end for any Phyician, as knowing, he will forbid thee the drinking of Wine, which, without any Feaver, is enough to make an end of thee in four and twenty hours.

div.p:
While Helenilla was making this Funeral Sermon to her once much beloved Montufar, the charitable Mendez ever and anon felt his Pule, and laid her hand on his forehead; and perceiving
her Mitres had given over peaking, he would needs alo give him a departing Lecture. Your Lordhip's head, aid he to him, burns extremely, and I am much in fear this unhappy accident will be the occaion of your marching off to ee your friends in the other world, without affording you the time to come to your elf again. Take therefore this pair of Beads, added he, and fall devoutly to your prayers till uch time as the Confeour comes. You will be o far in your way as to the dicharge of your Concience. But if credit may be given to the Hitoriographers of the Prion for Malefactors at Madrid, who have o often had occaion to pend their Pens in etting down your atchievements, your Lordhip's exemplary life may well exempt you from much Penance; beides that, God, who is very merciful, will no doubt put to your account in Heaven, the glorious progres you made bare-houlder'd through the principal Streets of Sevil, in the ight of o many people, and guarded by Beadles, and other Officers of the Garrion of common Rogues, Cut-pures, and Houe-breakers. You may alo produce as an acquittance for your further dicharge, the Voyage you made by Sea, during which, viz. for the pace of ix years, you did many things not unpleaing to God, taking much pains, eating little, and being till in danger, and conequently the more devout; but what is more coniderable, is, that you were hardly twenty years of age, when, to the great edification of your Neighbour you began that holy Pilgrimage. Moreover, it is very probable you will
be well recompens'd in the other world for another thing, which is, your care, that the Women who have had any dependance on you, hould not be idle or want omething to do, making them work, and live, not onely by the labour of their hands, but that of their whole body. To this I may add, that if you dye in your Bed, you will put a pleaant trick upon the Judge of Murcia, who hath olemnly worn, he would entence you to dye upon the Wheel, who expects the atisfaction to ee it; and who mut needs be enrag'd when it hall be told him, that you dy'd of your elf, without the aitance of any third peron. But I trifle away the day here in talking, and never think it is time to et forward on the journey we have a deire to make. Farewell, dear Friend that hath been, receive this lat Hugg as heartily as I betow it on you, for I think we hall never ee one another again. With which words Mendez cating her arms about his neck embrac'd him with o much kindnes, as that, had he us'd a little more, it had tifled him: Helenilla did the like, and with that Complement left the Chamber, and, without calling for any account, oon after, the Inn alo.

Montufar, who was us'd to their Abues, who had alo the faculty to return them as good as they brought, and who fondly imagin'd all they had aid to him, was onely for his diverion, look'd on them as they departed from him, without the leat upition, more inclin'd to conceive they went to give order for his Broths. He oon after, out of pure ecurity, fell into a little Drowines, which held him o long as that the two Gentlewomen
might well be gotten a League or better in their way, before he was perfectly awake. He ask'd the Hotes for them, who told him they were gone abroad, and had given order he hould not be diturb'd, for that he wanted leep very much, having not clos'd his Eyes all the night before.

Upon this account of them, Montufar began to believe, the Ladies had poken to him in good earnet. He wore at uch a rate as would have made ome think the Earth might open and wallow down the Inn and all in it; he threatned even to the very way they travell'd on, and the Sun that lighted them. He would needs get up to put on his Cloaths, and had almot broke his Neck in attempting it, uch was his weaknes. The Hotes endeavour'd to excue the Ladies, and did it the bet he could, but with uch impertinent Reaons that the ick man was the more enrag'd, and fell out with her. He was o incens'd that for four and twenty hours nothing went down his throat, and that diet with abundance of rage and fury prov'd o effectual, that after the taking of a certain Broath, he found himelf trong enough to purue his fugitive Slaves. They were got as far before him as they were able to travel in two days; but two Hackney Mules, he fortunately met with upon their return to Burgos, contributed as much to his deign as it prov'd fatal to that of the two counterfeit Pilgrims. He overtook them within ix or even Leagues of Burgos. They grew pale, and then bluh'd when they aw him, and excus'd themelves, if any uch thing could be done. Montufar mother'd his anger, for very joy that
he had found them, which he could not forbear expreing in his very countenance. He firt broke forth into a Laughter at the trick they had put upon him, and rais'd them to uch ecurity, that they thought him the veriet Sot they had ever met with. He thereupon made them believe they were out of the way to Burgos, and having (to bring them into it) led them among Rocks and Precipices, uch places as he knew no man travell'd through, he drew a long Dagger, an Intrument for which they had ever had a great repect; and commanded them very imperiouly to make preent delivery of what Gold, Silver, and Jewels they had. They thought at firt with their tears to have pacifi'd him o far as to bring the buines to ome compoition. Helenilla was very prodigal of them for her part, cating withall her arms about his Neck; but the unmerciful Hector grew o inolent upon their ubmiions, that he would not hear of any thing by way of treaty, and once more gave them the peremptory word of command, allowing them but half a quarter of an hour to reolve whether they would deliver or no. There was no way but to acrifice their Pures to the afety of their Perons, o that with much regret they parted with what was dearer to them than their very entrails. Yet was not Montufar's revenge atisfi'd with that. He pull'd out of his Pocket a parcel of Whip-cord which he had bought on purpoe for uch an execution, and having ty'd them to everal Trees one againt the other, he told them, with a treacherous mile, that, out of a certain knowledge he had of their negligence in doing Penance from time to time for their
ins, he would, for the good of their ouls, give them a little dicipline with his own hands, that they might remember him in their Prayers. The Sentence pronounc'd was immediately put in execution, with branches of green Broom that grew thereabouts in abundance, he having o much mercy in his jutice as not to do it with the Whip-cord, whereof he had had himelf experience both of the weight and mart, notwithtanding the grave reproaches of Mendez not long before to that purpoe.

Having diciplin'd them till he grew weary, at the cot of their poor skins, he ate him down between the two Patients, and turning himelf to Helenilla, entertain'd her omewhat to this effect. My dearet Helenilla, aid he, be not o much dipleas'd with me, for what hath happen'd between us, till thou hat conidered my good intention in it, and thereupon reflected, that every one is oblig'd in concience to follow his vocation: it is thine to commit leud actions and to be michievous; it is mine (the world coniting of good and evil) to punih leudnes and michief where I meet with them. Thou know't better than any one, whether I dicharge my duty as an honet man hould, and thou art to aure thy elf, ince I chatie thee o heartily, that I love thee no les. Were it not that it is more pardonable in me to be tender of my duty, than inclin'd to compaion, I hould not leave a Gentlewoman o well decended, and o virtuous, tark nak'd ti'd to a Tree at the mercy of the firt that paes by. Thy illutrious birth, which thou not long ince gavet me an account
of, deerves another detiny; but be ingenuous, and acknowledge thou wouldt do no les thy elf, if thou wert in my place. What will prove thy greatet misfortune, is, that, having been o common as thou hat, it will not be long ere thou art known, and then it is to be fear'd, that out of a Maxim of Policy, to the perpetual terrour of publick inners, order will be given for the burning of this michievous Tree, whereto thou art as it were incorporated, together with the wicked fruit that grows on it: but in recompence, if thou hat onely a fear of all the evils thou bringet on thy elf, thou wilt one day make very pleaant relations of thy adventures, and have this to adde, that, by the patient uffering of one hard night, thou halt have acquir'd an excellency, which will be much talk'd of amongt the many other thou art Mitres of already; and that is, my dear quondam-acquaintance, the knack of being able to leep tanding.

p.q:
But the charitable Mendez might jutly quarrel at my incivility, if I hould continue my dicoure any longer to thee, without o much as turning my face towards her, who was o free of her advice and aitance in my icknes: and I hould be much wanting as to the duty I owe my Neighbour, if I hould not out of a like motive of charity give her ome advice uitable to the preent poture of her affairs. They are indeed, added he, turning towards Mendez, in a much wore condition than you haply imagine; recommend your elf therefore earnetly to the goodnes of God, though it be the firt time
you ever did it: let your many wrinkles be as many remembrancers of the decays of your Microcom, and your inability to overcome this days perecution; were it the pleaure of Heaven you might have a Confeor as eaily as it is certain you tand in need of one. Not but that you may derive much quiet of thought and concience from the exemplary life you have led; ince you have always been o exceively charitable, that, intead of repining at the imperfections and micarriages of others, you have repair'd thoe of an infinite number of young Maids. Beides, hall there be no account made for the pains you have taken in tudying the mot occult Science • ? 'Tis true, the Inquiition lov'd you never the better for it, nay, betow'd on you ome publick marks of its diaffection; but you know, it conits of knowing men, and that there is ever an envy and emulation between perons of the ame profeion. Nay, they do much more, that is, they are far from any confidence of your alvation; but it matters not, Cutom makes all things tolerable, even in Hell it elf, where it cannot be but that you mut expect much kindnes from the Inhabitants of the place, as having held a great correpondence with them during your living here. I have but a word more to tell you, which is, that I might have chatis'd you much after another manner; but it came into my thoughts, that it is ordinary with old people to become children again; that you are old enough to be return'd to your firt tate of innocence, and conequently that a Rod was a more proper intrument to punih
you for the raskally childih trick you put upon me, than any other: and o I take my leave, recommending the care of your perons to your own dear elves.

div.p: Having thus had the atisfaction to return their abues, he went his ways, and left them rather dead than living, not o much through the grievounes of the chatiement they had receiv'd, as that he had carried with him all they had, and left them alone, bound to their good behaviour in a place, where, for ought they knew, they might become food for the Wolves.

They were very mournfully looking one upon the other, without aying any thing, when there paes by between them a Hare, which had not gone far ere they perceiv'd a Dog in puruit of her, and at ome ditance after the Dog, a Gentleman on Hore-back, and that no other than Don Sancho of Villefagnan, who was come to Burgos, to ee his Brother, whom he heard to have lien ick, and with whom he then ojourn'd at a Country houe he had not far off thence, whither he was come to take the air. He thought it a trange pectacle to ee two Women bound in that manner to Trees, and was much urpriz'd when he finds in the countenance of one of them, that of the beautiful Stranger he had een at Toledo, whom he had made o much enquiry after at Madrid, and who was perpetually preent to his imagination. But whereas he had, upon the firt ight of her, conceiv'd a trong impreion that he was a Woman of quality and married, he continu'd for a while in ome doubt whether it were he, as finding it a hard matter to be convinc'd, that he
durt preume to come o far in o poor an equipage, as he might perceive by her cloaths: but the countenance of Helenilla, which, though cat down and betraying a certain fright, had lot nothing of its beauty, atisfi'd him at length that he had found what had cot him o many deires and diturbances. He lifted himelf up upon the tirrups, and look'd all about him to ee if he were all alone, and he was imple enough to fear it was ome diabolical illuion (God o permitting it) ent to punih him for his debauches and enuality. Helenilla for her part had a reflection that was not much better, and was no les in fear, that Heaven had made choice of that day, to bring about her all thoe who had any thing to call her to an account for. Don Sancho beheld Helenilla with much atonihment; he him with much ditraction, each of them expecting the other hould firt peak; and Don Sancho was at lat going to fall into ome dicoure with her, when he perceives one of the Pages coming in full peed towards him, whereupon advancing to know what the matter was, the other told him, that the young Gentlemen, his Couins, were together by the ears ready to kill one another. He made all the hate he could, follow'd by the Page, to the place where he had left his company, and finds four or five of them in the heat of their drink railing one at another with their words drawn, and, at ome ditance, employing their drunken valour in cuts and lahes, which cot ome of the adjacent Trees the los of many a fair and hopeful branch.

Don Sancho, enrag'd at his being depriv'd the
pleaant viion he had lot, upon o frivolous an occaion, did what he could to appeae thoe irreconcileable, yet not very dreadful, enemies; but his arguments, his intreaties, and his menaces had prevail'd but little with them, if the wearines they were in, and the wine which diturb'd their brains had not laid them o often on the ground, as at lat to faten them to it, and et them a noring as peaceably as they had at firt with too much violence fallen out.

Leaving them o quieted of themelves, Don Sancho took his way back again towards the happy Tree, unto which he had left the Idol of his heart in a manner metamorphos'd; but his atonihment not to find there what he ought for, was greater than it had been upon the ight of her before. He rode about it everal times to ee if with earnet looking he might find what was not there; and not atisfi'd with that, look'd all about him, yet could dicover nothing but a ad Wildernes he rode up and down to all the places thereabouts, and returns again to the Tree, which, dull Plant as it was, never tirr'd for all the trouble he put himelf to.

Don Sancho, as I told you, had uch a devotion for the female ex, that he could love any Woman at the firt ight: but to compas his deires, if mony would not do, he would pare no courthip, no addrees, no ubmiions, no ervices, no importunity to do it. This you'l ay was the onely way to make a man a Poet, if he were capable of it. Don Sancho indeed could do pretty well at it, and was very happy in the humouring of any accident good or bad: and whereas the odnes of the ubject
given a Poet heightens his fancy, if he have it any thing trong, he thought the adventure had happen'd to him o trange, that it would have been inenibility in him, great as that of the Tree it elf, not to ay omething to it. Having therefore alighted, he dicover'd his Poetry to it in thee words, if it be true at leat, that he was as great a Fool as I am told he was. O mot happy, and mot to be envi'd Tree! ince thou hat been felicifi'd with the embraces of her whom I love, though I have no great knowledge of her, and whom I would not know but to love her, may thy leaves be mingled among the Stars, may the acrilegious Ax never offer the leat violence to thy acred and tender bark; may the Thunder bear a repect to thy • oughes, and the worms of the earth to thy roots; may the harh Winter pare thee, the Spring enrich thee, may the loftiet Pines envy thee; and, to conclude, may Heaven protect thee.

While the vertuous Gentleman was exhauting himelf in fruitles regrets, or, if you will, in bemoaning Po • tical ejaculations, which are of greater impo •• ance th • n any other, and which it is too violent <>
•••• cie for a man to make ue of every day; his ••••• nts, who knew not what was become of him, after a good while's earch, found him, and came about him. He return'd to his Brother's very melancholly, and, if I am not mitaken in wh •• I have been told, he went to bed uppe • les.

But 'tis not eaily credible, how many irons one that tells a tory, or writes a Novel, may have in the fire at once. He that tells the tory, it being uppos'd
he peaks to more than one, is troubled many times to ghes at what circumtances of it the greatet part of his Auditory ticks, and is impatient to have it proecuted: the other, though it may happen he hath to do but with one at a time (for, now the world grows more and more learned, people think it more edifying to read things of that nature themelves) is ubject to the ame inconveniences, not knowing where the Reader would have the deign proecuted, where interrupted by ome unthought-of accident. This brought into my thoughts, that the Reader I have now to do with, may think I leave him too long in upence, as being haply impatient to know, by what enchantment Helenilla and Mendez had been natch'd away from the ight of the amorous DON SANCHO. Let him have but ever o little patience; I am jut going to tell him.

Montufar upon his departure from them was much pleas'd in himelf at the piece of jutice he had done; but as oon as the fury of his revenge began to admit remiion, his Love was proportionably re-inflam'd, and repreented Helenilla to his imagination more beautiful than ever he had een her. He concluded from her great patience in receiving o cruel a chatiement (when he aw there was no remedy but to endure it) that he mut needs be of an excellent and tractable dipoition, and much inclin'd to forget and forgive injuries. He conider'd with himelf, that what he had taken away from them would be oon pent, and that her Beauty was a etled and contant revenue to him, while he continu'd in her
favour, the want of whoe company he already thought inupportable. Upon thee coniderations, he made all the hate he could back, and the ame barbarous hands which had with o little remore faten'd to the Trees the two Fugitives, and had afterwards o unmercifully wept their back-ides with good green Broom, knock'd off their Chains, I would ay, cut aunder, or unty'd their Cords, and e • them at liberty, while Don Sancho was Chritianly employ'd in reconciling thoe of his Drunken company who were fallen out.

Montufar, Helenilla, and Mendez, became good Friends again as they went along, and having reciprocally promis'd to forget all diatisfactions and differences, embrac'd one another with as much tendernes for their reconciliation, as regret for what was pat; doing jut as the Great ones do, who neither love nor hate any thing, and who accommodate thoe two contrary paions to their advantages, and the preent tate of their affairs. They held a Council concerning the way they hould take. Their Politicks advis'd them to forbear going to Burgos, where they might be in danger to meet with the Gentleman of Toledo: They therefore made choice of Sevil for their retreat, and it eem'd to them that fortune econded their deign, ince that, as they came into Madrid-Road, they met with a Mule-driver, who had three return'd Mules he could dipoe of, and which he was glad to let them have to carry them to Sevil, upon the firt propoition made by Montufar to that purpoe. He treated the Ladies upon
the way very civilly, to make them forget the ill treatment they had receiv'd from him. They at firt were omewhat ditrutful of his ininuations, and reolv'd to be reveng'd on him upon the firt opportunity: but at lat, more out of policy than any conideration of virtue, they became greater friends than ever. They bethought themelves, that Dicord had ruin'd the greatet Empires, and were convinc'd, that, in all appearance, they were born one for another. They play'd not any trick of their Profeion in their journey to Sevil; for having their thoughts ufficiently taken up with their removal out of a Country where enquiry might be made after them, they were afraid to run themelves into new inconveniences, which might hinder their going to Sevil, where they had great deigns to carry on.

They alighted a League hort of the City, and having atisfi'd the Mule-driver, made their entrance into it at the cloe of the Evening, and took up their Lodging in the firt Inn they came to. Montufar took a Houe, furnih'd it, but meanly enough, and put himelf into a black Suit, a Caock, and a long Clo • k. Helenilla put her elf into the habit of a Religious woman, having her hair o cloely imprion'd, as there was not ought to be een; and Mendez, clad like a devout Matron, got her a pair of Beads, of uch bignes as might well erve as Cae-hot for a mall piece of Ordnance. For ome days immediately after their arrival, Montufar walk'd up and down the Streets, habited, as I have decrib'd him, with his Arms a-cros, and cating down his Eyes when
ever he met with any of the female Sex. He cry'd out ever and anon, with a voice that would break the very tones: Bleed be the mot bleed Sacrament of the Altar, and the ever-happy Conception of the immaculate Virgin, with everal other exclamations of the ame kind. He caus'd the ame things to be repeated by the Children he met with in the Streets and got them together many times to make them ing Hymns and godly Songs, and to teach them their Catechim. He often viited the Prions, preach'd to the Prioners, comforted ome, minitred to others, bringing them Victuals, and many times carrying from the Market a heavy Basket fill'd with uch things as he had either begg'd or provided for them. Oh detetable Rogue! it eems there wanted onely thy turring Hypocrite, to make thee the mot accomplih'd Villain the Earth ever groan'd under!

Thee virtuous actions, done by the greatet enemy to Virtue of all mankind, in a hort time rais'd him into the reputation of a Saint. Helenilla and Mendez, for their parts, did uch things as made people begin to talk of their Canonization. One pretended to be Mother, the other, Siter of the bleed Brother Martin. They went every day to the Hopitals; waited on the ick, made their beds, wah'd their Linnen, and, if they wanted, accommodated them at their own charge.

Thus were the three mot vicious Perons in all Spain become the admiration of Sevil. Much about this time there happen'd to come thither a Gentleman of Madrid, about ome occaions of his own. He had been one of the acquaintances of
Helenilla; for uch Women as turn common, upply many in their time: he knew Mendez to be no better than he hould be, and had o much experience of Montufar, as to take him for no other th • n a dangerous cheat and a Pandar. One day, as they were coming all three together from Church, follow'd by a great number of perons, who kis'd their Vetments, and intreated them to be mindful of them in their Prayers, they were dicover'd by the Gentleman I poke of; who, upon ight of them being enflam'd with a Chritian zeal, and not able to endure that three perons o trancendently wicked hould abue the credulity of a whole City, broke through the multitude, and coming up to Montufar gave him a hearty blow over the face. Abhominable cheats! cries he to them! Do you neither fear God nor Man? He would have aid omething ele: but his good intention met not with the ucces it deerv'd, it being not onely imprudent, but dangerous, to be over-precipitate in the dicovery of any thing. All the people fell upon him, looking on him as one that h • d committed Sacriledge in his incivility towards their Saint. He was oon lay'd on the ground, loaden with blows and kicks, and no doubt had lot his Life among them, if Montufar, through a miraculous readines of wit, had not taken him into his protection, covering him with his body, thruting away the mot earnet to beat him, nay, expoing himelf to their fury and blows. My dearet Brethren, Crys he as loud as he could, let him alone for the holy Jeus ake; for the B. Virgin's ake, be not o violent.

Thee few words lay'd that great Tempet; and the people, as eaily quieted as they had been tirr'd up, made way for B. Martin, who came up to the unfortunate Gentleman, glad in his Soul to ee him o treated, but dicovering in his countenance a great trouble thereat. He rais'd him up from the ground where he tumbled over and over, embrac'd him, and kis'd him, though all blood and dirt, and reproved the people very harply for their rudenes. I am indeed, the wicked wretch, aid he to thoe who had any deire to hear him, I am the Sinner, I am he that never did any thing pleaing in the ight of God. Do you imagine, continued he, becaue you ee me now clad like an honet Man, that I have not been all my Life a Thief? a candal to others, and my own ruine? Let me be the object of your Injuries; 'tis at me you ought to cat Dirt and Stones, it is my Blood your Swords thirt after.

Having aid thee words with a peronated mildnes, and thereby abolutely quieted the people, he went, with a zeal yet more counterfeit, and cat himelf at the feet of his Enemy, and kiing them, he not onely ask'd him pardon, but got him again his Sword, Cloak, and Hat, which had been lot in the Tumult. He put them about him, and having led him by the hand to the end of the Street parted from him, after he had betow'd on him many embraces, and as many benedictions.

The poor Man was all this while as if he had been inchanted, o atonihed was he at what he h • d een, and what had been done to him, and conceiv'd o much hame at the adnes of the adventure,
that he was never een in the Streets afterwards, though his buines detain'd him in the City ome time longer.

In the mean time, Montufar, by this act of counterfeit humility had gain'd the hearts of the whole City. The people look'd on him with admiration, many came the oftner to Church purpoely to ee him, and the Children cry'd after him a Saint, a Saint, as they would a Fox, a Fox, had they met his Enemy in the Streets. From this time he began to live the happiet Life of any Man alive. The great Lord, the Gentleman, the Magitrate, the Prelate courted him every day to their Tables, and, happy thought he himelf, whom he honour'd with an acceptance of his entertainment. If any one ask'd his Name, he made anwer, that he was the Animal, the Beat, fit onely to carry Burthens, the Common-hore of filthines, the Veel of iniquity, and uch other attributes as his tudied Devotion furnih'd him withall. He pent the day in ome publick places with the Ladies of the City, importuning them with perpetual complaints of his own luke-warmnes: telling them that he was not ufficiently annihilated in Spirit, that he was guilty of too much Self-centreity, and wanted thoe recollections which hould confine his thoughts to celetial contemplations, and divert them from being diorder'd by the vanities of this World; in a word, never entertaining them with any thing but what was wrapt up in this futian Language: So great a Proficient had a hort time made him in Sycophancy and Hyprocriie!

Of the great Alms daily betow'd in Sevil, there pat mot through his hands, or through thoe of Helenilla, and Mendez; who, as to what might be expected from them, acted their parts to the heighth, and whoe names made no les hate to get into the Calender, than did that of Montufar. A certain Widow, a Lady of quality, and inexpreibly beotted with Devotion, ent them every day two dihes of Meat for their Dinner, and as many for their Supper, and thoe uch as had been ordered by one of the bet Cooks about the City. At lat, the Houe they liv'd in grew too little for the great number of preents that were brought in from all parts, and to entertain the Ladies that came to viit them. If a Woman was deirous to be with Child, her onely way was to put her Petition into their hands, that they might preent it at the Tribunal of God, and bring her a peedy and atisfactory anwer of it. She that had a Son in the Indies, took the ame coure; and o did he alo who had a Brother, Friend, or Couin, in Slavery at Algiers. And the poor Widow, who had a caue depending before an ignorant Judge, againt a powerful Adverary, doubted not of its going with her, ince he had made them a preent according to her ability. Some preented them with Sweet-meats, others with Pictures and Ornaments for their Oratory. Sometimes there were ent them in, all orts of clean Linnen and Cloaths for poor people that were aham'd of their neceities, and often, coniderable umms of Money, to be ditributed as they hould think fitting. No body came empty handed
to them, nor did any body doubt of their future Canonization. Nay it grew to that heighth, that ome deir'd their advice in things doubtful, and to come. Helenilla, who had a Diabolical wit, manag'd the buines of Anwers; and the cunning Gipie would be ure to deliver her Oracles, in few words, and in tearms ambiguous and capable of everal interpretations. Their Beds, imple in appearance were all the day cover'd with Mats, but at night with good Down-beds and Quilts, and good Coverlets; the Houe being full of all manner of Houhold-tuff, ent in by ome or other, for a charitable upply of ome Widow, whoe Goods had been taken in Execution, or to furnih the Houe of a young Maid married without any Portion. Their doors, in Winter, were hut up at five of the clock, in Summer, at even, as punctually as if their Houe had been a well regulated Convent; and then the Spits went, the Houe was perfum'd, the Fowls went to the fire, the Tables were neatly cover'd, and the Hypocritical Triumvirate, fed without any remore, and valiantly drank to their own good Healths, and ometimes remembred theirs whom they made uch Fools. Montufar and Helenilla lay together, for fear of the Spirits; and their Man and their Maid, who were of the ame Contitution, imitated them in their manner of paing away the night. But for the Matron Mendez, he always lay alone, and was more contemplative than active, ever ince he had given her mind to the black Art.

Thus did they pend their time, when the beotted
Inhabitants of Sevil thought they were at their mental prayers, or diciplining themelves. It is not to be ask'd, whether they were in good cae, as to the body, living at this rate. Every one bles'd God for it, and it was in a manner the general wonder, that a ort of people who exercis'd o great auterities, were of a better complexion, than thoe who liv'd in the heighth of luxury and abundance. During the pace of three years that they led all the people of Sevil by the noes, receiving preents from all parts, and converting mot of the alms that pat through their hands to their own ue, what a number of good yellow pieces they got together, will not eaily be credited. What ever happen'd uccesfully, was attributed to the effect of their prayers. They tood for all the Children that were chritned, they were the makers up of all Matches, and the adbitrators of all differences. At lat, God grew weary of uffering their wicked kind of living. Montufar, who was much inclin'd to choler, us'd often to beat his man; he, on the other ide, being high fed, and living at eae, receiv'd his chatiement with a great deal of indignation, and would many times have left his ervice upon it, if Helenilla, much more politick in that than her Gallant, h • d not ever and anon appeas'd him with kindnees and preents. He one day corrected him a little too everely for a trivial fault. The young fellow got out of doors, and, blinded by his paion, went and gave notice to the Magitrates of Sevil of the hypocriie of thee three bleed perons. Some evil pirit uggeted it into Helenilla, that the
fellow would do the michief he fear'd. She advis'd Montufar to take all the Gold, whereof they had a coniderable quantity, and to avoid the tempet he was afraid would fall upon them. No ooner aid than done. They took about them what they had of greatet value, and putting a good face on't in the treets, went out at one of the City gates, and came in again at another, to blind thoe that might follow them.

Montufar had ininuated himelf into the favour of a certain Widow, as leud, and as very a hypocrite, as himelf; He had made Helenilla acquainted with all that pas'd between them, who took not any thing amis, no more than Montufar would have done at her familiarity with a Gallant that had been profitable to the Community. To her houe they made their retreat, and there they were ecretly kept, and entertain'd to their own wihes; the Widow having an affection for Montufar, for his own ake, and for Helenilla upon Montufar's account.

In the mean time, the Magitrate, conducted by Montufar's revengeful ervant, was gotten into the houe of our Hypocrites, and made earch for the bleed Children and their glorious Mother, and neither meeting with them nor any tidings of them, the ervant-maid not knowing where they were nor whither they were gone, had c • us'd all the trunks to be ealed up, and an Inventory to he taken of all that was in the houe. The officers found in the Kitchin what to entertain themelves withal for above one day, and left not in danger to be lot any thing they could handomely make
their own. While things were in this poture comes the old Mendez into the houe, having not the leat imagination of what they were doing there. The Officers laid hold on her, and hurried her to prion with a great concoure of people at her heels. The man and the maid were ent thither alo to keep her company, and having poke omewhat too much as well as he, where condemn'd as he was, to the embraces of the Whipping-pot, and there to receive two hundred lahes. Mendez dies of it within three days after, as being too old to overcome o rigorous a chatiement, and the man and the maid were banih'd Sevil for their lives; o that the prudent Helenilla, by her foreight, kept her dear Montufar and her elf out of the hands of the Magitrate, who ought after them, but in vain, both within and without the City. The people were aham'd they had been o abus'd; and the Ballad-ingers, who were grown hoare in celebrating their commendations at all corners of the treets, et their muddy Poets at work to write as much in dipraie of the counterfeit Saints. Thee Inects of Parnaus, exhauted, upon this occaion, their atyrical vein; and the ongs they made, to cry down thoe whom not long before the people had made their Idols, are to this day ung up and down at Sevil.

Montufar and Helenilla reflecting on the ad Tragedy of Mendez, thought it their bet coure to take a counter-march to Madrid, which they did as oon as they durt venture with afety, bringing thither with them much wealth, and being
alo married together. They immediately made enquiry after what news there might be of Don Sancho o •
Villefagnan, and having undertood that he was not at Madrid, they appear'd publickly; he, as well cloath'd as as any Gentleman about the Court, and he, after the rate of a Lady of quality, and beautiful as an Angel. Before the treaty of marriage was concluded between them, there were certain Articles drawn up, with a mutual promie for the punctual obervance thereof; among others, thee; That Montufar as a husband of much dicretion and great patience, hould not be any way troubled at uch viits as upon the account of her beauty hould be made to her; he on the other ide being oblig'd not to entertain any but what were beneficial.

They had not been there long, ere thoe Women, who between the exes of Mankind are much of the ame predicament with Hore-courers in matter of Hores, uch as many otherwie be called the Publick Intelligencers in the affairs of Pleaure; otherwie, Haglers, and Caterers in human fleh; in the vulgar language, Bauds; or, to peak more honourably of them, Women of Deigns, began to beat the market about Helenilla. They made her appear one day at a Play, another in the Park, and ometimes in the great Street of Madrid, eated in the boot of a Coach, whence, looking on ome, miling on others, taking notice of all, he could on a udden muter uch a number of tranported Lovers as might pas for a coniderable Regiment. Her dear husband very punctually
oberv'd the articles agreed on at the Contract; uch as were bahful in their addrees he, by his ininuating behaviour, incourag'd into greater confidence, and did in a manner lead them by the hand to his wife, being o full of compliance and o ready to further their enjoyment, as never to want ome urgent occaions, purpoely to afford them the freedom of her company alone. He made acquaintances with none but uch as had money enough, and car'd as little how they pent it, and never came into his own houe ere he had been aur'd by a ignal that appear'd in the window, when the Mitres of the houe was buie, that he might come in without hindring any port; and, if the ignal were uch as for • ad him entrance, he went his way as well atisfi'd as a peron whoe buines is done in his abence, and pas'd away an hour or two in ome Gaming-houe, where all were glad to entertain him for his wife's ake.

Among thoe whom Helenilla had made her tributary vaals, there was a certain Gentleman of Granada, who urpas'd all his competitors both in the exces of his love and his expence. He was decended out of o noble a Houe, that the titles of his Nobility might be found among the Antiquities of the capital City of Judaea, and thoe who had a particular knowledge of his race, affirm'd, that his Ancetors had kept the Books for arraignment of Malefactors at Hierualem before and after the time of Caiaphas. The love he had to Helenilla made him in a hort time releae a great number of good Pieces which he had imprion'd
haply one by one. By this means came Helenilla's houe to be one of the bet furnih'd about Madrid. A Coach, whereof he knew neither the price, nor was at the charge of maintaining the Hores that drew it, waited every morning at the door, to receive her commands, and roll'd up and down till night, as he was pleas'd to order it. This prodigal Lover took a box for her at the Play-houe by the year, and there hardly pas'd a day but he entertain'd, with ome magnificent Collation, her and ome others of the ex, in the houes of recreation that are about the City. Thee entertainments were a certain Paradie to Montufar, who accordingly atiated his natural gluttony thereat; and being cloath'd like a Prince, and as full of c • h as if he had been a Treaurer, he fed every day like a French-wan, and drank like a German. He had very great compliances for the liberal Granadine, and was not paring of his acknowledgments to Fortune her elf.

But the wind turns of a udden, and brings with it a horrible torm. Helenilla entertain'd the viits of a certain young Hector, one of the Danger-fields of the City; who never durt hew their faces in the field; who live at the charge of ome wretched Curtezan whom they tyrannize over; who go every day to Plays to make tumults and defeat poor Citizens of hats and cloaks; and who every night beat their innocent words againt the walls, that they may have ome colour to wear in the morning, that they had a furious encounter with ome enemies. Montufar had many
times given Helenilla notice, that he was not pleas'd with that unprofitable acquaintance of hers. Notwithtanding all his remontrances, he till kept him company. Montufar was incens'd thereat, inomuch that, to atisfie himelf, he gave Helenilla the ame chatiement, as the deceas'd Mendez, and he, had ometimes receiv'd from him in the mountains of Burgos. Helenilla pretended her elf reconcil'd to him upon the firt acknowledgments of his paion [but was reolv'd to be reveng'd.] The better to compas her deign, he for eight days together treated him with uch unuual kindnees, that Montufar was abolutely atisfi'd: he was one of thoe Women, who adore their Tyrants, and exercie their cruelty on their adorers. One day, the Gentleman of Granada had order'd an excellent Supper to be provided, intending to make the third peron at it himelf; but ome buines o fell out, that he could not come. Montufar and Helenilla drank hand to hand to the health of their Benefactor. Montufar, according to his ordinary coure, made a hift to get drunk, and as they were taking away the cloth would needs tate of a Bottle of perfum'd Hypocras, which the Granadine had ent in, as a thing extraordinary. It was never dicover'd, whether Helenilla, who had open'd it before upper, had put into the bottle a dram of omething more than hould be: This is certain, that not long after Montufar had taken it off, he felt a trange heat in his intrails, and, preently after, inupportable pains and gripings. He had ome upition of his being poion'd, and ran to
get his word, which Helenilla perceiving, got in that interval out of the room to avoid his fury. Montufar went to her chamber whither he thought he had been gone to hide her elf, and earching after her in the heighth of his fury, he dicovers, as he took up a piece of Tapitry, Helenilla's young Gallant, who immediately run him with his word through the body. Montufar, though half-dead, made a hift to get him by the throa • . Upon the hrieks of the ervants, who made a hellih noie, the Magitrate comes into the houe, jut as the Murtherer was in hopes to make his ecape, having put Montufar out of all pain with a harp dagger he had.

In the mean time Helenilla, who was got into the treet, and knew not whether he went, enters the firt door he met with open. She perceiv'd a light in a low room, and a Gentleman walking up and down in it. She went and cat her elf at his feet imploring his aitance and protection, and was much atonih'd to find him to be Don Sancho, of Villefagnan, who was no les urpriz'd to meet with, in her, the Idol of his heart, which now appear'd to him the fourth time. Don Sancho had, ome time before, had ome differences with his wife, and thoe were come to uch heighth, as that they were thereupon abolutely parted, he finding it impoible to live with him, by reaon of his ill treatments of her, and his debauches. He had procur'd from the Court a Commiion to plant a new Colony in the Indies, and was within a hort time to take hipping at Sevil. While Helenilla entertains him with a thouand
forg'd tories, and that he is over-joy'd to find her willing to accompany him in his voyage; the Magitrate condemns the young Gallant to be hang'd for the murthering of Montufar, makes a earch after Helenilla all over Madrid, and eiz'd of all that was in the houe. Don Sancho and Helenilla had a properous voiage to the Indies, where there have happen'd to them tranger adventures than any have been related yet. Some particulars have been brought over, but more are till expected. Thoe that are lately come out of thoe parts give an account of Helenilla as being yet alive, in great properity, and Governes of a vat Country; She and Don Sancho living as happily and as lovingly as any couple in the world. She engag'd him to marry her ere he could have his deires of her; which when he made ome difficulty to do; he atisfi'd him with this, that, in everal worlds, it was lawful for a man to have everal wives. There are everal Bookellers, who with the lat Ship that went into thoe parts, ent over a young man to get the Copy of her and her Indian husband's adventure, before it comes to my perual; but though they do, I do hereby let them know, they mut have my hand in it before it be printed, becaue I have all the tories wherewith he entertain'd Don Sancho at her o udden meeting with him at Madrid ready for the Pres, which, conidering the urprize and confuion he mu • t needs be in at o fatal an accident, and the preence of pirit he had to invent them, will accordingly be thought the greatet miracle of female invention that ever was. I intend to put out all
together, (not including what is already publih'd) under the Title of THE COMPLEAT CURTEZAN, or THE MODERN LAIS, In the mean time, forbidding all manner of perons to trouble either Book-ellers or Friends to end them Books under uch names, till they find thee Titles at the beginning of the Book which they now meet with at the end, or hear further from their humble Servant.

div.head: THE INNOCENT ADULTERY.
The Third Novel.
div.p:
THE Court of Spain was at Vailladolid, and conequently the inconveniences of thoe that were oblig'd to attend it, were the greater, (it being a place as famous for the dirtines of it as Paris, if we may believe an eminent Spanih Poet, who hath given us that account thereof) when in one of the coldet Nights of a Winter that had been more harp than ordinary,
and about the hour that mot of the Monateries toll their Bell to Ma • ins, a young Gentleman, named Don Garcias, lip'd out of a Houe where he had pent the day in ome Company, or h • ply at Gaming, which, however we may be enible of the other loes conequent thereto, makes us little mind th • t of our Time, though haply the greatet. Though the night were dark, yet had he not any light with him; whether his Lacquey had through leepines lot his Link, or that his Mater car'd not much whether he had any; and was jut paing into the treet where his lodging was, when, at a door, opened of a udden, a certain peron was thrut out with uch rudenes and violence, that the party fell at his feet, on the other ide of the way, as he walk'd along.

He was much tartled at the trangenes of the adventure; much more, when going to give his hand to the peron he thought o unworthily treated, he perceiv'd, he was trip't to the Shirt, and heard him ighing and bemoaning himelf, without endeavouring in the leat to get up. Thence he inferr'd, he had hurt himelf in his fall, and thereupon, having, with the help of his Lacquey which was come up to him, et him on his feet, he ask'd him, Wherein he might do him any ervice. You may ave my Life, and ecure my Honour, replies the unknown Peron, with a Voice interrupted with ighs, and which convinc'd him of the mistake he had been in all the while, and that it was a Woman he had found o barbarouly forc'd out of doors at o uneaonable a time. I beeech you, added he, by the ame generoity
which makes you o ready to ait me in my misfortune, to dipoe of me into ome place, where I may remain conceal'd, provided none know of it but your elf, and uch as you hall be confident of their fidelity.

Don Garcias put his cloak about her, and commanding his Lacquey to hold her by the arm on one ide as he did on the other, he oon brought her to his Lodging, where all were in their Beds, but one Maid, who opened the door, curing and bitterly railing at thoe who made her it up o late. The Lacquey, whether upon the directions of his Mater, or the pleaure thoe of his quality take in the doing of michief, made her no other anwer than that of blowing out her candle, and while he was gone to light it again, calling him a hundred Rogues and Skip-kennels, Don Garcias, conducted, or indeed rather carried to his Chamber, (which was but one pair of Stairs) the ditreed Lady, who with much ado kept on her feet.

The Lacquey having brought up a light, Don Garcias perceived he had met with a very extraordinary adventure, having brought into his Lodging one of the handomet Women in all Spain, and one who immediately rais'd in him both Love and Compaion. Her hair was black, but withall of a brightnes out-vying that of Jet; her Complexion, a miraculous mixture of Lillies and Roes; her Eyes, to peak mo • etly of them, o many Suns; her Breat lovely, beyond all comparion; her Arms admirable; her Hands yet much more to be admired; and her Stature uch as a Man that were a great Monarch hould wih in her whom he
call'd his Queen! But that delicate black Hair was all in diorder; that attractive Complexion was pale and dicolour'd; thoe parkling Eyes were full of tears; that incomparable Breat all bruis'd; thoe Arms and Hands were not in a much better condition; in a word, that lovely Body, of o graceful a proportion, was full of black and bloody places, as if the owner had been beaten with Stirrup-leathers, a Girdle, or omething ele, no les unfit to be employed on o much tendernes and delicacy. If Don Garcias were infinitely pleas'd to look on o beautiful a peron, the ame beautiful peron was no les troubled to ee her elf reduc'd to the condition he was in; at the dipoal of a Man, he had not the leat knowledge of, and one that eem'd not to be five and twenty years of age. He took notice of her diturbance, and did all he could to peruade her, that he hould be far from fearing any thing unhandome from a Gentleman, who would think himelf happy to erve her, though with the hazard of his Life.

Don Garcias proffer'd himelf to go where ever he pleas'd to deire him, and receiv'd her commands, with that earnetnes and alacrity, as a peron newly fallen in Love, would do thoe of the Beauty he was become an adorer of. She gave him uch directions, as were neceary; he left her, upon engagement to make a peedy return, and he immediately fell to uch lamentations, as if he had but newly begun. It was not an hour ere Don Garcias return'd; and upon his coming into the room, perceiv • ng his fair Guet much alarm'd, as if he had had a preentiment of the ill news he brought her; Madam, aid he to her, if you are Eugenia, Wife of Don Sancho, I have omewhat to tell you which very much concerns you; Eugenia is not to be heard of, and Don Sancho in prion, charg'd with the death of his Brother, Don Lewis. Don Sancho, is innocent, aid he, I am the unfortunate Eugenia, and Don Lewis was the lewdet Man in the world.

Her tears, which thereupon broke their way with too much violence, and her obbs admitting very little intermiion, uffer'd her not to peak any more; and I think Don Garcias was not in the mean time a little troubled to compoe himelf to adnes, and to expres how enible he was of her affliction. At lat, as we find that violent things are eldome of long continuance, Eugenias's grief admitted ome moderation; he wip'd her eyes and face, and went on with the dicoure, which, as I aid, her tears and ighs had interrupted. It amounts not to much, aid he to him, that you know the name and quality of the unfortunate
Wom • n, you have in o hort a time o highly oblig'd; you may well expect he hould acquaint you with the particulars of her Life, and by that confidence repos'd in you, make ome kind of acknowledgement of the extraordinary obligation you have cat on her. I am come out of one of the bet houes in Vailladolid. I was born to a great fortune, and Nature hath been o indulgent to me, as to matter of Beauty, that, had I been proud of it, I needed not to have fear'd the checks and cenures of any: The accomplihments of my peron brought me more Gallants than the greatnes of my Etate; and the reputation of both together rais'd me Adorers in the mot remote Cities of Spain. Among thoe who propos'd to themelves the felicity of my enjoyments, Don Sancho, and Don Lewis, two Brothers, equal both as to the goods of Fortune and Nature, were the mot remarkable, as well for the violence of their paion, as the emulation they expres'd who hould do me the mot, and mot coniderable ervices. My Friends countenanc'd the pretenions of Don Sancho, who was the elder of the two, and my Inclinations were cononant to their choice, and dipos'd me to a m • n turn'd of forty years of age, who, by the mildnes and compliance of his dipoition, and the extraordinary care he took to pleae me, got a greater Interet in my oul, than would haply have done a peron whoe age had been more uitable to mine. The two Brothers, though they had been Rivals, had nevertheles liv'd o friendly together as never to have any difference; and
Don Sancho, upon his gaining of me, lot not the friendhip of his Brother Don Lewis. Their Houes joyn'd together, or rather were but one Houe, ince the common Wall that eparated them, had a Door in it, which, by joynt-conent was not lock'd of either ide. Don Lewis was not hie, even before his Brother, to make the ame addrees to me as he was us'd to do whilt he was his Rival; and Don Sancho, whoe affection was heightened by his enjoyment, and who lov'd me beyond his own Life, look'd on his Courthips as the expreions of an innocent gaynes and civility. He call'd me himelf his Brother's Mitres, who for his part palliated a real love with o much eluion and artifice, that I was not the onely peron deceived in it. In fine, having a while accutom'd himelf to entertain me publickly with his paion, not minding who were preent, he came at lat to make ome dicoveries of it to me in private, with o much importunity, and o little repect, that I was no longer to doubt of his unworthy deigns upon me. Though I was but very young, yet had I prudence enough to put him off with uch Retorts, as whence he might have taken occaion to let all things pas as if he till onely peronated the paionate Lover. I took in jet whatever he aid to me eriouly, and though to my remembrance I never was more angry than at that time, yet I never did my elf greater violence, to forbear doing any thing inconitent with the ordinary indifferency of my humour. This he was o far from making his advantage of, that
it incens'd him; and giving me a frightful look, wherein his wicked intentions were but too viible; No, no, Madam, aid he to me, I am not o much a counterfeit ince I lot you, as I was while I had yet hopes to gain you: and though your rigour be great enough oon to free you from a Love and Addrees which you think troubleome, you have o accutomed me to uffer, that it will be much better done of you to — Forbear ever being alone with you, aid I, interrupting him. Upon which one of my Women, coming into my chamber, prevented him, from making further dicoveries of his inolence, and me, from expreing my reentment thereof, as highly as the occaion requir'd, and I found my elf inclin'd to do. I was very glad ince, I had not done it, upon this account of my Husband, and was in hope that wicked Brother would have afforded me les of his love and more of his eteem; but he till continued both his prevarications before people, and his importunities in private. To elude his Tranportations and erious Addrees, I put on the greatet everity I could, o far as to threaten to give his Brother notice of his behaviour towards me. I made ue of all the ways I could think on, to make him enible of his micarriage. I entreated, I wept, I promis'd to love him as a Brother; but he would needs have that place in my affection which Lovers onely pretend to. In fine, ometimes born with, ometimes harply treated, and till no les amorous than abhorr'd, he would have made me the mot unfortunate Woman in
Spain, if my concience, which could not upbraid me with any thing, had not etablih'd and preerv'd the tranquility of my mind. But at lat my vertue, which had tood out the aaults of o dangerous an enemy, forook me; and I became a prey to one I little thought of, becaue I forook it. The Court came to Vailladolid, and brought with it that gallantry which makes Ladies that are unaccutom'd to it, entertain other thoughts than they had before. There is omewhat more than ordinary pleaing in all new things; our Ladies thought they aw omething in the Courtiers which they oberv'd not in thoe who amongt us went for the greatet Gallants; and the Courtiers on the other ide endeavour'd to pleae our Ladies, and to ininuate into their favou • , though they thought them little better than certain Conquets. Among the Gallants that follow'd the Court, in hopes of ome preferment in time for their attendance: a Portuguez, named Andrado, was much taken notice of, for the harpnes of his wit, the gracefulnes of his peron and countenance, and more particularly for the greatnes of his expences, a charm that h • th a trange power upon unexperienc'd Ladies, who meaure the excellency of the oul, by the magnificence of a man's retinue and his cloaths. Wealth he had not much, but Gaming brought that, which was haply uperfluous with others, to further his Accommodations; and the advantages he made of it were o coniderable, that he liv'd at as high a rate as the richet and mot umptuous about the Court. I was o unhappy
as to be thought worth his liking, and when, through my own vanity and his courthip, I was peruaded that he was taken with omething in me, I thought my elf the happiet woman of my quality in the world. I hould find it no mall difficulty to expres what artifices he had to force himelf into a woman's affections, and anwerably thereto what an exceive love I had for him. That Husband, whom not long before I thought o kind, o dear, and o worthy my repects, was grown, in my apprehenion, as depicable, as odious. For Don-Lewis I had a greater averion than ever; nothing pleas'd me but Andrado; I could love no man but him, and whereever I came and had not the ight of him, I atonih'd all people with my ditractions and diquiets. Nor was Andrado's affection to me les violent. His predominant paion of Gaming gave way to that of his Love; his preents gain'd my Women, his Letters and Sonnets took me infinitely, and the Muick he was omewhat over-prodigal of, gave all the Husbands that liv'd in my treet occaion to be thinking. In fine, he charg'd me o home, or I made uch weak reitance, that I was wholly at his devotion. I promis'd him all he could deire, inomuch that all the trouble we were at, was about the place and the time. My Husband was to make one at a Hunting-match, which was to have kept him in the Country for everal days together. I ent notice of it to my dear Portuguez, and we appointed the execution of our amorous deigns to be the very night after my Husband's going out
of Town. I was, at a certain hour agreed on between us, to leave the back-door of our Garden open, and, under pretence of paing away ome part of the night there, by reaon of the extraordinary heat, to et up a field-bed in a little waincot Bower, open of all ides, and urrounded with Orang-trees and Jeemine. In fine, my Husband left Vailladolid in the morning: but from that to night eem'd to me the longet day of my life. Night came at lat, and my Women having et up a bed in the Garden, I pretended before them an extraordinary leepines, o that as oon as they had undres'd me, I bid them go to their beds, one onely excepted who was privy to my deign. I was hardly got into bed, and the maid that t • id with me, whoe name was Marina, had but lock'd that door of the Garden which came from the houe, and open'd the back-door; when my Women came in all hate to tell me that my Husband was return'd. I had but o much time as to get that door lock'd, which I had caus'd to be open'd to let in Andrado. My Husband came to me with his ordinary carees, and I leave it to you to imagine how I entertain'd them. He told me the occaion of his o udden return, was, that the Gentleman who had invited him to Hunting, had been thrown by his Hore and broke a Leg; and having added to that an account of what ele had happened that day, he commended my ingenuity in making choice of a place to avoid the inconveniencies of the heat, and would needs pas away the night with me. He immediately put off his cloaths and
came into bed to me. All I could do was to put on the bet countenance I could, and to mother the trouble I was in at his return, and to aure him, by ome forc'd carees of mine, that I was not inenible of his. Andrado, in the mean time, came according to the appointment, and finding that door lock'd which he hould have found open, he with the aitance of his Lacquey made a hift to get over the Garden wall, with hopes, notwithtanding that obtacle, to pas away the night with me. He hath avow'd to me ince, that his engaging himelf in o preumptuous and dangerous a deign proceeded meerly from a motive of jealouie, as being in a manner confident, that ome Rival, more in my favour than himelf, was admitted to thoe enjoyments which he had been put into hopes of. The imagination he had, that haply I had put a trick upon him, put him into uch a fury, that he was fully reolv'd to be eaven with me, in cae what he upected hould prove true, and to exercie the greatet revenge he could think of, upon the Gallant he hould find poes'd of the place he had promis'd himelf. He made his approaches to the Bower where we were a-bed, with as little noie as he could. 'Twas a clear Moon-hine night, o that I both perceiv'd him coming in, and knew him. He aw I was frighten'd, and oberv'd the igns I made to him to withdraw. He could not of a udden dicern whether the peron who lay by me was my Husband or ome other; but perceiving in my countenance no les atonihment, than confuion
and hame, and finding upon the Table the Cloaths and Plume of Feathers, which he had een my Husband in, that morning, he was atisfi'd it could be no other than Don Sancho who was a-bed with me, and further confirm'd in that belief, by finding him leeping more ecurely than a Gallant could have done, had any been in his place. However he would needs come to that ide of the bed which I lay on, and give me a kis, which I durt not deny him for fear of awaking my Husband. He forbore putting me into any further fright, but went away, lifting up his eyes, hrinking up his houlders, and doing uch actions as betrai'd the regret he conceiv'd at his being o unhappily diappointed, and immediately got out of the Garden with the ame facility as he had got into it.

p.q:
The next morning betimes, I receiv'd a Letter from him, the mot paionate I had ever read, and an excellent Paper of Veres upon the tyranny of Husbands. He had pent in compoing them the remainder of the night after he had left me; and for the whole day after I had receiv'd them, I did nothing almot but read them over and over, when I could do it without any bodie's oberving it; nay, o far were we either of us from reflecting on the danger we had been in, that our thoughts were bui'd to contrive how we might run into the ame hazard again. And for my part, though I had not of my elf been ufficiently enclin'd to grant him any thing he deir'd of me, nor lov'd Andrado o much as I did, or had • ot yielded my elf up to the charms of his Letters; yet could
I not have withtood the peruaions of my Woman, who perpetually ollicited me on his behalf. She reproach'd me, that, ince I had o little confidence, it argu'd I had but little Love for Andrado, and entertain'd me with tories of the paion he had for me, with no les earnetnes than if he had been to repreent to ome Gallant of her own what he her elf had for him. I undertood by that carriage of hers, that he was as perfect as needed in the part he was to act, and withall of what importance it was to be careful in the choice of uch perons as are plac'd about thoe of my age and quality. But I had reolv'd to ruine my elf; and if he had been more virtuous than he was, I hould not have truted her o far. In fine, he got me to conent, that he hould receive Andrado into a Wardrobe adjoining to my Chamber where he lay alone: and we had ordered things o, as that as oon as my Husband were fallen aleep, he hould go into my bed to upply my plac • , while I pas'd away the night with Andrado. He was accordingly hid in my Wardrobe, my Husband fell aleep, and I was preparing my elf to go to him, with the earnetnes uual in perons who are violent in their deires, yet have much to fear; when a horrid confuion of Voices dolefully crying out fire, fire, truck my ear, and awakened my Husband; and immediately my Chamber was full of moak, and looking towards the Window, me-thought the Air was all in a flame. A Negro wench that belong'd to the Kitchin had in her
drink et the Houe on fire, and being fallen aleep it was not perceiv'd, till that, having made its way to ome dry Wood, and thence fatening on certain Stables, it began to break through the floor of my Lodging. My Husband was a Man very much belov'd. Of a udden, the Houe was full of Neighbours, who came to do what good they could. My Brother-in-law, Don Lewis, whom the common danger made more diligent than any other, came immediately in to our aitance with all his people, and, animated by his paion, makes a hift to come to my Chamber, even through the flames: which had already taken hold of the Stair-cae. He had made uch hate that he had nothing about him but his Night-gown, which having wrapped me in, he took me up in his arms, rather dead than living; but more out of a reflection on the danger Andrado was expos'd to, than what I was in my elf; carried me to his own Houe through the door that was common between us, and having put me into his own Bed, left me with ome of my Women to keep me company. In the mean time, my Husband, with their aitance, who concern'd themelves in the accident happened to us, order'd things o well, that the fire was extinguih'd after it had done much michif. Andrado found it no hard matter to make his ecape amidt the confuion and thronging of thoe who were come either to help us, or to teal; and you may imagine to your elf, how joyfully I receiv'd that good news from Marina. He writ to me the
next day ome things that were infinitely ingenious and handome, upon the trangenes of our diappointment, which I anwered as I could, and o we alleviated, by mutual Lette • s, the trouble we both equally conceiv'd, not to ee one another.

The michief which the fire had done, being in ome meaure repair'd, o that it was thought fit I hould remove from Don Lewis's Lodgings to my own; it prov'd no hard matter for Andrado to gain my conent to try the ame way once more, as being confident it would then have taken its effect, if by o extraordinary an accident it had not been prevented. But it o happen'd, that that very night wherein we had appointed to recover what uch unfore-een emergencies had depriv'd us of, a Gentleman of my Husband's acquaintance, being in ome trouble about a Duel he had been engag'd in, and thinking himelf not afe at an Ambaadour's where he had taken refuge, was forc'd to bethink him of ome place where he might be in les danger of falling into the hands of Jutice. My Husband brought him ecretly to our Houe, and commanded the Keys to be carried up to his own Chamber after he had caus'd the doors to be lock'd in his preence, for fear ome treache • ous or careles Servant might prove the occaion of his Friend's dicovery.

This order, whereat I was both urpriz'd and extreamly troubled, was but jut put in execution, when Andrado gave the ignal agreed
on between him and Marina, to let her know he waited in the treet for admiion. She, much at a los what to do with him, made a hift to ignifie to him that he hould tay a little. We conulted together, he and I, and not finding any poibility to get him into the houe at the door, he went to the window, and peaking as low as that he could but hear her, acquainted him with the new obtacle that had interven'd, and propos'd it to him, as the bet expedient he could think on, to expect till all were a-bed, and then to get in at a little window in the Kitchin, which he would open for him. Andrado, to atisfie his love, thought nothing too hazardous to attempt. My Husband aw his Friend a-bed, and upon my peruaion went in very good time to his own; all the Servants did the like, and Marina, when he thought all out of the way, et open the little window for Andrado, who immediately got half way in; but with o little care, and o unfortunately to himelf, that after much triving, which rather hindred than furthered his getting in, he was o lock'd in about the middle between the Iron barrs of the window, that he could get neither forwards nor backwards. His man, who tood all the while in the Street, could do him no ervice; Marina from the place he tood in, as little, without the help of ome other peron. She went and got out of her Bed one of the Maids whom he was very intimate with, telling her, that being to receive a kindnes that night from a Sweetheart
of hers, one he loved very well, and was hortly to be married to, he had endeavour'd to get him in at the Kitchin window, and that he had faten'd himelf between two Barrs o trangely, that it was impoible to get him out without either filing them off, or removing them out of their places. She deired her to come and help her, which the other was oon peruaded to; but wanting a Hammer or ome other Iron-tool fit for uch a purpoe, the aitance of thoe two maids had done Andrado but little good, if he had not himelf bethought him of his Dagger, which they made ue of o effectually, that, after abundance of pains, the barrs were got looe out of the wall, and the bold adventurer put out of the fear he was in of being found o hamefully faten'd in a place; where, to ecape bet, he could have been look'd on no otherwie than as a Breaker of Houes. This could not be done with o little noie, but that ome of our Servants over-heard it, and thereupon were looking into the treet when Andrado, carrying along with him that piece of the G • ate into which his Body had entred with ome violence, was running away as fat as he could, follow'd by his man. The Neighbours, and our people cry'd out, Thieves, and it was taken for granted, that it was only ome Rogues that would have broken into Don Sancho's Houe where they perceiv'd the Grate broken. Andrado in the mean time being come to his Lodging, was forc'd to get the Iron grate which he had carried away
about him, filed off; he and his man, with all their triving and endeavours, being not able otherwie to hift him of that troubleome girdle.

This third accident put him out of humour extremely, as I have undertood ince: but for my part, I entertain'd it otherwie, and while Marina, almot frighted out of her little wits, gave me the relation of it, I thought I hould have burt with Laughing. Yet upon econd thoughts could I not be les troubled than Andrado was, at the ill ucces of our enterpries: but o far were our deires from being cool'd thereby, that they grew the more violent, and permitted us not to delay the atisfaction thereof, any longer than to the next day after this pleaant and unhappy adventure. My Husband was gone into the City, to compoe the affairs of his Friend about the Duel, and, in all likelihood, to have been employ'd the remainder of that day. I ent Marina to Andrado's Lodging; which was not far from my Houe. She found him a-bed, having not yet orecome the wearines of his night-adventure, and o dicourag'd at the diappointments of his love, that Marina was not a little troubled to ee, with what indifference he entertain'd my furtherance of his deires, and the little impatience he expres'd to come to me; though he ufficiently repreented to him the opportunity which then preented it elf, and was not to be lighted. At lat, after much peruaion and many remontrances he came to me, and I received him with
that exces of joy and atisfaction, a peron abolutely at the command of her paion could be guilty of. I was o blinded therewith, that I oberv'd not o much as Marina with what coldnes he took my kindnees, though it were but too too remarkable. At lat the importunity of my carees forc'd from him ome dicoveries of his. Our mutual joy was grown to that heighth, as not to be expres'd otherwie than by our ilence; and the very thought of what we both deir'd with equal earnetnes, had rais'd in me a bahfulnes which made me avoid the looks of Andrado, and might have given him a confidence to do what he pleaed with me, when Marina, who was gone out of the room, as well to tand Sentinel without, as to leave us to the privacy of our enjoyments, comes in with a udden alarm that my Husband was in the Houe. She dragged Andrado, rather dead than living, into my wardrobe, as being, upon a udden reflection on the precedent dangers he had o narrowly ecaped, at a greater los than I was who had mot reaon to be frighted. My Husband had ome buines to put his Servants upon, before he came up into my chamber. The time that took him up below afforded me the leiure to put my elf into order, while Marina was buied in emptying a great trunk to make a lodging for Andrado.
