She had hardly lock'd it by that time my Husband was come into my Chamber, who, having onely kied me at his coming in, without making any tay with me,
went traight into my wardrobe, and lighting on a Play-book there, ate down and fell a reading. He pitch'd upon ome paage he thought pleaant, and conequently would have kept him reading a long time (for he was very Bookih) if, by the advice of Marina, I had not gone into the wardrobe, and, obliging him to lay aide his Book, brought him thence into my own Chamber. My mifo • tune was not an end with this; Don Sancho taking notice of my being melancholy and troubled in mind, as indeed I had reaon to be, endeavour'd to put me into a better humour by the mot divertive dicoures he could think on. He never made it o earnetly his buines to pleae me, and never dipleas'd me more, nor was more burthenome to me. I entreated him to leave my Chamber, pretending an extraordinary inclination to leep: but he, on the other ide, out of an exceive deire to ee me out of the adnes he thought me burthen'd with, kept me company, much againt my will, longer than I could have wihed; and though he were naturally a peron the mot complaiant of any in the Wo • ld, I thought him o importunate then, that I was forc'd to hunt him out of the room. He would, out of his kindnes, have return'd into my wardrobe, that he might be near me, but, upon ome private reaon I gave him why it was not convenient, he was peruaded to go to his Chamber. As oon as I had lock'd my door, I ran to my Wardrobe to deliver Andrado out of his cloe imprionment. Marina
made all the hate he could to open the trunk, and was little better than dead, as well as my elf; when we found him in a manner breathles, not dicovering either by pule or tirring any ign, whence we might think he was alive. Do but imagine what a terrible los I mut be at, and what I could bethink my elf to do in uch an extremity! I did as women do in uch occurences; I wept, I tore my hair, I grew deperate, and I think I hould not have wanted courage enough to run Andrado's dagger into my breat, if the greatnes of my affliction had not reduc'd me to uch weaknes as that I was forc'd to lay my elf down on Marina's bed. She for her part, though troubled as much as any could be, had a greater command of her judgment in our common misfortune, and endeavour'd to find out thoe remedies, which, weak as I was, I hould never have made ue of, though I hould have kept o much dicretion about me as to do it. She told me, that Andrado might onely be in a ound, and that a Chyrurgeon, either by letting him bloud, or ome other way, might recover him into the life he eem'd to have lot. I look'd on her without making any anwer, my grief having reduc'd me to enelenes and tupidity. Marina lot no more time in conulting me any further; he went to put in execution wha • he had propos'd to me; but as he open'd the doo • to get out, who hould meet her but my Brother-in-Law Don Lewis, coming, after he had look'd for me in my chamber, to the Wardrobe,
where he concluded I mut be, having been told by my husband that I was in no good humour. This econd misfortune we thought more terrible than the former. Had not Andrado's body been expos'd to his ight, as it unhappily was, there needed no more than the confuion and atonihment which he might have oberv'd in our countenances, to raie in him a upition that we were upon ome trange deign, which no doubt but he would have dicover'd, as one that concern'd himelf much in my actions, not onely as a Brother-in-law, but alo as a Lover. Unavoidable therefore it was that I hould cat my elf at the feet of a peron, whom I had o often een protrate at my own; and that, deriving a confidence from the affection he had for me, and that generoity which ought to be ineparable from the quality of a Gentleman, recommend to his abolute dipoal what was dearet to me. He did what he could to raie me up; but I, on the other ide, reolv'd not to tir off my knees, with all incerity, as well as my tears and obs would give me leave, gave him an account of the cruel accident that had befallen me, whereat I doubt not but in his oul he conceiv'd an extraordinary atisfaction. Don Lewis, aid I to him, I do not implore thy generoity to prolong my life for ome few days; no, my misfortunes render it o contemptible to me, that I hould not want the courage to be my executioner, did I not fear my depair would cat ome blemih on my honour, from which that of
Don Sancho, nay indeed, his life, are haply ineparable. Thou mait haply think the didain • I have had for thee, were the effects of my averion rather than my vertue; thou mai't rejoice at my digrace, nay haply make it contribute to thy revenge: but wilt thou have the preumption to impute the crime to me which thou wouldt have taught me, or wilt thou be o ungrateful as not to expres ome indulgence towards one that hath had o much for thee? Don Lewis not uffering me to proceed any further, You ee, Madam aid he to me, how jut Heaven is in punihing you, for having been o indicreet in the choice of what you hould have lov'd and what you ought to hate: but I have nothing to loe, as being to make it appear, by my freeing you out of the preent trouble you are in, that you have not a better friend in the world than Don Lewis. He thereupon left me, and returns preently again, with two Porters, whom he had ent one of his ervants for. Marina and I in the interim had made a hift to get Andrado's body into the Trunk again: Don Lewis himelf help'd the two fellows to get it on their houlders between them, and caus'd it to be carried to a friend of his, whom he acquainted with the adventure, having already made him privy to the love he had for me.

Having, as oon it was brought in, taken Andrado's body out of the Trunk, Don Lewis caus'd it to be laid all along upon a Table, and
as they were pulling off his cloaths, feeling his pule, and laying his hand upon that part of the body where the beating of the heart is felt, he found him to be not quite dead. With all expedition a Chirurgeon was ent for, while in the mean time they put him into bed, and us'd all the means they could think on to bring him to life. At lat, he came to himelf; he was let bloud; a Lacquey was left to wait on him; and the room was clear'd, that o nature and ret might perfect what art and indutry had begun.

You may well imagine what atonihment Andrado was in, when, after this long Trance, he found himelf in a bed, not able to call any thing to mind but the fear he had been in, and that he had been put into a Trunk, not knowing where he was, nor what he had either to hope or fear. He was in this terrible ditraction when he heard the chamber door open, and after the curtains were drawn, by the light of the torches that had been brought in, perceiv'd Don Lewis, whom he knew to be my Brother-in-law, and who having taken a chair poke to him in thee tearms: Do you know me, Signior Andrado, aid he to him? And do you not withal know I am Brother • o Don Sancho? I do indeed know you, repli'd Andrado, and withal to be Brother to Don Sa • cho. And have you any remembrance, ays Don Lewis, of what happen'd to you this day at his houe? But whether you do or no continu'd he, aure your elf, that if ever I hea • ,
of any further deigns you have upon my Siter, or are o much as een in the treet where he lives, I hall be indebted to you a michief, and will be ure to pay it, notwithtanding all your caution; and know, you had been ere this among your acquaintances in the other World, had I not too much pity and compliance for an impudent and unfortunate woman, who hath repos'd this confidence in me; and were not aured, that the criminal deigns you have laid together againt my Brother's honour, had not their effect. I advie you therefore to change your lodging, and flatter not your elf with any hope you can elude my reentment, if you perform not the promie I expect you hould make me to do it. Andrado would gladly have engag'd himelf to much more. He made the mot unworthy ubmiions to him he could think on, and acknowledged he ought him a life which it was in his power to have taken away from him. His weaknes was uch as might well confine him to his bed; but the cruel fear he had been in, trengthned him to get up. He thereupon conceiv'd an averion for me, greater than the love he had ometimes born me, inomuch, that it was a horrour to him but to hear me nam'd. I was in the mean time in no mall trouble, to know what was become of him, yet had not the confidence to make any enquiry after him of Don Lewis, nor indeed to look with any aurance upon him. I ent Marina to Andrado's lodging, whither he came, not long
after he had got thither himelf, and while he was packing up his things to be gone to a lodging he had taken in another quarter of the City. As oon as ever he aw her, he told her that if he had any meage from me, he might carry it to ome body ele, and having given her a hort account of what had pas'd between him and Don Lewis, he clos'd his relation with this character of me, that I was the mot ungrateful, and mot perfidious woman in the world; that he look'd on me no otherwie than as one that had plotted his ruine, and that I hould no more think of him, than as if I had never een him.

With thee words he dimis'd Marina; but notwithtanding the atonihment he was in at uch a harp entertainment, he had the wit to follow him at a ditance, and to oberve the place where his things were carried, and by that means dicover'd the new lodging he had taken. The trouble it was to me to be charg'd with an act of malice I was no way guilty of, and to be hated by a peron I lov'd o well, and for whoe ake I had hazarded my life and my honour, uffer'd me not to give way to all the joy which I hould have conceiv'd at his being out of danger. I fell into a deep melancholy, which oon turned to a icknes, and that being uch as the Phyicians could not well give any account of, my husband was extremely troubled thereat. To heighten my misfortune, Don Lewis began to pres, and make his advantages of the
extraordinary ervice he had done me, inceantly importuning me to grant him that which I was content Andrado hould have had, and reproching me with the love I had for my Gallant, when ever I repreented to him the duty I ought a Husband, and what he ought a Brother. Thus, hated by what I lov'd, lov'd by what I hated; depriv'd of the ight of Andrado, too often troubled with that of Don Lewis, and tormented with perpetual reflections on my ingratitude to the bet Husband in the world, who thought nothing too much to pleae me, and was more troubled at my indipoition than I was my elf, when, had he known the truth, he might jutly have taken away my life; inceantly baited with the inupportable remontrances of my concience, and rack'd between the two mot contrary paions, Love and Hatred; I kept my bed for two months, expecting death with gladnes: but it was Heaven's pleaure to reerve me to greater misfortunes. The trength of my age, much againt my will, overcame and dipell'd the adnes which I thought onely death could have put a period to. I recover'd my health, and Don Lewis renew'd his proecutions with greater inolence than before. I had given my women order, and particularly Marina, that they hould never leave me alone with him. Being enrag'd at that obtacle, and wearied out with my perpetual reitances, he reolv'd to obtain, by the mot horrid piece of treachery, that ever came into the mind of a peron conummately
wicked, what I had deni'd him with o much contancy.

I have already told you that between his houe and ours there was a door, eldom lock'd of either ide. Having et a night wherein he though: to put his damnable deign in execution, and taying till all, as well at our houe as his, were abed, he comes in at the door; open'd that of our houe which was to the treet, and going to our table let looe all the hores, whereof there was a coniderable number, and drove them into the court, whence they got into the treet. The noie they made oon awaken'd thoe who had the care of them, and their butling about the houe awakened my husband. He was a great lover of Hores; and had no ooner heard that his own were gotten into the treets, but putting on his night-gown, he runs out after them, very much incens'd at his Grooms, and the Porter, for being o careles as not to make fat the great gate. Don Lewis, who had hid himelf in the room next my chamber, and had een my husband when he went out, lipp'd down into the court ome time after him, and having made fat the treet door, and expected ome little while to avoid my upition had he come immediately upon me, he came at lat and laid himelf down by me, acting the part of my husband in every thing o well, that it is not much to be wondred at, if I were mitaken in him. His tanding o long in his h • rt, had made him very cold; o that as he came into bed: Good Lord,
weet-heart, aid I to him, how cold you are! How can I be otherwie, repli'd he, counterfeiting his voice; 'tis cold tanding in the treets. And for your hores, aid I, are they taken? My people are gone after them, repli'd he. And thereupon coming cloe to me, as it were to warm himelf; amidt his embraces and kindnees, he had his deign upon me, and dihonor'd his Brother. That Heaven was pleas'd to permit it, might haply be, that I hould be a future intrument to punih o enormous a crime, that my honour might be re-etablih'd by my elf, and my innocence publickly acknowledg'd.

Having • one what he came for, he pretended to be much troubled about his hores; he got up from me, went and open'd the treet door, and with-drew to his own lodgings: not a little elevated at the crime he had committed, and hugging himelf haply in the reflection of what was to prove the occaion of his ruine. My husband comes in preently after, and having cat himelf into bed, turn'd to me, frozen as he was, and oblig'd me by carees, which I thought extraordinary, to beg of him, that he would let me leep. He thought it very trange; I wondred much he hould; and thereupon made no further doubt of my being betrai'd. The very thought of it would not uffer me to cloe my eyes till it was day. I got up much earlier than I was us'd to do. I went to Mas, and there met with Don Lewis dres'd as if he had been for ome extraordinary entertainment, with a countenance as
chearful as mine was ad and dejected. He preented me with holy Water; I receiv'd it with much indifference at his hands, which he oberving, and looking on me with a malicious mile: Good Lord, Madam, aid he, how cold you are? At thee words, being the ame I had aid to him, and enough to atisfie me who was the Author of my misfortune, I grew pale, and immediately bluh'd, upon thought that I had grown pale. He might have oberv'd in my eyes, and by the diorder into which thoe words had put me, how highly I was offended at his inolence. I went away without o much as looking on him. What ditractions I was in all Mas-time, you may eaily imagine; as alo how infinitely my husband mut needs be troubled, when he oberv'd that all dinner time, and all day after, I minded not what was aid or done, and could not forbear ighing and dicovering the diturbance of my mind, though I endeavoured all I could to mother it. I withdrew to my chamber ooner than I was us'd to do, pretending to be omewhat indipos'd. I bethought my elf of a hundred everal ways to be reveng'd; but at lat my fury uggeted one to me which I fix'd upon. When bed-time was come I went to bed at the ame time with my Husband. I pretended to be aleep, to oblige him to do the like; and finding him fat enough, and confident all the ervants were no les, I got up, took his dagger, and (beotted and blinded as I was by my paion) it prov'd nevertheles o ure
a guide to me, that through the ame door, and by the ame way that my enemy got into my bed; I got to the ide of his. My fury, though violent, made me not do any thing precipitately; with the hand I had free I felt for his heart, and when by the beating thereof I had dicover'd it, the fear of miing my blow made not that hand to tremble which held the Dagger; but, with all the circumpection imaginable, I thrut it twice into the heart of the detetable Don Lewis, and o punih'd him with a gentler death than he had deerv'd. And doubting thoe two might not do my work, I gave him five or ix tabs more, and o return'd to my chamber, with a tranquillity; whence I inferr'd my elf, that I had never done any thing, from the doing whereof I hould derive greater atisfaction. I return'd my husband's Dagger, all bloudy as it was, into the heath; I put on my cloaths with as much hate and as little noie as I could: I took along with me what Jewels and Mony I had: and, no les ditracted by my love than troubled at what I had done, I left a husband who lov'd me beyond his own life, to cat my elf upon the courteie of a young man, who not long before had ent me word that he had not the leat repect for me. The fearfulnes incident to my ex, was o trangely fortifi'd by the impetuous paions I was hurried withal: that, all alone, and in the night time, I walked from my own houe to Andrado's lodgings, with as much confidence, as if I had done a good action,
at noon day. I knock'd at the door, and was anwered, that Andrado was not within, being engag'd at a Play at a friend's not far off His ervants who knew me, and were not a little urpriz'd to ee me, entertain'd me with much repect, and got me a fire in their Mater's chamber. It was not long ere he came in himelf, and I believe it was the leat of his thoughts to find me waiting for him in his chamber. He no ooner cat his eye on me, but betraying his atonihment in the wildnes of his looks: Madam Eugenia, aith he, what buines hath brought you hither? What can you expect more from a peron, you would have acrific'd to the jealouie of a Brother-in-law you are deperately in love with? Ah Andrado! repli'd I, do you make that contruction of an unavoidable accident, which forc'd me to make ubmiions to that man whom of all the world I was mot afraid of being oblig'd to? And hould you pas o diadvantageous a judgment on a peron that hath given you uch extraordinary demontrations of her affection? I expected omething ele than reproaches at your hands. If I am guilty of any crime, it is not againt you that I have committed it, but againt a Husband that hould have been dear to me; proving ungrateful to him becaue I would not be o to you, and foraking him to come to a cruel man whoe entertainment of me is as unworthy as my kindnees to him are great. When your death, which I thought really o, had put me into that
depair, wherein a woman, perpetually expecting the minute of being urpriz'd by her husband, might be; and when thereupon Don Lewis came upon me in that deplorable condition, what could I do les than trut my elf to his generoity and the love he had for me? He hath treacherouly made his advantages of the confidence, to the los of my honour; but 'tis my atisfaction, that he hath bought his enjoyments with the price of his life, which I have now taken away from him; and that, my dear Andrado, is the occaion of my coming hither. I mut keep out of the hands of Jutice, till uch time as it be known, what crime Don Lewis is guilty of, and what misfortune hath befallen me. I have mony and Jewels good tore, upon which you may live handomely in any part of Spain, whither you hall think fit to accompany my misfortune; while Time hall make all the world enible, that I am much more to be pitied than blam'd, and my future carriage atisfie you in particular, that it was not without reaon I did what I have done. Very likely, interrupted he, you have great Apologies to make for your elf, and I hall upply the place of Don Lewis, till thou art weary of me, and then be kill'd, as he was, to make way for another. Ah Woman inatiably lutful! continu'd he: What could I expect more than this lat wickednes of thine to be confirm'd in the peruaion I had, that it was thy deign to acrifice me to thy Gallant? But thou mut not think to ecape with bare reproaches; no, I will
rather be the Executioner to punih thy crime, than be thy Complice in it.

div.p: With thoe words he violently tore off my cloaths, and, with a cruelty, which rais'd horrour even in his own ervants, gave me a hundred blows, naked as I was, and having atiated his rage, till that he was grown weary, he thrut me out into the treet, where if you had not fortunately lighted upon me, I hould either have been dead, or in their hands who haply are earching after me.

Having given over peaking, he hew'd Don Garcias her arms all black and blew, as alo her breat, and what other parts of her body civility permitted her to dicover, which were in the ame condition. Whereupon re-auming her dicoure: Thus have you heard, generous Don Garcias, aid he to him, the deplorable Hitory of the unfortunate Eugenia. Let me beg your advice; if o there be any for an inexpreibly-unhappy woman, that hath been the occaion of o many fatal accidents. Ah Ma • am, replies Don Garcias, were it but as eaie for me to advie you what is to be done, as it will be to punih. Andrado, if you give me leave! Deny me not the honour to be the Revenger of your quarrel; and be not hie in employing upon any deign you would have to be undertaken, a peron who is no les enible of your misfortune, than of the injury hath been done you.

p.U:
aid this to her, with an earnetnes, which atisfi'd Eugenia, that the Compaion was not o great as the Love he eem'd to have for
her. She made the mot obliging acknowledgements of his kindnees which her civility and gratitude could inpire her with: and further intreated him to take the pains to go once more to her houe to be more particularly inform'd of what was aid concerning her departure and the death of Don Lewis.

div.p:
He got thither, as they were carrying to prion Don Sancho, his ervants, and thoe of Don Lewis, who had taken their oaths that their Mater had been in love with Eugenia. The common door, which was found open, and Don Sancho's dagger till bloudy, gave much upition of his being guilty of his brother's death, whereof he was no les innocent than troubled at it. The udden departure of his wife, and her taking away her Jewels and mony, put him into uch an amazement, as out of which he could not recover himelf, and troubled him more than his imprionment and the proceedings of Jutice againt him. Don Garcias was in much impatience to give Eugenia an account of thee things: but it o happened he could not do it o oon as he wih'd. Meeting in the treet with a friend who had ome buines with him, he kept him a good while in dicoure not far from his own lodging: and, as unlucky fortune would have it, over againt that of Andrado, whence he aw coming out a ervant, booted, carrying a Portmantue. He follow'd him at a ditance accompani'd by his friend; and having oberv'd his going to the Pot-houe, he went in after him, and found him taking up three hores, to be made ready within half an hour. Don Garcias uffer'd him to go
his ways, and bepoke the ame number of hores to be ready at the ame time. His friend ask'd him what he meant to do with them? he promis'd to tell him if he would go along with him: whereto the other conented, without troubling himelf any further what his deign might be. Don Garcias entreated him to go and put on his Boots, and expect him at the Pot-houe, while he took a turn to his lodging.

They thereupon parted, and Don Garcias went to Eugenia, to acquaint her with what he knew of her affairs, and to give his Landlady, a woman that might afely be truted with a ecret of that importance, order to get Eugenia cloaths and all things neceary, that he might be convey'd that very night into a Convent, whereof the Abbes was her kinwoman and very much her friend. Having o done, he whiper'd his Lacquey in the ear, and bid him carry to that friend's lodging whom he a little before parted with, his riding uit and boots: and having entreated his Landlady to be very careful of Eugenia, and to keep her from the ight of all people, he went to his friend, and oon after along with him to the Pot-houe, where they had not been long ere Andrado came alo. Don Garcias ask'd him which way he travell'd? he made anwer, to Sevil. Then one Pot-boy will erve us both, ays Don Garcias to him. Andrado was content, and haply look'd on Don Garcias and his friend, no otherwie th • n as two imple Cullies, whoe mony he thought o far due to him, as that he would not have given much to enure it. They
left Vailladolid all together, and ro • e on a good while not thinking of any thing but riding, there being indeed but little converation between people that ride Pot. At lat coming into a Champian far from any Houes, Don Garcias thought it a place fit for his Deign. He rid a little before, and turning about of a udden, he bid Andrado tand. Andrado asked him his meaning. My intentions are, replied Don Garcias, to fight with you, to revenge, if I can, the quarrel of Eugenia, whom you have injur'd beyond all hope of forgivenes, in treating her after the baet and mot unworthy manner, that could poibly fall into the imagination of a peron of quality. I am not orry for what I have done, replies Andrado with much confidence, not eeming to be in the least urpriz'd at the accident; but you may haply repent your forwardnes to do what you are now engag'd in. He was a peron that had Valour; he alighted at the ame time with Don Garcias, there having no more words pas'd between them; and they had their Swords ready to fall on: when Don Garcias's Friend tells them, they hould not fight without him, and profer'd to meaure his Weapon with Andrado's man, who was a fellow whom his countenance and proportion would not have betray'd for a Coward. Andrado proteted, that though he had to his Second the greatet Gladiator in all Spain, he would not fight otherwie than ingly one to one. His man not much minding the protetation of his Mater, proteted for his own part, that he would not fight
with any man upon any tearms at all. So that Don Garcia's Friend was forc'd to be onely a Spectator, or God-father to the Combatants, which is no new thing in Spain. The Duel lated not long: Heaven was pleas'd to favour the jut Caue Don Garcias was engag'd in, o far, as that his Adverary making at him with greater violence than skill, run upon his Weapon, and fell at his feet with los of blood and life. Andrado's man, and the Pot-boy, as fearful one as the other, cat themelves at Don Garcias's feet, who intended them not any hurt. He commanded Andrado's man to open the Portmantue, and to take out of it all his Mater had taken from Eugenia. He immediately obey'd, and deliver'd to Don Garcias, a Mantle, a Gown, and Coat, all very rich, and a little Cabinet, whereof, the weight dicover'd it was not empty. The fellow found the Key of it in his Mater's Pocket, and gave it Don Garcias, who thereupon dimiing him, told him he might dipoe of his Mater's body as he pleas'd, and threatened he would be the death of him, if ever he were een at Vailladolid. He commanded the Pot-boy not to come into the City till after night, and promis'd him he hould find at the Pot-houe the two Hores he and his Friend had taken up. I am apt to believe he was punctually obey'd by thee two perons: who thought themelves very much oblig'd to him, that he had not kill'd them as he had done Andrado. It was never heard what his man did with his body; and for his cloaths, and what ele he had, there is but too much probability,
he became Mater thereof. Nor was it ever known how the Pot-boy behav'd himelf in the buines.

Don Garcias and his Friend made all the peed they could to Vailladolid. They alighted at an Embaadours of the Emperour, where they had Friends, and continued there till after night. Don Garcias ent for his man, who told him that Eugenia was much troubled he could not ee him. The Hores were ent to the Pot-houe by an unknown peron, who having deliver'd them to one that belong'd to the Stable, immediately lunk away. There was no more talk in Vailladolid of the death of Andr • do than as of a thing which it was uncertain whether it were o or not; or if any poke of him, 'twas onely as of a Gentleman kill'd by ome ecret Enemy, or by High-way-men. Don Garcias went to his Lodging, where he found Eugenia put into uch cloaths as his Landlady had provided for her; uch I believe as were taken up at the Brokers; for in Spain perons of very good quality think it no diparagement to take up cloaths, and to furnih their Houes that way, no more than other people of les account. He ecretly return'd Eugenia her own Cloaths and Jewels, and gave her an account after what manner he was reveng'd of Andrado. The Relation he made to her wrought in her a compaion for the unfortunate end of a peron whom he had dearly lov'd; and, the thought of her being the occaion of o many Tragical accidents, cauing in her no les affliction than the remembrance of her own misfortunes,
he fell a weeping as bitterly as at any time before.

But what added not a little to her affliction, was, that Proclamation had been made that day all over Vailladolid, prohibiting all perons to entertain Eugenia, and that whoever brought tidings of her hould have two hundred Crowns. This made her reolve to get into a Convent o oon as he could. She pas'd away that night in Don Garcia's Chamber with as little tranquillity as the precedent. The next morning at break of day he went to that Superiour of the Covenant, who was a Kinwoman of Eugenia's: who, notwithtanding the Proclamation, promis'd to receive her, and to keep her undicover'd as much as lay in her power. Having left her, he went and took up a Coach, and order'd it to wait for him at a place not much frequented near his Lodging, whither he conducted Eugenia, accompanied by his Landlady. The Coach brought them to a place they had appointed the Coach-man to top at, where they alighted, that he might have no knowledge of the Convent, whither Eugenia was to retire. She was kindly entertain'd by the Kinwoman; Don Garcias's Landlady took leave of her, and went to inform her elf what poture the affairs of Don Sancho were in. She undertood it went hard with him, and that there was ome talk of putting him to the Rack. Don Garcias gave an account of all paages to Eugenia, who was o troubled to ee her Husband in danger to uffer for a crime he had not committed, that he took a reolution to cat
her elf into the hands of Jutice. Don Garcias peruaded her to forbear a while, and advis'd her rather to write to the Judge, to acquaint him that he onely could give an account of the murther of Don Lewis. The Judge, by good fortune chanc'd to be of ome Kin to her, came to peak with her, together with others that were to be his Aitants in the trial of Don Sancho. Eugenia confes'd that he had kill'd Don Lewis: gave them a particular relation of the jut motive he had to engage her elf in an action that eem'd o violent in a Woman, omitting nothing of what had pas'd between Don Lewis and her elf; what concern'd the love of Andrado, onely excepted. Her confeion was written down, and a report thereof was made to his Catholick Majety; who, taking into conideration the greatnes of Don Lewis's crime, the jut reentment of Eugenia, her courage and procedure thereupon, the innocence of Don Sancho and his Servants, et them at liberty; and, upon the intreaties of the whole Court mediating on her behalf, granted Eugenia her pardon. Her Husband was not dipleas'd at her for the death of his Brother, and, it may be, lov'd her the better for what he had done. He went to ee her as oon as he got out of Prion, and us'd all the entreaties and peruaions he could to get her home again; but all prov'd ineffectual. She doubted not but that he had conceiv'd uch a reentment for the death of Don Lewis as he ought to have done; that he had made ome dicoveries of what had pat between her and the Portugueze; and thence concluded,
that the leat upition a Woman gives in point of honour may oon be heightened into a jealouie in the apprehenions of a Husband, and will ooner or later diolve the trictet ties of conjugal Love.

While things tood thus, poor Don Sancho viited her often: and, by the tenderet demontrations of an exceive Love, endeavour'd to get her out of the Convent, to be once more the abolute Mitres of his etate and himelf. But he on the other ide continu'd contant to her reolution. She got him to allow her a Penion proportionable to her quality, and the fortune he brought; and, abating onely her obtinacy in denying to live with him, he behav'd her elf o obl • gingly towards that kind Husband, that he had all the reaon in the world to be atisfi'd with her.

But all he did in the Convent to pleae and humour him, heightned the regret he conceiv'd that he could not get her thence. He at lat took it o much to heart that it brought him into a Sicknes, and that icknes prov'd uch, as more than threatened the hortning of his days. He ent to Eugenia, begging the atisfaction to ee her once at his Houe before he took his final leave of her. She could not deny that fatal kindnes to a Husband that had been o dear to her, and whoe affection towards her was then no les violent than it had ever been. She went to ee him expire, and had almot, out of very grief, died with him, eeing him dicover no les atisfaction that he had had but a ight of her, than if he had retor'd him
the Life he was upon the point to quit: Nor did this goodnes of Eugenia go unrewarded; he left her his whole Etate, and conequently, one of the mot beautiful and richet Widdows in Spain, after her o near being one of the mot unfortunate Women in the World. The affliction he conceiv'd at the death of her Husband, was great, and not peronated: She gave order for his Funeral Solemnities, poes'd her elf of his Etate, and return'd to her Convent, reolv'd to pend the remainder of her Life there. Her Friends propos'd to her the bet matches in all Spain: She preferr'd her own quiet before their ambition, and troubled no les at their importunate remontrances than perecuted with the addrees of no mall number of Pretenders, which her Beauty and Wealth drew daily to the outer-room of the Convent where he was; She at lat would not be een, nor peak with any but Don Garcias. This young Gentleman had done her o eaonable a ervice, in an emergency o important, and with uch earnetnes, that he could not ee him, without bethinking her elf, that he ought him omewhat beyond civilities and acknowledgements. She had oberv'd by his Retinue and Equipage, that he was not rich, and he was generous enough to proffer him the aitances which a neceitous peron may without hame receive from another that is more wealthy: but in that mall time he had pent in his Lodging, and by the frequent dicoures he had with her, he had dicovered a Noble oul elevated above the common, and abolutely di-engag'd from all
manner of Interets, thoe only of honour excepted. This rais'd a fear in her he might take it unkindly, if he made him a Preent not uitable to the greatnes of her etate and mind; and he was afraid, on the other ide, he hould think her wanting in point of gratitude, if he made not ome dicoveries of her liberality.

But if her thoughts were in this ditraction for Don Garcias, his were in no les, as to what concern'd her. He was inenibly fallen in love with her; but though the repect he had for her, and the lownes of his Fortunes hould not have deterr'd him from making any uch propoal; what preumption would it have been in him to peak of love to a Woman, whom onely Love had expos'd to o great misfortunes? and that while the adnes of her countenance, and her frequent weeping, argu'd her oul too full of grief to be capable of any other paion.

Among thoe who viited Eugenia, as her mot humble Slaves, with deign to become afterwards her Maters, and thoe not eaie to pleae, among thoe, I mean, who made their addrees to her, and whom he hook off with abolute denial, one Don Diego was remarkable for his obtinacy, as having not any thing ele in him worth notice. He was as arrant a Coxcomb, as it was poible a young man could be; and, what is conequent to that, fantatick, and, what to that, inufferably humourome. Beides all this, the imperfections of his body were uitable to thoe of his mind; and as to the goods of fortune, he was as poor, as
greedy of them: but decending out of one of the bet Houes in Spain, and being of near Kin to one of the principal Miniters of State, which onely made him o much the more inolent, there was a certain compliance had for him where ever he came, upon the account of his quality, though it had not the leat recommendation of any thing of worth.

This ame Don Diego, uch as I have decribed him, thought he had found in Eugenia, all he could have wihed in a Wife, and imagin'd it no hard matter to obtain her, by the aitances of his Friends at Court, whoe encouragements put him into great hopes of it. But Eugenia was not o eaily peruaded to a buines of that importance, as they had flattered themelves he would have been, and the Court would not, to favour a private peron, do a violence that hould be of ill example to the publick. Eugenia's retiring into a Convent, her reolution to continue there, her avoiding of all viits, and the backwardnes of thoe who had encourag'd Don Diego in his applications to her, blated the hopes he had conceiv'd of obtaining her without trouble. He therefore reolv'd to force the Convent, and to carry her away, an attempt the mot highly criminal in Spain, and uch as wherein onely an extravagant fool, uch as he was, would engage himelf in. He found, for money, people as mad as himelf; he gave order for the laying of Hores at everal places, between Vailladolid and a certain Sea-port, where a Veel was to expect him ready to et Sail.
He forc'd the Convent; carried away Eugenia; and that unfortunate Lady was to become the prey of the mot worthles peron in the World, if Heaven had not trangely reliev'd her, when he l • at look'd for it. One ingle peron, who, upon the cries of Eugenia, met the Ravihers, forc'd them to a udden halt, and charg'd with o much valour, that, upon the firt meeting, he wounded Don Diego and divers of his Complices, and kept them in • otion till the Citizens making head, and econded by the Officers of publick Jutice, had reduc'd Don Diego and his party to thoe extremities, that they mut either be kill'd or taken.

Thus was Eugenia recu'd; but before he would be conducted back to her Convent, he would needs know who that gallant Peron was, who had o generouly expos'd his Life to erve her. He was found, wounded in everal places, and, through los of abundance of blood, in a manner Dead. Eugenia deir'd to ee him, and had no ooner cat her eyes on his countenance, but he knew him to be Don Garcias. Her compaion was great as her atonihment, and he made uch paionate dicoveries thereof as might have been interpreted to her diadvantage, if there had not been otherwie a jut ground of her affliction. She prevail'd o far, with much intreaty, as that they would n •• carry to Prion her generous Reliever, whom Don Diego expiring, and his complices, acknowledg'd not to be of their party, but the peron who had oppos'd their deign. He was carried to the next Houe, which by good fortune happen'd
to be that which had ome time been Don Sancho's was now Eugenia's, and where he had left all her Houhold-tuff and ome Servants. He was recommended to the care of the bet Surgeons of both Court and City. Eugenia return'd into the Convent, and the next day was forc'd to leave it; and come to her own Houe, upon the publihing of a Proclamation, that no ecular perons hould be entertain'd into Nunneries. The next day Don Diego dyes, and his Friends had much ado to hinder a Trial to pas upon him, though Dead but his Complices were punih'd according to their deerts. Eugenia in the mean time was almot out of her elf to ee o little hopes of Don Garcias's recovery; he implor'd the aitances of Heaven; She profer'd the Surgeons to reward them beyond what they would have ask'd her; but their Art was at a los, and all their hope was in God and the Youthful contitution of the ick peron. Eugenia tirr'd not from his Bed-ide, and her attendances on him day and night were o aiduous, that they might at lat have reduc'd her to a neceity of having others beides her elf. She often heard him pronounce her name in the tranportations of his Feaver, and among things incoherent, which his ditracted imagination made him peak, he was often heard talking of Love, and dicouring with himelf, as one that were fighting or quarrelling. At lat, Nature, fortifi'd by remedies, overcame the violence of his dieae; his Feaver remitted; his wounds appeared in a better condition; and the Surgeons a •• r'd
Eugenia of his recovery, provided no other accident happen'd to him. She made them very great preents, and caued him to be pray'd for, in all the Churches of Vailladolid. Then was it that Don Garcias undertood from Eugenia, that it was he whom he had recu'd, and he was told by him how it came to pas, that he happened to relieve her o eaonably, being upon his return into the City after he had been to ee a friend of his out of Town. She could not, even in his preence, forbear acknowledging how highly he thought her elf oblig'd to him; and he could as little mother the extraordinary atisfaction he conceiv'd to have done her o coniderable a ervice: but there was yet another thing of greater importance he had to acquaint her withal.

One day, he being alone with him, and intreating him not to uffer her to be any longer ungrateful, but to make ue of her in omething of conequence, he took that opportunity to dicover to her the true entiments he had for her. The very thought of what he was about to do, made him ign; he grew pale; and the diturbance of his mind was o viible in his countenance, that Eugenia was afraid he was in ome great torment. She ask'd him what poture his Wounds were in. Ah Madam! repli'd he, my wounds are not my greatet affliction. What is it then that troubles you, aid he to him much frightned. A misfortune, ays he, incapable of any remedy. It was indeed, replies Eugenia, a great misfortune to be o dangerouly Wounded for a peron you
neither knew, nor deerv'd you hould hazard your Life for her; but this is not beyond remedy, ince your Surgeons doubt not but you will oon recover it. And that is it I am to complain of, cries Don Garcias: Had I lot my Life in your ervice, continued he, I had brought it to a glorious period, whereas I mut now live againt my will, and be a long time the mot unfortunate man in the world. Being a peron o excellently qualifi'd as you are, I think you not o unfortunate as you would make your elf, replies Eugenia. How Madam, aid he, do you not account that man unfortunate, who being atisfi'd of your worth, having a greater eteem for you than any other whatever, loving you beyond his own Life, mut nevertheles come hort of deerving you, though Fortune hould prove as indulgent to him as he hath ever been malicious? You trangely urprize me, aid he bluhing: but the obligations you have cat upon me, give you a priviledge, which, in the condition I am in, I hould not grant any other. I pray you above all things endeavour your own recovery, and aure your elf, your misfortunes hall not continue long, when it hall come into the power of Eugenia to put a period thereto.

She tai'd not to hear what Reply he would make, and by that means pared him abundance of complements, which haply he would but poorly have acquitted himelf of, becaue he would have overtrain'd himelf to make them very good ones.
She call'd thoe Servants of hers who were to attend him, and went out of the room jut as the Surgeons were coming in to viit him. The atisfaction of the mind is the overaign remedy to recover a ick body. Don Garcias deriv'd uch hopes of the advancement of his Love, from what Eugenia had aid to him, that his oul, which before, as that of a Lover without hope, was orepres'd with adnes, dilated it elf for the entertainment of joy, and that joy contributed more to his recovery than all the remedies of Chirurgery. He came to perfect health. He out of civility went from Eugenia's houe, but carried with him, and continu'd, the pretenions he had to her affection. She had promis'd to love him, provided he made no publick dicoveries thereof, and it may be he lov'd him no les than he lov'd her: but having o lately lot a Husband, and been engag'd in adventures, which had made her the Table-talk of all Companies in Court and City, he thought it no prudence o oon to expoe her elf to rah cenures, by running upon a marriage with too much precipitation. At lat Don Garcias, by the exces of his merit and contancy, overcame all thee difficulties. He was, as to his peron, o accomplih'd, as might make a Rival run mad to think on't. He was a younger Brother of one of the bet Houes of Arragon, and though he had done no great things in the Wars, he might jutly, from the long ervices his Father had done Spain, derive ome hopes of a recompence from the Court, as advantageous as honourable. Eugenia
could no longer hold out againt o many excellent qualities, nor be longer oblig'd to him for all he had done and uffered upon her account. She was married to him. Court and City approved her choice; and that he might not have the leat occaion to repent her of it, it happened, that, not long after their marriage, the King of Spain betowed on Don Garcias one of the Commanderies of St. James. Another thing which had already happened, was, that he had atisfied his dear Eugenia the very firt night of their marriage, that he was much another Bed-fellow than Don Sancho, and that he had found in him, what he would not have met with in the Portuguez Andrado. Children they had many, becaue they took more than ordinary pains to get them; and the Hitory of their Loves and Adventures is to this day related at Vailladolid, not only among thoe that knew them, but to Strangers who occaionally Travel that way. For my part, I travelled not thither for it, but finding it Printed, made no doubt of the Truth of it, and expect the ame confidence in thoe who hall receive it from me.

div.head: SCARRON's NOVELS.
The Judge in his own Caue.
The Fourth Novel.
div.p:
PRince Mulei, on to the King of Morocco, having lot the company with whom he had pent the day in hunting, was got alone, and that in the night-time, among certain rocks on the Sea-ide, not above an hours gentle walking from the City of Fez. The sky was not over-cat with the leat cloud; the Sea glaz'd up
in an unditurbed calm, and o might erve for a Mirrour to the Moon and Stars, which <> to parkle no les there, than in their proper Elem • nt: in fine, it was one of the pleaantet nights of thoe warmer Countries, which exceed the fairet days of our colder Regions. The Prince galloping gently along the River ide, diverted himelf in conidering the emulation between the Contellations above in the Firmament, and thoe which eem'd to be on the urface of the Water, when the ad accents of ome doleful hrieking piercing his ears, rais'd in him a curioity to go to the place whence he conceiv'd it might proceed. After a little riding, he found, among the rocks, a woman, who, as much as her trength would permit, made her party good againt a man, who violently endeavour'd to bind her hands, while another woman was emploi'd to top her mouth with a linnen cloath.

The arrival of the young Prince prevented the Actors of that violence to proceed any further therein, and gave her a little repit, whom they intended to treat o unworthily. Mulei ask'd her, what might occaion her crying out, and the others, what they would have done to her? But intead of any reply, the man comes up to him with his Cimitar drawn, and would have dangerouly wounded him, had he not, by the nimblenes of his • ore, avoided the blow. How now, impious • retch, ays Mulei to him, daret thou offer vio
•• nce to the Prince of Fez? I knew thee very well to be my Prince, replies the Moor: nay it is becaue thou art my Prince, and that it is in thy power to punih me, that I mut either have thy life, or loe my own.

With thoe words he made at Mulei with uch a deperate fury, that the Prince, though much fam'd for his valour, was reduc'd to a neceity not o much of aaulting, as ecuring himelf againt o dangerous an enemy. The two women in the mean time were very eriouly engag'd, and he who a little before gave her elf over for lot, kept the other from running away, as if he doubted not but her Champion would obtain the victory. Depair ometimes heightens a man's courage, nay ometimes derives it to thoe who have leat of it. Though the Prince's valour was incomparably beyond that of his Adverary, and maintain'd by a more than ordinary skill and vigour; yet the punihment, which the Moor's crime deerv'd, made him hazard all, and gave him o much courage and force, that the victory was a great while in upence between the Prince and him: but Heaven, which commonly protects thoe it raies above others, fortunately directed the Prince's retinue, which he had lot the evening before, to pas o near the place, as to hear the noie of the Combatants, and the cries of the women. They make all the peed they could thither, and came in jut as their Mater having worted his bold Adverary, had laid him on the ground, where he would not kill him, but reerve him for a more exemplary punihment. He thereupon order'd ome of his people to bind him to a hore-tail, o as that he might not attempt ought againt himelf or any other. Two Gentlemen took up the two women behind them, and o Mulei and his retinue got to Fez, jut with the break of day. This young Prince gover • 'd as abolutely in Fez, as if he had been already King
of it. He order'd the Moor to be brought before him, his name was Amet, and he was on to one of the wealthiet Inhabitants of Fez. The two women were not known by any, in regard the Moors, the mot jealous of all mankind, are extremely careful in keeping their wives and laves from the ight of all others.

The woman, whom the Prince had reliev'd, urpriz'd both him and all his Court with the trancendency of her beauty, which was uch as had not been een before in Africk, and alo with a Majetick air, which the wretched habit of a lave could not hide from their eyes who admir'd her. The other was clad as thoe women of the country are, whoe quality is omewhat above the ordinary rate, and might pas for handome, though much les than the former. But though he might enter into competition with her as to beauty, yet the palenes which through a certain Fear had etled in her countenance depriv'd it of o much of its lutre, as that of the former receiv'd advantage from that lively rednes, which a modet bluh had gently pread over it. The Moor appear'd before Mulei with the countenance and deportment of a Criminal, having his eyes continually faten'd on the ground. Mulei commanded him to acknowledge his crime, or expect to die in the greatet torments. I know well enough what is prepar'd for me, and what I have deerv'd, replies the undaunted Moor, and as it will be of little advantage to me to confes any thing, o are there not any torments that hall make me do it. I cannot avoid death, ince I would have given it thee, I would have thee know, that the
rage I am in, that I could not dipatch thee, torments me beyond all that can be inflicted on me by the mot inventive executioners. Thee women, Spaniards by decent, were my Slaves; one of them hath done as I wih'd her, and compli'd with her fortune, by marrying my Brother Zaides; the other would never change her Religion, nor make the leat kind return to the love I had for her.

This was all could be gotten out of him. Mulei order'd him to be put into a Dungeon loaden with chains; The Renegado wife of Zaides was dipos'd into another prion, and the beautiful Slave was conducted to a Moor's houe named Zulema, a peron of quality, originally a Spaniard, who had left Spain, becaue he could not find in his concience to embrace the Chritian Religion. He was decended of the illutrious Houe of Zegris, heretofore o famous in Granada, and his wife Zoraida, who was of the ame Houe, had the reputation to be the fairet, and withal, the wittiet woman in Fez. She was immediately taken with the beauty of the Chritian Slave, and, upon the firt converation they had together, was no les with her ingenuity. Had this fair Chritian been capable of conolation, he would have found it in the carees of Zoraida; but as if he purpoely avoided whatever might alleviate her grief, he endeavour'd as much as he could to be alone, that he might afflict her elf the more, inomuch that, when he was in company with Zoraida, he did her elf no mall violence, to mother her ighs, and keep in her tears before her.

Prince Mulie in the mean time was extremely
deirous to have an account of her adventures. He had dicover'd o much to Zulema, who being a peron he much confided in, he withal acknowledg'd, that he had ome inclinations for that fair Chritian, and that he had made a dicovery thereof to her, had he not inferr'd, from her extraordinary affliction, that he might have an unknown Rival in Spain, who, though at a great ditance, might prevent his being happy, even in that Country where he was an abolute Prince. Zulema thereupon gave his wife order to enquire of the Chritian the particulars of her life, and by what accident he came to be Slave to Amet. Zoraida was as deirous to do it as the Prince, and found it no hard matter to induce the Spanih Slave to atisfie her; the other not knowing how to refue any thing to a peron, from whom he had receiv'd o many aurances of tendernes and friendhip. She told Zoraida, that he would atisfie her curioity when he pleas'd, but that, having onely misfortunes to acquaint her with, he fear'd the account thereof would be very tedious to her. You will find it otherwie, replies Zoraida, by the attention I hall give you, and my concerns therein will atisfie you, that you may afely entrut the ecret thereof to a peron who infinitely loves you. Embracing her with thee words, he entreated her not to put off any longer the atisfaction he deir'd of her. They were all alone, and the fair Slave, having wip'd off the tears which the memory of her misfortunes drew into her eyes, he thus beg • n • he relation thereof.

p.q:
My name is Sophia, aid he, I am a Spaniard, born at Valentia, and brought up with all the
care and tendernes which perons of quality, uch as were my Father and Mother, could expres towards a Daughter who was the firt fruits of their marriage, and oon appear'd worthy of their affection. I had a Brother, younger than my elf by a year, as lovely a child as could be een; he lov'd me as much as I lov'd him, and our mutual friendhip grew up to uch a height, that when we were not together, there might be oberv'd in our countenances, uch a adnes and diquiet, as the mot pleaant divertiements of perons of our age were not able to dipere. Order was thereupon taken that we hould not be aunder: we learn'd together whatever is commonly taught children, well decended, of both exes, • nd o it happen'd, to the great atonihment of all, that I came to be as skilful and dextrous as he, in all the violent exercies of a Cavalier, and he as ingenious in whatever is performed by young Gentlewomen. This extraordinary kind of education took o much with a Gentleman, an intimate acquaintance of my Father's, that he deir'd his children might be brought up with us. The buines was propos'd to my Friends, who approved thereof, and the nearnes of their houes promoted the deign of both parties. That Gentleman was not inferiour to my Father, either as to quality or wealth. He had alo onely a Son and a Daughter, much about my Brother's age and mine, inomuch that it was not doubted, but the two Houes would be united one day by a double marriage. Don Carlos and Lucia (o were the Brother and Siter call'd) were equally amiable: my Brother
lov'd Lucia, and he him; Don Carlos lov'd me; I, him, as much. Our Parents knew it, and were o far from being dipleas'd thereat, that had we not been too young, they would then have een us married together.

But the happy tate of our innocent Loves was diturb'd by the death of my lovely Brother; a violent Feaver natch'd him from hence in eight days, and this was the firt of my misfortunes. Lucia was o troubled thereat, that no peruaions could keep her from embracing a Religious life. I was ick to death, and Don Carlos was o far given over, as that his Father began to fear he hould ee himelf without iue, o great a grief did he conceive, at the los of my Brother, whom he lov'd, the danger I was in, and his Siter's reolution. Don Carlos's Father di'd oon after, leaving his Son a vat etate. Now was he in a condition to dicover the noblenes of his nature; the gallantries he invented to pleae me prevail'd on my vanity, made his love more publick, and added much to mine. Don Carlos often addre • s'd himelf to my Parents, deiring them to conummate his happines by betowing their Daughter on him. He in the mean time continu'd his extraordinary expences, which my Father perceiving, and conidering his etate could not hold out long at that rate, reolv'd we hould be married. He therefore put Don Carlos in hope, that he hould ere long be his Son-in-law, at which News he dicover'd uch an extraordinary joy, as would have peruaded me that he lov'd me above his own life, though I had not been o fully aur'd of
it as I was. He appointed a Ball for me, and invited all the Gallantry of the City to it: but to his misfortune and mine, there happen'd to be at it a Neapolitan Count, whom ome affairs of importance had brought into Spain. He thought me handome enough to fall in love with, and having enquired what quality my Father was of, he went, and, without any other ceremony, demanded me of him in marriage. My Father, dazled at the wealth and quality of this Stranger, promis'd him what he deir'd, and that very day ent Don Carlos word, that he might forbear all further addrees to his Daughter, forbad me to receive his viits, and commanded me to look on the Italian Count, as the peron I hould be married to, as oon as he we • e return'd from Madrid. I diembled my affliction before my Father; but as oon as I was got alone, Don Carlos preented himelf to my imagination, as the mot aimable peron in the world. I reflected on all could be quarrel'd at in the Italian Count; I conceiv'd an implacable averion againt him, and I felt my elf o poes'd with the love of Don Carlos, that it was equally impoible for me to live without him, and to be happy with his Rival. My recoure was to my tears, but what remedy were they in o great a misfortune.

While I was in this ditraction, Don Carlos comes into my chamber, without firt demanding my permiion, as he was wont to do. He found me as it were diolv'd into tears, nor could he forbear his, though he eem'd willing to conceal what lay heavy on his oul, till he had
dicovered the true entiments of mine. He cat himelf at my feet, and taking me by the hands, which he bedew'd with his tears, I mut then looe you Sophia! and a tranger, whom you hardly know, hall be happier than I, becaue he is omewhat richer. He will be poes'd of you, Sophia! and you conent thereto; you, whom I have o infinitely lov'd; you, who would peruade me that you lov'd me, and were promis'd me by a Father, but alas! an unjut Father, an interes'd Father, and one that hath baely recoyl'd from his word! If you are, continu'd he, a Jewel that may be et at any price, 'tis onely my fidelity that can purchae you, and it is upon the account of that, you hould be yet mine rather than any Man's; if you have not forgotten that you have promied me the like. But, cries he, do you imagine that a peron who had the courage to raie his deires to you, wants it to be reveng'd of one you prefer before him; or will you think it trange, that a Wretch who hath lot all hould not undertake any thing? If you are content that I alone hould perih, this fortunate Rival hall live, ince he is o happy as to pleae you, and you think him worthy your protection: but Don Carlos, who is now become odious to you, and whom you have given over to his depair, will dye of a Death cruel enough, to atiate the hatred you have for him.

Don Carlos, reply'd I, do you joyn forces with an unjut Father, and a peron whom I never could fancy, to perecute me, and impute • o me, as a particular crime, a misfortune
which is common to us both? You may rather bemoan than accue me, and bethink your elf of the means to preerve me yours, than pierce my oul with undeerv'd reproaches. I could make more jut ones to you, and force you to acknowledge, that you never ufficiently lov'd me, ince you never ufficiently knew me. But we have no time to looe in fruitles remontances. Carry me where you pleae, I'l follow you, and therefore I give you leave to attempt any thing, and promie to econd you in it, o that I may ever be yours.

Don Carlos was o reviv'd at thee words, that he was as much tranported with joy, as he had been before with grief. He begg'd a thouand pardons for his having charg'd me with the injutice he thought done him, and having atisfy'd me, that unles I were remov'd thence, it was impoible I hould avoid complying with my Father's will, I referr'd my elf wholly to his dipoal, and promis'd him, that the econd night after, I would be ready to go along with him. Don Carlos pent the next day in etting his affairs in order, made proviion of Money, and a Bark, which was to et ail, whenever he ent orders to that purpoe. In the mean time I made up all my Jewels, and what Money I had, and, being a peron o young as I was, o well diembled my deign, that no body had the leat upition of it. I was not oberv'd by any, o that I might afely take my way out at the Garden-door, where I found Claudio, a Page, whom Don Carlos had a kind of fondnes for, upon the account of his skill in Singing,
which was as excellent as his Voice, and that in his manner of peaking, and all his actions, he dicover'd a greater pitch of ingenuity, undertanding, and gentilenes of carriage, than the condition of a Page is commonly oberv'd to have. He told me, that his Mater had ent him before, to conduct me to the Bark, and that he could not come himelf, for ome reaons I hould know when I aw him. A Slave of Don Carlos, whom I alo knew very well, oon after came to us. We got out of the City without any trouble, and were not gone far from it ere we perceiv'd a Veel in the Road, and oon after a Shallop that waited for us at the Wateride. They told me, that my dear Don Carlos would come very uddenly, and that in the mean time, I hould go to the Veel. The Slave carry'd me into the Shallop, and everal Men, whom I had oberv'd on the hore, and took for Mariners, forc'd Claudio alo to get into the Shallop, who eem'd to make ome reitance, to avoid coming into it. This added to the trouble I was already in, for the abence of Don Carlos. I ask'd the Slave where he was; he roundly anwer'd, I was not to expect any Don Carlos there.

In the mean time, I could hear Claudio crying out as loud as he could, and burting forth into tears, aying to the Slave, Treacherous Amet! is it thus thou keep't thy promie with me, and, by removing my Rival out of the way, leav't me with my Lover? Imprudent Claudio! replies the Slave, is a Man oblig'd to keep his word with a perfidious peron, or could I expect,
that one that hath betray'd his own Mater, hould not erve me the like trick, by giving notice to thoe who have the over-ight of the Coats, to make out after me, and deprive me of Sophia, whom I love beyond my own Life?

Thee words poken to a Woman, whom I took all the while to be a Man, and whereof I could not undertand the meaning, caus'd me o great an affliction, that, I fell down in a manner dead in the arms of the perfidious Moor, who had not tirr'd from me. I continu'd a good while in the wound, which, when I had recover'd, I found my elf in one of the Cabbins of the Veel, which was now got a good way to Sea. Imagine to your elf what depair I mut be in, finding my elf without my Don Carlos, and among the profeed enemies of my Religion, for I oon perceiv'd that I was in the power of the Moors; that the Slave Amet had abolute power over them, and that his Brother Zaides was Mater of the Veel. The inolent Villain no ooner aw me in a condition to hear what he might ay, but, in few words he told me, that he had a long time had an affection for me, and that his paion forc'd him to carry me thus away by violence, and to bring me to Fez, where it hould be my own fault, if I were not as happy as I might be in Spain, as it hould be his, if I there had any occaion to regret the los of Don Carlos. I made a hift to cloe with him, notwithtanding the weaknes I was in by reaon of my former wounding, and, by a vigorous attempt, which he thought not off, and which, as I told you before, I had learnt when I
was a child, I drew out his Cymitar, and had punih'd him for his perfidiounes, if his Brother Zaides had not eaonably laid hold on my arm, and o av'd his Life. It was no hard matter to diarm me, for, having mis'd my blow, I forbore making any further vain attempts, againt o great a number of enemies. Amet, who had been frightned at my reolution, order'd all to withdraw out of the room where he had dipos'd me, and left me in an affliction not eaily to be imagined, after the cruel change which had happened in my fortunes. I pent the whoe night in bemoaning my elf, nor did the next day bring any remiion of my grief. Time, which m • ny times alleviates uch troubles, could do nothing on mine, inomuch that the econd day after our etting out to Sea, I was in a greater ditraction, than I had been that unlucky night, when, with my liberty, I lot the hope of ever eeing Don Carlos again, and ever having a minute of enjoyment while I liv'd. Amet had found me o terrible, when ever he preum'd to appear before me, that he came no more into my ight. At certain times, omewhat w • s brought me to eat, but I o obtinately refus'd it, that the barbarous Moor began to fear he had brought me away to no purpoe.

In the interim, the Veel had pas'd the Streight, and was not far from the Coat of Fez when Claudio comes into my Cabbin. As oon as I perceiv'd him, unhappy micreant, who hat thus betray'd me, aid I to him, what had I done to thee, that thou hould't make me the mot wretched peron in the world, and deprive
me of Don Carlos? You were too much belov'd of him, replies he, and ince I lov'd him as well as you did, I have committed no great crime, in endeavouring to remove a Rival, as far as I could from him: but if I have betray'd you, Amet hath alo betray'd me, and I hould haply be no les troubled than you are, did I not find ome comfort in this conideration, that I am not mierable alone. Prethee, let me undertand thee riddles, aid I to him, and know who thou art, and, conequently, whether I have, in thee, a Friend or an Enemy.

Know then, Sophia, aid he to me, that I am of the ame Sex as your elf, and, as well as you, I have alo been in love with Don Carlos; but if we have uffer'd by the ame flame, it hath not been with the ame ucces. Don Carlos hath ever lov'd you, and hath ever believ'd, that you lov'd him; whereas, on the contrary, he never lov'd me, nor could ever imagine that I hould love him, as having not known me to be what I truly was. I am of Valentia, as you are, and my quality and fortunes are uch, that if Don Carlos had married me, he needed not to have fear'd the reproaches made to thoe who under-ally themelves. But the affection he had for you wholly took him up, and it eems he had eyes onely for you. Not but that mine did what they could, to ave my mouth the labour of making a hameful dicovery of my weaknes. I went to all places where I thought to meet him; I plac'd my elf where he might ee me, and I did all things for
him, which he hould have done for me, had he lov'd me, as I lov'd him. I had the dipoal of my elf and etate, as having been left an Orphan while I was yet very young; and there were often propos'd to me matches equal to my condition, but the hope I till cherih'd, that I might at length engage Don Carlos to love me, hindred me from complying with any. Intead of being dicourag'd by the unhappy fate of my love, as any other would, who, as I, had ufficient perfections not to be lighted, I was the rather excited to the Love of Don Carlos, by the difficulty I found to ininuate my elf into his affections. In fine, to avoid the elf-reproach, that I hould neglect any thing which might promote my deign, I caus'd my hair to be cut, and having diguis'd my elf in Man's cloaths, I got my elf preented to Don Carlos by an old menial Servant of my own, who went under the name of my Father, a poor Gentleman of the Mountains of Toledo. My countenance and Meen your Lover lik'd o well, that he was oon induc'd to take me into his ervice. He knew me not again, though he had een me o many times, and he was as oon atisfy'd with my ingenuity as taken with my voice, and my skil in inging, and playing on all thoe intruments, on which perons of Quality may, without diparagement, divert themelves. He oon found in me thoe endowments which are not commonly een in Pages, and I gave him o many demontrations of my fidelity and dicretion, that he treated me rather as a Confident, than a Dometick ervant. You know
bet of any, whether I am to be credited in what I ay. You have a hundred times commended me to Don Carlos, even in my preence, and done many good offices, but what vex'd me to the heart, was, that I receiv'd them from a Rival, and while they made me more acceptable to Don Carlos, they render'd you the more hateful to the unhappy Claudia, (for o I am called.) In the mean time, the treaty of your marriage went forward, my hopes backward; that was concluded, thee were lot. The Italian Count, who, about that time, fell in love with you, and whoe Titles and Etate as much dazled your Father's eyes, as his warp'd countenance and his imperfections gave you occaion to light him, procur'd me at leat the pleaure, to ee you a little travers'd in your loves, and my oul began to flatter it elf with thoe fond hopes, which the unfortunate are over-apt to derive from viciitude. In fine, your Father preferr'd the Stranger, whom you fanci'd not, before Don Carlos whom you did. So I aw her, who caus'd my unhappines, in her turn, unhappy her elf, and a Rival whom I hated, more unfortunate than my elf, ince I lot nothing in a man, who had never been mine, whereas you lot Don Carlos, who was wholly yours, and yet that los, how great oever it might be, was haply to you a leer misfortune, than to have, for your perpetual Tyrant, a man, whom you could not love.

But my properity, or, to ay better, my hope, prov'd not long-liv'd. I undertood from Don Carlos, that you were reolv'd to follow him, and I was employ'd to et things in order to
the deign he had to carry you to Barcelona, and thence to cros over into ome part of France or Italy. All the force I had had till then to endure my cros fortune, left me upon this o harp an aault, it being a reolution I was the more urpriz'd with, the les I had apprehended • ny uch misfortune. The trouble I conceiv'd thereat cat me into a icknes, and that confin'd me to my bed. One day, as I was bemoaning my ad detiny, and that my preumption of not being overheard by any made me break forth into as loud expotulations, as if I had poken to ome Confident, who knew the ecret of my loves, I perceiv'd tanding before me the Moor, Amet, who had heard me. Having recover'd the trouble his unexpected preence had put me into, head-dres'd himelf to me in thee words.

I know thee very well, Claudia, and that even before thou hadt diguis'd thy ex, to become a Page to Don Carlos; and that I never dicover'd this my knowledge of thee, proceeded hence, that I had a deign as well as thou hadt. I have heard what deperate reolutions thou art ready to take; thou wilt dicover thy elf to thy Mater to be young Maid deeply in love with him, and yet hopet not any from him, and then thou wilt kill thy elf in his preence, o to deerve the regrets of him, whoe love thou couldt not gain. Wretched Las! what will be the effect of thy own elf-murther, but to give Sophia a further aurance of her Don Carlos? I have a better advice for thee, if thou art able to to take it. Deprive thy Rival of her Servant; it may eaily be done, if thou credit me, and though
it requires much reolution, yet no more than thou hat already expres'd, in putting on man's habit, and hazarding thy honour, to atisfie thy love. Hear me then attentively, continu'd the Moor, I will acquaint thee with a ecret, which I never dicover'd to any, and if thou liket not what I hall propoe to thee, it will be at thy own choice, whether thou follow it or not. I am of Fez, a peron of quality in my Country; my misfortune made me lave to Don Carlos, and Sophia's beauty, hers. I have told thee much in few words. Thou think't thy miery remediles, becaue thy Lover carries away his Mitres, and is bound for Barcelona. 'Tis both thy happines and mine, if thou cant make thy advantage of the opportunity. I have treated about my ranome, and paid it. A Galeot of Africk waits for me in the road, not far from the place where Don Carlos hath one ready for the execution of his deign. He hath put it off for one day; let us prevent him with as much diligence as ubtilty. Go and tell Sophia from thy Mater, that he hould make ready to come away this night, at the time thou halt come for her; conduct her to my Veel; I will carry her into Africk, and thou halt continue alone at Valentia, to enjoy thy Lover, who haply would have lov'd thee as oon as Sophia, had he but known that thou hadt lov'd him.

At thee lat words of Claudia, I was o overcome with grief, that with a deep igh, I fell into another wound, without any igns of life. The out-cries of Claudia, who haply then began to repent her that he had made me o unfortunate,
yet was nevertheles uch, brought Amet and his Brother into the room where I was. They appli'd all the remedies they could, till at lat I recover'd, and might hear Claudia till reproaching the Moor with his perfidiounes. Infidel Dog! aid he to him, why hat thou advis'd me to reduce this Beauty to the deplorable condition thou ee't her in, if thou hadt no mind to leave me with the peron I lov'd? And why hat thou caus'd me to commit againt a peron o dear to me, a treachery which proves as hurtful to me as to him? How dar't thou ay thou art of noble birth in thy Country, when thou art the mot perfidious and baet of all men? Hold thy peace, imple Maid, replies Amet, reproach me not with a crime, wherein thou art my Complice. I have already told thee, that he, who could betray a Mater as thou hat done, very well deerv'd to be betrai'd, and that taking thee along with me, I onely ecure my own life, and haply Sophia's, ince he might have di'd of pure grief, upon the knowledge of thy taying behind with Don Carlos.

At thee words, the noie made by the Marriners, who were ready to enter into the Port of Salley, and the hooting off of ome Guns, which were anwered by the Artillery of the Port, interrupted the reproaches reciprocally made to one the other, by Amet and Claudia, and for a while eas'd me of the ight of thoe two odious perons. We got a-hore; Claudia and I had veils put over our faces, and we were lodg'd with the perfidious Amet, at a Moor's, one of his kindred. The next day, we were
dipos'd into a cloe Chariot, and conducted to Fez, where, if Amet were receiv'd by his Father with much joy, I came in, the mot afflicted and mot deperate peron in the world. For Claudia, he oon provided for her elf, renouncing Chritianity, and marrying Zaides, brother to the treacherous Amet. The wicked woman us'd all the artifices imaginable to induce me to change my Religion, and to marry Amet, as he had done Zaides, and o he became the mot cruel of my Tyrants, even while, after they had in vain tri'd to draw me in by kindnes, fair promies, and treatments, Amet and all his people exercis'd on me all the barbarim they could. My contancy was ufficiently exercis'd againt o many enemies, and I was more able to endure my troubles than I could have wih'd my elf, when I began to imagine that Claudia repented her, that he had been o wicked. Before others he eem'd to perecute me with greater animoity than any, but privately he did me ome good offices, which made me look on her as a peron who might have been virtuous, had her education been accordingly.

For one day, while all the ret of the women were gone to the publick Baths, as you Mahumetans are wont to do, he came to me, and finding me very ad, he poke to me to this purpoe. Fairet Sophia! I have heretofore thought I had ome reaon to hate you, but now that hatred is at an end, ince I have lot the hope of ever enjoying him, who lov'd not me enough, becaue he lov'd you too much. It
grieves me to the oul, that I have occaion'd your misfortune, and foraken my God, for fear of men. The leat of thee tings were enough to make me undertake things beyond my ex. I can no longer live at this ditance from Spain, and all the Chritian part of the world, with thee Infidels, among whom I know it is impoible I hould ever work out my alvation either here or hereafter. You may aure your elf of my repentance by the ecret I hall acquaint you with, which putting my life at your dipoal, you may revenge your elf of all the michiefs I have been forc'd to do you. I have corrupted fifty Chritian Slaves, mot Spaniards, and all perons fit to undertake ome great enterprie. With the mony I have ecretly given them, they have ecur'd a Bark ready to waft us over into Spain, if it pleae God to favour o o good a deign. All you have to do is to joyn fortunes with me, and o ecape if I do, or, perihing with me, get out of the hands of your cruel enemies, and put a period to o unfortunate a life as yours is. Reolve therefore, Sophia, and while we cannot be upected guilty of any deign, let us, without los of any time, conider of the mot important action of your life and mine.

I cat my elf at Claudia's feet, and meauring her by my elf, I never quetion'd her incerity. I was at a little los to give her ufficient thanks, and aure her of the great reentments I had of the favour which I conceiv'd he would do me. We appointed a day for our ecape, towards a place on the Sea-ide, where
he told me that our Bark lay, under certain Rocks. The day, which I thought would prove o happy, came; we very happily got out of the houe and City. I admir'd the goodnes of Heaven in the eaines we found in compaing our deign, and I inceantly bles'd God for it. But the end of my misfortunes was not o near as I thought it. Claudia did all this by order from the perfidious Amet; nay, exceeding him in perfidiounes, the end of her bringing me to uch a olitary place, and that in the night time, was onely to leave me to the violence of the Moor, who durt not have attempted ought againt my chatity in his Father's houe, who, though a Mahometan, was yet a morally honet man. I innocently follow'd her, who led me to detruction, and I thought I hould never be ufficiently thankful to her, for the liberty I was in hope ere long to obtain by her means. I could not be weary of giving her thanks, not yet of going a good pace, in rough ways encompas'd with rocks, where he told me that her people expected her, when hearing a certain noie behind me, and turning my head, I perceiv'd Amet with his Cymitar drawn. You infamous Slaves, aid he, is it thus you run away from your Mater? I had not the leiure to anwer him.
