Claudia held my hands fat behind, and Amet letting fall his Cymitar, came up to the Renegado, and both of them together did what they could to bind my hands with cords, which they had provided for that purpoe. Having a greater trength and activity than women commonly have, I a good while reited the attempts of thoe two
wicked perons: but at length I grew weak, and my onely recoure was to my cries, which might draw ome paenger into that olitary place, where I rather hoped not for any relief, when Prince Mulei came in to my recue. You have heard how he av'd my honour, nay I may ay my life, ince I had auredly died of grief, if the detetable Amet had had his deires on me.

div.p:
Thus did Sophia conclude the relation of her adventures, and the amiable Zoraida encourag'd her to expect from the generoity of the Prince, that ome coure would be taken for her return into Spain; whereupon he acquainted her Husband with all he had heard from Sophia, whereof he afterwards gave Prince Mulei an account. Though all that had been related to him of the fortunes of the fair Chritian, flatter'd not the paion he had for her, yet was he glad, being a peron nobly inclin'd to vertue, to receive ome knowledge thereof, and find that her affection was engag'd in her own Country, that o he might not attempt a cenurable action out of a vain hope of finding it eaily compas'd. He had an eteem for the vertue of Sophia, and was inclin'd, by his own, to endeavour a remiion of her misfortune. He ent her word by Zoraida, that he would give order for her return into Spain, when he pleas'd, and, having once taken that reolution, he forbore to viit her, out of a ditrut of his own vertue, and the beauty of that amiable peron. She was not a little troubled to find out a ecure way for her return. 'Twas omewhat a tedious voiage into Spain, whoe Merchants traded not to Fez, and though he might have met with a Chritian veel, yet
being fair and young, as he was, he might find, among thoe of her own Religion, what he had been afraid to meet with among the Moors. Honety is not often found aboard a Ship; incerity is as little oberv'd there as in War, and whereever beauty and innocence are at the weaket, the inolence of the wicked will not fail to take its advantage to thrut them to the wall. Zaraida advis'd Sophia to put on Man's cloaths, ince her advantageous Stature, beyond that of other Women much further'd her diguie. She told her it was the advice of Prince Mulei, who knew not any peron at Fez, to whom he might afely trut her, and he told her withall, that he had had the goodnes to provide for the afety of her Sex, by aigning her a companion of the ame, of her own faith, and diguis'd as her elf, and that o he might avoid the diquiet it would be to her, to ee her elf alone, aboard a Veel, among Souldiers and Mariners.

Prince Mulei had bought of a Pyrat a Prize which he had taken at Sea; 'twas a Veel belonging to the Governour of Oran, which had aboard her the whole family of a Spanih Gentleman, whom the Governour, upon ome digut, ent over a Prioner into Spain. Mulei had heard that the aid Gentleman was one of the bet Huntmen in the world, and Hunting being an exercie the Prince was mot of any inclin'd to, he would needs have him to be his Slave, and to make the more ure of him, would not have him eparated from his Wife, his Son, and Daughter. In the pace of two years that he liv'd at Fez, in the Prince's ervice, he taught him how he might take any thing
with a Gun, whether it were on the Earth, or in the Air, and hew'd him everal other Games unknown to the Moors. By thee ways, he had o ininuated himelf into the Prince's favour, and was become o neceary in his divertiements, that he would not hear of any Ranome for him, but endeavour'd by all the obligations he could lay on him, to make him forget his own Country. But the regret he conceiv'd, that he hould not once more ee it, put him into a melancholy, which oon after ended in his Death, to which it was not long ere his Wife follow'd him. Mulei felt a certain remore, that he had not et him at Liberty, together with his relations, ince they had by their Services deerv'd it, and o reolv'd to repair, towards their Children, the injury he thought he had done the Parents. The Daughter was named Dorotea, much about the ame Age with Sophia, handome and witty. Her Brother was not above fifteen years of Age, and his name Sancho. Mulei pitch'd on them to accompany Sophia, and took that opportunity to end them together into Spain. The buines was kept very ecret. Men's cloaths, according to the Spanih mode were made for the two Gentlewomen, and little Sancho. Mulei hew'd his magnificence in the great quantity of Jewels he betow'd on Sophia. He alo betow'd very noble Preents on Dorotea, which, added to thoe her Father had receiv'd from the Prince's liberality, made her a very coniderable fortune.

About this time, Charls the Fift was engag'd in a war in Africk, and had beieg'd the City of Tunis. He had ent an Ambaadour to Mulei to treat about the ranome of certain Spaniards, perons
of Quality, who had been cat away on the Coat of Morocco. To this Ambaadour did Mulei recommend Sophia, under the name of Don Fernand, a Gentleman of quality, who deir'd not to be known by his own name; and Dorotea and her Brother were to be his retinue, one as a Gentleman waiting on him, the other as Page. Sophia and Zoraida could not part without regret, and many tears were hed on both ides. Zoraida betow'd on the fair Chritian a Necklace of Pearl, o rich, that he would not have receiv'd it, if the obliging Moor, and her Husband Zulema, who had as great a kindnes for Sophia as his Wife, had not aur'd her, that he could not dioblige them in any thing o much, as the refual of that pledge of their friendhip. Zoraida made Sophia promie, that he hould hear from her, by the way of Tangiers, Oran, or ome other places which the Emperour was poes'd of in Africk.

The Chritian Ambaadour took Shipping at Salley, having along with him Sophia, whom we mut henceforth call Don Fernand. He came to the Emperour's Army, while it was yet before Tunis. Our diguis'd Spanih Lady was preented to him as a Gentleman of Andaluia, who had ome time been a Slave to the Prince of Fez. She had no great reaon to be o fond of her Life, as to be afraid of engaging in the War, and being now to act the part of a Cavalier, he could not, in honour, avoid the performance of duty, as other gallant Perons did, whereof the Emperour's army was full. She thereupon lited her elf among the Volunteers, mis'd no deign that was
undertaken, and ignaliz'd her elf upon all occaions, o as the Emperour came to hear much of the counterfeit Don Fernand. Nay, uch was her good Fortune, that he happen'd to be near him, when, in the heat of an engagement, wherein the diadvantage was on the Chritian ide, he fell into an ambucado of Moors, was foraken by his party, and encompas'd by the Infidels, and in all probability he had been kill'd there, his Hore having already receiv'd that fate under him, if our Amazon had not mounted him on hers, and, econding his Valour with unexpreible efforts, given the Chritians time to ee their error, and to come into the relief of the Valiant Emperour. So ignal an action was not unrecompened; the Emperour betow'd on the unknown Don Fernand a Commandery of Saint James, of a vat Revenue, and the Regiment of Hore of a certain Spanih Lord, who had been kill'd in the lat engagement. He alo betow'd on him the equipage of a peron of Quality, and from thenceforward, there was not a Peron in the whole Army more highly eteem'd or more coniderable than this Valiant Virago. All the actions of Man were o natural to her; her Countenance was o fair, and made her eem o young; her Valour was o admirable, conidering her youth; and her Prudence and Conduct o remarkable, that there was not any Peron of quality or command in the Army, but courted her Friendhip. It is not therefore much to be admir'd, if, all pleading for her, but epecially her noble and heroick Actions, he came in a hort time to be her Mater's greatet Favourite.

About this time, there came over ome Recruits from Spain, in thoe Veels which brought over Money and Ammunition for the Army. The Emperour would needs ee them himelf in their Arms, accompany'd by the chiefet Commanders, among whom was our Amazon. Looking very earnetly on thee Recruits, he imagin'd that he had een Don Carlos, nor was he mitaken. She could not be at ret all that day; he ent to find him out among the new Levies, but he could not be found, in regard he had chang'd his name. She lept not all night, got up with the Sun, to find out, her elf, that dear Lover which had cot her o many tears. She found him, and was not known by him, he being grown omewhat Taller, and the ultry heat of Africk having a little chang'd the Complexion of her Countenance. She pretended to take him for another of her acquaintance, and ask'd him what news from Sevil, and how uch a peron did, naming the firt came into her mind. Don Carlos told her he had mitaken him, that he had never been at Sevil, and that he was of Valentia. You are extremely like a peron I lov'd very well, ays Sophia, I would ay Don Fernand, and for that reemblance I will be your friend, if you find in your elf no averion to become mine. The ame reaon, replies Don Carlos, which obliges you to proffer me your friendhip, had already enur'd mine to you, if it be worth your acceptance. You are omewhat like a peron I have a long time been in love with; you have her Countenance and Voice, but you are not of the ame Sex, and certainly, added he, with a deep igh, you are
not of her Humour. Sophia could not forbear bluhing at thoe words of Don Carlos, which he took no notice of, haply by reaon his eyes, which began to be moitened with tears, could not well perceive the alterations of Sophia's countenance. She was troubled, and not able at the preent to diemble it, he deir'd Don Carlos to come to her Tent, where he would expect him, and o left him, after he had decrib'd his Quarter, and told him that he was known in the Army by the name of Don Fernand, one of the

At the hearing of that, Don Carlos was afraid he had not render'd him the repect due to his Quality. He had already heard what eteem he was in with the Emperour, and that he was as much in favour with him as any about the Court. He oon found out his Quarter and Tent, which any one could direct him to, and he was as well receiv'd by him, as a imple Cavalier could expect to be, by one of the chiefet Field-Officers. He again imagin'd he dicover'd Sophia's countenance, in that of Don Fernand; was more atonih'd at it, than he had been before, and that much more at the ound of his Voice, which entred into his very Soul, and there renew'd the remembrance of that peron, for whom, of all the world, he had had the greatet affection.

In the mean time, Sophia, undicover'd by her Lover, entertains him at dinner, which done, he commands all the Servants to with-draw, and, having given order that none hould viit her, was told a econd time, by that Gentleman, that he was of Valentia, and afterwards very patiently heard him relate what he knew as well as himelf
of their common adventures, to the day that he intended to have carried her away. Could you imagine, Sir, aid Don Carlos to her, that a Gentlewoman of uch Quality, who had receiv'd o many aurances of my Love, and had given me as many of hers, hould be wanting in point of fidelity and honour; hould have the ubtilty to mother uch great failings, and be o blinded in her choice, as to prefer, before me, a young Page I had, who carried her away from me, the day before I hould have done it. But are you fully convinc'd it is o, ays Sophia to him. All things are in the dipoal of Chance, which ometimes is in an humour to confound our ratiocinations, by uch effects, as we leat expect. 'Tis poible, your Mitres may have been forc'd to that eparation from you, and, it may be, is rather unfortunate, than chargeable with any micarriage. O that it were the pleaure of the Gods, replies Don Carlos, I could make the leat quetion of it, I hould comfortably endure all the loes and misfortunes it hath caus'd me; nay, I hould not think my elf unfortunate, could I but imagine that he were till faithful to me; but he is onely uch to the perfidious Claudio, and never pretended love to the wretched Don Carlos, but to ruine him. Me-thinks, it may be inferr'd from what you ay, replies Sophia, that you never had any great affection for her, when your charge againt her is without your hearing what he may have to alledge for her elf, and you repreent her, not onely as an uncontant, but alo as a wicked peron. And could any one have been
more wicked than he hath prov'd, cries Don Carlos, when, to elude the upition of having been carried away by the Page, he left in her Chamber, the very night he vanih'd from her Father's, a Letter, writ with the greatet malice imaginable, which hath reduc'd me to more enible mieries, than that it hould ever get out of my memory. When you have heard it, you will haply be able to judge what Sycophancy o young a Thing could be guilty of.

body.head: THE LETTER.
body.p:
YOu hould not have forbidden me to love Don Carlos, after you had once laid your commands on me to do it. A merit o great as his must needs have rais'd in me an affection for him proportionable thereto, and when the mind of a young Peron is prepoes'd with uch a paion, it is o fill'd, that there is no place for interest. Know then, that I go hence with him, whom you were pleas'd I hould affect, even from my Infancy, and without whom it were as impoible for me to live, as it would be, not to dye a thouand times a day, with a Stranger, whom I cannot any way fancy, even though he were much richer than he is. Our offence, if it be any, deerves your pardon; which if you grant us, we will return
to receive it, with greater peed, then we are now forc'd to, to avoid the unjut violence you would do us.

p.q:
You may eaily imagine, continu'd Don Carlos, the extreme grief which Sophia's Parents conceiv'd at the reading of this Letter. They were in hopes I might be till with their Daughter, either in Valentia, or not far from it. They dicover'd not their los to any but the Vice-roy, who was their kinman, and it was hardly light the next morning, when ome Officers coming into my room found me aleep. I was, as well I might, very much tartled at uch a viit, and when, after they had ask'd me where Sophia was, I alo made the ame quetion to them, my adveraries were incens'd, and violently dragg'd me to prion. I was examin'd, and could make no plea for my elf againt Sophia's Letter. It was clear, that I had a deign to have carried her away; but it appear'd withal, that my Page had vanih'd at the ame time with her. Sophia's Parents ent people to find her out, and my friends, on the other ide, made diligent earch where the Page might dipoe of her. This was the onely means to clear me; but we never could hear any thing of thee fugitive Lovers, whereupon my enemies charg'd me with the death of them both. At lat, injutice, back'd with power, carri'd it againt oppres'd innocence. Notice was given me that I hould oon receive my entence, and that it would be that of death. I hoped not that
Heaven would do any miracles on my • ccount, and o I thought it my bet way to endeavour the recovery of my liberty by an act of depair. I join'd my elf to certain Bandits, who were prioners as well as my elf, and all perons of reolution. We forc'd the Prion-doors, and, aited by our friends, got into the Mountains about Valentia, ere the Vice-roy had any notice of our ecape. We continu'd a long time Maters of the Field. Sophia's incontancy, the proecution of her friends, the injutice I thought done me by the Vice-roy, and, in fine, the los of my etate, put me into uch depair, that I hazarded my life in all the engagements wherein my Camerades and my elf met with any reitance, and by that means I got into uch reputation with them, that they made me their Chief. I behav'd my elf in that charge o uccesfully, that our Party became dreadful to the Kingdoms of Arragon and Valentia, and we grew o inolent, as to impoe a Contribution on thoe Countries. I here make a dangerous dicovery to you, but the honour you do me, and my own inclination do o far enlave me to you, that I am willing to put my life into your hands, by acquainting you with the greatet ecrets of it. At lat, I grew weary of that leud coure of life; I got away from my Camerades, when they leat upected I hould, and took my way to Barcelona, where I was entertain'd onely as a private Gentleman, in the Recruits ready to be tranported into Africk, which have ince joyn'd with the Army. I have no great reaon to be in love with my life, and having been guilty of uch a miexpence
thereof, I cannot employ it better than againt the enemies of my Religion, and to erve you, ince the goodnes you are pleas'd to expres towards me, hath given me the onely joy, my oul hath been capable of, ever ince the mot ungrateful woman in the world hath made me the mot unhappy of all men.

div.p: Sophia, undicover'd, took the part of Sophia unjutly accued, and omitted nothing that might induce her Lover to forbear judging his Mitres o rigorouly, till he were more fully atisfi'd of her offence. She told the unfortunate Cavalier, that he concern'd her elf very much in his misfortunes; that he wih'd it in her power to alleviate them, and to give greater expreions thereof than words; that he deir'd him to accept of a relation to her, and when occaion erv'd, he would employ all the credit he had with the Emperour, and the interet of all her friends, to recue him from the proecution of Sophia's, and the Vice-roy of Valentia.

Don Carlos would not admit of any thing urg'd by the counterfeit Don Fernand, in the vindication of Sophia, but accepted of the entertainment he proferr'd him. That very day, that contant Mitres poke to the Commander, under whom Don Carlos was, that, being a kinman of hers, he might be under her command. Thus is our unfortunate Lover receiv'd into the ervice of his Mitres, whom he thought, either dead, or had foraken him. He finds himelf, as oon as entertain'd, very highly in his favour whom he thought his Mater, and wonders how he comes, o uddenly, to be o much lov'd. He is immediately made his
Treaurer, Secretary, and Confident. The ret of the ervants repect him little les than Don Fernand himelf, and no doubt he might be happy, in the love of a Mater that eems o amiable to him, and whom a ecret intinct forces him to love, if lot Sophia, if uncontant Sophia, did not perpetually preent her elf to his imagination, and gave him a adnes, which the carees of o dear a Mater and his better'd fortune were not able to mother. Though Sophia had a tendernes for him, yet was he not dipleas'd to ee him troubled, not doubting but he was the caue of his affliction. She often dicours'd with him concerning Sophia, and ometimes with o much earnetnes, nay indignation and bitternes, vindicated her whom Don Carlos charg'd with no les a crime than a forfeiture of faith and honour, that at lat he imagin'd, that Don Fernand, who would be till harping on the ame tring, had ometime been a Servant to Sophia, and haply was till.

The war in Africk came to the period mention'd in the Hitory thereof. The Emperour carri'd it on afterwards in Germany, Italy, Flanders, and other places. Our Female Warriour, under the name of Don Fernand, added to the reputation he had before of a valiant and experienc'd Commander, by many gallant encounters, wherein he hew'd no les valour than conduct, though the latter of thoe qualities be eldom found in a peron o young, as her ex made her appear. The Emperour was oblig'd to go into Flanders, and, to that end, to deire the King of France to give him paage through his Countries. The great Monarch who then reign'd, would needs, in generoity and
confidence, urpas a mortal enemy, who had ever urpas'd him in good fortune, whereof he had not at all times made good ue. Charls the Fifth was receiv'd into Paris, as if he had been King of France. The fair Don Fernand w • s one of the mall number of perons of quality, who accompani'd him; and if his Mater had made a longer tay in that gallant Court, the beautiful Spanih Lady, taken for a man, had rais'd love in many of the French Ladies, and jealouie in ome of the mot accomplih'd Courtiers.

In the mean time, the Vice-roy of Valentia dies in Spain. Don Fernand, encourag'd by the affection his Mater bore him, and the ervices he had done, preum'd to demand that important charge, and obtain'd it, without much envy. He oon acquainted Don Carlos with the good ucces, and put him in hopes, that, as oon as he had taken poeion of the Government of Valentia, he would accommodate the difference between him and the Relations of Sophia; procure his pardon from the Emperour for having been chief Commander among the Bandits, and endeavour to put him into poeion of his Etate.

Don Carlos might have deriv'd ome comfort from all thee noble promies, had not the misfortune of his Love made him abolutely diconolate. The Emperour came into Spain, and went treight to Madrid, and Don Fernand went to take poeion of his Government. The next day after his arrival at Valentia, Sophia's Relations preented a Petition againt Don Carlos, who was Steward and Secretary to the Vice-Roy. The Vice-Roy promis'd them jutice, and Don Carlos,
that he would protect his innocence. A new Indictment was put in againt him; the Witnees were examin'd a econd time, and, in fine, Sophia' Relations, exaperated at the los of her, and out of a deire of revenge, which they conceiv'd jut, olicited the buines o earnetly, that, in five or ix days, it was ready for judgment. They deir'd that the peron indicted might be ent to prion; the Vice-roy gave them his word, that he hould not tir out of his houe, and et down a day to pas judgment on him.

The eve of that fatal day, which held the whole City of Valentia in upence, Don Carlos deir'd a private audience of the Vice-Roy, which was granted him. Cating himelf at his feet, May it pleae your Highnes, aid he to him, to morrow is the time, that you are to atisfie all the world of my innocency. Though the witnees I have produc'd abolutely clear me of the crime laid to my charge, yet I now come to aure your Highnes with as much incerity, as if I were in the preence of God, that I had not onely no hand in the carrying away of Sophia, but withal, that, the day before he was carried away, I did not o much as ee her, nor ever heard of her ince. True it is, that I hould have carried her away, but a misfortune, to me yet unknown, remov'd her hence, either to my ruine, or her own.

No more, no more, Don Carlos, ays the Vice-Roy to him, go thy ways, and take thy ret ecurely; I am thy Mater and Friend, and better inform'd of thy innocence than thou dot imagine; nay, though I might doubt of it, yet hould
I not be oblig'd to be too exact to atisfie my elf, ince thou art in my houe, and of my houe, and that thou camet not hither with me, but upon the promie I made to protect thee. Don Carlos rendred his thanks to o obliging a Mater with all the eloquence he was mater of. He went to bed, and the impatience he was in to ee himelf clear'd, would not uffer him to leep. He got up at the break of day, and having dres'd himelf omewhat above his ordinary gath, waited at the riing of his Mater. But hold a little, I am mitaken, he went not into his chamber till all his cloaths were on; for from the time that Sophia had diguis'd her ex, onely Dorotea, the confident of her diguie, lay in her chamber, and did all thoe ervices, which done by another might have dicover'd what he would have kept conceal'd. Don Carlos therefore entred into the Vice-Roy's chamber, as oon as Dorotea had open'd it for all viitants; and the Vice-Roy no ooner aw him, but he reproach'd him with his early riing, being a peron accus'd, who would have himelf thought innocent, and told him, that a peron who could not leep betrai'd omething that lay heavy on his concience. Don Carlos a little troubled, made him anwer, that it was not o much the fear of being found guilty, as the hope of defying the further proecutions of his enemies, by the jutice he expected from his Highnes, that had hindred him from leeping. But you are very nearly dres'd, and gallant, ays the Vice-Roy to him, and I find you very calm, conidering your life is in o great a hazard. I am now at a los what to think of the crime wherewith you tand
charg'd. As often as we fall into dicoure concerning Sophia, you peak of her with les earnetnes and more indifference than I do; and yet I am not charg'd, as you are, to have ever been lov'd by her, and to have murther'd her, and poibly young Claudio too, on whom you would cat the charge of her conveyance away. You affirm'd that you have lov'd her, continu'd the Vice-Roy, and yet you live after you had lot her, and you have omitted nothing that could be done in order to your dicharge and quiet, you, who hould rather be weary of your life, and hate whatever might tend to the preervation of it. Ah! uncontant Don Carlos, it mut needs be that ome other Love hath induc'd you to forget the inclinations you had for lot Sophia, if o be you ever truly lov'd her, when he was wholly yours, and durt do any thing for your • ke.

Don Carlos, half dead at thee words of the Vice-Roy's, would have made ome reply thereto, but he would by no means permit him, Come, come, hold your peace, aid he to him, with a evere countenance, and reerve your eloquence for your Judges; for my part, I hall not be urpriz'd therewith, nor, on the account of one of my menial ervants, raie in the Emperour an ill opinion of my integrity. And therefore in the mean time, added the Vice-Roy, turning to the Captain of the Guard, let him be ecur'd; he, who broke prion, may much rather his promie, when he finds there are no other hopes of impunity, than what may be had by an ecap • .

Immediately Don Carlos's Sword was taken from him, which rais'd a great compaion in all thoe who aw him encompas'd by the Guards, cat down and dicourag'd, and having much ado to keep in his tears. While the poor Gentleman was repenting himelf, that he had not been ufficiently ditrutful of the uncontant humour of Grandees: the Judges, before whom he was to be tried, entred the room, and took their places, after the Vice-roy had taken his. The Italian Count, who had continu'd all this time at Valentia, and the Father and Mother of Sophia appear'd, and produc'd their witnees againt the Prioner, who was now at uch a los, that he hardly had the courage to plead for himelf. They hew'd him the Letters which he had ometimes written to Sophia; the Neighbours were brought in, and the Dometicks of Sophia's houe, and at lat there was produc'd againt him the Letter he had left in her Chamber, the day he had deign'd to carry her away. The Prioner brought in his Dometicks, who depos'd, that they had een their Mater in Bed; but he might have got up after he had made them believe he was aleep. For his own part, he wore very liberally, that he had not carried away Sophia, and repreented it to the Judges, that it was the mot improbable thing in the world, that he hould carry her away, oon after to be eparated from her: but a further charge againt him was, that he had murther'd her, and alo the Page, the confident of his Loves. There remain'd only to pas the Sentence, and no doubt it would have been that of death, when the Vice-roy order'd him to approach, and poke to him in thee words.

p.q: Unfortunate Don Carlos! Thou mait well conclude, after all the demontrations of affection thou hat received from me, that, if I could have but upected thee guilty of the crime laid to thy charge, I hould not have brought thee to Valentia. There's no way for me but to condemn thee, unles I would begin the exercie of my charge by an Injutice, and thou mait judge how much I am troubled at thy misfortune, by the tears I hed for thee. 'Twere poible thy adveraries might be atisfy'd, were they of a lower quality, or les reolv'd upon thy detruction. In a word, if Sophia appears not her elf to vindicate thee, prepare thy elf for death.

div.p:
Don Carlos, at this, depairing of all afety, cat himelf at the Vice-roy's feet, and aid to him, Your Highnes may be pleas'd to remember, that, in Africk, even from the firt time I had the honour to be entertain'd into your ervice, and whenever your Highnes engag'd me in the tedious relation of my misfortunes, I ever related them in the ame manner, and you might preume, that, in thoe Countries, and all other places, I hould not have affirm'd to a Mater, who o highly honour'd me with his affection, what I hould here deny before a Judge. I ever told your Highnes the naked Truth, as incerely as to my God, and I tell you till, that I lov'd, that I ador'd Sophia; How! ay that thou ador't her, ungrateful Man? ays the Vice-roy to him, urpriing all the Aembly by his Action. Yes, I do adore her, replies Don Carlos, very much astonih'd at what the Vice-roy had
poken. I promis'd to marry her, continu'd he, and we agreed together, that I hould carry her away to Barcelona. But if I did effectually convey her hence, if I know where he is, let me be put to the mot cruel death can be imagin'd. I cannot avoid it; but I hall dye innocently, unles it may be aid I have deerv'd death, for loving, even beyond my own Life, an uncontant and perfidious creature. But what is become of this perfidious Creature and thy Page, cries the Vice-roy, with a furious countenance? Are they gone up into Heaven? Are they unk down under the Earth? The Page was a Gallant; replies Don Carlos, he was handome; he was a Man, he was a Woman. Ah Traitor! aid the Vice-roy to him, how hat thou now dicover'd thy bae upitions, and the little eteem thou hadt for the unfortunate Sophia! Cured be the Woman that uffers her elf to be cajoll'd by the promies of Men, and comes afterwards to be lighted for her credulity! Neither was Sophia a Woman of ordinary virtue, wicked Man! nor thy Page Claudio a Man. Sophia was contant to thee; and thy Page was a ditracted Woman in love with thee, and robb'd thee of Sophia, whom he betray'd as a Rival. I am Sophia, unworthy, ungrateful Lover! I am Sophia, who have uffer'd unimaginable mieries, for a Man, that deerv'd not to be lov'd, and one who thought me guilty of the greatet infamy I could fall into.

Sophia could ay no more, her Father, who knew her, took her into his arms. Her Mother fell into a wound, on the one ide; and Don Carlos
on the other. Sophia di-engag'd her elf from her Father, to go to the relief of the two perons who had wounded, but oon recover'd themelves, while he was in upence to whether of the two he hould run. Her Mother wept over her, he did the like over her Mother. She embrac'd, with all the tendernes imaginable, her dear Don Carlos, who had almot fallen into another wound. But with much • do he kept upon his feet, and not preuming yet to kis Sophia's lips, as he could have wih'd, he reveng'd himelf on her hands, which h • kis'd a thouand times one after another. Sophia was hardly able to return all the embraces he receiv'd, and all the complements that were made to her. The Italian Count, making his among the ret, would have entertain'd her with the pretenions he had to her, as having been promis'd him by her Father and Mother. Don Carlos, who heard him, quitted one of Sophia's hands, which he was then greedily kiing, and drawing his Sword, which had been deliver'd to him, et himelf into uch a poture, as put the whole aembly into a fright, and wearing after the rate of millions, made it appear, that no human force hould deprive him of Sophia, if he her elf forbad him not to think of her. But he declar'd, that he would never have any other Husband than her dear Don Carlos, and entreated her Father and Mother to conent thereto, or reolve to ee her hut up in a Monatery for the remainder of her Life. Her Parents gave her liberty to make her own choice, and the Italian Count took Pot that very day, for Italy, or ome other place where he had a mind to go.

Sophia dimis'd not the Aembly, till he had g •••
• hem a relation of her adventure • , which w •••
• dmir'd by all. A peron was dipatch'd awa • expres to carry the news of this miracle to the • mperour, who continu'd to Don Carlos, after he • married. Sophia, the Vice-ro • alty and Government of Valentia, and all the kindnees which that Virago had deerv'd under the name of Don Fernand, and betow'd on that happy Lover a Principality, which his Poterity enjoys to this day. The olemnities of the Nuptials were extraordinary, dicharg'd by the City of Valentia; and D • rotea, who put on Man's cloaths at the ame time as Sophia, was alo, at the ame time, married, to a Cavalier, a near Kinman to Don Carlos.

div.head: SCARRON's NOVELS.
The Rival-Brothers.
The Fifth Novel.
div.p:
DOrothea and Feliciana were the two mot beautiful and mot amiable Ladies of any about the famous City of Sevil; but though they had not been uch, their quality and great fortunes were o coniderable as might well engage all thoe, who were deirous to be advantageouly m • tch'd, to make their addrees to
them. It is not then to be doubted, but that, of Sutors, there was a pretty Catalogue, yet had not Don Manuel, their Father, declar'd himelf in favour of any man's pretenions, and Dorothea, who, being the elder, hould, by the coure of the Cards, be married firt, had, as well as her iter, been o reerv'd in her demeanour and actions, that the mot preumptuous of her humble Servants were in ome doubt, whether their ervices were kindly or unkindly received. Thee two Beauties never went publickly to Mas, but they were attended by a number of the greatet Gallants about the City, wherein the Miracle was, that o many different pretenions hould agree o well, and that in a upertitious Country young Gentlemen hould be guilty of any devotion, beides what they have for their Mitrees. Before they could get off their gloves to take a little Holy-water, other hands, ome fair, ome otherwie, betow'd on them more than they needed. Their fair eyes were no ooner off their Prayer-books, but they were the centre of I know not how many immodet looks: and every tep, as they went out of the Church, they had alutations to return.

But if they were thus importun'd with courthip in Churches, and publick places, where people conceive themelves oblig'd to oberve ome reerv'dnes, they wanted it not at home. For, their Father's houe being in the midt of a pacious plain, there pas'd not a day without ome of thoe divertiements, whereby Lovers would ininuate themelves into the favour of their Mitrees. And thee our young Ladies took the more kindly, in that they made that retraint, which the tyrannical
cutom of the Country impoes on their ex, the more upportable to them. In the day time, Cavalcades, Tilting, and uch exercies were their entertainment, every night everal orts of Muick. One d • y above the ret, there came in an unknown Peron who did uch things as atonih'd all the beholders, and had been particularly oberv'd by the two fair Siters, to be one o neatly made, as if nature had intended him for a pattern. Several Gentlemen of Sevil, who had known him in Flanders, where he had the command of a Regiment of Hore, invited him to make one at their port of Tilting, which he did, habited as a Soldier.

Not long after, there happened to be at Sevil, the ceremony of the Conecration of a Bihop. The Stranger we poke of before, who went under the name of Don Sancho de Sylva, came into that Church where it was to be performed, with everal others the greatet Gallants about the City, and the two fair Siters Dorothea and Feliciana de Monalvo were alo there among divers Ladies, all diguis'd, according to the mode of Sevil, with mantles of a thick tuff, and hats with plumes of feathers in them. It was Don Sancho's fortune to tand between the two Siters, and another Lady, with whom he would have enter'd into ome dicoure, but he civilly intreated him, to forbear peaking to her, and to reign the place he was in, to a peron he expected, to meet her there. Don Sancho compli'd with her deires, and thereupon turning about, he makes towards Dorothea d • Monalvo who tood nearer him than her Siter; and had oberv'd what complements had pas'd
between him and the other Lady. I was in hopes, Madam, aid he, addreing himelf to her, that, being a tranger in this place, the Lady to whom I would have poken, would have vouchaf'd me her converation; but he hath punih'd the confidence I had to think that mine was not to be lighted. I acknowledge my overight, and I hall be more ditrutful of my elf another time. And therefore, be you pleaed, Madam, to expres les rigour towards a Stranger, whom you have een treated with o much direpect, and, for the honour of the Sevillian Ladies, to give him occaion to make ome acknowledgment of their kindnes. You rather give me occaion to treat you with as much contempt as the other Lady did, replies Dorothea, ince your applications to me are the effects of her refual of them: but that you may not have too great caue to complain of the Ladies of this Country, I am content to dicoure onely with you, as long as this Ceremony hall lat, and thence, beides the kindnes you may conceive done to your elf, you may infer, that I have not appointed any one to meet me here. Being o excellent a peron as I imagine you to be, ays Don Sancho, I cannot forbear wondring at it, but mut withal conclude, that you are much to be fear'd, or that the Gallants of this City are very timorous, or rather that he, whoe place I have taken up, may be abent. And do you think, Sir, ays Dorothea to him, that I am o ignorant in the matter of loving, that, in the abence of a Gallant, I could not forbea • going to an Aem • ly, where I hould not • ail meeting with
ome other? Take heed another time how you pas o rah a cenure, of a peron you know not. You would find, Madam, replies Don Sancho, that what you call my Cenure is more to your advantage than you think, if you permit me to erve you anwerably to the inclinations I have for you. Our firt motions are violent, and therefore not always to be follow'd, ays Dorothea to him; beides there is a great difficulty in what you propoe to me. Not any o great, replies Don Sancho, but I hall be able to overcome, when the reward of it is to become your Servant. 'Tis not a deign to be compaed in few days, ays Dorothea; I find you a peron will be eaily tranported, in that you eem to have forgotten, that you onely take Sevil in your way to ome other place, and perhaps are yet to learn, that I hould not take it kindly any man lov'd me, en paant, that is, by the way. Be you but pleaed, Madam, aid he, to grant me what I deire, and I promie you not to go any further than Sevil while I live. There is a great deal of pirit and gallantry in what you ay, replies Dorothea, and thence I wonder much, that a peron who is able to ay uch things, hath not already made choice of a Lady, on whom he might betow his gallantries. Proceeds it hence that he thinks them not worth his trouble? No, but rather out of a ditrut of his own trength, ays Don Sancho. Anwer me preciely to what I ask you, ays Dorothea, and confidently tell me, which of our Ladies is Mitres of thoe charms that might force your tay at Sevil. I have already told you, that it is in your power to do it
if you pleae, replies Don Sancho. You never aw me, ays Dorothea; it mut needs be ome one that you have een, therefore name ome other. Since you pres o much upon me, ays Don Sancho to her, I mut acknowledge, Madam, that if the Lady Dorothea Monalvo were as ingenious as you are, I hould account that man happy, whoe merit he might value, and whoe ervices he might allow of. There are in Sevil many Ladies as handome as he is, nay many exceed her, ays Dorothea, both in beauty and wit; but ince you are pleas'd to pitch upon her, pray tell me eriouly, did you never hear it reported, that he favour'd any one of her Gallants particularly above all the ret? Finding my elf at a great ditance from deerving her, ays Don Sancho, I never made it my buines to enquire. And why do you think you might not deerve her as well as another, ays Dorothea? I took you to be a peron of greater courage than to betray o great a ditrut of your elf. Had you tudi'd Ladies as much as I imagin'd you might have done, you would have found them mighty humourome and fantatick, and that many times the firt onet of a new comer makes a greater progres in their affections, than everal years of ervices rendred by thoe Gallants, who are never out of their ight. From the character you give thoe Ladies, Madam, ays Don Sancho, I may infer you would be loath to be included in the number, and o you take an ingenious way to rid your hands of me, by encouraging me to love ome other Lady, and I clearly ee, you would have but little regard for the ervices of a
freh Gallant, to the prejudice of one to whom you had been long before engag'd, though 'twere out of no other reaon than that you would not be thought humorous or fantatick. Take heed how you entertain any uch thing in your imagination, replies Dorothea, but rather peruade your elf, that I am not o eaily induc'd to receive a witty complement for an aurance of a growing inclination towards me, from a peron who never aw me. If there wants onely that to make way for the amorous inclination I have for you, replies Don Sancho, conceal not your elf any longer, from a peron, who, though a tranger to you, is already infinitely taken with your wit. It's poible you might not be o much with my countenance, ays the Lady. Ah Madam, ays Don Sancho, it's impoible you hould be otherwie than very beautiful, when you o ingeniouly acknowledge that you are not; and now I am fully atisfi'd you would be rid of me, either, becaue you think me troubleome, or that your heart is already taken up. 'Twere therefore unjut, the goodnes oblig'd you to bear with me thus far, hould be any longer pres'd upon, onely be pleas'd to aure your elf, that what I have aid was not merely to pas away the time with you, but to make a incere proffer of that of my whole life to erve you. To atisfie you, Sir, replies Dorothea, that I would not have that thought lot which I have pent in dicouring with you, I hall be glad, ere we part, to know who you are. I can do no les than obey you, replies he; know then, Madam, whom I think o amiable, though I have not een, that I am
known by the name of Sylva; that my Father is Governour of Quitto in Peru; that by order from him I am come to Sevil; and that I have pent mot part of my Life in Flanders, where I have, by my Services, attain'd to the highet Commands in the Army, and gotten a Commandery of Saint James. This is a hort account of what I now am, what I would be while I live, it lies on you, Madam, to give me leave, in ome les publick place than this is, to aure you. That hall be as oon as I may conveniently do it, replies Dorothea; in the mean time, trouble not your elf to get any further knowledge of me, unles you will run the hazard of never knowing me for your friend: onely take this for your preent atifaction, that I am a peron of quality, and that my face is uch as will not frighten any body.

Don Sancho was atisfy'd, and having, with a low Congee, taken his leave of her, he thrut himelf in among a great number of fine Gallants, who were very eriouly dicouring together. There are a ort of evere Ladies, who may be more particularly known by the character I hall here give of them, to wit, uch as extremely concern themelves in the conduct and demeanour of others, and are very ecure as to their own; who imagine themelves the onely fit Judges of what is well or ill done, though there may be good wagers laid of their virtue, as a thing whereof there is no great certainty, and think that upon the dicovery of a little brutih rudenes, they m • y pretend to upererogation in point of Honour, though the micarriages of their greener years gave more
candal, than their wrinkles will ever good example; thee Ladies, I ay, who are very hort-ighted in the ordinary occurrences of humane Life, will take occaion to quarrel at the Author, and affirm, that Madam Dorothea was guilty of a great want of reerv'dnes, and indicretion, not onely in being o over-free to favour a peron whom he onely knew by ight, but alo in permitting him to peak to her of Love, and that if a young Gentlewoman, over whom they had any power, had done as much, he hould make no long aboad in this world. But let thee yet-to-be-taught Ladies learn from me, that every Country hath its particular cutoms, and that if in France, England, and ome other parts, married Women and Maids, who are truted to go any where upon the ecurity of their own good behaviour, are offended, or at leat hould be o, at any the leat expreion of Love; in Spain, where they are kept in as Nuns, they take it not amis that any one hould tell them they love them, though the peron that hould tell them o, had not any thing for which he might expect a return of his Love. Nay, they do much more, they are the Ladies commonly that make the firt overtures, and are firt taken, inamuch as they are the lat een, by their Gallants, whom they have the advantage to ee daily, in Churches, and other publick places, and ometimes from their Balconies and Chamber-windows.

Dorothea acquainted her Siter Feliciana with the dicoure had pas'd between her and Don Sancho, and made no difficulty to tell her, that he was more taken with that Stranger, than with all
the Gallants of Sevil, and her Siter approv'd the deign he had upon her Liberty. Thereupon the two fair Siters had a great deal of erious dicoure together, concerning the advantageous priviledges which the Men have above the Women, who were eldome married without the conent of their Friends, which many times happen'd contrary to their liking, whereas the Men were at liberty to make choice, where they bet fancied. For my part, ays Dorothea to her Sister, I am confident, Love hall never be able to make me do any thing contrary to my duty; but I am on the other ide fully reolv'd never to be married to a Man, who hall not alone be poes'd of whatever I could wih in everal others, and I had rather pend my Life in a Monatery, than in the company of a Husband I could not affect. Feliciana told her Siter, that he had taken the ame reolution, and they confirm'd one the other therein, with all the fine arguments, which their ingenuity could furnih them with, upon that occaion. Dorothea found it ome difficulty to make good the promie he had made Don Sancho, of dicovering her elf to him, and acquainted her Siter how much he was troubled thereat: but Feliciana, who was very fortunate in finding out expedients, put her Siter in mind, that a certain Lady, a Kinwoman of theirs, and one of their mot intimate friends (for all of ones Kinred are not uch) would do her all the ervice lay in her power, in a buines wherein her quiet was o much concern'd. You know, ays this best-natur'd Siter in the world, that Marina, who hath liv'd with us o ma •• years, is now married
to a Surgeon, who hath taken of our Kinwoman a little Houe adjoyning to her own, and that there is a common Entry between both. The place where they tand is a remote treet not much frequented, and though it hould be oberv'd, that we viited our Kinwoman oftener than we had been wont, there would be no notice taken of Don Sancho's going into a Surgeons, beides that the buines may be o contriv'd, that he may come thither onely in the night, and diguis'd.

While Dorothea, with the aitance of her Siter, was contriving how to compas this amorous interview; while he was dipoing her Kinwoman to erve her, and preparing Intructions for Marina, Don Sancho's thoughts were wholly taken up with the unknown Lady. One while he is in upence whether the promie he had made him, that he hould hear from her, were not an abue; another, he imagin'd, that there was omewhat in her lat words which dicover'd a certain kindnes towards him. He aw her every day, though he knew her not, in the Churches or ome other publick places, receiving the adorations of her Gallants, who were all his intimate acquaintance • , and the greatet friends he had in Sevil. He was one morning putting on his cloaths, his thoughts full of his unknown Mitres, when a me • ge was brought, that there was a woman deir'd to peak with him. Being conducted to his chamber, he receiv'd from her, this

p.hi: THat you heard not ooner from me, attribute not to any remiion of that kindnes I expres'd to you at our first meeting, but purely to want of convenience. If you still perist in a deire to be better known to me, receive directions from the Bearer, where you are to meet her in the evening, and he will conduct you to the place, where I hall be ready to receive you.

div.p:
It may be eaily imagin'd how gladly he entertain'd this meage, His tranportation was uch, that he could not forbear embracing that happy Ambaadres, and he preented her with a Gold chain, which, after ome ceremony, he receiv'd from him. She appointed him to meet her at a certain place in the dusk of the Evening, leaving him the mot atisfy'd, but withall the mot impatient man in the world. At lat night came; he went to the place where the morning Ambaadres expected him, trick'd up and perfum'd as if he had pent the whole day about it. He was conducted by her to a little obcure Houe, which look'd omewhat upitiouly, and thence into a noble large Room, where he found three Ladies, all veil'd. He dicover'd his unknown Mitres by her Stature, and immediately broke forth into complaints, that he would not vouchafe to unveil her elf. She taid not for any further intreaties,
whereupon he and her Siter uncovering their faces, Don Sancho knew them to be the fair Siters, Dorothea and Feliciana de Monalvo. You are now convinc'd, ays the Elder to him, taking off her Veil, that I told you but truth, when I aur'd you, that a Stranger might ometimes obtain that in a minute, which thoe Gallants whom a Lady ees every day hould not deerve in many years: but I would have you withall conider with your elf, that you will be the mot ungrateful of all Men, if you do not highly eteem the favour I hew you, or pas any cenure of it to my diadvantage, though I told you uch things might be the effect of a fantatick humour. I hall ever value what I receive from you, as if it were ent me from Heaven, ays the paionate Don Sancho, and you hall find, by the care I hall take to preerve the kindnes you do me, that if I ever loe it, it will not be my negligence, but my misfortune.

This harp onet was as eagerly puru'd on both ides, to the mutual atisfaction of the two Lovers; which the Mitres of the houe and Feliciana perceiving, took occaion to tand at a coniderable ditance from them, and o they had all the convenience they could have wih'd, to counter-charge one the other with amorous complements, and heighten the flames they had already rais'd in each other; nay, though the Love there was between them, might be accounted, conidering the little time of their acquaintance, very great, yet would they appoint another day, to make ome additionals thereto, if any might be admitted.
Dorothea promis'd Don Sancho that he would endeavour to ee him as often as he could: he return'd her his mot humble thanks, with all the Rhetorick he was mater of.

Upon this ceation of dicoure, the two other Ladies came up to them, and they fell into it afreh, and continu'd the kind engagement, o long, that Marina thought it time to mind them of their departure. Dorothea was troubled at that alarm, and Don Sancho grew pale and ilent; but there was a neceity of parting. The tranported Cavalier took occaion the next day, to write a Letter to his Mitres, and ent it by the common Ambaadres Marina, and he return'd him uch an Anwer thereto, as he could have wih'd. I hall forbear inerting their amorous Epitles here, becaue there never came any of them to my hands, and I am loath to foit in any of my own dreing, out of a fear they might not prove as good as theirs. They had many interviews afterwards at the ame place, and they pent the time, as they had done at the firt, and o by a continu'd progres, their Loves came up to that fervency, that, abating their not hedding their blood as Pyramus and Thisbe are recorded to have done, they were not behind them as to a violent tendernes one for another. 'Tis commonly aid, that Love, Fire, and Money cannot be long conceal'd. Dorothea, who was in a manner tranported with continual thoughts of her lovely Stranger, could not peak of him with any moderation, nay, he commended him o highly beyond all the Gentlemen of Sevil, that ome Ladies, who would have carried on their deigns ecretly as he did, hearing
her inceantly peaking of Don Sancho, and preferring him o as to cat a certain contempt on thoe they fancied, took-notice of it, and were offended. Feliciana had often privately advis'd her, to peak of him with more caution and reerv'dnes; nay, many times, in company, when he aw her tranported with the pleaure he took in dicouring of her Gallant, had trod on her foot o hard as to make her cry out, and find omewhat ele to talk of.

Thee dicoveries were at lat o oberv'd, that a certain Cavalier, a Suitor of Dorothea's, had notice given him thereof, by a Lady he was intimately acquainted with. He was the more eaily induc'd to believe, that Dorothea had a more than ordinary kindnes for Don Sancho, when he conider'd, that ever ince the coming of that Stranger to the City, thoe who accounted themelves the Slaves of that fair Lady, of which number he thought himelf the mot heavily chain'd, had not receiv'd the leat favourable look from her. This Rival of Don Sancho's was a peron of great wealth, decended of a noble Houe, and much in favour with Don Manuel, who yet was the more backward to pres his Daughter to m • rry him, in regard that when ever he poke to her of it, her anwer was, that he wanted two or three years of being ripe for that tate.

This ame young Gentleman (now his name comes into my head, Don Diego) before he engag'd himelf in an action which might be charg'd with imprudence, thought it requiite to be fully aur'd of a thing, which yet he did onely upect. He had a very pruce fellow that waited on him in
his Chamber, one of thoe inolent attendants who think it is for their Mater's credit that they wear as good Linnen as themelves, or at leat wear theirs; and all, that they may be the more gracious in the eyes of the waiting women. This Servant's name was Guzman; he pretended much to ingenuity, out of a conceit that it had been deriv'd to him from that Country-man of his, whoe adventures are o famous; but having, among other endowments, a mattering in Poetry, he employ'd his Talent in compoing uch Romances as in other Countries are known by the name of Ballads. He ung them playing on his Gitthar, but o wretchedly, that his wry mouths and the tretching out of his tongue, poil'd the dicord, at leat to thoe that look'd on him. He had alo the graceful knack of dancing a Saraband, and never went without his Catagnets. He had once ome intentions to turn Comedian, but omewhat in his humour was not lik'd, for he was very much addicted to Vapouring and Hectorhip, and to give you a true character of him, there was ome upition of his nocturnal atchievements, as being one who would bid people tand with as much confidence as a Contable, but with this greater civility, that he would dimis their perons, and ecure onely what he found about them.

All thee excellent Talents, heighten'd by a little eloquence, which reach'd onely o far as he had read, and what he heard from his Mater, made all the Waiting-women, even thoe who pretended to omewhat of Beauty, look on him as the blank (if I may make that comparion) of their amorous deires. Don Diego gave him intructions to
go and court Iabella, a young Maid who waited on the two beautiful Siters. He went, and ininuated himelf o far into Iabella's favour, that he thought her elf the happiet creature in the world, to be lov'd by Guzman, nay, the kindnes they had one for another grew to uch a degree, that he became very earnet in the continuance of what he had begun onely to obey his Mater. Iabella had o well feather'd her Net in her ervice, that he might well be accounted a good fortune, for the proudet attendant of any in Spain. Her Mitrees treated her very kindly, and were very liberal to her, beides omewhat he had to expect from her Father, who was an honet Trademan. In fine, Guzman thought it his bet coure to make ure of her, by propoing a match; he was as willing as he was, and took him at his word; they made one another mutual promies of marriage, and ever after liv'd together as if the ceremonies had pas'd between them.

Things tanding thus, Iabella began to conceive an extream indignation againt Marina, the Surgeon's wife, at whoe houe Don Sancho and Dorothea had their private meetings, and it troubled her much, that though he had liv'd with her Mitres before her, he hould till be her Confident in a buines of that nature, wherein the liberality of a favour'd Lover is very coniderable. She had heard of the Gold chain which Don Sancho had betow'd on Marina, as alo of everal other preents he had made her, and imagin'd he might have receiv'd many more, which he knew nothing of. This rais'd a deadly hatred in her againt Marina, which makes me think, that the
pretty Gentlewoman was not a little troubled. It is not therefore to be wondred, if, upon the firt Interrogatories which Guzman made to her, and particularly this, whether it were true that Dorothea was in love with any one, he hould dicover the ecrets of her Mitres, to a peron, whom he look'd on as part of her elf. She acquainted him with all he knew of the deigns of our young Lovers, Don Sancho's liberality to Marina, whom he enrich'd by his continual preents, till at lat he broke forth into down-right railing at her, as one that made thoe advantages, which hould rather have been receiv'd by a Servant that liv'd in the houe. Guzman intreated her to give him notice of the next meeting they were to have there. She did o, and he fail'd not to give his Mater an account of it, as alo of all had been told him by the perfidious Iabella.

Upon this intelligence Don Diego put himelf into the habit of a Beggar, and laid himelf down in the treet not far from Marina's door, into which he aw his Rival enter, and not long after came a Coach, out of which alighted Dorothea and her Siter, and went into the ame Houe, leaving Don Diego in a great rage, to ee what he could not then remedy. He went home, and reolv'd to rid himelf of o formidable a Rival. Having hir'd ome of thoe, whoe profeion it is to murther any they are et upon, (a ort of people may be as eaily procur'd in Spain, as Porters in other places) he expected Don Sancho everal nights together, and at lat meeting with him, he et upon him, econded by two of thoe mercenary Hectors, as well arm'd as himelf. Don
Sancho, on the other ide, was reaonably well provided for them, as having about him, beides Sword and Poniard, a cae of Pitols charg'd. He defended himelf at firt as a Lion, and found that his enemies had this advantage of him, that they defi'd any thing he could do with his Sword. Don Diego pres'd upon him more than the others, who, being hir'd men, behav'd themelves accordingly. He retreated till all he could, to remove the noie of the engagement farther from the houe where his Dorothea was: but at lat fearing to endanger himelf too far, and finding Don Diego till violently puruing him, he dicharg'd one of his Pitols, upon which he fell down half dead, and call'd as loud as he could for a Confeor, and the two Hectors immediately vanih'd. Don Sancho got to his own lodging, and the neighbours came out into the treet and found Don Diego, whom they knew, ready to depart this life, and charging Don Sancho with his death. He had oon notice of it by his friends, who told him, that though he might clear himelf upon the judicial proceedings which might be brought againt him, yet Don Diego's friends would be ure to revenge his death, and find out ome way or other to kill him. He retir'd into a Monatery, whence he gave his Mitres an account how his affairs tood, and et all things in order to his departure from Sevil, as oon as he might do it afely. A trict earch was made for Don Sancho, but he could not be found. The heat of it being over, and all peruaded that he had made an ecape, Dorothea and her Siter, under pretence of ome Devotion, were conducted by their Kinwoman, at whoe houe they had met, to
the Monatery, where Don Sancho was, and there, by the means of one of the Religious men, the two Lovers had an enterview in a private Chapel. After ome dicoure, they made mutual promies one to the other of a contant fidelity, and parted with o much regret, and uch melting expreions, that her Siter, her Kinwoman, and the Religious man, who were witnees thereof, not onely wept then, but could never ince think of it without tears.

Having deliver'd certain Letters to his Father's factor, to be ent to him to the Indies, he left Sevil, in a diguie. In thoe Letters he acquainted him with the accident, which had occaion'd his departure from Sevil, and that he intended for Naples. He got well thither, and was nobly entertain'd by the Vice-Roy, who, among the many favours he did him, honour'd him with a near relation to his peron. But the main atisfaction was wanting, that of hearing from his dear Dorothea, o that within a year he grew weary of the kindnes of his entertainment, and wih'd for ome oppotunity to leave Naples. He expected not long; for the Vice-Roy being to end out a mall Squadron of ix Gallies againt the Turk, Don Sancho's courage would not let lip o fair an occaion to exercie it elf. He was receiv'd, to the great atisfaction of the Commander, who was glad to have a peron of his worth and quality abo • rd him. This Squadron of Naples met with eight Turkih G • llies, almot in ight of Meina, and eng • g'd them. After a long ight, the Chritian Gallies took three of the enemies, and unk two. The Admiral of the Chritian Gallies was engag'd againt that of
the Turks, which being better arm'd and mann'd t • an any of the ret, had accordingly made the greater reitance. In the mean time, the wind began • o rie, and the ea to grow rough, o that both Chritians and Turks thought it concern'd them more to ecure themelves againt the Tempet, than any further to proecute the Engagement. They jointly loos'd the Grapling-irons, whereby the two Gallies were fatned together, and the Turk • h Admiral parted from the Chritian, j • t • s Don Sancho had cat himelf into it, no • follow'd by any body. Finding himelf all alone amongt his enemies, he thought death to be preferr'd before lavery, and, what ever might be the conequence of it, cat himelf into the Sea, hoping to recover the Chritian Gallies by wimming. But the weather prov'd uch, that he could not be perceiv'd, though the Chritian General, who had been witnes of Don Sancho's action, and was extremely enrag'd at his los, which he thought unavoidable, caus'd the Gallie to tack about towards the place where he had cat himelf overboard. In the mean time Don Sancho made his way through the waves, and having wum a good way towards the hore, aited by the wind and tide, he fortunately lighted on a plank of one of the Turkih Gallies, and with the help of it got to land on the co • t of Sicily. Having return'd God his humble thanks for o great a deliverance, he made towards a little hamlet inhabited by ome poor Fiher-men, who gave him the bet entert • inment they could. The extraordinary actions he had done in the engagement, what he • ad uffer'd in the Sea, and the cold he endur'd, and his walking
afterwards in his wet cloaths, brought him into a violent feaver, which forc'd him to keep his bed for many days; yet at lat, without any trouble of Phyicians he recover'd his former health. During his icknes, he made a reolution to continue the world in the peruaion of his death; as well that he might be in les fear of his enemies, the Relations of Don Diego, as make a further trial of the fidelity of his Dorothea.

During the time of his aboad in Flanders, he had contracted an intimate friendhip with a Sicilian Marques, of the houe of Montalto, whoe name was Fabiano. He ent one of the Fihermen to Meina, where he liv'd, to enquire whether he were then in the Country; and anwer being brought him, that he was there, he went thither, habited as a Fiher-man, and, in the night, goes to the Marques's houe, who, with all others to whom he was known, bewail'd his death. The Marques was over-joy'd to meet with a friend, whom he had given over for lot. Don Sancho gave him an account how miraculouly he had ecaped, as alo of his adventures at Sevil, and particularly the violent paion he had for the Lady Dorothea de Monalvo. The Sicilian Marques proffer'd to go along with him into Spain, and to bring away Dorothea, if he would conent, into Sicily. Don Sancho was extremely well pleaed with the propoal, yet would not receive from his friend o dangerous demontrations of his friendhip, telling him, that he would be infinitely glad of his company into Spain, but for what might be the conequence of it, he would remit all to fortune.

Don Sancho had a ervant, of whoe fidelity he
• ad had many years experience. This fellow, whoe name was Sanchez, took his Mater's los o heavily, that when the Chritian Gallies, which had been in the former Engagement againt the Turks, put in at Meina, to refreh themelves, he came aho • e and got into a Monatery, with a reolution to • end the rem • inder of his days there. The Marque •
Fabiano h • ving heard of the relation <>
••• mes had to Don Sancho, ent to the Superiour of the Monatery, (who indeed had entert • in'd him upon the recommendation of that Sicilian Lord) deiring he might be dimis'd, which was eaily granted, in regard he had not yet put on the habit of the Religion Sanchez not knowing what might be the occaion of his dimiion, made ome difficulty to come out; but when he was brought into the preence of his dear Mater, his oul was too narrow for his joy, for having cat himelf at his feet, there was a neceity of ome aitance to help him up again.

Some days after, he was ent by Don Sancho into Spain, to make preparations for his coming thither, and particularly to give him an account of Doro • hea, who, in the mean time, was peruaded, with all others, that Don Sancho was dead. Nay the report of his death oon flew into the Indies. Don Sancho's father di'd out of grief, not long after he had receiv'd that ad news, and left another Son he had four hundred thouand Crowns, conditionally, that his Brother hould have the one moiety of that umme, in cae the news of his death hould prove fale. This Brother of Don Sancho's was called Don Juhan de Peralto. He took hipping for Spain, with this vat um of
mony, beides abundance of rare Indian commodities, utable to the magnificence of a peron, who had been Governour of a coniderable place in thoe parts, and arrived afely at Sevil, about a year after the accident, which had happened to Don Sancho. Going under a name much different from his Brother's, it was eaie for him to conceal the relation he had to him, beides the particula • concernment he had to keep it ecret, by reaon of the long tay his occaions might oblige him to make in a City, where his Brother had o many enemies. He chanc'd to have a ight of Dorothea, and fell in love with her, as his Brother had done, but with this difference, that he made him no return of his love. That afflicted Beauty could fancy nothing after the los of her dear Don Sancho: whatever was done by Don Juhan de Peralto, intead of pleaing, was the greatet trouble in the wo • ld to her, nay he daily refus'd the bet Matches about Sevil, which were earnetly propos'd to her by her Father Don Manuel.

Much about that time Sanchez comes to Sevil, and, according to the intructions he h • d receiv'd from his Mater, ecre • ly made the bet enquiry he could, how the Lady Dorothea had behav'd her elf, ince their departure thence. He was oon inform'd by common report, that a young Gentleman, of very great wealth, l • tely come from the Indies, was fallen in love with her, and made the mot magnificent dicoveries of his affection that a paionate Sutor could imagine. He writ to his Mater, repreenting things much wore than they were, and his Mater imagin'd them yet wore than his Man had repreented them. He
communicated the whole buines to the Marques, expreing o great a ditraction at the account he receiv'd of his Mitres, that he was in ome upence whether he hould ee her any more. His friend comforted him the bet he could, telling him, that it was not impoible but his man might be mis-inform'd, and that the affairs of his love might be in a much better poture than he expected. The reaons urg'd by the Marques, together with his own reflections on the mutual promies of fidelity that had pas'd between them, epecially the endearing expreions at their parting, dipell'd thoe clouds of upition, and repreented his Dorothea as faithful and contant to him as he had engag'd to be. They thereupon reolv'd for Spain, and embark'd themelves at Meina in ome Spanih Gallies, and in a hort time happily arrived at St. Lucar's whence they took pot for Sevil. They came into the City after night, and alighted at the houe which Sanchez had taken for them. They tirr'd not out all the next day, but as oon as it was night, Don Sancho and the Marques went their rounds, about the place where Don Manuel liv'd. They heard ome people etting their Intruments in tune, under Dorothea's windows, and oon after very excellent Muick, and that having ceas'd, a ingle Voice join'd to a Theorboe, made heavy complaints of the cruelty of a Tygres diguis'd into an Angel. Don Sancho felt ome temptations within himelf to poil all the harmony of the Serenade, and to end away the Muicians with fleas in their ears: but the Marques prevail'd with him to forbear, repreenting to him that he could have done no more,
if his Mitres had appear'd in the Balcony, to aure his Rival, that he was not dipleas'd with his Courthip; or the words of the Air, which had been ung, were acknowledgments of kindnees receiv'd, rather than complaints of a dis-atisfi'd Lover. The Author of the Serenade, and his Company, went away, in all probability, not over-atisfi'd with what they had done, as having not o much as the tirring of a dog, to aure them that any body regarded their Muick: and Don Sancho and the Marques, finding the coat clear, return'd to their quarters, where they had a long debate what contruction they hould make of the pretenions of this new Sutor. Don Sancho was inclin'd to a peruaion, that his Dorothea might have ome ecret kindnes for him, though, for ome reaons which hindred her from making any hew of it at that time, he eem'd to take no notice of his Courthip, epecially when he conider'd, that he might, with all the others, be aur'd of his death. On the contrary, the Marques entreated him to upend his belief of her being engag'd to any other, till he had made ome fuller dicoveries thereof.

p.U:
ubmitted to the remontrances of his friend, and that the rather, when it came into his mind, that the greatet expreions of cou • thip made by one, whoe peron is not affected, are o much the more importunate. And indeed o were thoe of the Indian Cavalier, to the fair Dorothea, who was o far from giving him any encouragement by her acceptance, that he could not but perceive they were more and more troubleome to her. Her Father Don Manuel was extremely deirous
to ee her dipoed in marriage, and he doubted not, but that if the Indian Cavalier, Don Juhan de Peralto, being a peron o well decended, and o wealthy, hould proffer himelf for a Son-in-law, he would be preferr'd before all others, and he more earnetly pres'd by her Father to accept of him than he had been.

div.p:
The next day after the Serenade, whereof the Marques Fabiano and Don Sancho had had their part, Dorothea took occaion to confer notes with her Siter, concerning Don Juhan, and his courthip, and told her, that he could not brook the gallantries of that conceited Indian, and thought it the tranget thing in the world, he hould make uch publick demontrations of his love to her, before he had made any overtures thereof of her Father. 'Tis uch a kind of procedure, ays Feliciana to her, as I hould never approve of, and if your cae were mine, I hould give him uch an entertainment, upon the firt opportunity that preented it elf, as might immediately dah all the hopes, he had conceiv'd of ever pleaing you. For my own part, continu'd he, I could never fancy his peron; he has not that delicacy, and ininuation of carriage, which is acquirable onely at Court, and the vat expences he is at here in Sevil, argue not o much the noblenes of his dipoition, as the extravagant and alvage humour of that yet unciviliz'd part of the world whence he came. It is oberv'd, that thoe parts of the world which u • ply us with gold and ilver, are mot barren as to the other productions of nature; o thoe people that inhabit them, think they need no other recommendation, than what
they derive from the entrails of certain almot inacceible Mountains, created onely for the punihment of Slaves and Malefactors. All your Servant's actions mell o trongly of the Indian, that he mut be allow'd ome years, to refine the barbarim of the Climate he hath liv'd in o long, before he can be reduc'd to the civility of this, wherein we have had our education. If ever you grant him the favour to peak to you, advie him to tudy the courting of a Lady after another manner then he hath been taught among the Topinambous, and then you may promie to hear what he hall have to ay for himelf.

This was partly the character he gave Don Juhan de Peralto, which he deliver'd with uch bitternes and deriion, that Dorothea could do no les than wonder at it. It eems the cornful young Lady had clearly forgotten, that upon his firt appearance at Sevil, he had confes'd to her Siter, that he lik'd him well enough, and when ever he had occaion to peak of him, he was as liberal of her commendations, as he was now of her reproaches. Dorothea oberving her Siter o much chang'd, or at leat eeming to be, as to the entiments he ometimes had for the Indian Cavalier, immediately imagin'd, that her inclination towards him might be the greater, the more earnet he eem'd to have it thought, that he had not any. To be more fully aur'd of it, he told Feliciana, that he was not dipleas'd with the gallantries of Don Juhan, out of any averion he had for his peron, nay, on the contrary, oberving in his countenance omewhat of the air of Don Sancho's, he might prefer him before any other
Cavalier about Sevil; beides he doubted not, but that, having all the advantages of birth and fortune, he would eaily get her Father's conent. But to what end, continu'd he, hould I fancy to my elf thee imaginary pleaures? I have lot Don Sancho, and ince it was not my fortune to be his wife, I am reolv'd never to be any other man's, and therefore, to avoid all future addrees, my onely coure will be to pend the ret of my days in ome Monatery. Ah Siter, ays Feliciana, though you were not fully reolv'd upon o trange a deign, yet could you not give me a tranger affliction than by telling me of it. That I am o reolv'd, Siter, you may be aur'd, replies Dorothea; but for your part, you have the les reaon to be troubled at it, in regard it will be to your advantage, for, by that means, you will be the mot coniderable fortune about Sevil. Upon this account it was, that I had a deire to ee Don Juhan, that I might peruade him, to addres that courthip to you, which he vainly betows on me, after I have convinc'd him of the impoibility there is, that we hould ever be married together. What may be the conequences of his applications to you, Time onely can dicover; Love is full of viciitudes, and there is not o great a ditance between affection and averion, but that one of them may tread on the heels of the other. Nay, to deal iterly, that is, freely, with you, I am not a little troubled, to find you expres o much of the latter, towards a peron, who is o far from deerving it, that he might jutly expect omewhat of kindnes from you, both as a Stranger, and
one that hath not run the the hazard of dipleaing you, by any preumptuous demontration of his love. Think what you pleae of my judgment in this cae, but this it is, that I do not ee any peron about Sevil, with whom you might he more advantageouly match'd than with him. I mut confes, I look on him, rather with a certain indifference than averion, ays Feliciana, and when I told you, that I could not fancy him, it was more out of complaiance to you, than any real prejudice I had againt him. Nay if it be o, Siter, replies Dorothea, you are rather to acknowledge, that you deal not ingenuouly with me, and that when you expres'd the little eteem you had for Don Juhan, it was clearly out of your mind, that you had ometime very highly commended him to me; or I am to conclude, that what you have aid ince, betrai'd not o much your own dilike of him, as your fear of his being too well lik'd by me.

Feliciana bluh'd at thee lat words of her Siter, and was vex'd to the heart. Her thoughts were in uch a ditraction, that he poke abundance of things, which rather betrai'd her guilt, then contributed ought to her vindication; o that at lat he was forc'd to confes, that he had a more than ordinary kindnes for Don Juhan. Dororothea encourag'd her to continue it, and promis'd to ait her all he could in the proecution of her love. Having thus brought her to acknowledge what he before but upected, he took compaion of her, and forbore all further reproaches.

That very day, Iabella, who had dicarded her beloved Guzman, ever ince the unhappy accident
that had happen'd to Don Sancho, receiv'd orders from her Mitres Dorothea, to go to Don Juhan de Peralto, deliver him the key of one of the garden doors of Don Manuel, to tell him, that he and her Siter would expect him there, with a charge, that he hould not fail to be at the place appointed, at mid-night, before which time, it was likely their Father would be abed. Iabella, who had been already corrupted by Don Juhan, and done all lay in her power, to bring him into her Mitres's favour, but to no purpoe, was extremely urpriz'd to ee her humour o chang'd, and not a little glad, to be the meenger of uch good news to a peron, of whom, though he had not brought him any before, he had yet receiv'd many great preents. No doubt then but he made all the hate he could to the lodgings of the amorous Cavalier, who had receiv'd o little encouragement before, that he could hardly have believ'd his own good fortune, had it not been for the convincing aurance of the key, which he deliver'd him. That key open'd a place it was never intended it hould, I mean the breat of the amorous Gallant, who preented his faithful Sollicitres with a perfum'd pure lin'd with a hundred good yellow pieces, which glorious ight rais'd in her as much fatisfaction as he had brought him.

Were there a contant current of good fortune, that is, no viciitude in humane affairs, and that what ever were fortunately begun might, without any rub or diater, be brought to its period of happines, there hould be much les work for thoe who write Romances and Novels, and o the world would be depriv'd of a great deal of that
pleaure which is deriv'd from endeavors of that kind.
