But their delight wholly coniting in a certain conflict, and interfering of unexpected accidents, 'tis likely there will be a contant upply of uch things, as long as mortals hall walk on this Mole-hill, as on a Ches-board, perpetually contriving how to cros the deigns of one another.

Whoever hall eriouly conider this grave advertiement, will not think it trange, that, the very ame night, Don Juhan was to come into Don Manuel's Garden, to meet with the two Siters, Don Sancho, accompany'd by his friend, the Marques, hould be walking their rounds about Dorothea's Lodgings, to be more fully atisfy'd of the deigns of his Rival. It was no otherwie, and it will ever be a maxim, That one man's misfortune makes another man's port. About eleven that night, the Marques and he being gotten into that treet, where Dorothea liv'd, four men well arm'd came up and poted themelves cloe by them. The jealous Don Sancho preently imagin'd it was his Rival, whereupon coming nearer them, he told them that the Pot they had taken up, was very convenient for him, in order to the compaing of a deign he was then engag'd in, and o deir'd them to quit it. We hould do it, Sir, reply'd one of them, without much intreaty, if the • me Pot, you are o deirous of, were not abolu •• ly neceary for the carrying on of a deign th • t we alo have, and will be o oon dip •• ch'd, that it will not much retard the execution of yours.

Don Sancho was as much enrag'd at this, as if
it had been the mot uncivil anwer that could have been given upon uch an occaion: to draw therefore, and to charge perons, whom he thought o diobliging, was the ame thing with him. That unexpected aault of Don Sancho's, urpris'd and put them into diorder, and the Marques behaving himelf no les gallantly than his Friend had done, they defended themelves o poorly, that they were in a trice beaten out of the treet. Don Sancho receiv'd a light wound in his arm, and run him who had given it him o heartily through the body, that it was a good while ere he could get out his Sword again, and doubted not but he had dipatch'd him. The Marques in the mean time was in puruit of the others, who ran away as fat as they could, as oon as they aw their Camerade laid on the ground.

Having rid themelves of thoe pies, Don Sancho look'd about him, and perceiv'd at one end of the treet ome people with a Light, coming up towards them, upon the noie of their engagement. He was afraid it might be the Magitrate with his Officers, and it was no other. He made all the hate he could into the treet, where they began to fight, and thence into another, in the midt whereof he met full but with an old Gentleman, who had a Lantern with him, and had drawn his Sword upon the noie which Don Sancho made by running towards him. The old Gentleman was Don Manuel, who had been at a Neighbour's houe at play, as he was wont to do every day, and was then going to his own, by the Garden-door, which was not far from the place where he met Don Sancho. He call'd out to the amorous Cavalier,
Who goes there? A man, replies Don Sancho, whom it concerns to make all the hate he can away, and therefore deires you would not hinder him. It may be, ays Don Manuel, there is ome accident happen'd, which obliges you to eek out for anctuary; fear nothing, my Houe, which is here hard by, may erve your turn. 'Tis very true, replies Don Sancho, I am omewhat at a los how to avoid the puruit of the Magitrate, who it may be is now making a earch for me; but ince you are o generous as to proffer me, though a Stranger to you, a reception upon o dangerous a core as this, I accept of your kindnes, and entrut you with my afety, with this promie, never to forget the favour you do me, and to pres it no farther, than till uch time as thoe who look after me are pas'd by.

They were by this time come to the Garden-door; Don Manuel open'd it with a Key he had about him, and having brought in Don Sancho, he dipos'd him into a cloe Arbour, while he went into the Houe to take order for his more ecret retirement, o as that none might know of his being there. Don Sancho had not been long in the Arbour, when he perceives coming towards him a Woman, who approaching poke oftly to him, O Sir, are you come, my Mitres Dorothea tays for you. From that word Don Sancho imagin'd that he might be in the houe of his Mitres, and that the old Gentleman, who had brought him in thither, was her Father. He preently upected that Dorothea had appointed his Rival to meet her there, and follow'd Iabella,
more tormented with jealouie, than troubled about the puruit of the Magitrate.

In the mean time Don Juhan came, according to his appointment, preciely at the hour aign'd him, opened the Garden-door with the Key he had receiv'd from Iabella, and went into the ame Arbour, out of which Don Sancho was but newly gone. He had not been there long, ere he perceives a Man coming treight towards him; he put himelf into a poture of defence, for fear he might be aaulted, and was not a little urpris'd, when he found that Man to be Don Manuel, who bid him follow him, auring him he hould be o dipos'd of, as that he need not fear being dicover'd. Don Juhan concluded from Don Manuel's words, that he might poibly have receiv'd into his Garden ome Gentleman puru'd by the Officers of Jutice. He could do no les than follow him, giving him thanks all along as they went for the favour he hew'd him: but it may be withall conjectur'd, that he was not o much troubled, at the hazard he was running into, as the obtruction whereby his amorous deign was diappointed. Don Manuel brought him into his own Chamber, and, having left him there, went out, and ordered a Bed to be made for himelf, in another room.

We will leave him lock'd up where he is, extremely troubled, yet not daring to make the leat dicovery of it, and ee, what is become of his Brother Don Sancho de Sylva. Iabella brought him into a Ground-room, which look'd into the Garden, where the two Siters Dorothea and Feliciana expected Don Juhan de Peralto; one, as a
Lover, whom he was very deirous to pleae; the other, to aure him that he could not have any kindnes for him, and to peruade him he would do better to make his applications to her Siter. Don Sancho enters the room where the two fair Siters were; they were frightned at his appearance. Dorothea tood like a tatue, as if he had not been able to tir from the place; but her Siter fearing he could not continue long in that poture, dipos'd her into a Chair, let he might have fallen down all along. Don Sancho after he had fix'd his Eyes on them, tuck to the place he was in: Iabella was ready to ink into the ground for fear, and imagin'd it might be the Ghot of Don Sancho, that appear'd to them, to revenge the injury his Mitres did him. Feliciana, though much tartled to ee him rien from the dead, was yet more troubled at what had happened to her Siter, who being come to her elf, Don Sancho took her by the hand, and made this dicoure to her.

p.q:
Ungrateful Dorothea! if the Report which hath been pread of my death did not in ome meaure excue your incontancy, the affliction I conceive thereat would not allow me Life enough to make you the deerv'd reproaches of it. I was willing the world hould be peruaded that I was dead, that I might be forgotten by my enemies, not by you, who had engag'd your elf not to love any other beides me. But how have you broken that promie! I ee there needs onely but a common Report of ome unfortunate accident, to make a Woman forget all engagements of fidelity, even to that peron,
whom, of all the world, he onely pretended to fancy. I might eaily be reveng'd, and make o great noie by my complaints and expotulations, as hould awake your Father, and give him directions how to find out the favour'd Gallant, whom you have dipos'd into ome ecret place about his Houe: but beotted Man that I am! I feel in my elf till a certain fear to dipleae you, and am more troubled at the neceity you give me, not to love you any longer, than at the dicovery I have made of your being in love with another. Make much of your dear Lover, O as fale as fair Woman! make much of him I ay, and fear no more diturbances in your enjoyments, for you hall ere long be rid of a Man, who might, while you liv'd, have reproach'd your proving treacherous to him, even while he hazarded his Life to wait on you.

div.p: With thee words Don Sancho would have quitted the room: but Dorothea tays him, and was going to vindicate her elf, when Iabella comes running in to tell her, that her Mater, Don Manuel, was coming after her. Don Sancho had onely time enough to get behind the door, and, while the Old man was chiding his Daughters that they had not been a-bed, and had his back towards the Chamber-door, made a hift to get out, and going back the ame way into the Garden, went into the ame Arbour where he had been before, and were preparing himelf for what ever might happen, he expected a favourable opportunity to make his ecape thence.

There are, no doubt, thoe, who think Love the
pleaantet thing in the world. But far is it from their imagination, that a Lover's contant courthips and adorations may at lat be requited with contempt, corns, frowns, and eluions, which require an extraordinary meaure of patience and good nature to endure them. Little do they apprehend, that a young Spark, after many years continu'd addrees, even when he thinks himelf as it were within a barrs length of felicity, may, by ome unexpected obtructions and diappointments, be tumbled into eternal digrace, and all this occaion'd, not o much by any backwardnes of his Mitres, as his own unhappy miapprehenions.

Thee were the reflections of the unfortunate Don Sancho, while Don Manuel was gone into his Daughter's chamber to fetch a Light, to bring in the Officers who were imperiouly knocking at the Garden-door, upon the information they had receiv'd, that Don Manuel had entertain'd into his Houe one of thoe who had been fighting in the treet. Don Manuel made no difficulty to let them in, to earch his Houe, out of an aurance they would be o civil as not to look into his own Chamber, and that the Gentleman whom they expected to find, was afely lock'd in there. Don Sancho perceiving out of the Arbour, that it was impoible for him to ecape the earch of o many Officers as were catter'd up and down the Garden, comes out to Don Manuel, and whipers him in the ear, that a peron of Honour would be more tender of his promie then to abandon one whom he had taken into his protection. Don Manuel, who was much urpris'd to find him there, entreated
the chief Officer, to leave Don Sancho, in his cutody, till the next morning; which requet was oon granted him, as well out of a repect to his quality, as for that the party, whom Don Sancho imagin'd he had kill'd, was not very dangerouly wounded.

The Officers, having receiv'd omewhat towards a morning's draught, took their leave, and departed; and Don Manuel, having dicover'd by the ame dicoure which had pas'd between him and Don Sancho, when he firt met him, that he mut needs be the peron whom he had receiv'd into his Garden, doubted not, but that the other was ome Gallant, brought into the Houe, either by Iabella, or his Daughters. To be more fully atisfy'd of it, he conducted Don Sancho de Sylva into a room by himelf, and deir'd him to tay there till he return'd again. He went to that place where he had left Don Juhan de Peralto, to whom he told a feign'd tory, that his man was come into the Houe along with the Officers, and waited below to peak with him. Don Juhan knew that his man lay very ick at that time, and not in a condition to come to him, though he had known where he was, which he did not. He was therefore omewhat troubled at what Don Manuel had aid to him, and o he had no other anwer to make him, than that his m • n hould go and tay for him at his Lodging.

By this dicoure and ome others Don Manuel found him to be that young Gentleman lately come from the Indies, who was o much talk'd of about Sevil, and, being ufficiently inform'd as to his quality and etate, reolv'd, he hould not go
out of the Houe ere he had married that Daughter of his, to whom he had ever o little addres'd himelf. He pent ome further time in dicoure with him, to be more fully atisfy'd as to ome doubts, which then burthen'd his mind. Iabella tood all the while at the door, and over-heard them, and gave an account of all to her Mitrees. Don Manuel had a glimpe of her, and imagin'd he was come with ome meage to Don Juhan, from one of his Daughters. He left him, to run after her, jut as the Wax-light, which was in the room, being at an end, went out of it elf. While the Old man is groping to find out Iabella, he acquaints Dorothea and Feliciana, that Don Sancho was in their Father's chamber, and that he had een them talking together. The two Siters ran thither upon her word, Dorothea being not afraid to find her dear Don Sancho with her Father, reolv'd, as he was, to acknowledge, that he lov'd him, and that he had been lov'd by him, and withall to tell him, upon what motives he had appointed Don Juhan to come thither that night. She therefore goes into the room, which was without any light, and having met with Don Juhan, jut as he was coming out, he took him for Don Sancho, and having him fat by the arm, he thus expotulated with him. Why dot thou avoid me, tygre-hearted Don Sancho! and why wouldt thou not what anwer I hould make to the undeerv'd reproaches thou hat made me! I mut confes, thou could't not bethink thy elf of any too great for me, if I were as guilty as thou hat ome grounds to imagine: but thou art not to learn, that there
are ome fale things, which have many times more likelihood of truth than truth it elf, and that this latter is ever dicover'd by time. Allow me but o much, as may hew thee that which will recover thee out of the confuion, in which thy own misfortune, and mine, and haply that of divers others, hath involv'd us both. Ait me to vindicate my elf, and run not the hazard of being unjut, by an over-hatines to condemn me, before thou hat found me really guilty. 'Tis poible thou mait have heard, that a certain Gentleman loves me; but hat thou heard that I made any return to his love? Thou mait have met him here; for it is true, that his coming hither was by my appointment; but when thou halt undertand what deign I had in it, I am confident thou wilt have a cruel remore, that thou hould't injure me, while I give the greatet aurance of fidelity I could. O that this importunate and troubleome Servant of mine were here before thee! thou houldt find by the treatment I gave him, whether he ever had any ground to affirm, that I lov'd him, nay, whether he could ever o much as tell me that he lov'd me, or that I ever vouchaf'd even the reading of any Letter that came from him. But that misfortune of mine, which always procur'd me the ight of him, when it hould prejudice me, will not permit me to ee him, when he might help to undeceive thee.

Don Juhan had the patience to uffer Dorothea to peak, without offering to interrupt her, that he might learn omewhat more than he had yet
dicover'd to him. But perceiving he had given over, and expected ome return from him, he was going to give her a harp anwer, when Don Sancho, who was looking for the way into the Garden, and heard Dorothea peaking to Don Juhan, comes up cloe to her, making the leat noie he could, yet not o as but that he was perceiv'd by Don Juhan and the two Siters. They had not the time to peak one to another, ere Don Manuel comes into the room with a Light, which ome of his Servants carried before him. The two Rival-Brothers look'd one on the other, and were oberv'd to be in a poture ready to fall one upon the other, as having their hands on the hilts of their Swords. Don Manuel teps in between them, and commanded his Daughter to make choice of one of them for her Husband, that he might fight with the other. Don Juhan told him, that for his part he was ready to quit all manner of pretenions, if he might have any, and ubmitted himelf to the Cavalier he aw before him. Don Sancho aid the ame thing, with this addition, that ince Don Juhan had been brought into Don Manuel's houe by one of his Daughters, it was probable they had a mutual affection one for the other, and that for his part, he would rather dye a thouand times, than enter into the tate of Matrimony with the leat cruple. Dorothea cat her elf at her Father's feet, beeeching him to give her audience, and he hould know how all things tood. She related to him all that pat between her and Don Sancho de Sylva, before he had, in her quarrel, kill'd Don Diego. She acquainted him that Don Juhan de Peralto fell afterwards in love
with her; as alo with the deign he had engag'd her elf in, to undeceive him, and to advie him to demand her Siter in marriage, and at lat concluded her dicoure with this protetation, that if he could not atisfie Don Sancho her innocency, and the continuance of her affection to him, he would that very day enter into a Monatery, whence no peruaions in the world hould ever get her out again.

Don Sancho was oon atisfy'd with the account Dorothea had given of her fidelity towards him, and immediately demanded her in marriage of Don Manuel. By ome paages of her dicoure concerning Don Juhan, particularly by the time of his firt appearance at Sevil, the place whence he came in the Indies, and the Relations he had there, the two Rival-Brothers came to know one the other. Don Juhan finding alo by ome circumtances of Dorothea's dicoure, the affection which her Siter Feliciana had for him, humbly addres'd himelf to her, auring her that if he till perited in the ame entiments, he hould think himelf the happiet man in the world. He thereupon demanded her in marriage of Don Manuel, who receiv'd them both for his Sons-in-law, with a atisfaction that cannot well be expres'd.

As oon as it was day, Don Sancho ent for the Marques Fabiano, who came to participate of his friend's joy, after he had pent the night in ditracted thoughts what hould have become of him. The whole buines was kept ecret, till Don Manuel and the Marques had dipos'd a Couin of Don Diego, to whom his Etate, upon
the other's Death, had faln, to forget his Kinman's misfortune, and accommodate himelf with Don Sancho. During this negotiation, the Marques fell in love with a Siter of that Gentleman's, and demanded her of him in marriage. He gladly entertain'd a propoal o advantageous to his Siter, and thereupon was content to accept of any thing they could offer on the behalf of Don Sancho. The three marriages were olemnized the ame day, with o great content of all parties, as was not onely remarkable at that time, but continu'd many years after.

div.head: SCARRON's NOVELS.
The Inviible Mitres.
The Sixth Novel.
div.p:
DON Carlos of Arragon was a young Gentleman of an illutrious Family, well known in Spain under that name; his peron uch, that a curious eye might have oberv'd omewhat in him trancending all decriptions of the mot elaborate Romances, yet not comparable to the noble accomplihments of his mind.
But what comes more particular to the character we have to give of him, is, that, at certain Showes, wherewith the Vice-Roy of Naples entertain'd the populace, upon accaion of the Nuptial olemnities of Philip, the econd, third, or fourth, of Spain, (I cannot now well call to mind) he did things beyond their belief, who onely receiv'd them by relation. The next day after a famous Tilting, at which he had behav'd himelf with uch gallantry, as rais'd no les atonihment in the beholders, than indignation and hame in thoe who ventur'd at a trial of their addres in the ame exercie, the Ladies obtain'd a permiion of the Vice-Roy, to go about the City diguis'd, and mask'd after the French mode, for the convenience of uch Strangers as thoe magnificencies had brought thither from all parts of the Kingdom. That day, Don Carlos put on the richet cloaths he had, and went, among many others, who, as o many Cockatrices, intended to murther all the Ladies they look'd on, to a Church, where mot of the Gallantry were to meet. Where be it oberv'd by the way, that Chritian Churches may be prophan'd, as well in thoe Countries which profes mot obedience to the holy See, as in others, and in tead of being us'd as the Temples of God, become a Rendezvous for thoe who have not the opportunities o well to meet ele-where. The onely remedy I can at preent think of to prevent this candal, is, that there be a new Officer created in every Parih, whoe charge it hall be, to mark what perons come to thoe Sacred places upon Love-appointments, and if they will not depart the place by fair means, to drive them thence
with as little regard, as they would do thoe narling creatures, which many times tick not to quarrel there, to the great ditraction of people's devotion.

But ome buie-body will haply be o impertinent as to ask, why I hould trouble my head with thee abues, as if I were ome Mater of a Parih, or Lay-Elder, that had a Maid who hould exercie his dog at home? I would have the fool that is candaliz'd at it, know, that in this lower part of the world, all men are fools, as well as liars, ome more, ome les, and perhaps I who now peak a greater fool than any, though it might abate omewhat of my folly, that I am o free to acknowledge it, and withal that this Book of mine, and all others of this kind, being but o many collections of fooleries, I hope, every fool in his quality and degree, will ome-where or other light upon a little decription of himelf, if he be not too much beotted with elf-conceit.

But let the Reader take it as he will. Let me go on with my tory. Don Carlos, as I told you, was gotten into a Church, with divers other Gentlemen, Italians and Spaniards, who were trutting up and down in their feathers, like o many Peacocks, and making reverences to more perons than they were known to, (a vanity practis'd ometimes in Churches as well as Hide-Parks) when three Ladies, all cloe mask'd, ingl'd him out from among the ret, and having led him a little aide, one of them addres'd her elf to him either in thee words, or others to the ame effect.

p.q:
Signor Don Carlos, aid he to him, I have a buines to impart to you, whereof perhaps you
little thought either before or at your devotions, which is, that there is in this City a Lady to whom you are extremely oblig'd. She was preent at the Tilting, and all thoe other exercies, wherein you have lately been engag'd, and always wih'd you might come off with honour, as you have done. She is not o vain to think your ucces wholly the effect of her wihes, but leaves it to your elf to conider, what degree of kindnes you will allow her good wihes, and what a Ladie's concerning her elf o particularly in your good fortune may ignifie; if it were expres'd in other tearms.

div.p: The young Gallant was a little urpriz'd at the trangenes of the adventure; but having recover'd himelf, he made this Reply. The greatet advantage I can make to my elf of what you tell me, Madam, is, that I receive it from you, who eem to be a Lady of quality, and I am to aure you, that could I have imagin'd any Lady had had uch tender wihes for me, I hould have endeavour'd to do more than I have done to deerve her approbation. And therefore, I am to account the obligation he hath put on me the greater, in that it proceeds from a peron, to whom I have not the honour to be known.

The diguis'd Lady told him, that he had not omitted any thing which might render him, even in the judgment of perons les prejudic'd by kindnes than that Lady, one of the mot accomplih'd men in the world. But another thing he had taken particular notice of, was, that it might be preum'd, by his Liveries of black and white, his affection was not any where engag'd. I never
undertood, Madam, replies Don Carlos, what colours ignifi'd in uch a cae; but this I know, that it is not o much out of any inenibility, or indifference I have towards your fairer ex, that I have not made my addrees to any one of it, as an apprehenion of my own want of merit.

There pas'd abundance of other ingenuous complements between them, for their dicoure continu'd a long time; but I hall forbear the communication of them, not onely becaue they never came to my knowledge, and that I am loath to make others out of a fear it might be to the diadvantage of Don Carlos and the unknown Lady, who were infinitely more witty than I am, as I have been ince inform'd by an honet Gentleman of Naples, who was intimately acquainted with them both. The reult was this, that the mask'd Lady declar'd her elf thus far to Don Carlos, that he her elf was the peron who had that inclination for him. He deir'd to ee her; She deir'd him to excue her for the preent, telling him he would endeavour to atisfie him ome other time, and to aure him that he was not afraid to give him a meeting, at which there hould be none but themelves, he would give him a pledge. With that he dicover'd to the gentile Spaniard, the fairet hand he had ever een, and preented him with a Ring, which he made no difficulty to receive, but with uch ditracted reflections on the odnes of the accident, that he had almot forgotten to make her a congey, when he took leave of him.

The other Gentlemen, who had, at a ditance, oberv'd what had pas'd between Don Carlos and
the Lady, though not over-heard their dicoure, eeing they were parted, came up to him, very deirous to know what might occaion o long a convere in o publick a place. He freely told them what had happen'd, and hew'd them the Ring, wherein was a Diamond of very great price. Whereupon every one pas'd his judgment on the adventure, and the reult of the whole debate was, that Don Carlos found himelf eiz'd by as violent a paion for the unknown Lady, as if he had een her face, uch an inevitable influence hath Wit over thoe that have any. Eight tedious days, and thoe attended by ten times more tedious nights, pas'd away ere he heard any further account of the Lady; which that he was extremely troubled at, I hould eaily have believ'd, though I had never been told o much.

During that time, his divertiement was to go every day to an acquaintance of his, a Captain of Foot, at whoe houe everal perons of quality met to pend ome few hours and pieces at play. One night, that Don Carlos was not in an humour to venture any thing, but was going home much ooner than he was wont, he was call'd by his name, from a ground-room belonging to a houe, which eem'd to be ome perons of great quality. He comes up cloe to the window, which had a grate before it, and preently ound by her voice, that he was his inviible Mitres, who preently aid to him; Come as near as you can to the window, Don Carlos, I have been here a good while expecting you, that we may decide a difference there is between us. I have ome apprehenion of your impatience, and mut permit
you to expotulate, though you have not o great reaon to complain, as you imagine to your elf. What contruction, Madam, replies Don Carlos, can I make of all thee bravadoes of yours, when in the mean time you dare not trut me with the ight of your face, nay, after my o long expectation, think it a ignal favour to me, to make your appearance at a grated window, and that in the night. No more of your cenures, Don Carlos,
ays he him, be atisfi'd, that I think it not yet time we hould be fully known one to another, and imagine it not want of any confidence in me, that I have been o backward to meet you, but impute it to a curioity I had to know you, before I uffer'd you to ee me. I need not tell you, that in appointed combats there hould be an equality of arms: if your heart hould not be as free and dis-engag'd as mine, the advantage would be of your ide; and thence it came, that I was deirous to be inform'd concerning you. And what account have you receiv'd of me, ays Don Carlos? The world, Madam, is full of flattery and calumny, it concerns you to examine well the credit of your ininformation. But may you communicate what you have found out by an enquiry which hath been o long a making as it is ince I had the honour firt to meet you? I have as much as I am atisfi'd with, replies the diguis'd Lady, and it is onely this, that we are free enough to become one another's. No, Madam, ays Don Carlos, there is a great inequality in the cae; for you ee me, and know who I am, nay you acknowledge your elf, that you have particularly enquir'd of me,
whereas I never aw you, nor know who you are, nor where to be inform'd. What judgment do you conceive I hould make of this hines, and the earnet care you take to keep your elf from my knowledge. Thee myterious proceedings are eldom us'd by thoe, whoe deigns are jut and generous; and it is no hard matter to deceive a peron who mitruts no treachery; but he is not o eaily deceiv'd twice. If you think to make ue of me, to raie a jealouie in ome other, give me leave to tell you beforehand, that you will not find me for your purpoe, and that I am not to be drawn into any other plot than that of being your mot humble and mot faithful Servant.

With thee words he hut to the window, leaving Don Carlos with his mouth open, ready to make her ome Anwer, o urpriz'd at the martnes of her expreions, o paionately in love with a peron he had never een, and o ditracted at the trangenes of the procedure, that, not able to tir from the place, he tood till for a good quarter of an hour, making everal reflections on o extraordinary an adventure. He knew there were many Princees and Ladies of great quality then at Naples; but he knew withal, that there were many ubtil Curtezans, eagerly bent to trapan Strangers, greet cajollers of uch as were ignorant of their impotures, and o much the more dangerous, by how much they were the more beautiful.

Having recover'd his atonihment, he went very diconolately to his lodging, but reolv'd to proecute the deign wherein he was engag'd, with all the caution he could, out of a fear it might prove a cheat put upon him. I hall not tell you
exactly whether he upp'd, or not, nor yet whether, in cae he went to bed upperles, he lept, or not, and yet there might be much probability of the latter. Thee coniderable circumtances of a Hero's life, I eldom trouble my elf or my Reader with, though it be very much practis'd by the Authors of much greater Romances, than the world is ever like to have from me. For thoe Gentlemen give uch a punctual account of all their Hero's do, and regulate their employments according to the everal parts of the day, appointing them to do uch a thing firt, and then ome other, as if they were hut up in ome place of piritual Retreat. For example, they mut rie betimes in the morning, and having met with ome-body, though they had never een the party before, entertain him or her, with the Hitory of their adventures, till they be call'd in to dinner: dine very lightly, and, as oon as they have din'd, retire into ome arbour, to proceed in the continuation of it, or pend the afternoon in reading ome Romance; when-ever they drink, take as many go-downs as there are letters in their Mitres's names, in commemoration of them; and if the clock trikes, make o many ejaculations for the good ucces of their Loves. If the weather be inviting to go abroad, they are led into ome Grove, where they are to acquaint the Trees and Stones with their misfortunes, till their upper-time calls them home, at which having, intead of eating, pent the time in ighes and reveries, go and build Catles in the air upon ome Turret, that looks towards the Sea, while ome Squire or Servant dicovers that his Mater is uch a one, the Son of uch a King, and
that there is not a better natur'd Prince in the world; and though he be then one of the handomet men in the world, that he was quite another peron, before Love had disfigur'd him. And thus they make thoe whom they would repreent for exemplars of all the great and heroick Vertues, in many things no better than o many Extravagant Shepherds and Don Quixots.

But to return to my Story. Don Carlos came the night following to the ame pot, where he found his inviible Mitres ready to entertain him. She ask'd him whether he had not been much troubled at the former convere they had together, and whether it were not true, that he had entertain'd ome ditrut of what he had told him. Don Carlos, without anwering her quetion, entreated her to atisfie him, what danger or inconvenience there might be, in dicovering her elf, ince things were upon eaven terms on both ides, and that they propos'd to themelves no other ends in their gallantries, than uch as might be approv'd by all. In that lies the whole danger of it, ays the inviible Lady, as you hall find in time; be you therefore aur'd, that I am real, and, in the relation I gave you of my elf, I have been o modet, that, without injury to truth, I might have told you much more. Their dicoure lated a long time. They made ome advance in the mutual love they had rais'd in one another, and at lat parted, after a reciprocal promie to meet there every night, at the time they had agreed on.

The next day, there was to be an extraordinary Ball at the Vice-Roy's Palace. Don Carlos was in hopes to make a dicovery there of the peron, who
would be inviible to him in all other places. In the mean time he made enquiry, whoe houe that was, where he had receiv'd uch favourable audiences. He was told by the neighbours, that there liv'd in it an antient Lady, the Relict of a certain Spanih Captain, that he liv'd very private, and had neither Daughters nor Nieces. He knock'd at the door, and deir'd to ee the old Lady; anwer was brought him, that ince the death of her Husband, he admitted no viits from any peron whatoever; which added not a little to the diturbance of his thoughts.

Don Carlos went at night to the Vice-Roy's, where you may imagine there was a noble Aembly of Gallants. He very exactly oberv'd all the Ladies, to find out her whom he o much deir'd to know. He fell into dicoure with thoe he met; but without any atisfaction. At lat he ingl'd out the Daughter of a certain Marques, where his Title lay I know not, nor care much, epecially now we are come to an age wherein people are too forward to aume Titles of Honour to themelves. The Lady was young and beautiful enough, and her voice came omewhat near hers whom he look'd for: but after much obervation, he found uch a ditance between her intellectu • ls and thoe of his inviible Deity, that it r • pented him he had in o hort a time made uch a progres in his courthip to that Beauty, as whence he might preume that he had a more than ceremonious kindnes for him. They danc'd together everal times, and the Ball being done, little to the atisfaction of Don Carlos, he took leave of his Captive, whom he left highly conceited of her elf, that he alone, in
o noble an Aembly, had receiv'd the gallantries of a Cavalier, who was no les eteem'd by all the women, than envi'd by all the men.

From the Vice-Roy's, he immediately went to his lodging, and thence, having taken uch arms as he thought requiite, to the fatal Grate, which was not far from it. The Lady, who was already got to her pot, ask'd him what news he brought from the Ball, though he had been there her elf. He ingenuouly told her, that he had danc'd everal times with a very beautiful peron, and had entertain'd her with dicoure as long as the Ball lated. This confeion gave her occaion to put divers quetions to him, whereby he might eaily have perceiv'd that he was jealous. Don Carlos on the other ide dicover'd the trouble of his mind, that he had not been at the Ball, and that it gave him ome caue to mitrut her quality. She oon oberv'd what he would have been at, and to prevent the diturbance uch a doubt might raie in him, he us'd all the wit and Rhetorick he had, and hew'd him all the kindnes could be expected between two perons eparated by an iron-grate, which concluded with a promie, that he would be viible within a very hort time. They thereupon took leave one of the other, he very doubtful whether he hould believe her, and he a little jealous of the beautiful Lady, whom he had entertain'd all the time of the Ball.

The next day, Don Carlos going into a Church, to hear Mas, and meeting jut at the door with two Ladies mask'd, preented them with holy water, to p • re them the trouble of taking it themelves. The better clad of the two told him, that in requital of
that civility he had omewhat to acquaint him with, wherein he might be highly concern'd. If you are not too much in hate, Madam, ays Don Carlos to her, you may immediately eae your elf of what you have to tell me. Follow me then into the next Chapel, replies the unknown Lady. She went in firt, and Don Carlos follow'd her, much in doubt whether he were his Mitres, (though he was atisfi'd he was about the ame tature) in regard he found ome difference in their voices, this Lady peaking omewhat fater than the other.

Having hut themelves into the Chapel, he made him this dicoure. Signor Don Carlos, aid he, the whole City of Naples is full of wonder, at the great reputation you have acquir'd, ince the mall time of your reidence in it, and you are look'd upon, by all, as the mot accomplih'd peron in the world, Onely this occaions a general atonihment, that, being what you are, you hould not have oberv'd, there are in this City everal Ladies of great quality and worth, who have a particular eteem and kindnes for you. They have expres'd o much, as far as modety and the reerv'dnes of their ex would permit, and though they earnetly wih you aur'd of it, yet would they rather it might be aid, you regarded it not out of a certain inenibility, than diembled your inadvertency, out of indifference. There is, among others, one, of my acquaintance, who, not regarding what may be aid of uch a dicovery, gives you this eminent aurance of the eteem he hath for you, as to give you notice, That your mid-night adventures
are oberv'd; that you indicreetly engage your affection to what you have no knowledge of, and ince the peron you court as a Mitres will not vouchafe you a ight of her, that it is either out of a fear he is not amiable enough to gain your love, or aham'd of her own. I doubt not but the object of your contemplative love is ome Lady of high quality, and trancendent wit, and that you imagine to your elf a Mitres who is, uch, of all the excellencies her ex is capable of, and conequently deerving the adoration of uch a peron as you are; But Signor Don Carlos, let me give you this advice, not to trut your imagination, to the prejudice of your judgment, but rather mitrut a peron, who diguies her elf, and avoid all further engagement in thee nocturnal converations. To deal freely with you, 'tis I who am jealous of this fantam of yours, troubled you hould peak of her, and, ince I have expres'd my elf thus far, am reolv'd to quah her deigns, and defeat all her projects, o as to deprive her of a victory which I may jutly dipute with her; ince I am not inferiour to her, either as to beauty, fortune, or quality, or indeed any thing that may render a woman amiable. Farewell, I leave you to make your advantage of the good counel I have given you, which, if you are wie, I doubt not but you will.

With thee lat words he went out of the Chapel, not taying for the Anwer, which Don Carlos was ready to make her. He would have follow'd her, but he found at the Church-door a peron of quality, who preently fell into dicoure,
with her, and continu'd it o long, that he grew weary of taying to ee her dis-engag'd. All the remainder of the day, his thoughts were wholly taken up with this adventure, and he upected, at firt, that the Gentlewoman he had met with at the Ball, might be the lat mask'd Lady, that had appear'd to him: but conidering with himelf, that he eem'd to be much more ingenuous, than the other had dicover'd her elf, he was at a los what to think of it, and began to wih he had not engag'd himelf o far to his obcure Mitres, that he might have addres'd his devotions to her whom he had lat parted with. But at lat, reflecting that he was no more known to him than his former inviible Lady, whoe wit had charm'd him in the converation he had had with her, he reolv'd what coure he hould take, and little regarded the menaces which had been made him, as being a peron not to be frighten'd with great words.

In puruance of this reolution, he went that very night to his iron-grate at the hour appointed. The two Lovers pent their time, much after the ame rate as they had at their former meetings. But being come near the height of their amorous dicoure, it was unexpectedly interrupted by a trange accident. Don Carlos was of a udden urpriz'd by four men in vizards, who having diarm'd him, carri'd him away by main force into a Coach, which waited at the lower end of the treet. I leave the Reader to imagine how heartily he rail'd on them, and the reproaches he made them, that they had taken him o much at their advantage. Nay, he tri'd what fair words and promies might do; but intead of prevailing ought
upon them, it onely oblig'd them to look more narrowly to him, and deprive him of all hope to help himelf either by his trength or courage.

In the mean time, the Coach went forward as fat as four good Hores could draw it, and about an hour after they had left the City, he was brought into a magnificent Palace, the great Gate whereof tood open, as if it had been purpoely for his reception. The four diguis'd perons receiv'd Don Carlos out of the Coach, holding him fat under the arms, as if he had been ome Ambaadour conducted to the Grand Signor, or the King of Peria. He was brought up the firt Story with the ame ceremony, and there, two Gentlewomen mask'd receiv'd him, at the entrance of a pacious Hall, having each of them Torches in their hands. The diguis'd men took leave of him, and withdrew, after they had made him a mot low congey. 'Tis very probable, they left him neither Sword nor Pitol, nor that he return'd them any thanks for the care they had of him, and their trouble to bring him thither. Not but that he was a peron of as much civility as any man in the world, but one urpris'd may well be pardon'd the backwardnes of expreing it o much as another.

I hall not tell you whether thoe great Waxlights which the Gentlewoman held, were in Silver Candleticks, but this I am ure of, that they were carv'd and embos'd work, and the Hall was one of the mot umptuous in the world, and, if you pleae, the furniture of it, without diparagement, comparable to ome Appartments of our late Romances, as for example Zelmana's Ship in Polexander, Ibrahim's Palace in the Illustrious
Baa; or the Room, in which the King of Ayria entertain'd Mandana, in the Grand Cyrus, which, not to diparage thoe other I nam'd, is, one of the mot magnificently furnih'd Books of any in the world. Imagine then how much our cajoll'd Lover was atonih'd to find himelf in o umptuous an appartment, attended onely by two Gentlewomen mask'd, who poke not at all, and conducted him thence into another room, more nobly furnih'd than the Hall, where they left him all alone. Had he been of the humour of Don Quixote, he would have been tranported into ome extravagance befitting o great an Adventurer, and he would have conceited himelf at leat Esplandian or Amadis; but our grave Spaniard was no more troubled at it, than if he had been in ome Inn, or Country-houe of his own. True it is, he was much troubled for his Inviible Mitres, and having his thoughts continually fixt on her, he thought that room adder than any Prion, which is neve • accounted handome, but on the out-ide. He was confident they intended him no hurt who had Lodg'd him o nobly, and wanted not much of being atisfy'd, that the Lady, who had poken to him the day before in the Church, was the Sorceres, who had wrought all thee enchantments. He admi'd in himelf the fantatick humours of Women; and with what expedition they execute what they have once reolv'd; and thereupon he concluded it his bet coure patiently to expect the period of the adventure, and to continue faithful to his Mitres at the Grate, what promies or menaces whatoever might be made to him.

Some time after, certain Officers belonging to the Houe, all in Vizards, but very richly clad, came in to lay the cloath, which done, Supper was brought up. All was very magnificent; Muick and Perfumes were not wanting, and our Don Carlos, beides the enes of Smelling, and Hearing, atisfy'd alo that of the Tate, much beyond what I hould have imagin'd, the condition he was in conider'd; my meaning is, that he made a good Supper, for, as I told you, he could not live on the airy entertainments of ighs, and amorous imaginations. I forgot to tell you, that I think he wah'd his mouth before he ate down, for I have heard, that he had an extraordinary care of his teeth. The Muick continu'd playing a good while after Supper, and all having left him, Don Carlos walk'd up and down the room a good while, ruminating on all thee enchantments, or omewhat ele, it m • tters not much. At lat two Gentlewomen mask'd, and a little Dwarf of a Page mask'd alo, after they had laid a rich cloath on a Side-table, came to help him off with his cloaths, without any previous quetion, whether he had any mind to go to Bed or not. He uffer'd them to do what they pleas'd; the Gentlewomen order'd his Bed, and march'd away; the Page help'd him off with his boots or hooes, and afterwards with his cloaths. Don Carlos got into Bed, and all this was done with as trict an obervation of ilence of all ides, as if he had been in ome Monatery of Carthuians. He reted well enough for an amorous peron; the Birds of an adjoyning aviary awak'd him at the break of Day; the mask'd Dwarf was ready to wait on him, and brought
him the finet Linnen, the whitet, and bet perfum'd that he had ever een.

'Twere too hard a task to give an account how he pas'd away the time from Morning till Noon, let thoe who feel the gripings of a paionate love imagine it, as for other people, it matters not what they think. The ilence, which had hitherto been exactly oberv'd of all ides, was broken at lat, by another mask'd Gentlewoman, who came to ask him, whether he would be pleas'd to ee the Princes of that enchanted Palace. He told her, it was his deire, and that he hould be very welcome. Not long after, he comes into the room, attended by four Gentlewomen very richly clad, and with that lutre and attraction, as if the Graces had betow'd the whole morning in dreing her. Never had our Spaniard een a greater conjunction of Love and Majety in one countenance, than he now aw in that of this unmask'd Urganda. He was o ravih'd and atonih'd together, that all the Congees he made, and the everal potures he put himelf into, while he led her by the hand into an adjoyning room, were little better than o many tumblings. What he had thought o umptuous in the Hall, and the other room, whereof I told you before, were nothing in comparion of what he found in this, and yet as magnificent as all things were, they receiv'd ome addition of lutre from the mask'd Lady, who honour'd the place with her divine preence. They ate down on a umptuous Couch, the mot umptuous that had ever been made, ince the firt invention of Couches. Having view'd him a while, to ee how he kept his countenance, he at lat
poke to him, with a Voice as weet as a Virginal, dicovering her mind in a dicoure, not much different from that I am now going to give you.

p.q: I doubt not, Signor Don Carlos, ays he to him, of your being urpris'd, at what hath happen'd to you in my Houe ince your coming into it lat night; but if it have not had that effect on you which I imagine to my elf, I have however the atisfaction of auring you that I am no wore than my promie, and convincing you, by what I have already done, what I am further able to do. 'Tis poible, my Rival, your Inviible Mitres, may, by her artifices, and the good fortune of having engag'd you firt, be abolutely poes'd of that place in your heart, which I am to dipute with her: but he is no Woman that will be put off with one denial, and if my fortunes, which are not to be lighted, and all may be had with me be too weak a motive to induce you to love me, I hall yet have this elf-content, that I have choen rather to run the hazard of being lighted for my imperfection, than obcure my elf out of ubtilty or hame.

div.p:
With thoe words he took off her mask, and gave Don Carlos a full dicovery of Heaven, or, if you pleae, a mall draught of it, the loveliet Head in the world, utein'd by a Body of the noblet-tature he had ever admir'd, in a word, both together making up a peron wholly divine. By the freh complexion of her countenance, a Man would have gues'd her not to exceed ixteen years of age; but a certain mixture, of majety and gallantry in the air of it, uch as young perons
are not arriv'd to, gave a greater aurance of her being four years elder.

p.U:
tood mute a while, as being unreolv'd what anwer he hould make her, not a little incens'd againt his inviible Lady, who hindred him from making an abolute dipoal of himelf to the mot beautiful peron he had ever een, and at a perfect los, both as to what he hould ay, or what he hould do. At lat, after an interiour conflict, which lated long enough to raie ome doubts in the Lady of the enchanted Palace, he took a firm reolution, to make her a clear dicovery of his oul, and it prov'd (uch is commonly the reward of incerity) one of the noblet and mot advantageous actions he ever did. But you expect his anwer. Many perons, who have heard of it, have been of opinion he might have done better, and declar'd his mind a little more martly, when he had once reolv'd which game he would be at. But I am onely his Secretary, and think my elf concern'd in point of concience, to lay down the very words he deliver'd, which were thee, as near as I can remember. I mut acknowledge, Madam, aid he, that it would have been too great a happines to pleae uch a peron as you are, could I have been but o happy as that I might have lov'd you. I am ufficiently enible, that I refue the mot beautiful peron in the world, to court another who poibly may be uch onely in my imagination. But, Madam, would you think me worthy your affection, if you thought me capable of an unfaithfulnes, towards a peron, whom I had promis'd contancy? And is it conitent mith my
contancy that I hould addres my affection to you? But why do I ay mine, when I have not had any to dipoe, ince the engagement of fidelity I made to that Mitres, who is yet pleas'd to be inviible to me? You are therefore, Madam, not o much to blame me, as bewail my mifortune; or rather let us jointly bemoan our elves, you, becaue you cannot obtain your deires, and I, that I cannot ee what I love.

div.p:
He deliver'd this with o ad an accent, that the Lady might eaily oberve he made a incere dicovery of his thoughts. She omitted nothing which he conceiv'd might peruade him, to fall off from his former love; he was deaf to all, her entreaties, nay was little mov'd at her tears, though the greatet Rhetorick a Woman can ue. She renew'd the charge everal times; he as obtinately kept his ground. At lat he fell to bitter railings and reproaches, and having vented on him all the injurious expreions, that could proceed from exaperated rage, and that a woman's, he left him, not o much to conider what he had to do, as to cure his mifortune. A Gentlewoman came in a while after, to tell him, that, if he pleas'd, he might take a turn or two in the Garden. He went, not meeting with any body in his way, till he came to the bottom of the tairs, where he found ten men with vizards on, who waited at the door, arm'd with Partizans and Carbines. As he pas'd through the Court, to go towards the Garden, which was in all things anwerable to the Palace, one of thoe men, who tood Centrie at the gate, comes up to him, and whipers him in the ear (as if he had been much
afraid to be over-heard) That he had receiv'd from an antient Gentleman a Letter directed to him, and that he had promis'd the delivery of it into his own hands, though it might hazard his life, if it were dicover'd: but a preent of twenty pieces, and a promie of a like umme afterwards, had prevail'd with him to venture the doing of that dangerous kindnes. Don Carlos promis'd ecreie, and made all the hate he could into the Garden to read what he had receiv'd from him.

body.head: THE LETTER.
body.p: YOu may eaily imagine what trouble I have been in, ever ince I lot you, by that you are in your elf, if o your love be as violent as mine. My affliction was not capable of any abatement, till I had dicover'd the place where you are, and that's the onely comfort I have. The Lady, who contriv'd your urprize and carrying away, from the place where we thought our elves ecure from uch ambuhes, is the Princes Porcia. To atisfie her own humour, he lights all other coniderations, and you are not the firt Reynaldo that hath fall'n into the hands of that dangerous Armida. But I hall break all her enchantments, and it hall not be long ere I force you, out of her embraces, into my own, a happines you will deerve, if you are as contant as I wih you hould be, to

div.p: Don Carlos was ravih'd to receive this account of his Lady, for whom he had a real and violent affection. He kis'd the Letter till he grew weary of that divertiement, and return'd to the gate, to find out him from whom he had receiv'd it, and to require his kindnes with a rich Diamond-ring, off his finger. He walk'd a good while longer in the Garden, wondring extremely at the trange humour of that Princes Porcia, of whom he had heard much, as of a young Lady of a very great fortune, and decended of one of the noblet Houes in the Kingdom; and being a peron of great vertue, he conceiv'd uch an averion for her, that he reolv'd, though with the hazard of his life, to do all he could to get out of that retraint wherein he kept him.

As he was coming out of the Garden, he met with a young Gentlewoman, unmask'd (for upon the Ladie's dicovery of her elf, orders were given there hould be no more masks een about the Palace) who ask'd him, whether he would be pleas'd to admit of her Ladie's company, to dine with him that day. I leave you to judge, whether he return'd, She hould be welcome, or With all his heart, or, That it was an honour he could not have apir'd to. Soon after, dinner was brought in; the Princes appear'd fairer than the Day, and her converation took the amorous Spaniard o highly, that it bred in him a ecret trouble to ee, in a peron of o great quality, uch excellent endowments o trangely miemploi'd. He endeavour'd all he could to put himelf into a pleaant humour, though his thoughts were continually fix'd on his unknown Mitres, whom he was impatiently deirous
to meet with once more at the grate.

As oon as they had taken away, and all the attendants had quitted the room, the Lady aaulted his contancy one more, in thee words. I know not, Signor Don Carlos, aid he, whether I may, from the chearfulnes, which me-thinks I have oberv'd in your countenance, derive any hope of ome change in your mind, or preume that my face and carriage, have at leat rais'd in you a doubtfulnes, whether the inviible Beauty, you o much dote on, be more capable to force your love than I am. I have not diguis'd what I would have betow'd on you, becaue I was not willing you hould repent your having receiv'd it; and though a peron accutomed to receive Petitions, may eaily be offended at a denial, yet I hall forget all reentment of that which I have receiv'd from you, on condition you repair it, by your future compliance, in giving me what I conceive my elf more worthy of than the inviible and inacceible object of your adorations. Let me therefore know your final reolution, that if it prove not to my advantage, I may endeavour to find a counter-battery of reaons, trong enough to beat down thoe which I think I have had to love you, that I may no longer purue a vain hope, which will deceive me at lat.

Don Carlos paus'd a while, to ee whether he would have gone on with the dicoure, but perceiving he had given over, and that, with her eyes faten'd on the ground, he expected the entence he was to pronounce, he perited in the reolution he had taken to deal freely with her, and put her out of all hope that he could ever be her
Servant, and o made her this cold and comfortles Anwer. Madam, before I atisfie you, as to what you are o deirous to know, I am to beg a real dicovery of your entiments concerning what I hall propoe to you, with the ame freedom and inceritie, as you expect I hould oberve towards you. If your elf had oblig'd a peron to offer up his affections to you, and by all the endearing favours, which a Ladie may grant, without injurie or prejudice to her virtue, you had engag'd this peron to wear and vow an inviolable contancy to you, would you not account him the baet and unworthiet of men, if he hould not perform the promie he had made you? And hould not I be this verie bae and and unworthie peron, if, though to obtain one o infinitelie deerving as you are, I hould forake a woman, who hath ome grounds to preume that I love her?

He would have proceeded with this and other formal arguments, to atisfie her, but he gave him not the time. I have enough, aid he, I perceive what your Anwer will amount to, and cannot forbear admiring your contancie, though it be o much contrarie to my atisfaction. I hall importune you no further, to a change of the reolution you have taken; you hall be deliver'd out of your retraint, onelie this kindnes I hall pres you to, that you remain here till night, to be remov'd hence, in the ame manner as you were brought hither, auring my elf, that if you ever come to dicover where you have been, you will be o generous as to conceal the deign I had upon you, and be moderate in the
triumph of your fidelity. She held a handkerchief before her eyes, while he poke thoe lat words, as it were to keep her tears from being een by the Spaniard, who, if, on the one ide, troubled at what he had aid, was, on the other, o tranported with joy at the recovery of his liberty, that he could not have conceal'd it, though he had been the greatet hypocrite in the world: and 'tis to be imagin'd that if the Lady had oberv'd, he could not have avoided her reproaches. I know not whether he thought it long ere night came, for, as I told you before, I trouble not my elf much about the precie obervance of times and hours: you may be aur'd it came, and that, being dipos'd into a Coach, he was brought back to his own lodgings, attended by the ame perons who had waited on him the night before.

Being one of the kindet Maters in the world, his Servants were over-joy'd to ee him again; but they enjoy'd him not long. He put on armour, and accompani'd by two of them, whoe courage he had former experience of, he made all the hate he could to the Grate, nay his hate was uch, that thoe who attended him, had much ado to follow him. He had no ooner made the accutom'd ignal, but the inviible Deitie anwer'd him. They had a long dicoure, and that o full of affectionate tendernes, on both ides, that I never think on it, without tears. At lat, he told him, that, having receiv'd ome affront in the houe where he then was, he had ent for her Coach, to remove thence; but in regard it would be long ere it came, and that his might be ooner got ready, he entreated him to end for it, to conduct her to a place, where
he hould not any longer complain of her inviibility. The amorous Gallant taid not for a longer entreaty, he ran to his Servants, whom he had left at the end of the treet, and ent them for his Coach, which being come, the inviible Lady kept her promie, and went along with him into it. She gave the Coach-man directions which way he hould go, and bid him top at a great houe, into which he drove, by the light of many torches, which met them at the gate. Don Carlos conducted the Lady as he directed him, up a large pair of tairs, into a patious Hall, where he continu'd omewhat troubled to find her till mask'd. At lat, everal Gentlewomen richly apparrell'd, coming to receive them, every one with a great wax candle in her hand, the inviible Lady dicover'd her elf, and taking off her mask, atisfi'd Don Carlos, that the Lady at the grate and the Princes Porcia were but one and the ame peron.

It were no eaie matter for me to tell you, how trangely the Spaniard was urpriz'd. The beautiful Neapolitan told him, that he had brought him away a econd time, to know his final reolution; that what pretenions oever the Lady at the grate had to him, were now become hers, with a thouand other things highly amorous and witty. Don Carlos cat himelf at her feet, embrac'd her knees, and kis'd her hands, and o avoided the uttering of many impertinences, which people overjoy'd are apt to be guilty of. When thee firt tranportations were over, he rallied together all his wit and gallantry, to celebrate the pleaant humour of his Mitres, and acquitted himelf in expreions o advantageous to her, that he was further aur'd
of her not being mitaken in her choice. She told him, that he was unwilling to trut any but her elf in a trial, without which, he could never have lov'd him, and that he would never have been any man's les contant than he had hewn himelf.

Upon this, the Relations of the Princes Porcia being acquainted with her deign, came in to them. She being one of the mot coniderable perons in the Kingdom, and Don Carlos of great quality, it prov'd no hard matter to get a Dipenation from the Arch-bihop, for their marriage. They were married that very night, by the Paron of the Parih, who being an eminent Preacher, 'tis likely, there wanted not a very good Exhortation. Some reported, that it was very late ere they were tirring the next day, which I am apt enough to believe. The News was oon divulg'd, whereat the Vice-Roy, who was nearly related to Don Carlos, was o glad, that the publick divertiements began afreh in Naples, where they till talk of the Loves of Don Carlos and his INVISIBLE MISTRESS.

div.head: SCARRON's NOVELS.
The Chatiement of Avarice.
The Seventh Novel.
div.p:
NOT many years ince, a young Lad, poor, to the very lowet degree of poverty, yet of an ambition exceeding it, and infinitely more deirous to be thought a Gentleman, than to be accounted, either a rational Creature or a Chritian, came along with his Father out
of the Mountains of Navarr, with a reolution (whether guided by intinct, or encourag'd by the directions of ome others of his friends, I could never learn) to plant themelves at Madrid. They had heard much of the gallantry of that place, and were put in hopes, that they hould meet with thoe thing • there, which they could not find in their own Country, I mean the favours and indulgences of Fortune, which are to be had at the Court, rather than any where ele, yet are eldom obtain'd, without much courthip, and exceive importunities. It was the young Lad's good luck, though I know not by what charms procur'd, to be entertain'd a Page by ome Grandee, or rather Prince, (for they have the vanity to think themelves uch) a condition, not thought very honourable in Spain, that is, much at the ame rate as that of Lacqueys in France or England. He was put into the Livery about twelve years of age, and, no doubt, he look'd very prettily in it, uch an alteration is the firt mile of good fortune able to make, in one who, till then, had liv'd no otherwie than as an unciviliz'd Highlander. 'Tis poible, ome other peron would have grown inolent upon o trange a Metamorphois; but he was of a quite different temper, and withal the mot frugal Page that ever was, nay, what is the greatet commendation of a peron of his quality, the leat addicted to an Art call'd the Lightnes of the Fingers, as haply having not yet been long enough in the City, to undertand the advantages of his profeion.

Having old his former rags to the Brokers, he began to think himelf a rich man; yet did not his wealth conit o much in the gaudines of his accoutrements,
as in the greatnes of his hopes, and a wretched Bed, dipos'd into a mall partition of a Garret, which he had taken, not far from his Mater's houe, and there he retir'd in the night, with his Father, rich in years, ince he liv'd, and, upon that account, raiing a compaion in all he met, ome were o charitable as to relieve him. Thoe charities were his daily revenue, but o mall, that, many times, he went to his Cell, not onely upperles, but hungry. At lat the old Man dyes, and his Son was glad to ee him o well provided for, out of this reflection, that being disburthen'd of that charge, he was in a fair way to become a rich man. From the hour of his Father's interrment, he impos'd upon himelf o great a frugality, and enter'd into o trict and autere a kind of Life, that he pent in a manner nothing, of that little, which was allow'd him every day for his ubitance. 'Tis true, it was not without the grumbling and barking of his Stomach, and to the cot of all thoe, with whom he could make any acquaintance.

Don Marcos (o was called this remarkable example of penury) was a peron of a tature omewhat below the middle ize, and, through pure want of eaonable nourihment, he, in a hort time, became the lenderet, and driet peron in the world. When he waited on his Mater at table (which, it eems, was not o often as he could have wih'd) he never chang'd his plate, but that, if there were any thing left on it, he had the admirable leight of conveying omewhat into his pocket, whether it were dry or liquid he matter'd not much. But finding by experience, that, when he ecur'd any thing of the latter kind, it could not
be done without offence, he found out an expedient to prevent that inconvenience, for having converted into mony the wax of a great number of Torches ends, which he had very carefully kept together, he bought him a pair of pockets of your Latten-ware, wherewith he afterwards did miracles, in order to the advancement of his fortune.

Mot covetous perons are commonly vigilant and careful, and thee two qualities, heightned by the inatiable paion, which Dom Marcos had, to become a rich Man, rais'd in his Mater uch an extraordinary kindnes towards him, that he would not, by any means in the world, have parted with o excellent a Page. He continu'd him in his Livery, from the twelfth, as I told you, to the thirtieth year of his Age, o that, upon the account of his Seniority, he might have taken place of all the Pages in Spain. But there happen'd an inconvenience, which prevail'd with his Mater to change that reolution, and that was, that this over-grown Page was oblig'd to have himelf every day; whereupon being transform'd from a Page into a Gentleman, he was made by his Mater what Heaven would never have made him.

The advantage of this transformation was, that his allowance was advanc'd, by a daily addition of ome few Ryals; but he, intead of adding any thing to his expence, rein'd his Pure-trings the more, not regarding how much his new employment oblig'd him to betray a proportionable liberality. He had heard indeed, that ome of his Profeion, intead of a Boy, to wait them, in the morning, made ue of uch as old Aquavitae, to make clean their rooms, into which they got them,
pretending that they would have drunk of their Water, and ometimes in the Winter-time, they call'd up thoe that old Wafers and Jumbals (a ort of people that walk as late as the Bak'd-pipin wenches do about London) to get off their Cloaths; but in regard this could not be done without a kind of violence, and that our Dom Marcos was of an humour, not to be unjut to any but himelf, he conceiv'd it his bet coure not to be troubled with any Servant. Never was there a Candle's end burnt in his Chamber, but he came to it by light of hand, and to make it lat as long as might be, he began to undres himelf in the treet, from the very place where he had lighted it, o that by that time he was come to his Chamber, he was in a manner ready to get into his Bed. But conidering with himelf, that it was poible a Man might go to his ret with les charge, his inventive imagination found out another expedient, which was, to make a little hole in the partition, which eparated his room from his next Neighbours, o as that, as oon as he had lighted his Candle, Dom Marcos opened the hole, and o had light enough to do any thing he had to do at that time of the Night.

That one ide of his Body hould not laugh at the other, nor either of them at the middle of his haunches, he wore his Sword one day on the right ide, the next day, on the left, the third hanging perpendicularly down his back, and all this, that his Cloaths might be equally worn out of all ides, and that the D • mmage hould be the les, being equally divided. Upon the very break of Day, he tood at his door, with a little Earthen pitcher in his hand, begging a little water of all the Water-bearers
that pas'd by, and o he uppli'd himelf with water for many days together. He went many times into a little Buttery, jut at the time that the other Servants belonging to his Mater, who had their Diet in the Houe, were at Meals, and there he would take occaion to commend what they had before them, that ome body might invite him to tate of it. He never bought any Wine, yet drunk of it every day, either by tating what the publick Criers carri'd about, or taying in the treets thoe, who had been buying at the Cabarets, of whom he begg'd a tate, as if he intended to buy himelf of the ame. Coming to Madrid upon a Mule, he cat uch a mit before the eyes of his Hots, that he kept the poor Beat onely with pieces of the Bed-mats on which he lay, and what other remnants of old Mats he could meet with.

There happen'd a neceity, one time, that he mut take a Servant along with him, upon a Journey he had to make; but growing weary of him the firt day of his ervice, he bethought himelf of a pretty device to put him off. Pretending that he could not drink the Wine at the Inn where he then was, he ent the poor fellow to another, a good League ditant, where he aid there was much better. There was no way but to obey the commands of his new Mater; but, before his return, he was gone away, and had left fale directions, where to find him, and o the poor Boy was forc'd to get back again to Madrid with a weeping-cros, as being reduc'd to play the Pilgrim, and beg all the way, for the Mony he had given him to buy the Wine prov'd naught. In fine, Dom
Marcos became the living pourtraiture of bae thrift and avarice, and was o well known to be the mot covetous Man that ever Spain bred, that, in Madrid, they had no other name for a mierable fellow, than Dom Marcos.

His Mater, and all his Friends, told a thouand pleaant tories of him, and that even in his preence, for he never troubled himelf at their dicoure, as minding his own advantage more than their raillery, though he undertood it well enough, and would put in ever and anon ome grave aying or Apothegm. One of them was, that a Woman could never be handome, if he lov'd to receive; nor ever deformed if he had any thing to give: And that a prudent and thrifty Man hould never go to Bed, till he had made ome advantage or other. This excellent Theory, econded by as exact a Practice, had brought him in, by that time he was arriv'd to forty years of Age, ten thouand Crowns in ready mony, a vat um for a Gentleman, waiting on a Grandee, epecially one of Spain. But what will not a long proces of time bring a Man to, when he robs himelf of all he can, as well as other people.

Dom Marcos having thus acquir'd the reputation of being rich, without that of following any evil coure or gaming, was oon look'd upon as an advantageous Match, by everal Women, who, above all things, and with all the artifices imaginable, proecute their own concernments. Among the many who proffer'd him their enjoyments and liberty, (for Women in Spain are but a mall degree above Slaves) there was one Iidora, a Woman that went for a Widdow, though
he had never been married, and that it was at leat forty years ince he had been a Maid. She eem'd to be much younger than he was, o well was he vers'd in the diguies and artifices, which Women ometimes ue, to bely their Age and Wrinkles. Her fortune was meaur'd according to her expence, which was very high for a Woman of her condition; inomuch that the common report, which is ever rah and apt to lye, gave her out to be worth, beides what he might have in Mony and Jewels, three hundred Pounds terling per ann. and at leat ten thouand Crowns in Houhold-tuff. He who propos'd the match between Dom Marcos and this Iidora, was a famous Trapanner, one that traded in all orts of Commodities, and a Hole-ale-Marchant in the common Druggs of the female Sex. He gave Dom Marcos uch an advantageous account of the Lady Iidora, that it made his teeth water to be acquainted with her, a curioity he had never had for any peron before. Nay, he peruaded him o far that he was rich, and the Widdow of a Cavalier, of one of the bet Houes of Andaluia, that, upon the firt propoals, he accounted himelf as good as married to her. That very day, this ubtle Sollicitor of Venereal Caues, whoe name was Gamara, prevail'd with Dom Marcos to go along with him to viit Iidora at her houe. The covetous wretch was ravih'd at the neatnes and magnificence of the Houe, into which Gamara brought him, but much better pleas'd, when he conductor aur'd him, that both it, and all within it belong'd to Iidora. He found therein uch Houhold-tuff, uch Alcoves, Couches, and a profuion of Perfumes, as might become a
Lady of the greatet quality, rather than the future Spoue of a imple Gentleman, that waited on a Grand Signor of Spain; and for her own part, he thought her at leat a Goddes. Dom Marcos found her very buie, about ome extraordinary Works, itting between two of her Waiting-women, both o highly clad, and o handome, that, notwithtanding the natural averion he had for expence, and epecially that occaion'd by a uperfluous number of Dometicks, he would have married Iidora, though 'twere onely out of an ambition he then had, to have, at his command, uch beautiful young Maids, as he took them to be. Iidora's dicoure was o excellent, that it not onely pleas'd, but in a manner enchanted, Dom Marcos; and what made an abolute conquet of his heart, was a magnificent Collation, at which the finenes of the Linnen, and the umptuounes of the Plate were anwerable to the other rich Houhold-tuff of the Lady, at whoe charge it was. There was preent at this Collation a proper young Lad, named Augutine, well cloath'd, whom Iidora aid was her Nephew, and whom his good Aunt, to hew her fondnes of him, diminutively called Augutinetto, though he were above twenty years of Age. Iidora and Augutinetto out-vy'd one the other in their treatment of Dom Marcos, and were ever preenting him with what they thought bet in the Collation; and while our up-tart Gentleman atisfi'd his half-tarv'd Stomach with proviions for at leat one week, at the charge of another, his ears were charm'd by the weet Voice of the Waiting-woman Marcella, who, to the ound of a Virginal, ung certain paionate Airs. Dom
Marcos forgot his Gentility, and fed like a Farmer, and the Collation ended with the day, the light whereof growing deficient was uppli'd by that of four great wax-candles, in candleticks of maie ilver exquiitely wrought, which Dom Marcos immediately reolv'd within himelf to reform into one ingle Lamp, as oon as ever he were married to Iidora. Augutinetto took a Gitthar, and plaid everal Sarabands, which the crafty Marcella, and the other Waiting-gentlewoman Inez, danc'd admirably well, exactly anwering the ound of the Gitthar with their Catagnets. The dicreet Gamara whiper'd Dom Marcos in the ear, that the Lady Iidora went to bed betimes. The civil Gentleman taid not for a econd advertiement, and thereupon addreing himelf to Iidora, with uch extraordinary complements, and o great protetations of love and ervice, as he had never made to any before, he took leave both of her, and her Nephew Signor Augutinetto, leaving them at liberty to ay what they thought of him.

Dom Marcos being thus deeply fallen in love with Iidora, but much more with her mony, acknowledg'd to Gamara, who accompani'd him to his own lodging, that the beautiful Widow had mitten him in the more amorous part of his oul, and that he would have parted with a finger, on condition he were already marri'd to her; inamuch as he had never met with any woman that pleas'd his fancy better than he did, telling him withall, that after their marriage, he hould not live at uch an extravagant rate. She lives rather like a Princes, than the wife of a private peron, ays the cautious Dom Marcos to the diembling
companion Gamara, and coniders not, that the houhold-tuff and plate he hath, being turn'd into mony, and that mony added to that which I have, might bring in a coniderable yearly rent, which we may lay up for a reerve, and, by the indutry it hath pleas'd God to betow on me, raie a plentiful etate and fortunes for the children we may have between us. But if Heaven hall think fit, that we have no iue, ince Iidora hath a hopeful Nephew, we will ettle all we hall gather together upon him, provided he anwer the expectation I have of his well-doing.

Dom Marcos entertain'd Gamara with thee dicoures, or others to the ame effect, walking till on, till he found himelf jut at the door of his lodging. Gamara took his leave of him, after he had promied, that the next day he would conclude his marriage with Iidora, and given him this reaon for his expedition therein, That affairs of that nature, many times, micarried as much by delay as by the death of either of the parties. Dom Marcos kindly embrac'd the dear carrier on of his deigns, and dimis'd him. He went immediately back to Iidora, to give her an account in what poture he had left her humble Servant, and in the mean time our amorous Gentleman taking out of his pocket the end of a wax-candle, he faten'd it to the point of his word, and having lighted it at a lamp, which burn'd before a publick Crucifix, in a place hard by, not without making a kind of ejaculatory prayer, for the good ucces of his marriage, he open'd, with a Mitres-key, the door of the houe where he lay, and laid himelf down in his wretched bed, rather to pas away the night in reflecting on his Loves, than in leeping.

The next morning Gamara comes to him, and acquainted him with the good news of the concluion of his marrirge with Iidora, who referred it to Dom Marcos, to appoint the day, on which it hould be olemnized. The amorous Mier told Gamara, that though he were married that very day, yet would it not be as oon as he wih'd it. Gamara repli'd, that it depended wholly on himelf to conummate his own happines: whereupon Dom Marcos, embracing him, deir'd the contract might be drawn up that very day. He appointed Gamara to meet him in the afternoon, as oon as he pleas'd, after he had waited on his Mater at dinner. They both punctually met at the time and place appointed. They went to Iidora's houe, where Dom Marcos was more nobly entertain'd than he had been the time before. Marcella ung; Inez danc'd; Augutinetto plai'd on the Gitthar; and Iidora, the principal Actres, gave her future husband an extraordinary Treatment, whereof he knew who hould defray the charge at lat. He devour'd all was preented to him with as little remore as a Wolf half-tarv'd; and yet he could not forbear cenuring the uperfluity of the expence in his oul. Gamara was ent for a publick Notary; he brought one to act that part. The Articles of the Treaty of Marriage were oon et down, and as oon igned on both ides.
