There was a motion made to Dom Marcos, that he would play a game at Primero, to pas away the time. Heaven and all the Inhabitants of it forbid, ays Dom Marcos, I play at any kind of game! No, no; I erve a Mater, who would turn me out of his ervice within a quarter of an
hour, if he hould ever hear that I were a Gameter; and for my own part, I am not o well skill'd, as to know the Cards. How infinitely am I pleas'd with what Signor Dom Marcos hath aid, replies Iidora, I am every day preaching the ame thing to my Nephew Augutinetto, but the world is come to that pas now, that the younger ort think themelves too wie, to receive the good counels and admonitions of their elders, much more to follow them. Go thy ways, unhappy boy, ays he to Augutinetto, go bid Marcella and Inez make an end of their dinner, and come and divert the company with their Catagnets.

While Augutinetto was gone down to call up the Maids, Dom Marcos, addreing himelf to Iidora, acquainted her with his mind in thee terms. If Augutinetto will do as I would have him, there are two things he mut abtain from, as the mot contrary to my nature of any thing in the world, and that is, Gaming, and being abroad late in the night. I am deirous that all thoe who lie within my doors hould be in their beds betimes, and that, as oon as it is dark, the houe-doors hould be well bolted and lock'd. Not that I am of a ditrutful humour; nay, on the contrary, I do not think any thing more impertinent than to be o, epecially when a man hath an honet and careful wife, as I am more than in hopes to have: but thoe houes, where there is any thing to be taken, can never be too ecure from Thieves, and Houe-breakers, for if there be but a ink-hole left open, they will make a hift to get in; and for my part, it would break my heart, if ome idle racal of a Thief, without
taking any other pains, than what it co •• s him to carry away what he finds, hould, in an intant, convey away, what I had much ado • o get together in many years. For thee rraons therefore, continues Dom Marcos, I will abolutely forbid him Gaming and Night-walking, or reign him up to be dealt with according to the dicretion of the Devil, for Dom Marcos hall be no longer his Tutor.

The cholerick Signor poke thee lat words with o much tranportation, that it cot Iidora a great many intreaties and ubmiions, to lay his great pirit, and reduce him to his ordinary tranquility. She did as good as fall on her knees, to deire Dom Marcos, that he would be no longer angry, auring him, that her Nephew hould give him all the atisfaction he could expect, for he was but young, and of the mot docile and compliant nature of any he had ever known.

They fell into ome other dicoure, upon the coming in of Augutine and the Dancing-women, and they pent ome part of the night in dancing and inging. Dom Marcos, to pare himelf the trouble of returning to his own lodging, would have peruaded Iidora, to condecend, that they might, from that time, live together, as man and wife, or that at leat he might lie in her houe, in regard it was grown later than he had imagin'd. But he put on a evere countenance, and earnetly proteted, that ever ince the unhappy day that had reduc'd her to the condition of Widdow-hood, never had any man et his foot into the chat bed which had ometime been her dear Lord's, nor hould any, till the Church had interpos'd her authority, and
that, while he were a widow, no peron hould ever lie under her roof, but her Nephew Augutine.

Dom Marcos was much pleas'd with her reolution, notwithtanding his amorous impatience. He bid her good-night, return'd to his lodging, accompani'd by Gamara, took out of his pocket the candle's end, tuck it to the point of his word, lighted it at the Lamp before the Crucifix, in a word, did all he had done the night before, o punctual was he in all things, unles it were that he aid not his prayers, as he had done, haply becaue he thought his buines effected, and that he tood not in any need of Heaven's further aitance. The Banes of Matrimony were oon ask'd out, for there happen'd to come two or three holy-days together. At lat, the marriage, o much deir'd on both ides, was conummated, and the olemnity thereof occaion'd a greater expence then was expected from the penuriounes of the Bride-groom, who, out of a fear of making any breach in his ten thouand Crowns, borrow'd mony of his friends. The chiefet of his Mater's ervants were at the wedding, and took occaion ever and anon to commend the good choice he had made. The cheer was extraordinary, though at the charge of Dom Marcos, who for that time was content to defray all, and, by a prodigy of affection, had caus'd very rich cloaths to be made for Iidora and himelf.

The Guets departed in good time, and, the coat being clear, Dom Marcos went himelf and lock'd the doors, and hut to and barr'd the windows, not o much for the ecurity of his wife, as that of the Trunks, wherein his mony lay, which he order'd to be brought into his own room and et cloe by the
nuptial bed. The young couple went to bed, and while Dom Marcos was groping for what he could not find, Marcella and Inez were grumbling in their own chamber, at the trange humour of their Mater, and blaming the forwardnes of their Mitres, in taking a husband. Inez burt forth into down-right wearing, and aid he had rather be a Lay-Siter in a Monatery, than Servant in a houe, whereof the doors were lock'd up at nine of the clock. And what would you do were you in my condition? ays Marcella to Inez; for your buines is to go up and down, to provide for the houe, but for my part, who am a Gentlewoman made up in hate, I mut le • d a retir'd life, with the chate poue of a jealous husband, and, of all the Serenades, which were given under our windows, I mut hear no more talk, than of the pleaures of the next world. And yet we are not o much to be bemoan'd as our friend Augutinetto, ays Inez. He hath pent his youth in waiting as a Gentleman-uher on her whom he call'd his Aunt, though he were no more o than I am, and now that he is come to write Man, he puts him under the tuition of a Paedagogue, who, no les than a hundred times a day, will reproach him with his diet and cloaths, and God onely knows and himelf, whether he came honetly by them. Thou tell't me in that omewhat I knew not before, replies Marcella, and I give over wondring at the everity our Mitres pretended to, when her Nephew ad honores grew a little more familiar with us than he would have had him. Had I been any thing forward to believe his protetations, I hould oon have depriv'd the Aunt of
the Nephew; but he hath bred me up from a child, and it is a certain gratitude, for us to be faithful to thoe, whoe bread we eat. To tell thee the truth, continu'd Inez, I cannot find in my heart to have any av • rion for that young fellow, and I mut confes, that it rais'd a great compaion in me, when I aw him onely dis-atisfi'd, and out of humour, among o many others who enjoy'd themelves and were merry.

In thee dicoures did the two Waiting-women pend the time, after they were got into bed, and uch were their comments on the marriage of their Mater. Honet Inez fell aleep, but Marcella had omewhat ele to do. As oon as he perceiv'd that her companion was aleep, he puts on her own cloaths, and made up a great bundle of thoe of Iidora's, and ome of Dom Marcos's, which he had lily got out of their chamber, before the over-cautious Signor had lock'd the door. Having dipatch'd her buines, he went her ways, and, becaue he had no intention to return ag •• n, he left open the doors of that part of the houe where Iidora liv'd. A while after, Inez awakes, and not finding her companion a-bed with her, he was very deirous to know what hould become of her at that time of the night. She hearken'd a while at Augutine's chamber-door, not without ome ditrut and jealouie: but not hearing any noie within, he went to earch for her in all thoe places where he conceiv'd he might be, and found her not, but all the doors, through which he had pas'd, wide open. She went and knock'd at that of the new-married couple, and did it with o much noie as put them into a fright. She told them that Marcella was run
away, that he had left the doors open, and he was afraid, that he had carried omewhat with her, whereof he intended not ever to make any retitution. Dom Marcos tarts out of bed, as a peron out of his wits, ran to look for his cloaths, but could not find them, nor Iidora's wedding-gown. But what compleated his ditraction, was, that, after a light was brought into the room, he found, what he leat upected, his dear poue of a far different figure, from that, under which he had been o much taken with her; nay, o dreadful was the pectacle, that the narrow-hearted fellow was ready to wound. The poor Lady itting up half-aleep, half-awake in her bed, never minded, that her periwig was fallen off. At lat, he ees it on the ground, fallen down by the bed-ide, and, taking it up, would have put it on; but a thing is never well, when it is done with too much precipitation. She put on the dres with that part before which hould have been behind, o that her face, which, o betimes in the morning, had not receiv'd all its diurnal ornaments, appear'd in a very odd poture, and painted as it was, eem'd o dreadful to Dom Marcos, that he was afraid it might be ome apparition. If he cat his eyes on her, he aw an uncouth monter, and if he look'd about the room, he could not ee his cloaths. Iidora, extremely at a los, made a hift to perceive that ome of her counterfeit teeth were entangled in the long, bruhy, and well-britled mutachoes of her husband. She went to retrive them thence with much confuion; but the poor man, whom he had frighten'd almot out of himelf, imagining he had no reaon to put her hands o near his face, out of any other deign, than to take
him by the throat, or cratch out his eyes, retreated, and hunn'd her approaches, with o much nimblenes, that he, not admitted to cloe with him, was at lat forc'd to acknowledge, that his Mutachoes had got away ome of her teeth. Dom Marcos, upon that, began to troak them up, and having met with his Wives teeth, which had ometime been thoe of an Elephant, an original Inhabitant of Africk, or the Eat-Indies, he flung them at her head with much indignation. She gather'd them together, as well thoe catter'd in the Bed, as thoe about the Room, and made her ecape into a little Cloet, with that exquiite treaure, and ome head-bruhes, which he took out of the Bag, where her Night-cloaths were.

In the mean time, Dom Marcos having ufficiently renounc'd his Chritianity, et himelf down in a chair, where he made mot ad reflections on the misfortune had befallen him, in marrying a woman, who, by the nows of at leat ixty winters, that powder'd her hav'd pate, had dicover'd her elf to be older than he was, by twenty years, yet not o well tricken in them, but that he might pend the other core in his company, nay, haply more. Augutinetto, who was awak'd by the noie, came into the room, with his cloaths half off, half on, and did all lay in his power to appeae the Husband of his Aunt by adoption: but all the Anwer the poor Man could make to his remontrances, was, to igh, and ometimes mite his thighs, ometimes his face, with his bare hand. Then was it, that he bethought him of a noble Gold chain he had borrow'd, to adorn himelf withal on his Wedding-day; but all he had left of it, was that ad
remembrance. Marcella had got it in the bundle of cloaths, which he had carried away. He look'd up and down for it, with ome patience and tranquility, very diligently earching every crany about the Chamber: but when he had wearied himelf with earching, and was convinc'd, that it was lot, together with all the pains he had taken to look for it, never was there uch a conflict of rage and affliction, as then ditracted the poor Dom Marcos. His ighs were o loud, that, if people had been awake, they might have been heard over the whole quarter. Upon thoe doleful lamentations, Iidora comes out of the cloet, but o chang'd, and o beautiful, that he thought his Wife now the third time metamorphos'd. He look'd on her with a certain atonihment, and poke not to her with any indignation. He took out of one of his Trunks the cloaths he wore every day, put them on, and, follow'd by Augutinetto, went out to weary himelf in running up and down the treets, after the michievous Marcella. They ought, and earch'd, and enquir'd, but all to no purpoe, till the clock triking twelve minded them of their Dinner, which was made up of what had been left of the Wedding-feat. Dom Marcos and Iidora fell a quarrelling, as people that were deirous to eat, and fed as heartily as people inclining to quarrel. Yet would Iidora now and then put in a word, to pacifie Dom Marcos, and to bring him into his former peaceable humour, peaking to him with the greatet humility and mildnes imaginable, and Augutinetto did all he could to make an accommodation between them: but the los of the Chain of Gold was as great a torment to Dom
Marcos, as if he had been run through the Body with a Dagger.

They were ready to rie from the Table, and onely taid for Augutinetto to make an end, who minded his belly more than their difference, when there came into the room two men, from the Admiral of Casteel's Steward, to entreat Madam Iidora, that he would return the Plate he had lent her for fifteen days, and which he had now kept a month. Iidora knew not any other Anwer to make them, than that it hould be forth-coming. Dom Marcos told them that it was now his, and that he would keep it. One of the men taid in the room, to be in ight of what they made o much difficulty to retore, while the other went to the Steward, who immediately came, and reproach'd Iidora with her unhandome carriage, made little account of the oppoition of Dom Marcos, and all he had to ay for himelf, carried away the Plate, and left the Man and Wife ready to quarrel, upon this new occaion of quarreling. Their contet was almot brought to an accommodation, when a Broker, accompanied by his Servants, and ome Porters, came into the room, and told Iidora, that, ince he was richly match'd, he came for the Houhold-tuff he had taken upon hire, together with the Brokage-mony, unles he had a mind to buy them out-right, and o pare him the trouble of taking them down.

This unexpected accident put Dom Marcos out of all patience; he would have beaten the Broker; the Broker made it appear that he was a man as able to return as to receive, and fell a railing at Iidora, who return'd him as good as he brought.
He beat her; he reveng'd her elf as well as he could, the conequence whereof was, that, in a hort time, the floor was trew'd with the teeth and hair of Iidora, and the cloak, hat, and gloves of Dom Marcos, who, though he had little reaon for it, would needs take his Wife's part.

While the Combatants gather up the broken pieces of their harnes, and the Broker carries away the goods, and is paid for the ue of them, as a Broker, and that all together make a noie as if Hell were broke looe, the Landlord of the Houe, who had Lodgings in ome part of it, comes into Iidora's room, and told her, that he would not have uch a tir kept in his Houe, and that if they reolv'd to continue it, they hould look out for another Lodging. How now, you impertinent Coxcomb, ays Dom Marcos, do you get out of mine, or I hall end you hence with more expedition than you came hither. The Landlord anwer'd him with a box on the ear; he who had receiv'd it, being weary of that kind of engagement, look'd about for his Sword or Ponyard; but Marcella had carri'd them away. Iidora and her pretended Nephew tep'd in between them, and appeas'd the Landlord, but could prevail little with Dom Marcos, who running his head againt the walls, call'd Iidora a thouand damn'd-bae-pilfering-impudent-cheating-and-trapanning-Whores. Iidora made him Anwer, weeping, that he could not ue too much ubtilty, to draw in o deerving a Dom Marcos as he was, and therefore he hould rather applaud her ingenuity, than beat her, as he had done, adding withal, that a Husband, even in point of honour, was blameable for beating his Wife.
Dom Marcos, wearing very learnedly, proteted, that he knew no other point of honour than his Mony, and that he would be unmarried. Iidora, with an exceive humility, made a contrary protetation, that he would never conent thereto; wore to Dom Marcos, that it was not in his power to diolve the acred tye of a lawful Marriage, and advis'd him to patience.

He was once more appeas'd, and bethought himelf, that a new Lodging mut be taken, the old one being grown too hot for them. Dom Marcos and the Nephew went out to take one, and o Iidora had a little relaxation. Thee unexpected accidents rais'd a little commotion within her, but when he look'd about the room, and aw, not the Hangings, for thoe were gone, but the Trunks well lin'd with Silver, he took heart, and bore the more patiently the tety dipoition of the Husband which brought them thither.

Dom Marcos took ome convenient Lodgings in the ame Quarter, where his Mater liv'd, and ent back Augutinetto to dine with his Aunt, being himelf, as he aid, too much pres'd with grief, to eat out of the ame Dih with that trancendent Cheat. But in the evening he came to her, with all the day's vexation, and cruel as a Tygre; not o much out of kindnes to the Woman, as to viit his Trunks, and, by his preence, to ecure them. Iidora entertain'd him with all the ubmiions and complacency imaginable; inomuch that they lay together, and pas'd away the night without any alarms. In the morning, as oon as he was dres'd, he had the confidence to deire him, to go to the new Lodgings, there to receive the Goods, which he
would order her Nephew and Inez to ee brought thither in a Waggon. Dom Marcos went thither, and, while he was contriving how to dipoe of them into everal rooms, the ungrateful Iidora, the young Rogue Augutine, and the perfidious Inez plotted together, and pack'd up all the bet things in a Wagon, got into it themelves, leave Madrid, and take their way towards Barcelona. Dom Marcos grew weary of taying for them, and went back to his old quarters, where he found the Doors lock'd, and was told by the Neighbours, that they were gone away with the Goods many hours ince. He return'd to the place from whence he came, imagining he had mis'd the Wagon by the way, but found no more than what he had left there. He immediately marches back again, mitruting what misfortune might have happened to him; he breaks open the Door, and found there, onely ome old Bed-teeds, Stools, Tables, and Fire-irons, which it eems they thought either too troubleome, or not worth the carrying away. There was no body to be reveng'd on but himelf; his venerable Beard and Hair were the firt ufferers for his folly; then his Eyes; he bit his Fingers till the blood guh'd out, and had a great temptation to make away with himelf; but the hour was not yet come.

There are not any o unfortunate, but they flatter themelves with ome hope: he ran up and down to all the Inns about Madrid, to find out thoe, who had left him o baely in the lurch, but could not meet with any tidings of them. Iidora had not been o imple as to hire a Wagon that hould return thither any more; he had taken it up at a Village not far from Madrid, and, to avoid
puruit, had agreed with the Wagoner, that he hould make no longer tay in the City, than were requiite to take in her elf, her company, and her goods. Wea • ier than a Dog, that had run all day after a Hare and mit her, the poor Gentleman was returning from his earching the Inns about the City and Suburbs, when it was his chance, to meet Marcella full-but in the treets. He laid hold of her, Have I met with thee, O thou mot michievous of all thy Sex, aid he, thou halt now retore all thou hat tollen from me. O my God, my dear Creator, replies the crafty Baggage, without the leat dicovery of any trouble, how did it always run in my thoughts, that all the michief would fall upon my head! My dearet Mater, be pleas'd to hear me, for the Bleed Virgin's ake: do but give me the hearing, before your dihonour me. I am an honet Maid, and of good repute, and the leat candal you hould force me to give my Neighbour, would be infinitely prejudicial to me, for I am upon the point of marriage. Be pleas'd to go along with me into the Entry of this Houe, and afford me but your patient attention for a quarter of an hour, and I will tell you what is become of your Chain, and all you have lot. I had been already inform'd, that I was charg'd with all that had pas'd, and I told my Mitres what it would come to, when he commanded me to do what I accordingly did: but he was Mitres; I, her Servant. Wo is me! How mierable are they whoe dependance is upon others, and what pains they take, and what michief they mut ometimes do, to earn a piece of bread.

Dom Marcos was a peron guilty of as little malice as any other; the tears and eloquence of the crafty Marcella prevail'd with him, not onely to hearken to her, but alo to believe what he aid to him. He went therefore along with her into the entry of a great houe, where he told him, that Iidora was an old decai'd Curtezan, who had ruin'd all thoe who were o unh • ppy as to fall in love with her, yet had not much advantag'd her elf thereby, by reaon of the vat expences he was at. She further acquainted him with what he had undertood from her companion Inez, that Augutin • tto was not Iidora's Nephew, but a kind Night-bird, the Batard of another Curtezan, of her acquaintance, and that he maintain'd him, under the notion o • her Nephew, to gain her elf the greater authority among thoe of her own profeion, and to revenge her quarrels. She told him, that he had deliver'd th • gold-chain & the other things he had carri'd away, to that young Hector, & that it was by his order, he had gone away in the night, and without taking her leave, which was a pure trick put upon her, that he onely might be thought guilty of o l • ud an action.

This plauible tory Marcella told Dom Marcos, out of a hope it might procure her ecape out of his hands, or at leat to oberve the good cutom, which mot Servants have, to be very apt to lie, and to tell of their Maters, as well what they do not, as wh • t they do, know. She concluded her vindication, with a promie that all things hould • e return'd him when he leat expected it, exhorting him in the me • n time to exercie his patience. You peak very well, ays Dom Marcos to h • r, but I think it as likely, that I hall never ee a • y thi • g again;
there being but little probability, that the perfidious Quean, who hath carried away all I have been gathering together thee thirty years, hould ere come back again to make me any retitution. He thereupon told Marcella all that had happen'd at Iidora's lodgings ince her departure thence. Is it poible, he hould be at uch a los of all concience, ays the leud Marcella to him. Ah! my dear Mater, now I perceive, it was not without jut grounds, that I pitied your condition; but I durt not tell you o much, for the very night your t • ings were carried away, I was repreenting it my Mit • es, that it would be unworthily done, to meddle with your chain; but what bitter words, and blows it cot my poor carcae, he above onely knows. I have told thee but the truth, how all things tand, ays Dom Marcos to her, fetching a deep igh, and the wort of it is, that I have not the leat apprehenion of any remedy. I have then omewhat to propoe to you in this extremity, repli'd Marcella. There is a certain peron in this City, of my acquaintance, who, with God's permiion, will tell you where you may find thee people, who have o highly injur'd you. He is a peron admirable for his deep learning, and one that hath Legions of Devils at his devotion, and comm • nds them with uch an abolute power, as if he were the Prince of darknes himelf. And what makes mo • e for the attainment of your deires, you are to know, that this excellent man hath o great a kindnes for me, that I am in hopes ere long to be his wife.

The credulous Dom Marcos entreated her, of all love, that he would bring him to the ight of
this miracle of the Black Art; which Marcella promis'd he would do, and appointed him to meet her, the next day, at the ame place. Dom Marcos came, and had not been there long, ere Marcella came alo, who immediately told the beotted man, that the Magician, of whom he had poken to him the day before, had already taken ome pains, in order to the finding out of what had been tollen from him, and that, to carry on his work, he wanted onely a certain quantity of Amber, Musk, and ome other Perfumes, to entertain the Spirits he was to invoke, who were all of the firt order, and of the bet Houes in Hell. Dom Marcos, without any deliberation, carri'd Marcella to the Drugters, and bought what quantities thereof he appointed him, o infinitely did he think himelf oblig'd to her, that he had found him out a Magician. She afterwards conducted him to an obcure houe, which look'd very upitiouly, where, in a ground-room, or rather a Cellar, wretchedly matted about, he was receiv'd, by a man in a long Caock, with a huge buhy beard, who poke to him with a great deal of gravity.

After a little dicoure, the Student of the infernal Sciences, whom Dom Marcos look'd on with abundance of repect and fear, lighted two black wax-candles, and gave them the frighten'd fellow to hold, in each hand one; caus'd him to it down in a very low chair, and exhorted him, but too late, not to fear any thing. He put afterwards everal quetions to him, as to his age, coure of l • fe, and the goods which had been taken away from him; and after he had look'd into a Gl • s that tood by, and read ome time in a certain book, he told Dom
Marcos, who was ready to— for fear, that he had found out where the things were, and thereupon decrib'd them, one after another, o exactly, according to the intructions he had receiv'd from Marcella, that Dom Marcos let the candles fall out of his hands, to go and embrace him about the neck. The grave Magician blam'd him very much for his impatience, and told him, that the operations of his infallible Art requir'd a erious and reerv'd compoure of the body, adding withal, that, for actions, of a lower degree of confidence & familiarity, the Spirits had ometimes beaten, nay trangled ome men. Dom Marcos grew pale at thoe words, and etled himelf again in his chair, after he had taken up the candles.

The Magician ask'd for the perfumes, which Dom Marcos had bought, and the counterfeit Marcella deliver'd them to him. Till then, he had been a de • out pectator of the Ceremonies; but, being now upon the point of Invocation, he order'd her to quit the room, pretending that the Spirits could not endure the company of woman-kind, epecially if there were any mitrut of the dilapidation of t • eir Virginity. Marcella, making a low curtzy, went out of the room, and the Magician taking a copper chaffing-dih, full of coals, made as if he c • t on them the perfumes, which Dom Marcos had brought, but he had mix'd among them a good quantity of tinking ulphur, which made uch a thick mo • k, that the Magician himelf, who had unadv •
• dly bow'd down his head too near the co • ls, was almot choak'd by it. He cough'd as viol • n • ly as if he had had a burr in his throat, and o o • ten, that his buhy beard, which was not of the
growth of the Country where it was then planted, and it eems had not been well faten'd, fell down, and dicover'd the Magician, to be the ame pernicious Gamara, who had trapann'd him into all his misfortunes.

Upon this dicovery, Dom Marcos made no difficulty to fling away his magical candles and to take the Impotor by the throat, which he grap'd as hard as he could, crying out, with a dreadful voice, Thieves, Thieves. The Magitrate, attended by ome Officers, chanc'd to pas by jut at that time; They came into the houe, where they imagin'd the noie was made, which was the greater, in regard Gamara, whom Dom Marcos till had by the throat, cri'd out as loud as the other. The Officers, at their entrance into the houe, met with Marcella, whom they ecur'd, and, afterwards, having broke open the door of the Necromantical chamber, they found Dom Marcos and Gamara grapled together, and tumbling up and down the floor. The Magitrate knew Gamara for a peron, he had look'd after a long time, and one he had order to apprehend as a notorious Night-walker, a Pandar, and a earcher of other mens houes without any Commiion. He commanded them all three to prion, and caus'd an inventory to be taken of all things found in the room. Dom Marcos was et at liberty the next day, upon his Mater's engagement for him. He was brought in as a witnes againt Gamara and Marcella, who were found guilty of having tollen thoe goods of his which were named in the Inventory. There were many other things found, ome whereof they had tollen, ome taken in, as Pawns, for Gamara was a Jew, and conequently a Broker, and an Uurer. When he was taken, he was upon the point of marriage with Marcella, who brought him, as a portion, beides what
he had toll'n from Dom Marcos, an inclination to teal, not inferiour to that of her future husband; an aptitude to learn any thing he would have taught her, nay to exceed her Tutor, and a body handome, wholeome, and young enough, to be often bought, often eal'd and deliver'd, and likely to weather out, a long time, all the ervices and inconveniences of Curtezanim.

The jutnes of Dom Marcos's caue, upported by the mediation of his Mater, procur'd him the retitution of all had been tollen from him. Gamara was condemn'd to the Gallies for the remainder of his life, unles he hould out-live ninety-nine years; and Marcella was order'd to be everely whipp'd, and banih'd; and the common opinion was, that they were both very favourably dealt with. As for Dom Marcos, he was not o glad of having recover'd ome of his things, and being reveng'd of Gamara and Marcella, as troubled, that the cheating Rogue was no real Magician. The los of his ten thouand Crowns made him in a manner ditracted. He went every day to viit all the Inns about Madrid, till, at lat, he met with certain Mule-drivers, who, returning from Barcelona, told him, that they had met, within four or five days journy of Madrid, a Wagon, loaden with houhold-tuff, in which there were two women and a young man, and that they were forc'd to make ome tay at an Inn, becaue two of their Mules had di'd by the way, through over-driving. They decrib'd the man and the two women, o as that Dom Marcos preum'd they could be no other than Iidora, Inez, and Augutine. Upon this advertiement, without any further deliberation, he put himelf into a Pilgrim's habit, and having got Letters of recommendation from his Mater, to the
Vice-Roy of Catalonia, and a Decree out of the Court againt his fugitive wife, he took his way towards Barcelona, ometimes a foot, ometimes on Mules, and got thither in a few days.

He went immediately to the Port, to take up his lodging, and the firt thing he aw, as he came into it, was his own Trunks, carried by Porters into a Shallop, and Iidora, Inez, and Augutine marching after them, as a Convoy, to be thence convey'd into a Veel that lay in the Haven, wherein they were to embark for Naples. Dom Marcos follow'd his enemies, and went along with them into the Shallop, as fierce as a Lion. They knew him not, by reaon of his broad-brimm'd Pilgrim's hat, and took him for one going to our Lady's of Loretto, whereas the Mariners receiv'd him as one of the ame company, becaue he came in o confidently along with them.

Dom Marcos, being thus got into the Shallop, could not it till, by reaon of the ditraction of his thoughts, not o much out of any reflection what hould become of himelf, as what hould become of his Trunks. In the mean time, the Shallop made towards the Veel, and with uch peed, or rather Dom Marcos was o taken up with what run in his mind, that he was got under the Veel, ere he thought himelf near her. They began to get up the things; which action awaken'd Dom Marcos out of the Lethargy he was in, which yet was not uch, but that he till had his eye on the dearet of his Trunks wherein all his mony wa •
One of the Marriner • came to faten that Trunk, with • ome others, to the pully, to be drawn up into the Veel. Then it w • s, that Dom Marcos forgot him • elf; he aw • he Trunk faten'd; though he ate cloe by, yet was not mov'd; but eeing it lifted up in
the air, he laid hold on it with both hands, by the iron rings, whereby it was remov'd from one place to another, reolv'd never to part with it any more. 'Tis poible, he might have had his deire; for what will not a covetous peron do, to preerve his mony? But, as ill fortune would have it, that Trunk got looe from the other two, which were faten'd with it, and falling jut upon the head of the unfortunate Mier, who yet would not let go his hold, tumbled him into the Sea, and thence into another place ten times deeper than it. Iidora, Inez, and Augutine knew him, jut as he and the Trunk were falling into the water: but the los of the one put them into a greater trouble, than the revenge they fear'd from the other. Augutine, enrag'd to ee uch a vat umme of mony lot, and not able to mother the firt eruptions of his fury, gave the Mariner, who had been o negligent in the fatning of the Trunks, a hearty blow over the face. The Mrriner return'd it with interet, and proecuted his revenge o far, till, at l • t, he turn'd him over-board. As he was falling into the water, he laid hold on the unfortunate Iidora, who could not lay hold on any thing, and o was forc'd to accompany her dear Nephew, who, much againt his will, went to ee what was become of Dom Marcos. Inez made a hift to get up into the Veel, with what was remaining of the goods, which he quander'd away in a hort time at Naples; and, after he had traded, and liv'd many years, a Curtezan, he at lat di'd like a Curtezan, that is, in the Hopital.
